DOC.HEAD: State Rejects Reading Textbooks Opposed by Fundamentalists
DOC.TEXT: A state textbook committee on Wednesday rejected a reading series opposed by fundamentalists because of references to ghosts and scary themes like child abandonment. The publisher called the vote censorship. ``It's a blessing,'' proclaimed Eric Coloney, a Peachtree City parent opposed to the ``Impressions'' reading series. The 13-8 vote against the series virtually assures that most school systems will not use it. The state Board of Education will make final decisions in November. Schools can use books that aren't on the approved state list but must use local funds to buy them. Several committee members expressed disappointment at the vote against the series, which publisher Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. designed as an innovative reading program for teachers. It uses the so-called ``whole language'' approach in which pupils study real children's literature rather than sample paragraphs and phonics exercises. ``I do feel like the special-interest people influenced the textbook selection process,'' said committee member Lynne Donehoo, a Bibb County counselor. Mrs. Donehoo said that when parents and teachers in her area reviewed ``Impressions,'' none objected to the content. But with the high-profile complaints against the series, including 190 opposition phone calls to the state Department of Education in recent days, committee members took a harder look at the series, she said. Only 22 of 822 stories mention ghosts or goblins, and most of the troubling issues raised in the stories - from adoption to sexism to witchcraft - are addressed constructively in the teacher's manual, said Jan Spalding, director of sales support services for Harcourt Brace. Selections ranging from Laura Ingalls Wilder's ``Little House on the Prairie'' to speeches from Martin Luther King Jr., both of which appear in the books, got little attention as the committee focused on witches, child abandonment, chants and ``scary'' pictures, she said. Joyce Washington-Bray, a reading specialist in Marietta and member of the state committee that voted against the books, said the content could detract from teaching. ``When it's this stuff about outer space, material that is eerie - that muddies it up for thinking and reading,'' Ms. Washington-Bray said. Said Pat Turner, an assistant principal from Americus city schools: ``In some ways, I'd say we just went through a witch hunt.''

DOC.HEAD: Public Relations Nightmare: Mother vs. Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY40 sent Sept. 26.
DOC.TEXT: Violent crime, racial tensions, Korean grocery boycotts - at least Mayor David Dinkins has a fighting chance against them. But what are the options when you're under attack by an 85-year-old saint-in-waiting? That public relations nightmare is now reality for Dinkins, who was ripped this week by the heroic Mother Clara Hale over a city policy that has kept children out of her nationally known group care nursery for the past year. The city now requires placement of infants in foster care, rather than in group centers such as Hale House. The decision is costing the Harlem center $30,000 to $36,000 per month in city subsidies, clouding its financial future. Mrs. Hale has charged the mayor is doing what white leaders tell him. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor, asserts he acted independently, and adds that he can't believe that comment was ever made. ``This is what happens when they give a black man a job. He does what the white man tells him to do,'' the 85-year-old black woman told The New York Times. Contacted at a Manhattan hospital where she checked in last week with chest pains, she did not back off that statement. Dinkins expressed disbelief when asked about the remark. ``That's just not true. I don't bow to anybody,'' said Dinkins, whose wife, Joyce, was the host for Mother Hale's birthday party at Gracie Mansion earlier this year. ``I doubt Mother Hale said that. If I heard Mother Hale say it, I wouldn't believe Mother Hale said it. That's not our relationship.'' Mother Hale's credentials are many. More than 800 drug-addicted infants have passed through her brownstone since 1969. President Reagan hailed her as ``an American hero'' on national television five years ago. Today, she still helps care for the babies she calls her children. Mother Hale's care may be special, but the city position - one echoed by experts - is that foster homes are better for the children than group care centers. The city hasn't placed a child at Hale House since October 1989. Hale House's operators believes the success of their program speaks louder than any expert on what's best for the children. They attempted to explain their position to Dinkins, but became infuriated when their first meeting was rescheduled and the second lasted less than five minutes. The meeting failed to change the mayor's mind and put Hale House on the offensive, although Dinkins has offered to provide city funds to it for other programs in an effort to keep it open. When Reagan praised Mother Hale five years ago, her center on West 122nd Street was 70 percent government funded; today, it is two-thirds subsidized by private contributions, said Jesse Devor, public relations consultant for Hale House. Devor said it was only the center's good name that allowed it to continue operating: ``If it wasn't for our visibility and our track record, we'd be dead right now. ... It's a crisis, but we're still viable.'' There are 10 children staying at Hale House, which has space for 15. The length of the stay varies from child to child; it can be as short as a few months, as long as two years, depending on the rehabilitation of the parent or parents. With an eye to the future, Hale House is pumping up its fund raising. Backers plan to distribute 100,000 bumper stickers reading ``The city says no. We say yes. Support Hale House.'' While the Dinkins administration has sweated out the story, Republican leaders quickly turned up the heat. A member of national drug czar William Bennett's staff wasted no time in criticizing the Democratic mayor's position. ``I don't know of many places like Hale House in the nation, and not to use it is dreadful,'' said Herb Kleber, deputy director of demand reduction for the Office of National Drug Control. Mother Hale's position was echoed by The City Sun, a black-owned Brooklyn newspaper that questioned the city's motives in this instance. ``Is it because some people in government don't think black and Latino children are worth saving?'' asked an editorial. Dinkins responded simply that the charges are not so: ``Before, they needed that kind of (group) care. They have plenty of foster care today. Foster families ... are deemed to be an eminently superior method of caring for children.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Identifies 83 Potential Leaks on Columbia
DOC.TEXT: A NASA team trying to pinpoint Columbia's dangerous hydrogen leaks has narrowed the list of possible sources - to 83. ``Any combination might actually be the culprit,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. A hydrogen buildup in the shuttle's engine compartment during fueling last week forced NASA to call off its fourth attempt to send Columbia on an astronomy mission. Three of the postponements were caused by hydrogen leaks. The shuttle is grounded until all leaks are found and fixed. A nine-member investigative team assigned to the problem is scrutinizing every item in Columbia's crowded engine compartment as a possible source of leaks. ``Even if the first thing they do is find a big, roaring leak, they will worry about how do we fix that leak, but they will continue everywhere else to look for things that might also be leaking,'' Lenoir said Wednesday. Workers will remove insulation from each suspected part and then flush the system with non-flammable, room-temperature helium, Lenoir said. If no leaks are found, the process will be repeated with a different crew and equipment ``to be absolutely sure we haven't missed anything,'' he said. So far, Columbia's leaks have appeared only when the shuttle's external tank is filled with highly flammable liquid hydrogen at super-cold temperatures, which might cause shrinkage of a metal part and form the leak. To test for that possibility, the external tank will twice be filled with cold liquid hydrogen, around mid-October and in November. About a dozen TV cameras will be placed inside the engine compartment for both tests. NASA, meanwhile, is working to send Discovery aloft Oct. 6 with a satellite to study the sun's poles. The shuttle must fly within the following 2{ weeks or else wait more than a year for the planets to be in the right alignment. The space agency plans no tanking test for Discovery, the only shuttle in which hydrogen leaks have not been found. Such a check would take five days. A tanking test will be performedon Atlantis before its early November flight. Hydrogen leaks were detected on the spacecraft in June. Lenoir said that he is hopeful Columbia can be back on track in December but that there is no timetable. ``They're not driven by schedule. They are to go out and find the leak, find all of the leaks, and then we can get on with it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Bikerbank' Bandit Enthralls the Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: He walked into the bank wearing his crash helmet and told a teller to put the cash in a plastic bag. Then he fired one shot from his .38-caliber Smith and Wesson pistol into the ceiling, strolled out and vanished on his red motorcycle. ``Bikerbank'' had struck for the 19th time. They seek him here, they seek him there and the public looks on, enthralled by the cool precision that characterizes his crimes. State television has done a prime-time report on his exploits. The daily Hadashot is running a series of articles, trying to pierce the mystery of the man hiding behind the nickname and the dark visor. An ex-commando? A former policeman? Theories abound. His adversary is a tough, mustachioed detective known to colleagues as Shogun. He is Deputy Superintendent Chaim Pinchas, head of special investigations in the Tel Aviv force. Shogun's prestige is at stake. Bikerbank has robbed 19 banks in 12 towns in 21 months, leaving no clue and description - just one fingerprint that draws a blank in the police computer. He strikes between 10 a.m. and noon. He always robs the teller nearest to the door. He's about 6 feet tall, wears cowboy boots and, according to some witnesses, has a slight limp. He rides a high-powered Suzuki motorcycle. Bikerbank's loot, so far, totals slightly more than $150,000. ``He took out a gun, showed it to everybody ... and shouted: `This is a robbery.' He went straight for the counter,'' Reuven Avraham, an official at a Bank Leumi branch in suburban Tel Aviv, recalled on Israel Television. ``He did not care whether we pushed the buttons or used silent alarm systems. I think he was there no longer than a minute and a half,'' Avraham said. Officers have spent hours on stakeouts and roadblocks. Dozens of bikers have been questioned. Some adorn their helmets and bikes with stickers proclaiming ``I'm not the robber.'' At least four suspects, including a reserve Air Force officer, have been held. Vehicle registry records have been no help, and it is believed his bike was bought from a tourist and not registered. When Bikerbank first struck in February 1989, the customer behind him thought it was a joke and interfered, forcing the robber to flash his pistol and fire in the air. ``Today, his actions are completely professional. ... He knows where to find the weak spots of the police,'' investigator Pinchas said. ``I don't think he has a criminal background. I think he comes from a good family. Either he saw a lot of movies ... or had contact with criminals and decided to go along this way,'' Amnon Halper, a former senior detective, told Israel army radio. To compound police embarrassment, Bikerbank twice has struck while suspects were being held. ``At some stage he began to provoke the police. ... It has become something beyond robbery,'' Pinchas says. If the public is not outraged by Bikerbank, it may be because it hasn't forgiven the banks for the 1983 stock market crash that wiped out many people's savings. Israelis blame the banks for manipulating the prices of their own shares to keep them artificially high. The robber's nickname, Ofnobank, is an acronym of the Hebrew words for biker and bank, a play on the catchy acronyms the banks use to advertise their services. ``Some in the public have some sympathy for the man, but we have to remember it's a real robbery, a weapon is being used and it's a serious violation of the law,'' says Police Minister Roni Milo. Still, as long as Bikerbank doesn't shoot anyone, his scampish image is likely to endure. ``I think the sympathy would be the same if he robbed government ministries or post offices, anything linked to the establishment,'' said Noam Pinto, a spokesman for Bank Hapoalim. ``It's very frightening,'' Pinto said. ``So far nobody has been hurt, but we worry for the safety of the workers and the public. The workers are under orders to hand out the money without provoking or opposing him.'' Shogun vows: ``I will get him. It does not matter if he continues or stops. One day we will get him.''

DOC.HEAD: Toto and Samantha Outnumber Piero and Maria
DOC.TEXT: Sue Ellen Orlando? Lothar Palmieri? Yes, children with first names like Toto and Samatha could outnumber Pieros and Marias by the year 2000 in a country increasingly influenced by television and soccer. An Italian Catholic magazine, in a national survey, found that names linked to religious tradition are dropping in favor of names of popular soccer and television stars. Francesco Ruppi, the archbishop of Lecce, in southern Italy, called for a return to tradition. ``Baptize your children after the names of their grandfathers ... Give your children the joy of celebrating their name-day,'' the archbishop said. Prospettive nel Mondo, a Rome-based Catholic monthly magazine, reported that a recent survey showed that out of 100 girls born in the past year, only two were named Maria. There were three Elisabeths and one Catherine. Out of 100 boys there was only one Piero (Peter) and two Giovannis (Johns). Instead, there were more Totos, Diegos and Lothars - named after World Cup soccer stars Schillaci, Maradona and Matthaeus. Most Diegos - 23 out of 100 children - were in the area of Naples, the southern Italian city where the Argentine star plays with local major league team Napoli. Salvatore ``Toto'' Schillaci, the popular forward of the Italian national team and of Juventus of Turin, was the leading scorer in this summer's World Cup, earning him nationwide celebrity status. Schillaci, in keeping with the trend, named his own baby daughter Jessica. Matthaeus, who plays in Italy with Internazionale of Milan, led West Germany to the World Cup title in July. There's also an increasing number of Silvios and Rauls, named for Italian television tycoon and A.C. Milan president Silvio Berlusconi and Raul Gardini, head of the Ferruzzi agro-industrial group and owner of Rome's Il Messaggero basketball team. Many children were named after the popular figures of soap operas, such as Sue Ellen, Pamela and J.R. (called Geiar in Italy) of ``Dallas.'' Others were given names of movie heroes, such as Rocky.

DOC.HEAD: Old Volcanoes, Lava River, Giant Craters Seen in Magellan's Venus Pictures
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Magellan's latest pictures of Venus show meteorite craters the size of Los Angeles, a river of solidified lava 200 miles long and a collapsed volcano twice as deep as the Grand Canyon. ``These are extremely jazzy images,'' said Gordon Pettengill, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology scientist who leads the spacecraft's radar science team. NASA displayed the pictures of the cloud-covered planet at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory on Tuesday. ``Believe me, it's giving us a revolutionary new view of Venus,'' said Brown University geologist Jim Head, a Magellan scientist. With Magellan only 10 days into its 243-day mission to map the planet, Head advised: ``Don't touch your dial. We think we have a blockbuster fall season.'' Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist, displayed a computer-generated videotape of three-dimensional images showing Venus from the perspective of someone swooping down to and around a crater on its surface. Magellan started its $744 million picture- and map-making mission Sept. 15, two weeks later than planned because engineers temporarily lost radio contact with the spacecraft twice in August. One picture displayed Tuesday shows two volcanoes, each with a windblown fan of debris extending about six miles from the mountain's summit crater. NASA said the fans look like ``fallout from volcanic explosion plumes.'' While Magellan hasn't seen a volcano actually erupting, it has made pictures of so many volcanic features that ``there is an excellent possibility there is active volcanism somewhere on the planet,'' Head said. Magellan also spotted a caldera, or crater caused by the collapse of a volcano's summit, almost two miles deep - roughly twice the depth of the Grand Canyon and deeper than any other caldera seen in the solar system, scientists said. A hardened lava river eight-tenths of a mile wide and about 200 miles long was mapped by Magellan as well. NASA also showed a picture of a meteorite impact crater about 28 miles wide. ``Greater Los Angeles would fit approximately in the floor of this crater,'' Head said. Another picture showed three big impact craters, one of them even larger, with a width of about 30 miles. Magellan was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis in May 1989 and arrived at Venus after traveling a looping path of 948 million miles. Chief engineer John Slonski Jr. said a backup computer that played a role in the radio blackouts still malfunctions occasionally, so contact might be lost again. The cause of the problems remains unknown. Suspicion focuses on possible damage to electronic components that happened when Magellan started orbiting Venus Aug. 10 and on static in the wiring linking its computers, Slonski said.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Hall Begins Its Centennial Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Carnegie Hall tonight begins a seasonlong celebration of its 100th birthday, secure as a centerpiece of American culture one generation after it nearly fell victim to the wrecker's ball. The auditorium on West 57th Street, still sparkling from a $50 million facelift four years ago, will be host in the coming months to the best and brightest of the music world, from pops to Placido Domingo, from jazz to Jessye Norman. Opening night honors go to the Los Angeles Philharmonic, conductor Andre Previn and violinist Itzhak Perlman. The second night, also by the orchestra, will present the first of 13 pieces of music commissioned by Carnegie for its centennial season. That's the largest number of commissioned works ever in one season by an American presenting organization. The second night premiere will be ``Angelus,'' based on the chiming of bells and composed by Steven Stucky. Last December, a month before he was 85, Sir Michael Tippett completed ``Byzantium,'' which will have its premiere in April by the Chicago Symphony, with conductor Sir Georg Solti making his final visit to Carnegie as music director of that orchestra. ``It's probably the most extraordinary season that any hall has ever had,'' violinist Isaac Stern said. Stern has been president of Carnegie Hall since 1960 when he saved it from the fate of being torn down so an office building could rise on the corner of 57th Street and 7th Avenue. ``Carnegie Hall, when you're playing in form, makes a performance larger than life. It's an enormously powerful hall and it does give even average performers a glamour and power they wouldn't have in other halls,'' Stern said in an interview shortly before his 70th birthday in July. ``Carnegie was the place where you came to prove whether you belonged or not. For that reason, it was very necessary to play there. It still is. ... It has been the crown proving place for every single orchestra, every one, every conductor, every pianist, singer, violinist, cellist, jazz player, comedian, pop singer.'' Andrew Carnegie donated $2 million, approximately nine-tenths of the cost of construction. But it was Leopold Damrosch, founder of both the Symphony Society, the city's second orchestra after the New York Philharmonic, and the Oratorio Society, who felt New York needed another large hall besides the Metropolitan Opera. His son, Walter, music director of both organizations in 1887, happened to sail that year on the same ship as Carnegie and his bride, who were on their honeymoon. By the time the ship reached Europe, Carnegie had agreed to build a fine concert hall in New York. Ten concerts starting April 26 will lead up to the centennial date itself, May 5. The day will start with a morning concert by eight choruses conducted by Robert Shaw. The New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta and Leonard Bernstein, will perform at 4 p.m., take a dinner break and resume. Soloists at that concert will include sopranos Leontyne Price and Miss Norman, mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne, tenor Domingo, pianist Rudolf Serkin, violinists Stern and Pinchas Zukerman, cellists Mstislav Rostropovich and Yo-Yo Ma and the Empire Brass Quintet. Carnegie Hall ``is the center from which the entire development of American music came,'' Stern said. ``Nothing happened in this country that didn't come through Carnegie.'' The hall has been acclaimed throughout its history for its architecture and acoustics. During the most recent renovation, workmen closed a hole that had been cut in the ceiling over the stage for a movie in the 1940s. That and some other changes prompted some critics to complain that the hall's warm acoustics had been damaged. In response, a row of free-standing panels was built that can be placed along the back wall behind orchestras. What's important to Stern is that Carnegie Hall - now restored as much as possible to its 1891 look, with air-conditioning improved and less street noise coming in - stands for another 100 years. ``It's something to hold on to, some connection with man's involvement with education, with the quality of civilization. Those are the things which are worthwhile.''

DOC.HEAD: When It Comes To Unity, German Intellectuals Marching In Hopeless Disarray
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is one of a series on the German countdown to unity on Oct. 3.

Guenter Grass and other authors are among the last holdout opponents to unification, firing salvos of dissent that have not damaged the unity express but have fractured the German intelligenstia. The debate has triggered a furious philosophical feud over whether star East German writers like Christa Wolf indirectly bolstered the hard-line Communist state by not actively opposing it. Some leftist German writers have charged that the real beneficiaries of unification are not the common people, but businessmen and politicians who stand to reap financial and political profits. But many critics maintain that Grass and other members of Germany's mostly leftist literary pantheon are hopelessly out of touch with the rest of the population. ``The foremost feature of these people is an unbelievable vanity,'' Enno von Loewenstern, editorial writer for the conservative Die Welt newspaper, said in an interview. ``If the common folk refuse to follow their line, they have not wakened to their true consciousness.'' Conservative writers from both Germanys have expressed similar views. The debate began soon after the first cracks appeared in the Berlin Wall last fall. Wolf, novelist Stefan Heym and other East Germans published a manifesto warning against ``a sellout of material and moral values'' to their rich West German neighbors. The message was that East Germany - with a new democratic government and freedom for the people - was something worth preserving. West German critics asked why the same East German intellectuals hadn't been as loud with critical pronouncements during Stalinist rule. The ultimate question was: Had East German intellectuals acquiesced to the repressive rule for the special privileges bestowed upon artists and writers? The debate turned angrier when Wolf published an autobiographical novella called ``What Remains'' in which she suggested she had been hounded by the Stasi secret police in the late 1970s. A critic for Die Welt questioned whether Wolf has the right to portray herself as a ``martyr because she had to endure three Stasi observers sitting in a car across from her apartment.'' ``Many people ... have lived through this and worse,'' the critic said. Grass and other leftist West German authors have rushed to Wolf's defense. He has compared the campaign against Wolf to an inquisition and said it could do irreparable damage to the German intellectual community. Grass has accused Wolf's critics of hypocrisy, pointing out that no one seemed to mind during the Communist years that her status allowed her to deliver readings and lectures to enrapt listeners and reviewers in the West. The debate goes beyond whether East German intellectuals chose a cozy life under Communist rule over trying to bring about real change. At the heart of all the arguing is unification itself. This spring, millions of East Germans loudly voiced their support for unification by shouting ``We are one people!'' at election rallies. German intellectuals heard the cry, but many leftist writers say unity is a mistake. Grass, evoking the Third Reich and Auschwitz, at one point said a united Germany would be a danger to itself and other nations. In in interview in early September, Grass said he favored a confederation between the two Germanys but not unification. ``The (previous) united German state lasted briefly, from Bismarck to 1945. It was only 70 years and was the unhappiest phase in all of German history and in European history as well,'' he said. East German Heiner Mueller, one of Europe's best-known playwrights and a die-hard socialist, says the Germans' destiny has been taken from their hands by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, the architect of unification. ``What's happening now is an economic conquest'' of East Germany, he said. Other intellectuals disagree. Martin Walser, the West German novelist, said the East Germans do control their destiny. They could have chosen to create a free socialist state as, he points out, was favored by many intellectuals. ``I would have said, `OK, if that's what you believe,''' Walser said in a recent newspaper interview. ``But the people decided on something else.'' Reiner Kunze, a leading poet who was thrown out of East Germany in 1977, has scolded Grass for his views. ``No one needs to fear Germany,'' Kunze said. West German Patrick Sueskind, author of the best-selling novel ``Perfume,'' has written a new book titled ``Fear of Germany,'' in which he takes aim at the hoopla and hype accompanying unification. He said the idea of unity has taken his generation of postwar baby-boomers by surprise. ``We thought we had a grasp on our existence and understood the world ... and now we're suddenly confronted with this midlife crisis,'' Sueskind writes. ``We were prepared for impotence, for prostate problems, false teeth, menopause, for cancer .... death and the devil - but definitely not for Deutsch-land-ei-nig-Va-ter-land!'' The phrase means ``Germany, united fatherland,'' a favorite chant at East German election rallies this year.

DOC.HEAD: House Reported Nearing Compromise on Obscene Art
DOC.TEXT: House negotiators are reported near agreement on legislation to extend the life of the National Endowment for the Arts and let the courts decide whether its grant recipients have violated obscenity laws. ``I think we're going to get a deal,'' said Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., a central figure in House bargaining over the fate of the embattled federal arts agency. In an interview Tuesday, Williams predicted that lengthy talks with Rep. E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., will yield a compromise on the ``obscene art'' issue that will attract the support of a solid majority of House members. He said the compromise is likely to be patterned after a formula the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved last week with strong bipartisan backing. The Senate bill would require the NEA to recoup grant money from artists who are convicted of using federal funds to produce works that violate obscenity laws. The guilty artists would be barred from receiving further NEA grants for at least three years. On Thursday, the House tentatively plans to begin what promises to be a bruising floor battle over a proposed five-year extension of the arts endowment, whose statutory authority expires Sunday. Lawmakers readied no fewer than two dozen amendments, most of them seeking to prohibit NEA support for works that might be considered obscene or sacrilegious. One proposal would abolish the arts endowment altogether. Strict anti-obscenity curbs imposed on the endowment last fall at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., also will lapse next week when the current fiscal year ends, unless Congress renews them in some form. In a related development, the House Appropriations Committee on Tuesday rebuffed an attempt by its chairman, Rep. Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., to recommend forbidding the NEA to finance ``any indecent, anti-religious or obscene picture, play or writing.'' On a voice vote, the committee eliminated Whitten's non-binding proposal from a stopgap bill intended to keep the federal government operating at current spending levels for the first three weeks of the new fiscal year - until Oct. 20 - and to provide $2 billion for U.S. military operations in the Persian Gulf. The effect of the bill, later approved and sent to the House floor, was to continue the NEA temporarily at the level of its current, $171 million budget, with the Helms anti-obscenity curbs intact. Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., argued that Whitten's anti-obscenity proposal should be considered later, when the committee acts on the NEA's proposed $180 million appropriations bill for next year. The prospective compromise between Williams and Coleman, opposing figures in the NEA controversy, would leave to the courts - not the endowment - the responsibility for deciding whether federally subsidized works are obscene. Coleman previously had proposed forbidding the NEA from supporting works that meet the Supreme Court's obscenity standards. The Helms ban went further, prohibiting support for any works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homoeroticism, sadomasochism and sexual exploitation of children. Williams said another Coleman proposal to shift 60 percent of NEA grant money to the control of state arts agencies remains in dispute. He said the compromise bill may include a limited increase in the 20 percent of grant funds currently allocated to the states. Colemot return calls seeking comment. Williams, a staunch NEA supporter, is chief sponsor of the Bush administration's original bill to extend the NEA's life for five years without any anti-obscenity restrictions. Congressional sources said the House probably would vote for a shorter extension, perhaps three or four years, to allow Congress more frequent reviews of NEA operations. Rep. Dick Armey, R-Texas, expressed support Tuesday for a proposed amendment by Rep. Phil Crane, R-Ill., that would abolish the NEA. Armey said he found ``abhorrent the very existence of a politically appointed government panel charged with determining what art is worthy of funding.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Economic Sanctions, U.S.-Style
DOC.TEXT: How long can a nation embroiled in a costly military standoff endure harsh economic sanctions? Not Iraq - the United States. Americans may get a chance to find out as early as Monday if Congress and the White House fail to reach a budget agreement. No one calls them sanctions, but the automatic spending cuts that would be triggered under the Gramm-Rudman law could have some of the same consequences: possible food shortages, massive transportation disruptions and a heavy drain on economic growth. These are self-inflicted sanctions that are written into the law intended to lead to a balanced federal budget by 1993. The impact of the cuts - from $85 billion to $100 billion - combined with higher energy prices resulting from the Middle East crisis could easily topple the U.S. economy into a recession, many economists suggest. And that's even before the $1-billion-a-month cost of the Persian Gulf military operation is factored in. With the budget talks deadlocked, President Bush is giving no signs of blinking first in what Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., says ``is a game of chicken, that's all it is.'' Bush was quick on Tuesday to show he won't go along with a Democratic-led effort to delay the spending targets at least until Oct. 20 to give budget negotiators more breathing room. Shortly after the House Appropriations Committee approved stopgap legislation calling for such a delay, Bush told reporters, ``I will veto'' any spending measure that ``suspends Gramm-Rudman and budget discipline.'' White House officials say they are bracing for the spending cuts to take effect Monday. Although perennial financial crises in Washington have a solid history of evaporating in 11th-hour compromises, some key presidential aides have said privately that this time the resolution may not come until after spending cuts actually take hold. At the same time, officials say Bush has no plans to curtail his plans to travel extensively around the country in October campaigning for Republican candidates - even if the spending cuts take place. Bush, who is off today for two days of campaigning in the Midwest, has scheduled campaign trips for Oct. 4-5, 10, 15-16 and 25-28. However, he may have to do it without part of his staff and he may find it difficult to travel at night. Most of the nation's 2.2 million federal employees already have been warned they may be furloughed to a shorter work week beginning next week - including most White House employees. The National Weather Service has said it will close 250 weather stations from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. beginning Monday in the absence of a budget agreement, including those that provide local weather information to pilots. That, combined with plans by the Federal Aviation Administration to sharply cut back on the number of air traffic controllers, could keep most flights grounded at night. ``And if you think that sounds draconian, you ain't seen nothing yet,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Noting that the Gramm-Rudman cuts will force a 40 percent across-the-board cutback in most government programs, Fitzwater said: ``You're going to see a lot more dramatic and difficult things to deal with than night flights.'' Administration budget officials have said that imposition of the spending cuts also may delay Medicare and Social Security checks and could result in food shortages because of reductions in government inspections. They also say the cuts will mean fewer guards in prisons, a halt to toxic waste sites, elimination of Pell Grants to 1.2 million college students and reductions in programs for vaccinating children. And Fitzwater may not be on hand to brief reporters on these developments. Like the rest of his press office staff, Fitzwater has himself received a furlough notice. (Secret Service agents are among the few in the White House exempted.) ``Basically, in my office, the way the furlough would work would be essentially everybody would be off one day a week for the first couple weeks, and then two days a week for the next several weeks and so forth,'' the press secretary said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Shoots to No. 1 in the Ratings
LaserGraphic
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: CBS finally made it out of the ratings basement and shot to No. 1 in the opening week of the fall season. In a photo finish for first place, CBS nosed ahead of usually top-rated NBC last week by two-tenths of a ratings point in the tightest premiere race since 1966. It was the first time in six years that CBS won the fall season's opening week. CBS had a 13.6 average rating, NBC a 13.4 and ABC a 13.2, the A.C. Nielsen Co. said Tuesday. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. NBC responded to the ratings with a news release that began, ``Premiere week almost by definition is an atypical week.'' In a top 10 list where every show but one was a season premiere, NBC's ``Cheers'' was the top-rated program. CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' which began its new season the previous week, tied for third with the network's ``Designing Women.'' ABC's lone top 10 entry was the fall premiere of ``Roseanne,'' which finished second. ``The Cosby Show'' opened its season at No. 5 and again embarrassed ``The Simpsons,'' which has plummeted in the ratings since moving to the same time period. It was last in its time slot and 67th for the week. At CBS, executives were ecstatic about finishing first but cautious about calling it a season-long trend. ``We're not saying we're going to be No. 1'' all the time, said CBS ratings expert David Poltrack. ``But we are going to be competitive.'' CBS has the most new shows this fall. Ten of CBS' 13 original series have aired. The ambitious slate represents the first fall schedule delivered by entertainment president Jeff Sagansky, who has held the job less than a year. ``His instincts and his collaborative spirit have changed the whole atmosphere of this place,'' said Poltrack. CBS hasn't won a season since 1984, when its lineup included ``Dallas,'' ``Falcon Crest'' and ``Magnum, P.I.'' There also was a twist in the network news ratings, with NBC and Tom Brokaw breaking out of last place for the first time since July. NBC ranked second with an 8.8 average, edging past CBS and Dan Rather with an 8.5. In first for the 37th consecutive week were ABC and Peter Jennings with a 10.3. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 22; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 20.1; ``Designing Women'' and ``60 Minutes,'' CBS (tie), 20; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 19.8; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 19.6; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 18.8; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 18.6; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 18.4; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, ``Major Dad,'' CBS, (tie) 17.7.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Deepens US-Soviet Understanding
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, in an astonishing speech by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, is suddenly in the forefront of the international drive against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, while pushing relations with the United States to unprecedented heights. The two superpowers are still haggling over arms control measures. Unless Secretary of State James A. Baker III achieves a sudden breakthrough today in a private meeting with Shevardnadze, two summits may have to be set back. But with world attention riveted on the United Nations and the precarious pressure campaign to force Iraq to relinquish its conquest of Kuwait, Shevardnadze has given President Bush all the support he could hope to have - and then some. The genial Georgian, who sits at Mikhail S. Gorbachev's right hand in the Soviet power structure, not only blasted Saddam on Tuesday as a terrorist threatening the new world order but suggested his seizure of Kuwait might call for a war crimes trial. Those who take hostages, employ torture and threaten other nations with destruction are engaged in ``crimes against humanity'' and should be judged by an international tribunal, Shevardnadze said. Moreover, the Soviet foreign minister raised the prospect of a U.N. military force against Iraq if the 7-week-old economic blockade fails to induce Saddam to give up the oil-rich emirate. ``The United Nations has the power to suppress acts of aggression,'' Shevardnadze observed. The first proposition conjured up images of the Nuremberg trials of Nazi leaders after World War II. The second carried echoes of President Harry S. Truman's U.N.-sanctioned defense of South Korea against aggression from the north. Significantly, both proposals were sterner than any advanced by the Bush administration. In some ways, Shevardnadze vaulted past the United States in taking the moral high ground against Baghdad. ``It was a very strong speech,'' Canadian Foreign Minister Joe Clark said afterward. ``It certainly indicates that we are in a new era of international affairs.'' Clark also complimented Shevardnadze for the way he chaired Tuesday's U.N. Security Council session, in which the body voted 14-1 to impose an air embargo against Iraq. ``It is a dramatic demonstration of how much has changed internationally,'' he said. U.S.-Soviet relations have been on the upsurge for years, but until the Soviets withdrew their troops from Afghanistan in 1988 many in Washington questioned the sincerity of Gorbachev's moves. Even in this new era of good feelings, the two sides still are struggling to resolve their differences over cutting long-range nuclear weapons and reducing their tanks and other conventional arms in Europe. Failure to agree on nuclear cutbacks could imperil the trip Bush hoped to take to Moscow in December to sign a treaty slashing long-range arsenals of bombers, submarines and intercontinental ballistic missiles. The dispute over conventional forces could postpone the 35-nation summit France proposed to host in Paris in mid-November. There is time to rescue both pacts. In the meantime, cooperation on coping with the crisis in the Persian Gulf is at a maximum. When Bush set out in early August to impose an economic stranglehold on Saddam he encountered some hesitation from Moscow. Soviet support was considered essential for several reasons. First of all, as a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council the Soviets could kill any measure against Iraq. Second, the United States needed the other superpower's support to persuade the world the campaign against Iraq was not a solo show of force by Washington. Third, the credibility of the campaign would gain immensely if it had the support of the Soviets since they had been allies of Iraq. The Soviet hesitation on sanctions recurred in late August when the Bush administration went back to the Security Council to enforce the sanctions. Again, Moscow's anxieties about inflaming a touchy situation yielded to a judgment that Saddam must be contained despite the risk. Two weeks ago, Bush and Gorbachev agreed in Helsinki, Finland, that additional measures might be required. The imposition of a U.N. air blockade was the result. Not too many years ago, the Soviets were the targets of the sort of condemnation Shevardnadze heaped on Saddam. Their actions in Eastern Europe and treatment of their own people generated the kind of outrage now being visited on Iraq. But now, as Gorbachev struggles to transform the Soviet Union into a market economy with and to institute political democracy, Shevardnadze appealed to Iraq's leaders ``to obey the demands of the law and also of plain common sense, to take a responsible and human attitude.'' He said the Soviets are making the appeal as old friends of the Iraqis. Shevardnadze said the Soviets spoke also ``as a country that found the courage to condemn its own wrongdoings against certain states in the past.'' Such admissions are rare on the world diplomatic stage and they served to intensify the respect Shevardnadze earned with his speech. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is The Associated Press' chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: Black Market Frays Tempers at Romania-Bulgaria Crossing
DOC.TEXT: The Bridge of Friendship over the Danube once symbolized comradely communist ties between Bulgaria and Romania, but it's been a source of tension since authorities began cracking down on smugglers. It can take as long as three days toget across the bridge between Russe, Bulgaria and this town 60 miles south of Bucharest, heating up tempers and radiators alike. Under the two countries' former Communist governments, lines were virtually non-existent because travel and the opportunity for private trading were strictly limited. All that changed after last year's democratic upheaval. The Romanian and Bulgarian economies are in chaos as new goverments start steering away from central planning and toward free-market practices, and Romanians who face shortages of basic foods such as bread and sugar at home are going on shopping sprees in Turkey. They can even pick up some coffee in Bulgaria, through which they must travel on their way to Turkey. The goods are sold for a profit back home. Bulgarians, whose economy has been sliding into deepening crisis, face strict food rationing themselves. In August, Bulgaria said Romanians could travel within Bulgaria only on organized tours or in transit to another point. Authorities cited a cholera epidemic in Romania but many Romanians believe the reason behind the clampdown was to stop illegal cross-border trade. The state Bulgarian news agency BTA charged that: ``in Russe, the Romanians swear they are transit travelers. ... However, having struck quick bargains on the Bulgarian black market, they go back, explaining their cars broke down.'' In a recent televised speech, Romanian President Ion Iliescu attacked ``speculators ... who think the free market is a way to get rich quickly.'' Growing Romanian-Bulgarian antipathy got a further boost when Romanian television showed footage of Bulgarian militiamen at the Russe station beating Romanians who didn't have correct papers and forcing them back across the border. Since summer, lines at Romanian customs have been growing and relations with Sofia have started to strain. Seething Soviet truck drivers now jockey daily with Turkish emigrant workers and Romanian unofficial traders for a place on the rickety 1{-mile bridge over the Danube River. Experienced travelers arrive prepared with food, drink and extra gasoline for the crossing. At the Giurgiu customs post recently, a handful of officials - no more than in the days of former dictator Nicolae Ceauscescu - deliberately search every car and often confiscate hidden taxable goods. Smugglers offer cigarettes and whisky as bribes. Fights break out occasionally in the midday heat, as drivers squabble about who should go first. The lines trail back miles over the bridge and spew into the opposite lanes, blocking the way to Bulgaria. Bucharest officials say there are no plans to widen the 40-year-old bridge or add lanes to the customs crossing.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troop Total has Jumped by More Than 50 Percent This Month
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad has boosted its troop strength in Kuwait and southern Iraq by more than 50 percent over the past two weeks to a total of about 430,000 men, the Pentagon says. In the past week President Saddam Hussein has added 70,000 troops to the area, following an increase of 95,000 the previous week, the Pentagon said Tuesday. The United States has about 165,000 troops in the Persian Gulf region. Separately, a senior Pentagon official disclosed that Soviet military advisers in Iraq are performing maintenance on Iraqi aircraft behind the front lines. The official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said U.S. intelligence analysts believe that between 500 and 1,000 Soviet advisers remain in Iraq and that an undetermined number are helping maintain Iraq's warplanes. ``We're not very sure about exactly what they're doing'' in Iraq beyond working on aircraft and performing unspecified training roles for the Iraqi military, the official said. He added that withdrawal of the Soviet advisers would not have much effect on Iraq's military capabilities. Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said Iraq has shifted mechanized forces back from Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia into ``tactical reserve positions.'' They are being replaced on the front line with infantry units, he said. The result has been a large increase in the total number of troops in the area. ``Our analysts think that what they're gaining is flexibility'' for the mechanized units, Williams said. The spokesman said the reported increases in Iraqi troops and tank deployments are partly due to the Pentagon including a larger geographic area in its count. Williams said he could not estimate how much of the increase was due to this factor, which he said reflected the wider deployment of mechanized forces. Williams said the Iraqi deployments still appear to be ``essentially a defensive force,'' but are capable of readily converting to an offensive strike force. The number of Iraqi tanks in the Kuwait theater has jumped by 700 from last week to 3,500 tanks, Williams said, and the number of armored personnel carriers has risen to 2,500, an increase of 700. Artillery pieces now total about 1,700, up by 250. Williams said the United States had no plan to increase its deployment of forces to Saudi Arabia as a result of the continuing Iraqi buildup. U.S. forces are still flowing into the area.

DOC.HEAD: Apathy Marks Campaign Despite Tough Market Reform
DOC.TEXT: A week before key elections, most Brazilians seem apathetic about choosing a national congress and state governors. The Oct. 3 election is the first since voters in December made Fernando Collor de Mello Brazil's first freely elected president in 29 years. Almost all 570 congressional seats are up for grabs, as well as all 26 state governorships. Runoffs will be held in mid-November if no gubernatorial candidate receives an absolute majority in next Wednesday's vote. Polls show the country is sharply divided on the Collor administration. Still, conservatives sympathetic to his free-market economic reform are expected to win the majority of governor's chairs. The same outcome is being forecast on the congressional side, even though polls show voters aren't familiar with the candidates. A recent survey in Rio revealed 74 percent of the voters were undecided. The lack of enthusiasm is striking compared with the population's high involvement in last year's vote between Collor and socialist Luis Inacio Lula da Silva. Some observers say that after 25 years of military dictatorship, which ended in 1985, Brazilians have had an ``overdose'' of democracy. Federal, state or local elections have now been held in five of the last six years. ``This accumulation of elections is going to transform the electoral process into something so routine and boring hat nobody's going to want to know anything about it,'' said Mario Amato, a business leader. Others say the apathy stems from a frustration with the last six years of civilian rule. Elected government ``was seen as the country's salvation from misery and corruption, and it was nothing of the sort,'' said Rep. Fabio Feldman of the center-left Brazilian Social Democratic Party. ``Grave problems are not resolved with miracles.'' Also dimming voter interest is widespread dirty campaigning. In several states, electoral courts temporarily suspended TV ads after mudslinging reached alarming proportions. In Rio, opponents of Leonel Brizola, heavily favored in the governor's race, bribed poor children with sweets and sandwiches to alter the words from his campaign song from ``La-la-la-Brizola'' to ``Blah-blah-blah Brizola.'' A film of the scene ran as TV spots for several nights before a judge banned the ad. The country's leftist parties, once expected to benefit from voter anger about Collor's tough economic austerity measures, are suffering most from the voter apathy. They depend more on active participation from their supporters than do the largely money-driven campaigns of most conservatives. Analysts say the opposition has also hurt by internal squabbles. After uniting behind da Silva's candidacy last year, leftist alliances disintegrated; new coalitions may emerge only for second-round governor's races. ``The left has been totally incompetent,'' said political observer David Fleischer. ``It has failed to recover psychologically from last year's presidential defeat and is blowing its chance due to petty quarrels.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Says Domination by Race Ending in South Africa
LaserPhotos WX6-7
DOC.TEXT: South African President F. W. de Klerk says the new system he envisions for his country will ensure that no racial group - black or white - will ever be able to achieve political domination again. Speaking to reporters hours before ending his official visit Tuesday, de Klerk ruled out a ``winner-take-all'' electoral approach in which broad powers are granted to one person. Never again, he said, should there be a situation in which a powerful executive, regardless of color, is ``in a strong position to suppress'' South Africans of different races. De Klerk said he foresees a new system in which there will be a sharing of power within the executive branch, thus guarding against any concentration of authority. During his three-day visit, the first by a South African head of state since 1945, de Klerk relentlessly sought to convince doubters in the United States that his country is embarking on a new era of democracy and racial equality. ``I want to say here today that the time has come to realize that apartheid is really something of the past,'' he said at a National Press Club luncheon. As proof, he said more than 100 discriminatory laws and regulations have been removed from the statute books. He promised that the remaining impediments will be erased by the time a new constitution takes effect. De Klerk also said he was determined to avoid the chaos that has prevailed in many other African countries in the post-independence era. ``We intend to ensure that our plan will absolutely and effectively prevent South Africa from becoming just another typical African one-party state, sliding down the scale of poverty into oblivion,'' he said. ``We intend to ensure that the new South Africa will be based on the very values which we share with you.'' De Klerk said the issue of U.S. sanctions against South Africa were discussed only indirectly in his talks with President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and congressional leaders. ``I did not put forward any specific requests,'' he said. The sanctions, among other things, bar new U.S. investment in South Africa and forbid South African aircraft from landing in the United States. Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., the House majority whip and top-ranking black in Congress, said he ``came away hopeful'' from de Klerk's session with congressional leaders. Gray said he told de Klerk that Congress will not be ready to ease sanctions until South Africa writes a new constitution removing the legal pillars of apartheid. ``Apartheid is alive and well and a reality and until there is a new constitution there will be no significant change in that society,'' Gray said. Asked about the impact of the sanctions, de Klerk said, ``To a great extent it was counterproductive. People under threat tend to react negatively. We don't like as a country to be prescribed to by other countries. And there's an emotional reaction which is brought about by that.'' He said South Africa began moving toward abandoning its apartheid system not because of the sanctions ``but because we believed it must be done.'' ``We are going to do it whether the legislation was instituted or not. We would have done it according to the policies which we have accepted,'' he said. De Klerk has moved partway toward creating conditions that would permit the lifting of sanctions through a series of measures. These include freeing African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners, ending the state of emergency in all but one province, lifting bans on democratic political parties and agreeing to negotiate a new democratic system.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Most Hated Tax Takes Center Stage
DOC.TEXT: An unprecedented constitutional battle over a hated tax is shaping up between Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative-controlled House of Commons and the Liberal majority in the usually somnolent Senate. The object of the revilement: the Goods and Services Tax. Polls indicate 75 to 85 percent of Canadians oppose the 7 percent tax. It will be imposed on nearly all merchandise and services beginning Jan. 1 - on top of the existing provincial sales taxes, which range from 8 to 10 percent. That is, if the Senate doesn't kill it off. The confrontation pits the elected House of Commons against the unelected Senate, which Canadians refer to with a snicker as Parliament's chamber of sober second thought. Senate seats long have been used as payoffs for political service rendered and the chamber rarely has roused itself to do battle over burning issues of the day. The so-called GST tax bill was approved by the House in March. The government then proceeded with plans for collecting the tax as if its passage was a foregone conclusion, ignoring claims that it is bafflingly complex. One letter to the editor of the Toronto Globe and Mail said the government's GST Guide Book for accountants is a nightmare, ``400 pages and growing.'' But suddenly, last week, Liberal opposition leader Jean Chretien announced that his party would try to kill the measure in the Senate. On Monday, Banking Committee Chairman Sidney Buckwold recommended that the Senate kill the bill. ``It's a very bad piece of legislation that Canadians by the millions asked the Senate to reject and we've acted accordingly,'' said Buckwold. ``We want to have a quick vote to kill the GST,'' Chretien said Tuesday. Sensing growing resentment against the tax, Mulroney filled 15 vacant Senate seats with Conservatives over the past month, but that wasn't enough. The Liberals hold 52 seats in the 104-seat chamber and the Conservatives 46. The remaining seats are held by one Reform Party member and five independents. The prime minister was said to be considering a resort to an obscure, never used section of the constitution which would allow him to ask the queen to appoint up to eight extra senators. That still would not guarantee success, leaving the fate of the tax in the hands of the independents. The 7 percent tax would replace the 13.5 percent Manufacturers Sales Tax, which raises about $10 billion a year but is considered inefficient and levied on a very narrow base. ``The argument is that it (the Manufacturers Sales Tax) discriminates heavily against manufacturing industries in Canada and against Canadian firms vis-a-vis imports,'' said Dr. Robin Boadway, a professor of economics at Queen's University and an expert on taxation. ``The GST is essentially the same as the value-added tax that the Europeans use,'' said Boadway. But consumers, already paying 8 to 10 percent in provincial sales taxes, are horrified at the prospect of seeing 15 to 17 percent tacked on their purchases, plumbing bills, haircuts and music lessons. Manufacturers love it. ``Dismantling the existing federal sales tax would remove a longstanding source of competitive disadvantage for Canadian manufacturers, exporters, and all businesses that compete with imports in the domestic Canadian market,'' said Thomas d'Aquino, president of the Canadian Business Council. One of the main fears of the tax-paying public, however, is that once the tax has been implemented, governments will be very tempted to hike the rate. ``It has such a broad base, it can raise a lot of revenue with small rate increases,'' said Boadway. Out in the tiny Saskatchewan village of Elstow, population 140, Mayor Brad Cabana's town council has voted not to collect or pay the GST, come what may. ``It's another example of government not listening to the people,'' he said. ``It's not a fair tax and it's quite inflationary.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Analysts Say Terrorism Unlikely Unless Gulf War Erupts
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli analysts say they see little likelihood of Palestinians launching a terrorist attack in support of Saddam Hussein unless war breaks out between Iraq and the U.S.-led forces arrayed against it. But they say Palestinian militants are ready to do the Iraqi president's bidding, and raise the possibility of Palestinians acting separately to draw attention from the Persian Gulf crisis to their own plight. The assessments come from Anat Kurz and David Tal of the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, a Tel Aviv University research group. The two addressed a news conference Tuesday presenting the center's survey of international terrorism in 1989. Tal pointed to statements by extremists on the fringes of the Palestine Liberation Organization expressing readiness to act on Iraq's behalf. He also spoke of attempts by Saddam to make contact with Abu Nidal, the PLO renegade behind some of the worst terrorist incidents of the 1980s. However, Tal added, ``So far we can say quite clearly that the Palestinians and Iraq are not going to initiate a spate of terrorism.'' He doubted the mainstream PLO wants to be involved in terrorism, and said all Palestinian declarations so far ``refer to a case in which a war or hostile activity erupts.'' ``So I think the Palestinians will turn to terrorism only if hostile activity starts,'' he said. Tal said he was trying to assess the threat logically, ``but of course I can never tell whether Abu Nidal will feel that this is the time to help Saddam Hussein, even if Saddam Hussein doesn't know it.'' Ms. Kurz saw a growing danger of PLO elements taking the initiative even if their attacks ``contradict the timing and interests of Baghdad.'' This could happen, she said, not out of solidarity with Iraq but as ``an expression of frustration and an effort to bring back the Palestinian issue and the intefadeh (the anti-Israeli uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip) back to the headlines.'' ``The probability of this kind of threat seems to be increasing as long the (gulf) crisis becomes a protracted stalemate,'' she said. The center's report counted 406 incidents of international terrorism in 1989, compared with 433 in 1988 and 377 in 1987. Bombing and arson remained the most common tactics, accounting for 49 percent of incidents. Armed assaults accounted for 35.5 percent, kidnappings for 5.9 percent, and ``specific and concrete threats'' for 6.7 percent. Latin America suffered the most terrorism in 1989 - 39 percent of all incidents. Western Europe accounted for 19.7 percent, down from 24.2 percent in 1988. The report said 553 people were killed by international terrorism, 278 of them by bombs planted on two planes - one that blew up over the Sahara and another in Colombia. Trends changed little from 1988, it said. Political figures were targeted in 42.1 percent of attacks, economic objectives in 32 percent, and the public in 22.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Kleiber Conducts `Rosenkavalier'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Conductor Carlos Kleiber brought magic to Strauss' ``Der Rosenkavalier'' on the second night of the Metropolitan Opera's season. The English soprano Felicity Lott, who has been singing opera regularly at Covent Garden, made her Met debut as the Marschallin. Her voice is lovely, though not large. In fact, all voices at the Met on Tuesday night seemed either small or held back. One listened very much to the orchestra, as Kleiber brought out subthemes and made the music glow. Anne Sofie von Otter is the best-looking Octavian we've seen. She is slim and straight and moves like a true young gentleman. Instead of the plummy mezzo-soprano one is accustomed to in the part, her voice is small and has a soprano quality. With the addition of Barbara Bonney in Act 2 as the young Sophie, the leading women's voices are all sweet, unstrained, a delight to listen to - but too much alike. The Marschallin, in Act 1, thinks about losing her youth. She does this in the wondering, almost humorous way of a person thinking about it for the first time. This is appropriate when the singer is as young and attractive as Miss Lott. However, it doesn't add the texture of deep human understanding that some sopranos who've sung the Marschallin have given. This ``Der Rosenkavalier'' was more a musical experience than an emotional one. Aage Haugland, who looked like Charles Laughton, sang Baron Ochs. He hit the high notes in Act 1 and the low notes in Act 2, something that not every singer of the part can do. He sounded as though he wasn't singing full voice. The very stylish production, designed by Nathaniel Merrill and Robert O'Hearn, dates from 1969. Some of the staging has been changed; Ochs picked up Sophie after he asks her to dance and swung her off her feet, side to side, several times. There is now more dancing than before, much of it by Sarah Walker and Anthony Laciura, the ``Italian intriguers.'' Juliana Gondek, a native of Pasadena, Calif., made her Met debut in the small part of Sophie's duenna. Kleiber, who lives near Munich and picks and chooses what operas he will conduct, decided in August that he was willing to conduct the first seven performances of ``Der Rosenkavalier.'' He also decreed there be one, not two, dogs in the Marschallin's bedroom in Act 1. Met Artistic Director James Levine, who had intended to conduct, was able to relinquish that without breaking anybody's contract. Levine will conduct the performances next February and March. In the performances of Oct. 4, 9, 17 and 20, Luciano Pavarotti will sing the one aria by Act 1's ``Italian singer.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: President and Barbara Bush have agreed to donate their organs to science when they die, and the first lady has also signed a living will. ``I had a dog I loved put down, because I didn't want the dog to suffer,'' Mrs. Bush said in the Oct. 30 issue of Woman's Day. ``I would certainly hope someone would do the same thing for me.'' Mrs. Bush also said her husband sheds tears over ``touching, poignant things'' but holds up in emergencies. ``He's not a crybaby like me, and he'd never cry during a crisis,'' she said. What makes the president cry? ``When George first saw our last child, Doro, he just put his head up against the nursery window and had tears streaming down his face,'' Mrs. Bush said. The president insists on clearing the table after a meal, she said. ``I married a man who is a great help at hustling dishes out after a meal,'' she said. ``Even when we just have pickup, I grab his plate to get it first, or he'll rinse it and put it in the dishwasher.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Rep. Joseph Kennedy said politics mucked up his personal life, but he never considered bailing out of public service. ``Politics is a great profession - an exciting, demanding, profession. But it takes a tremendous toll ... on your personal life,'' Kennedy said in an interview for the syndicated TV program ``Personalities.'' The Massachusetts Democrat and his wife, Sheila Rauch, filed for divorce earlier this month. Kennedy, 38, is the oldest child of Robert Kennedy, who was assassinated in 1968 during his bid for president. Kennedy also is the nephew of Sen. Teddy Kennedy, D-Mass., and President Kennedy. Kennedy, who is seeking his third term, said, ``It was just not something that ever dawned on me, to shun public service because of these difficulties.'' --- BURBANK, Calif. (AP) - Animator Ollie Johnston said he wasn't ``on'' anything when he worked on the phantasmagoric Walt Disney classic ``Fantasia.'' Johnston was one of the legendary ``nine old men'' who animated Disney features from 1937 into the 1980s. He drew the centaurettes for the Pastorale sequence of ``Fantasia,'' released in 1940 and due out again Oct. 5. The cartoon interpretation of classical music was a box office failure in the 1940s and 1950s. The turning point came in the 1960s, when young people embraced it as a psychedelic trip. ``People have asked what we were `on' when we made the picture,'' Johnston laughed during a recent interview. ``We weren't `on' anything.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Ann Archer liked almost everything about starring in the thriller ``Narrow Margin'' - but not the stunts atop a fast-moving train. ``I thought there would be a stunt person doing most of it and there would just be a close-up of me when the train was at a dead standstill,'' she said. ``I questioned my whole reason for being an actress. ... I didn't study this,'' she said in a recent interview. ``I used to kid them that every day I felt like I was going to the dentist and it's turning more and more into a root canal as we go along.'' The movie opened nationwide on Friday. Miss Archer plays a witness to a murder who is taken to Los Angeles aboard a train by a prosecutor, portrayed by Gene Hackman. --- PASADENA, Calif. (AP) - Bob Newhart is so thrilled about being picked grand marshal of the Tournament of Roses New Year's Day parade that he doesn't mind working for free. ``It's a huge honor,'' Newhart said after he was chosen Tuesday. ``It's not so much me they're honoring as they are comedy and the role it plays in our lives and how it gets us through the day.'' The 61-year-old master of deadpan comedy will oversee the 102nd annual parade. The theme is ``Fun and Games.'' If he were to design a float on a comic theme, Newhart said, he would plaster flowers over his longtime friend, Don Rickles, and have people sit on him as he waddled down the street. The parade precedes the annual Rose Bowl college football game. The soft-spoken actor recently ended an eight-year run on the CBS sitcom ``Newhart,'' in which he played an embattled hotelier in a quaint Vermont town. He also played a Chicago psychologist in ``The Bob Newhart Show,'' which ran on CBS from 1972 to 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Two Cold-War Era Treaties to Limit Nuclear Tests
DOC.TEXT: More than a decade after they were signed, two Cold War-era treaties that limit the size of nuclear tests by the United States and the Soviet Union have won approval from the Senate. The two agreements now seem less significant than they did when they were negotiated by Presidents Nixon and Ford, but the means of verifying them - recently worked out by President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev - have far-reaching implications. The Senate voted 98-0 on Tuesday to consent to ratification of the 1974 Threshold Test Ban Treaty and the 1976 Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty. Lawmakers used the occasion to call for the eventual elimination of nuclear testing. The treaties, which limit underground explosions to 150 kilotons or less, were delayed for years, first because of efforts to seek a more comprehensive test ban, then by misgivings over whether they could be adequately verified. The latter doubts were largely erased by a new set of verification rules agreed to by Bush and Gorbachev on June 1 during their Washington summit. Those rules, a sign of the new trust between the two former adversaries, provide for intrusive on-site verification. Each side may establish three seismic monitoring stations in the other's territory. Soviet monitoring sites are in Newport, Wash.; Tulsa, Okla.; and in the Black Hills of South Dakota. U.S. monitoring sites are in the Ural Mountains, near Moscow and in Siberia. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, the senior GOP member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, cautioned that the Soviets could use their monitoring teams for spying. He urged that no inspections be permitted until security procedures are tightened. Other than the verification measures, the two modest treaties lag far beyond current arms control reality, which contemplates massive reductions in the U.S. and Soviet nuclear arsenals and sharp cuts in conventional forces. Supporters said the new verification measures are likely to become important precedents for the more ambitious arms control treaties to come. The treaties are a followup to the 1963 Limited Test Ban Treaty, which barred nuclear tests in the atmosphere, underwater and in space. They were intended as a first step toward slowing the race to develop ever-larger nuclear bombs. Several senators said their approval should be the occasion to launch a new effort toward elimination of testing. ``I urge the administration to take seriously the call for further steps'' toward a phased elimination of nuclear test blasts, said Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, noted that President Reagan pledged to begin work on eliminating testing once the two treaties were ratified. ``That was a very important pledge, and it now comes into play,'' Nunn said. At a hearing last week, Ronald F. Lehman II, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said that process will begin in a matter of months with a gradual lowering of the ceiling on test yields, Nunn said. The treaties ran into delays after they were signed, first because of the Carter administration's desire to seek a comprehensive test ban rather than a limitation. The Reagan administration then held them up because it believed the United States would be unable to make sure the Soviets did not cheat, and charged that Moscow had violated the ceiling on at least two dozen occasions. The Threshold Test Ban Treaty puts a ceiling of 150 kilotons on the size of weapons tests and provides detailed procedures to ensure that the other side can accurately measure yields. The Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty places identical limits on nuclear blasts for peaceful purposes, such as seismic exploration or excavation. The United States has not detonated such a ``peaceful'' explosion since 1973, and the Soviets ceased such blasts in 1988. The pact is intended primarily to ensure that large nuclear weapons tests are not carried out under the guise of peaceful explosions. Meanwhile Tuesday, Bush sent to Capitol Hill a treaty to end the 45-year-old division of Germany. In it, the United States relinquishes all rights and responsibilities over Germany it assumed after World War II with France, Great Britain and the Soviet Union. At a White House ceremony, the president called the agreement ``the culmination of more than four decades of Western resolve and determination, from the darkest hours of the Cold War to the bright new horizons that stretch before us.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Seen Unable to Become Self-Sufficient in Grain
DOC.TEXT: It will take much more than an order from Baghdad for Iraq to boost wheat production significantly, Agriculture Department analysts say. The Iraqi government this week ordered farmers to plant 80 percent of their land to wheat in an attempt to offset food shortages caused by the international trade embargo that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But USDA analysts questioned Tuesday said it will be virtually impossible for Iraq to become self-sufficient in food grains under the present circumstances. The sources, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, cited Iraq's sparse rainfall, limited arable land and poor prospects for irrigation development as limiting factors. ``No political structure exists that would encourage agricultural development at the present time,'' one analyst said. ``The years of war with Iran helped stall what progress they were making.'' According to Iraq's agriculture ministry, as reported in the Baath party newspaper, Al-Thawra, committees have been formed in all provinces to oversee the country's wheat program. Ministry Undersecretary Abdul Sattar Hussein was reported to have said the extra effort was needed because of the economic blockade and that farmers should ``plant every inch of our land and increase the production of grains, especially wheat because this is the basic foodstuff of our people.'' Iraq has a total land area of about 43 million hectares, or about 106 million acres, according to USDA records. A hectare is 2.47 acres. More than two-thirds of Iraq is desert, wasteland or urban areas, and only about 14.3 million acres are arable, or fit to grow crops, according to one USDA analyst. Pasture land, which depends greatly on seasonal rains, makes up an additional 9.9 million acres, and irrigation is available on about 6.2 million acres. ``But they've got a terrible salinity problem on a lot of their irrigated land,'' the analyst said. According to USDA accounting, Iraq's biggest wheat crop was 2.6 million metric tons harvested in 1972, a year of good weather and more favorable policies in Baghdad. ``It drifted down from there,'' the analyst said. ``And they need about 4 million tons of wheat a year for consumption.'' Iraq's wheat production in 1990-91 is projected by USDA at 800,000 tons, one-fifth of the country's needs. About three-fourths of Iraq's food needs have been imported, with the United States a major provider of wheat and other grain. In the 1989-90 marketing year, Iraq was the eighth-largest U.S. overseas market for wheat. The Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service said in a recent outlook report that the Persian Gulf conflict ``could have an adverse impact on U.S. wheat exports'' and noted that Iraq alone accounted for more than 1 million tons of wheat last year. ``Kuwait itself has been a relatively small wheat market, importing about 150,000 tons annually - about 50,000 tons from the United States,'' the report said. ``However, Kuwait recently exerted its influence in the world wheat market by providing credit to Egypt.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says Census Figures May Have to be Delayed
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a congressional panel overseeing the 1990 census says release of official state population figures may have to be delayed because too many people are going uncounted. Rep. Thomas Sawyer, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Post Office subcommittee on the census, said the Census Bureau is rechecking disputed figures and has assured that several million people will be added to the preliminary U.S. total population count of 245,837,681. ``I am increasingly concerned, however, that these programs are not designed to find the significant numbers of people who may have been overlooked during the primary counting phases,'' Sawyer said Tuesday at a hearing by his subcommittee. The lawmaker plans to introduce a bill that would delay release of official state population counts until the commerce secretary has adjusted the figures based on the rechecks, or determined that no adjustment is necessary. That decision must be made by July 15, 1991. State population counts were to be released by next April 1 so that state governments would have plenty of time to redistrict before the 1991 state election season. The final count also will lead to congressional redistricting, although timing is not quite so critical for that since the next congressional election is not until 1992. Testimony before Sawyer's committee emphasized the problems the Census Bureau is having counting this complex society with its ethnic diversity, extensive travel habits, diverse living arrangements and huge geographic areas. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said, for example, that in Monroe, Mich., census workers apparently listed vacancies for houses whose inhabitants were simply out of town. ``Michigan has a long winter, and many permanent residents are away from home during the early spring,'' Dingell said. According to census reports, 389 Monroe houses and apartments are vacant, although city officials say there are only 41 units without residents, Dingell said. Rep. Frank McCloskey, D-Ind., said census workers missed 7,000 students in dormitories on the Bloomington campus of Indiana University.
