He said Bloomington Mayor Tomi Allison also told him that about 900 housing units in the city are missing from preliminary census figures. Rep. Arthur Ravenel Jr., R-S.C., who represents Charleston County, said Hurricane Hugo caused many of his constituents to be displaced and uncounted. ``Prior to the hurricane, the city of Charleston had an estimated vacancy rate of 7 percent,'' said Ravenel. ``In April of 1990, after the storm, it was reported to be 11.6 percent (according to the census),'' he said. Rep. Mike Espy, D-Miss., whose district is the third poorest in the country, said the Census Bureau didn't seem to understand the complications of counting a predominantly poor, minority, rural district where many citizens lack the basic education needed to fill out forms. Barbara Everitt Bryant, director of the Census Bureau, said the post-census review was finding clusters of missed housing units and group quarters, such as dormitories. She said 39,000 local governments have had a chance to review preliminary counts and identify discrepancies that will be rechecked. ``We have heard some people claim the census was a disaster,'' Bryant said. ``Making such statements is at best premature, and at worst misleading and potentially mischievous.''

DOC.HEAD: Bill to Boost Fuel Economy Dead for Year
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of a bill that would require sharp increases in automobile fuel economy say they will try again next year to get the measure passed after hitting a roadblock in the Senate. The Senate refused Tuesday to limit debate on the bill, which would have required the automakers to attain a fleet fuel economy average of 40 miles per gallon by the year 2001. The measure then was withdrawn from consideration. The vote was 57-42 in favor of invoking cloture, or limiting debate, but 60 votes were required. ``The minority (of senators) won a small and shortsighted victory,'' Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., said after the vote. ``We will be back next year.'' The auto industry had vigorously fought the legislation, claiming it would force them to build only small cars and lead to the demise of the six-passenger family sedan. Environmentalists and the bill's sponsors disputed the claim and argued that industry would develop technologies to increase gas mileage and still provide a broad range of car sizes. Bryan said he was heartened by the fact that a majority of the senators voted to advance the bill, although not enough to cut off debate. The Senate action came as the Environmental Protection Agency released its fuel economy statistics for 1991 model cars. The list showed that automakers have made virtually no overall fuel efficiency gains over the last five years. The average fuel economy for all cars was 28.1 mpg, the same as in 1987. More than half of the cars get less than 23 mpg, the EPA said. The auto industry had waged a vigorous campaign against Bryan's legislation, which would require manufacturers to produce cars with a company-wide average fuel economy of 35 mpg by 1995 and 40 mpg by the year 2001. The industry argued that such advances would be impossible to achieve without making cars dramatically smaller. Bryan had said earlier he was optimistic about the chances of the bill's passage in light of the increased awareness about the need to reduce the country's dependence on foreign oil. He contended that his legislation eventually would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day. Environmentalists also had lauded the bill as the best way to conserve energy and reduce demands for Mideast oil. ``Today the gas guzzlers won and they're popping the champagne corks in (Iraqi leader) Saddam Hussein's palace,'' said Daniel Becker, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club. Opponents, led by Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., maintained that the tougher fuel economy standards could not be achieved unless manufacturers stopped making a full line of family-size cars. Riegle argued during debate that Bryan's legislation would have imposed an unfair $62.5 billion cost on automakers over five years as they shiftedto complying with more stringent fuel economy requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Chairmen Reach Accord on Deposit Insurance Measure
DOC.TEXT: The chairmen of the House and Senate Banking committees agree on key elements of a sweeping plan to revamp the deposit insurance system, improving the chances for passage of major banking legislation next year. Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, on Tuesday introduced legislation that would force regulators to abandon their ``too-big-to-fail'' policy of protecting all deposits, regardless of amount, at large banks. His bill would impose losses on depositors with more than $100,000 in a failed bank or savings and loan institution. Currently, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. has an unstated policy of protecting all depositors in large institutions whose failure they fear would ripple through the financial system. The drawback is that this encourages depositors to put their money in unsound institutions paying high interest rates. Under Riegle's bill, depositors would still be allowed to insure all of their money by splitting it among several institutions. But currently permitted ways of insuring more than $100,000 at a single institution - through trust and joint accounts - would be banned. Riegle's bill also would force regulators to restrict the risk-taking of ailing banks and S&Ls before they become insolvent. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, has proposed similar legislation. He called Riegle's bill ``right on target.'' At a meeting of his committee Tuesday, Gonzalez released a study by his staff showing the FDIC protected 99.5 percent of deposits in all bank failures during the past five years, even though on average only 75 percent are insured. In S&L failures between August 1989 and June 1990, 99.97 percent of all deposits were protected at an excess cost of $7.8 billion, the study found. The agreement of the two chairmen on the fundamental issue could pave the way for major banking legislation next year that extends far beyond deposit insurance. Curbing the insurance would give lawmakers the leeway to restructure the financial system, permitting banks to enter the riskier but potentially more lucrative businesses of insurance and securities underwriting. However, some members of the House committee and FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman warned that it will not be a easy to get rid of the too-big-to-fail policy. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said big depositors would shift their money to foreign banks whose governments, one way or another, protect their large banks from failing. Seidman said Riegle's bill, as written, would simply push the job of protecting big banks from collapse from the FDIC to the Federal Reserve, which supplies temporary advances to institutions experiencing runs by depositors. If it were revised to effectively force all regulators to abandon too-big-to-fail, it could be dangerous, he warned. ``That could be a very destabilizing factor in our financial system,'' Seidman said. To permit modernization of the financial system without added risk to taxpayers through deposit insurance, Seidman advocated letting banks expand into new areas through separately capitalized subsidiaries that would not use deposits. He suggested that some riskier activities already permitted to banks also should be shifted into subsidiaries. Among these are loans to foreign countries, corporate takeover and leveraged buyout lending, foreign exchange trading, long-term commercial loans and loans for land purchases.

DOC.HEAD: Conference Committee Approves Civil Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: A major civil rights bill designed to spur minority hiring is out of a House-Senate conference committee but under threat of a presidential veto on grounds it would lead to quotas. ``We are optimistic that the president will approve the action of the Congress,'' Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., said Tuesday after lawmakers reached a compromise between slightly differing House and Senate versions. But other lawmakers indicated it was far from certain that President Bush would sign such a measure. ``The president has a historic choice to make,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Five Supreme Court decisions last year would be effectively negated by the bill, which is the top item on the civil rights movement's legislative agenda this year. The bill's features range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to measures aimed at locking in court-approved fair-hiring plans. The main dispute has been over provisions designed to make it easier for minorities to win job discrimination suits. Administration officials contend that these provisions are so skewed against employers that companies would seek employment practices that would automatically provide them with an airtight defense in the event of a suit. And that would mean hiring quotas, say the administration and business groups that oppose the legislation. Civil rights forces scoff at that notion, saying the bill would basically restore the law to what it was before last year's Supreme Court decision in a case involving an Alaskan salmon cannery. The bill passed by the House was for the most part adopted by the conference committee as well. The only major departure was a provision placing a cap on punitive damages that could be awarded in civil rights suits. The cap would be either $150,000 or the total of compensatory damages plus any lost pay, whichever was larger. The House had approved a cap of either $500,000 or the total of compensatory damages, whichever was larger. There was no cap in the Senate bill. Under the House version, the cap would have applied only to employers with 100 or fewer workers. Larger companies would have been vulnerable to unlimited punitive damages. The conference committee placed all companies under the cap. The vote on the cap provision was 9-7, with Republicans voting against the measure.

DOC.HEAD: Millions Suffer From Sleep Disorders That Cause Accidents, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Sleep disorders affect millions of Americans, often causing accidents and ruining careers, but they usually are ignored by physicians and victims may go years without treatment. In a hearing on Capitol Hill of the National Commission on Sleep Disorders Research, victims and experts said Tuesday that more attention must be paid to the suite of sleep ailments that can cripple lives, end marriages, disrupt careers and even cause death. ``The need for sleep research is virtually ignored,'' said William C. Dement, chairman of the commission and a medical professor at Stanford University. ``The house of research does not have a bedroom.'' Sleep disorders range from an irresistible urge to sleep - an ailment called narcolepsy - to insomnia, which is the inability to achieve adequate or restful sleep. Other problems include ``restless leg syndrome,'' the jerking and twitching of the lower limbs during sleep; snoring, which may be habitual for almost half of all adults, and sleep apnea, a disorder in which breathing stops and restarts through the night, disturbing rest and perhaps causing death in some victims. People also suffer from sleep disorders caused by travel and work schedules that disturb the natural rest-wake cycle. Sleep cycle changes may pose a particular hazard in modern society, the experts said. David Dinges, a University of Pennsylvania psychologist, said that poor sleep and the resulting lack of alertness is becoming a major element in industrial accidents, particularly for shift workers, jet travelers who cross many time zones and those working too many hours. ``Inadequate sleep is a major cause of human error, and at least as important as drugs, alcohol and equipment failure'' in workplace accidents, he said. Dinges said airplanes, ships, factories and power plants all are becoming increasingly automated, which means humans must sit and alertly monitor what the machines are doing. ``That's a task we do poorly after missing some sleep, especially if we have to work at night,'' he said. Dinges said industry and the military are beginning to recognize the need to shift work hours to allow for the human need to adjust sleep cycles to new schedules. He said that the use of bright lights to readjust sleep cycles ``shows promise.'' Allowing pilots to nap in the cockpit has been shown useful in keeping them alert during long transoceanic flights, he said. But other proposed treatments, such as special diets, have proven useless in treating the fatigue of jet lag and night shift work. Sufferers of narcolepsy testified that they must constantly fight the tendency to suddenly drop off to sleep, often at the very worst of times. Lori Highland of Ashford, Wash., said she has spent her life ``in a haze of sleepiness.'' ``My life is haunted by this,'' she said. ``I can't drive. I have been hospitalized repeatedly for injuries'' that occur when she collapses suddenly into sleep. Mrs. Highland said that powerful emotions, such as anger, laughter or fear, will bring on cataplexy, a sudden muscle weakness that causes a victim to collapse and be unable to move. She said that her grandfather had similar symptoms, as did her mother and now her young daughter. ``This has affected four generations,'' said Mrs. Highland. ``My mother was labeled a `ne'er do well' because she couldn't stay awake long enough to do her housework.'' She said doctors could not identify her problem for years and that she tried many different treatments, all unsuccessful. Mrs. Highland said she was being prepared for surgery, to search for what was thought to be a brain tumor, when a doctor who had taken a recent seminar on sleep disorders diagnosed her disorder. Allen Music of Silver Spring, Md., said he suffers from sleep apnea, which destroys normal sleep and keeps him in a state of ``uncontrolled drowsiness.'' Before his illness was diagnosed, Music said he routinely drove a car and often would awaken to find the vehicle wrecked because he had fallen asleep at the wheel. To make even a short trip, Music said he learned that he had to take a nap before he left, stop en route and nap, and then nap when he arrived. Gerald Schefey, a former Methodist minister now in his 50s, said he had to retire on disability because sleep apnea pushed him to the point that he was falling asleep while counseling parishioners or while driving. ``Apnea is not considered a disabling disorder, but it is,'' he said. Dement and other experts said the causes of narcolepsy are not known and there is virtually no treatment for the ailment. Few patients respond to drugs, they said. Sleep apnea is now treated with surgery, which works about half the time, and with a sleep mask that feeds oxygen at a pressure that keeps airways from sagging closed, said Dr. Philip Smith of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old With AIDS Resists Death to the End
LaserPhoto NR1 of Sept. 25
DOC.TEXT: Twelve-year-old Sandy Rodriguez resisted to the end the death that had stalked her since Christmas. When it took her in its clutches early Tuesday at her Elizabeth, N.J., home, she enlisted her nurse to help her from her deathbed and drive her to a hospital chapel. ``Dear God. This is Sandy,'' she pleaded aloud. ``Please help me, God. Help me, please. I don't want to hurt anymore. I'm scared.'' Almost every part of her body, from her head to her toothpick-thin legs, had been hurting from AIDS. The virus had apparently slipped into her body through a transfusion needed when she was born prematurely, her family says. Sandy, who succumbed later on Tuesday, was among the nearly 2,500 children under 13 who have contracted AIDS in the United States since the epidemic began. More than half those children have died. In the days before her death, those who loved Sandy were unable to hold her because her 40-pound body and 4-foot-5 frame were so brittle and so black and blue with bruises caused by the slightest touch. At 3 a.m. Tuesday, she prayed in the chapel to realize a child's dreams: to walk out of her bed without the pain in her belly and legs, to go back to school and her friends, to have another party like the big barbecue the aunt who raised her gave for her 12th birthday on May 1, and to see New Kids on the Block. Her No. 1 wish was to fly to Puerto Rico to visit her grandmother, Minga, and to see the clouds from the plane. She had fought to the very end to fulfill that wish, which seemed to be within reach. Angel Pena, of Allendale, N.J., an account executive for an electronics company, read of Sandy's ill-fortune two weeks ago and visited her. He said he was helping arrange the trip for her and her aunt. Instead, Sandy flies to Puerto Rico in death for burial there. ``I don't want to die,'' her nurse, Holly Popovich, who took her to the chapel, heard her pray from her wheelchair. ``I want to live.'' ``I think she knew all weekend,'' said Ms. Popovich. ``She didn't want to sleep. She was afraid to fall asleep.'' Sandy had told Ms. Popovich, ``You take me for a ride in your car. I want to go to church. I want to talk to God. I want to pray.'' On her way out of the chapel, she blessed herself with holy water and took some for her aunt, Carmen Candelaria, whom she called her mother. Mrs. Candelaria took Sandy from her own sister when she was born because the sister was unable to care for her. Sandy's mother died two years ago after mixing Valium and alcohol at a party, Mrs. Candelaria said. She said she knows nothing about Sandy's father. Her own husband, the man Sandy called her father, was killed when she was 7 in a holdup in Puerto Rico, where the family lived for five years. Fearing death, Sandy stalled it. After leaving the chapel, she insisted on going to an all-night supermarket, where she bought candy, gum and a Mickey Mouse book. Upon returning home shortly after 5 a.m., she blessed her aunt with the holy water. ``Mommy, I love you,'' she said. They kissed. Tears came to Mrs. Candelaria. ``Don't cry, Mommy,'' Sandy implored her. ``I just want you to lie down and sleep,'' Mrs. Candelaria told her. ``No, Mom. I just want to do some coloring. Put the bed up. Give me some crayons and a book.'' Mrs. Candelaria put the crayons and book on the bed next to Sandy. The girl loved to color and had painted many pictures for her day nurse, Doreen Small, to make amends for taking out her anger on her. She was too weak to use the crayons. She called out the names of friends absent, her final roll call of goodbyes: ``Glissette,'' her sister, ``Lues,'' her cousin, ``Doreen,'' her nurse, ``Wanda,'' her friend. Shortly after 9 a.m., dressed in a New Kids on the Block T-shirt, she slipped away to a place where, she had told a recent visitor, everything is beautiful. ``You go to God, go to Jesus in a big place where he lives,'' she had said. ``My father is in there. Everyone who dies goes there. ... I can walk in there. No pain in my stomach, no pain in my knee and I walk again.''

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Sues National Enquirer for $20 Million
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor has filed a $20 million libel suit against the National Enquirer, claiming the supermarket tabloid falsely labeled her a heavy drinker with a disfiguring disease. The Superior Court lawsuit filed Tuesday said the actress was hospitalized with near-fatal pneumonia when a front-page headline June 12 screamed: ``Liz Docs Furious. She's Boozing it Up in the Hopital.'' The lawsuit also cited a Jan. 19 article headlined: ``Liz's Beautiful Face Ravaged by Killer Disease. Doctors Order Suicide Watch After They Finally Diagnose the Mystery Illness.'' The lawsuit said that story suggested Miss Taylor had lupus, a destructive skin condition. Miss Taylor claimed the Enquirer was notified about inaccuracies in its stories and headlines before publication. Iain Calder, National Enquirer editor and president, wasn't in the office late Tuesday at the newspaper's Lantana, Fla., headquarters, a receptionist said. Miss Taylor's publicist, Chen Sam, did not immediately return calls after business hours Tuesday. In 1983, Miss Taylor acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and painkillers. She has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam: Bush Leading World to Edge of `Bottomless Abyss'
With PM-Gulf-Finances, Bjt
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is trying to turn Americans against President Bush, saying he is leading the world to ``the edge of a bottomless abyss.'' ``Bush wants to bring back the sorrows of America and humanity by repeating the Vietnam experience, only this time in a more radical manner and more violent and more casualties,'' Saddam said in an address to Americans. Saddam taped the 75-minute message in Baghdad last week, and it was delivered in Washington on Tuesday. Excerpts were aired on the major networks, and CNN decided to show the entire message early today. ``Bush, ladies and gentlemen, pushes your children to a war which has no human value whatsoever, it has no significance except fatal arrogance ... which says to those who are weak - obey - and they obey,'' Saddam said. Wearing a dark suit rather than the military uniform he often favors, Saddam warned that if Bush were to launch war against Iraq, ``it would not be up to him to end it.'' Saddam taped his address in response to an eight-minute message by Bush that was broadcast unedited on state-run Iraqi television 10 days ago. Bush too warned Iraqis that their president had brought them to the brink of war. Sitting at his desk with an Iraqi flag at his side, Saddam said he wanted Americans to know the truth about Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait. His rambling speech was peppered with frequent references to Allah and his teachings, and accused Bush of lacking faith in God. Saddam described Bush as ``promoting a form of neo-Nazism'' by viewing himself as leader of the free world. He made frequent reference to Israel's occupation of Arab lands and its presence in ``al-Quds,'' or Jerusalem, one of Islam's holiest sites. Saddam spoke in Arabic. His remarks were translated with English subtitles supplied by Iraqi authorities. Bush is ``placing you in a critically embarrassing situation ... on the edge of a bottomless abyss,'' by defending undemocratic governments like those of Kuwait, Saddam said. Although Bush told the Iraqi people his administration had no quarrel with them, Saddam said, ``We have evidence that President Bush was himself involved in the Iran-gate or Iran-Contra conspiracy against Iraq in 1986 when he was Reagan's vice president.'' As vice president, Bush was privy to the Reagan administration's decision to sell weapons to Iran - which was at war with Iraq - in an effort to win freedom for American hostages held by pro-Iranian radicals in Lebanon. Congress, too, was involved in a conspiracy against Iraq long before the Aug. 2 invasion, Saddam said. Lawmakers wanted to impose economic sanctions against his country, under the influence of the powerful ``Zionist'' lobby of Israel's supporters, he said. He challenged Bush, again, to an international television debate, adding, ``If Bush has truth on his side, why should he evade debate?'' Iraq desires peace, but one that is based on a broad resolution of all the region's problems, Saddam said. He repeated his call for a peace conference to resolve Israel's 23-year occupation of Arab lands, Syria's 14-year occupation of Lebanon, and Iraq's claims to Kuwait. Kuwait, he said, was part of Iraq under the Ottoman Empire until the British took control of the country in 1899. He called for ``the return of Kuwait to the fold of Iraq, its motherland from which it was long severed, and usurped, like an infant separated from its mother.'' He repeatedly attacked the credibility and integrity of the al-Sabah family which ruled Kuwait for nearly 250 years until the invasion. Kuwait's leaders were ``busy amassing wealth and women,'' he said. So profligate were the rulers, that a Kuwaiti prince once wanted to marry a young woman only to find out she was his daughter, Saddam said.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Rebellion Derails Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: Democratic leaders are trying to revive a major crime bill that conservatives derailed in a protest over death penalty provisions they said are too weak. ``This is a travesty,'' Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., said Tuesday as he and other conservatives fought the measure on the House floor. They said it needed stricter provisions to end excessive delays in carrying out death sentences. The conservatives, who usually lack enough support to win such fights in Democratic-controlled House, managed to defeat, 258-166, a rule that would have barred the House from considering a tighter version of the death penalty provision. The vote forced Democratic leaders to pull the bill from the floor after only brief debate and search for a new procedure that would withstand any such attack. It was a bad day on the anti-crime issue for House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. He also came under fire from police lobbying groups over a separate provision barring consideration of an amendment to increase controls on handguns. The overall anti-crime package calls for the death penalty for 10 federal crimes, ranging from assassination of the president to espionage. It would allow courts to consider evidence gathered with flawed search warrants if police had acted ``in good faith.'' A major controversy is brewing over ``habeas corpus'' provisions designed to end delays of a decade or more in carrying out executions while the condemned file repeated appeals claiming they were treated in an unconstitutional manner. The bill is designed to limit death row inmates to one such petition in many cases to be filed no later than one year after their other appeals are exhausted. The Bush administration and conservatives led by Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., say however that it needs to be far stronger. As it stands, the bill would ``reduce the degree of finality of convictions by weakening procedures relating to habeas corpus,'' the administration said in a statement Tuesday. The administration also called for approval of warrantless searches if police acted in good faith and it attacked a provision of the House bill that would enable convicts to use racial statistics as a basis for appealing death sentences. Defenders of the bill said it could be improved but that it did provide not only powerful weapons for police in the war against crime but ones that could win approval on Capitol Hill. ``It puts more arrows in the quiver of law enforcement,'' said Rep. Romano Mazzoli, D-Ky. But there were many Democratic defectors. Meanwhile, police groups said at a news conference that controls on semiautomatic assault weapons and handguns are needed if police are to be effective in fighting crime. ``Should we wait until the blood of law enforcement officers and peaceful citizens is running in the halls of Congress before we pass sensible gun legislation?'' asked Fraternal Order of Police leader Dewey Stokes. The police groups criticized a Rules Committee decision Monday barring consideration of an amendment that would require a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases. ``Right now, Speaker Foley is not permitting the (amendment) to come to a vote on the floor of the House, so who else can we blame?'' Stokes said. Foley's spokesman, Jeff Biggs, noted the House Judiciary Committee had approved the anti-crime package and the handgun bill as separate measures and said the speaker often goes along with the wishes of committee chairmen. He also said that Foley had not ruled out consideration of the gun bill as a separate item.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Official Rejects National Academy of Sciences Study
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department official rejected a call by the National Academy of Sciences for an overhaul of the nation's critically important agricultural seed collection system. The academy found that nearly half the seed samples in the nation's principal collection are in danger and that only a new, centralized administration can correct the deficiencies that led to that. ``We think the system has worked very, very well,'' countered Edward Knipling, deputy administrator of the USDA's Agricultural Research Service. He said Tuesday he didn't think stronger, centralized management of the nation's scattered seed banks and seed laboratories was possible. The genes contained in the 232,210 samples in the National Seed Storage Laboratory in Fort Collins, Colo., the nation's largest collection, have been used to develop new varieties of corn, wheat and other important crops. Those new varieties have contributed to the tripling of corn yields and other huge gains in American agricultural productivity in recent decades, the study said. Those gains have in turn boosted the nation's economy. Cash receipts from U.S. crops were $72.6 billion in 1988, up $10.7 billion from the year before, the study said. ``Managing genetic resources, therefore, is a strategic necessity for the United States,'' the academy study said. But the study found that 45 percent of the seed samples in the National Seed Storage Laboratory contained fewer than 550 seeds. That means they are in danger of vanishing as the seeds age and die. Such samples may contain irreplaceable genetic traits. But the laboratory does not have the resources to regenerate those samples or increase their size by growing them to produce more seeds, the study said. ``Regeneration of these samples is urgently needed,'' the study said. Many of the study's conclusions echo the findings of a series last year by The Associated Press that concluded that thousands of irreplaceable crop seeds are dead or dying in an antiquated, underfunded federal seed bank. Peter Day of Rutgers University in New Jersey, chairman of the academy committee that conducted the study, said that Henry L. Shands, who heads the National Plant Germplasm System, is ``extremely capable'' but appears to have little or no authority. ``He has to depend on the agreement of large numbers of other committees in order to get anything done,'' Day said. ``It's a very difficult situation.'' Shands, of the Agricultural Research Service in Beltsville, Md., was traveling Tuesday and could not be reached for comment. Genetic materials used in breeding are referred to as ``germplasm.'' The National Seed Storage Laboratory is the cornerstone of a network of perhaps 20 seed collections and laboratories around the country, without a central administration, the report said. ``The great strategic importance of plant genetic resources requires that the system be administered centrally, at the national level,'' the study said. The study said it will be ``very difficult, if not impossible, for the system to function properly without a major overhaul in its structure and administrative procedures.'' Other recommendations in the study included the appropriation of more money to regenerate seeds and the expansion of the National Seed Storage Laboratory.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Arabs Organizing to Change Western Attitudes
LaserPhoto WX11
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 13th graf,``So he xxx to CORRECT Eastern to East
DOC.TEXT: Gay and Arab. They are two words rarely spoken in the same breath, and almost never in the conservative Middle East, but Ramzi Zakharia hopes to change that. A year ago, Zakharia founded the Gay and Lesbian Arabic Society and discovered other Arab-Americans in the homosexual community who wanted to define a distinct gay Arabic identity. ``The result was very positive. A lot of people wrote, `Well, it's about time,''' Zakharia says. Zakharia rented a post office box, started a newsletter and began to hold monthly meetings at people's houses around Washington. Today, there are chapters in San Francisco, Detroit, Los Angeles and New York, as well as a scattering of contacts in Middle Eastern countries, including Lebanon, Morocco, Egypt and Yemen. Zakharia estimates total membership at about 400, and says gay Arabs in London and Paris are talking about organizing chapters as well. The groups are both social and political in focus, with an eye toward changing the ingrained Middle Eastern attitude that homosexuality is ``a Western problem'' as well as Western prejudices against Arabs, Zakharia said in a recent interview. ``There are so many negative stereotypes of Arabs, even in the gay community,'' he said. ``Ever since we started the association, we have gotten the most bizarre and sometimes hilarious letters.'' Some people have written looking for ``young dark men in white turbans ready to offer 1,001-night orgies,'' he said. Others think all Arabs are oil-rich sheiks who throw lavish parties. Zakharia, dressed in blue jeans and a T-shirt, belies either stereotype. He is 26, a computer worker at the World Wildlife Fund. Recent events in the Middle East have galvanized Arab-Americans, Zakharia said, and gay Arab-Americans have been no exception. The Intifada uprising in the occupied West Bank and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait have overshadowed some of the other interests of the Gay and Lesbian Arabic Society, he said. ``The Palestine issue unites everyone,'' he said. ``About 90 percent of Arab-American activism has centered around the Palestine question.'' Zakharia, a Palestinian who grew up in Lebanon, came to the United States in 1982 to attend college. He first tried school in West Virginia, ``but that was a little too rural for me,'' he said. So he transferred to East Tennessee State University, where he studied broadcasting. After graduating, he moved to Washington and became active in Arab-American political causes. Only later did he come out as a gay man, he said. ``There isn't really any `coming out' (in the Middle East) because there isn't a lifestyle per se. Here, there's a lot of lifestyle, and organizations to handle our needs,'' Zakharia said. In Arabic countries, he said, men meet each other at certain restaurants or cafes, but there is nothing overtly ``gay.'' Nevertheless, meeting men for sexual encounters ``is very available,'' he said. ``You can sleep with men, but you can't fall in love with them. Falling in love with them is the bad part.'' The GLAS newsletters voice a common theme of creating and promoting an Arabic gay identity, distinct from the American gay identity. ``That's an issue that comes up a lot, people asking, `Why do you sound and why do you seem so Americanized?''' Zakharia said. ``Well, that's the only example we have.'' One gay Arab who has been corresponding with the society from Beirut complained that the group was too free and open: ``You have to keep in mind that if you want to have Middle Eastern members, secrecy must be No. 1 on your agenda.'' The man, who begged that his identity be shielded, said he would continue to contribute to the newsletter and declared himself ``a militant supporter of your movement, and a passionate one.'' But he added: ``As for establishing a chapter here, that is out of the question. I don't even know gay people here in Beirut. You see, I'm a student here and I keep a low profile. My gay friends are militia men who are uneducated and wouldn't care less for a gay movement.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Amendment Permitting Abortion Counseling
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted to nullify administration rules that prohibit federally supported family-planning clinics from offering abortion counseling or information. By a vote of 63-35 Tuesday night, the Senate approved an amendment requiring the clinics to provide ``information and counseling concerning all legal and medical options'' to pregnant women who ask for it, including ``pregnancy termination.'' The Department of Health and Human Services issued the no-counseling rules in 1988 during the Reagan administration and the Bush administration continued them. They have been debated by the opposing sides of the abortion issue and legal challenges are pending before the Supreme Court. The clinics, many of which are operated by Planned Parenthood Federation of America, receive federal money to provide health care and family planning services for the poor. The amendment was added to a Senate bill that extends the life of the family planning program, established 20 years ago by Title X of the Public Health Service Act. The clinics would still be prohibited from using federal money to perform abortions. The Senate rejected, 58-34, an administration proposal to scrap the program and replace it with block grants to the states, a move that would have handed the issue to each of the states. Other amendments to the bill were pending. Opponents of abortion opposed the amendment reversing the administration's regulation, arguing that the federal government should not encourage abortions or make them more available. ``Most Americans do not want their tax dollars used in any way to facilitate abortions,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Advocates of abortion rights argued that the regulatory ban discriminated against poor women, preventing them from having the same information that women who could afford their own doctor would receive. They said the clinics would not encourage abortions. ``Whether it's abstinence, adoption or abortion, I believe young people have a right to know,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md. Since enactment in 1970, Title X has prohibited aid from going to ``programs where abortion is a method of family planning.'' Until 1988 that was interpreted as barring the use of federal funds to pay for abortions. That year, HHS adopted a broader interpretation that federal money couldn't go to family planning programs that provide abortion counseling and referral. The action touched off a series of lawsuits, and federal appeals courts have delivered conflicting rulings. One of the cases is scheduled for argument before the Supreme Court in its October term. ``Why not let the court make this decision, because it's probably going to have to in the end anyway,'' Hatch said.

DOC.HEAD: Weld Gets Bellotti Fundraiser
DOC.TEXT: The man who raised nearly $4 million for Francis Bellotti's Democratic gubernatorial bid is jumping to the campaign of GOP nominee William Weld. Peter Berlandi said he would bring more fund-raising muscle to Weld, following a primary that was declared by a state agency Tuesday to be the most expensive in state history. The five candidates spent $12.4 million starting on Jan. 1, 1989. Berlandi, who described himself as a strong believer in the Democratic Party, said he was taking the move because Weld and Bellotti possess the same qualities of ``courage, creativity and integrity.'' ``I am not here to change my party affiliation,'' he said. But the move reflected a further shift in political lines in the governor's race. On Monday, former Democratic Gov. Edward J. King, who switched to the Republican Party, said he would support Democratic nominee John Silber. King now lives in Florida. Weld, who has taken progressive stances on several social issues, said he expected more Democrats would come to his side. Berlandi said he does not share Weld's support for the Citizens for Limited Taxation petition that would roll back taxes and fees. But he said Weld could do a better job managing the state's finances than Silber, who is on leave as president of Boston University.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Hold Wide Margins in Brown Poll
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider is losing ground to Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell, according to a new Brown University poll. And Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete, is 42 points behind Democrat Bruce G. Sundlun, says the poll. DiPrete, who wants a fifth term, trailed Sundlun 66 percent to 24 percent, with 10 percent undecided. Pell, who seeks a sixth term, led Miss Schneider 58 percent to 35 percent, with 7 percent undecided. A Brown survey in July had Pell leading 51 percent to 36 percent, with 13 percent undecided. The Sept. 16-19 telephone survey included 414 likely Rhode Island voters. There is one chance in 20 the results could be skewed by more than 5 percentage points either way. Schneider's deputy campaign manager, Robert J. Rendine, called the results ``way out of whack.'' He countered with a Sept. 13-18 telephone poll showing Pell ahead 49 percent to 40 percent, with 11 percent undecided or refusing to answer. With 601 likely voters, the error margin was 4 percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Black Church Endorses Campbell Bid
DOC.TEXT: The predominantly black African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church endorsed Gov. Carroll Campbell's re-election bid. The church's announcement meant that for the second time in a week, a black organization has spurned Democratic gubernatorial candidate Theo Mitchell, who is black, in favor of Campbell, a white Republican. Last week, the South Carolina Conference of Black Mayors endorsed Campbell. Bishop Richard L. Fisher of the AME-Zion's Palmetto Conference said Tuesday that Campbell is ``one of the brightest stars in the political horizon.'' Fisher said the endorsement should not be interpreted as a rejection of Mitchell. ``It's a bit of pragmatism on our part, and a bit of cynicism. I don't believe the Democratic Party in this state is ready to support a black governor,'' Fisher said. The bishop also said that while he and Campbell have had frequent contact in the past few years, ``We've not heard from Senator Mitchell ... I don't know anything about the Mitchell campaign.'' Asked what party he belonged to, Fisher said, ``I'm a Republican, I guess.'' Blacks should not feel that just because Mitchell is black, they should have to vote for him, Fisher said. ``The black community is growing up,'' Fisher said.

DOC.HEAD: Spotlight Shifts to East Europe
With PM-Gulf-Finances Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For years, the World Bank group has been the major source of loans and expertise to stimulate economic development in poor, mostly tropical countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America. Now the bank and the related International Monetary Fund find themselves at the center of the action in a cooler part of the world - nations of the former Soviet bloc in central and eastern Europe. ``We are bringing to Europe what we have been doing in Africa, the Caribbean and so forth,'' said Douglas Gustafson, director of investments for Europe and the Middle East of the group's private sector branch, the International Finance Corp. Currently, the spotlight is on privatization of large-scale government enterprise, something Gustavson described as ``totally uncharted territory.'' Dramatizing the changes, Czechoslovakia, one of the 22 founding countries of the World Bank group at Bretton Woods, N.H., at the end of World War II, rejoined last week - 36 years after its exit was forced by the communist takeover. Prague seeks credits to support drastic price and currency reforms planned for the end of 1990 and technical assistance for plans to privatize about 70 percent of its state-controlled industry. It will use such techniques as distribution of shares to the public and, perhaps, an IFC-designed mutual fund. Depending on the strength and quality of its reforms, newly democratic Czechoslovakia could draw $300 million to $500 million a year of the $11 billion the World Bank may lend Central and Eastern European countries in the coming three years, said bank department director Eugenio F. Lari. The World Bank anticipates lending Poland about $800 million a year, Hungary about $400 million and Yugoslavia $600 million to $700 million, Lari told reporters. Hungary, in the forefront of economic reform, has been allocated $2.3 billion and Poland $1 billion worth of World Bank credit since becoming bank members in 1982 and 1986, respectively. They also have received assistance in such matters as organizing stock exchanges and modernizing banking. Post-communist Bulgaria becomes the 153rd World Bank member on Tuesday. Soviet finance officials are guests at the annual World Bank-IMF meeting here as scores of experts study the Soviet economy in preparation for the Soviet Union's expected accession to the bank group. The Supreme Soviet in Moscow voted Monday to abandon 70 years of communist economics and move toward a market economy, in what some delegates at the annual meetings termed ``a second Russian revolution.'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady told fellow bank governors Monday that the international lending agencies must adjust their operations to emphasize development of the private sector rather than strengthening of government enterprises. But Gustavson said the actual privatization process would require experimentation. ``We do not have a cookbook solution'' to reversing the balance from 90 percent state ownership and 10 percent private to 10-90, he said. Nations until recently under communist rule want to privatize but ``there's an underlying sensitivity about ... the disquieting prospect of selling out cheaply to foreign investors,'' said Gustavson, an American who has worked in Africa for the governments of Sierra Leone and Nigeria. ``When the Hungarians started spontaneous privatization, there were indeed some very sweetheart (concessional) deals done,'' he continued. ``The Hungarians observed it and put the brakes on, slowing the process.'' Gustavson said history may show the best solution to be Czechoslovakia's plan to distribute shares of state-owned property to its own citizens in the form of free or low-cost vouchers not transferable to foreigners until a later stage of reform.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Schedules 20 Sessions With Foreign Leaders in New York
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will hold one-on-one talks with 20 foreign leaders during his three-day stay in New York over the weekend before addressing the United Nations General Assembly. Among the leaders he will confer with are British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and Czech President Vaclav Havel, as well as Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Most of the meetings will be held at Bush's suite at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. Here is the president's preliminary schedule:

Meetings with: -President Cesar Gaviria of Colombia. -Prime Minister Salim Al-Huss of Lebanon. -President Violeta Chamorro of Nicaragua. -Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland. -Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan.

Bush first attends a reception at the U.N. with heads of state, and the opening ceremony for the Children's Summit. Afterwards he meets with: -NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner. -President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador. -President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico. -Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain. -President Hussain Mohammad Ershad of Bangladesh. -President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil. -President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela. -President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia. -Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of the United Kingdom. Bush and Thatcher will dine together.

Meetings with: -President Carlos Menem of Argentina. -President Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay. -Organization of African Unity Chairman Yowery Museveni of Uganda. Bush will also have coffee with African heads of state before departing for the United Nations. There he will meet with: -U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. -U.N. General Assembly President Guido de Marco of Malta. After his address to the General Assembly, Bush will return to the Waldorf Astoria and meet with: -Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Before returning to Washington, Bush will also speak at the ministerial meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation group that includes the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Council Calls for Air Embargo Against Iraq, Halt Shipping
With PM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the official English-language version of the air embargo Resolution 670, adopted 14-1 Tuesday by the U.N. Security Council: The Security Council: Reaffirming its resolutions 660, 661, 662, 664, 665, 666 and 667, condemning the continued Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, its failure to rescind its actions and end its purported annexation and its holding of third State nationals against their will, in flagrant violation of resolutions 660, 662, 664 and 667 and of international humanitarian law; Condemning further the treatment by Iraqi forces of Kuwaiti nationals, including measures to force them to leave their own land and mistreatment by Iraqi forces of persons and property in Kuwait in violation of international law; Noting with grave concern the persistent attempts to evade the measures laid down in Resolution 661; Further noting that a number of states have limited the number of Iraqi diplomatic and consular officials in their countries and that others are proposing to do so; Determined to ensure by all necessary means the strict and complete application of the measures laid down in Resolution 661; Determined to ensure respect for its decisions and the provisions of Articles 25 and 48 of the Charter of the United Nations; Affirming that any acts of the Government of Iraq which are contrary to the above-mentioned resolutions or to Articles 25 or 48 or the Charter of the United Nations, such as Decree No. 377 of the Revolution Command Council of Iraq of 16 September 1990, are null and void; Reaffirming its determination to ensure compliance with Security Council resolutions by maximum use of political and diplomatic means; Welcoming the secretary-general's use of his good offices to advance a peaceful solution based on the relevant Security Council resolutions and noting with appreciation his efforts to this end; Underlining to the Government of Iraq that its continued failure to comply with the terms of resolutions 660, 661, 662, 664, 666 and 667 could lead to further action by the Council under the Charter of the United Nations, including under Chapter VII, with potentially severe consequences; Recalling the provisions of Article 103 of the Charter of the United Naitons; Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations: 1. Calls upon all States to carry out their obligations to ensure strict and complete compliance with Resolution 661 and in particular paragrpahs 3,4 and 5 thereof; 2. Confirms that Resolution 661 applies to all means of transport, including aircraft; 3. Decides that all States, notwithstanding the existence of any rights or obligations conferred or imposed by any international agrement of any contract entered into or any license or permit granted before the date of the present resolution, shall deny permission to any aircraft to take off from their territory if the aircraft would carry any cargo to or from Iraq or Kuwait other than food in humanitarian circumstances, subject to authorization by the Council or the Committee established by Resolution 661 and in accordance with Resolution 666, or supplies intended strictly for medical purposes or solely for UNIIMOG (the Iran-Iraq peacekeeping group); 4. Decides further that all States shall deny permission to any aircraft destined to land in Iraq or Kuwait, whatever its state of registration, to overfly its territory unless: a. the aircraft lands at an airfield designated by that State outside Iraq or Kuwait in order to permit its inspection to ensure that there is no cargo on board in violation of Resolution 661 or the present resolution, and for this purpose the aircraft may be detained for as long as necessary; or b. the particular flight has been approved by the Committee established by Resolution 661; or c. the flight is certified by the United Nations as solely for the purposes of UNIIMOG; 5. Decides that each State shall take all necessary measures to ensure that any aircraft registered in its territory or operated by an operator who has his principal place of business or permanent residence in its territory complies with the provisions of Resolution 661 and the present resolution; 6. Decides further that all States shall notify in a timely fashion the (sanctions) Committee established by Resolution 661 of any flight between its territory and Iraq or Kuwait to which the requirement to land in paragraph 4 above does not apply, and the purpose for such a flight; 7. Calls upon all States to cooperate in taking such measures as may be necessary, consistent with international law, including the Chicago Convention, to ensure the effective implementation of the provisions of Resolution 661 or the present resolution; 8. Calls upon all States to detain any ships of Iraqi registry which enter their ports and which are being or have been used in violation of Resolution 661, or to deny such ships entrance to their ports except in circumstances recognized under international law as necessary to safeguard human life; 9. Reminds all States of their obligations under Resolution 661 with regard to the freezing of Iraqi assets, and the protection of the assets of the legitimate Government of Kuwait and its agencies, located within their territory and to report to the committee established under Resolution 661 regarding those assets; 10. Calls upon all States to provide the Committee established by Resolution 661 information regarding the action taken by them to implement the provisions laid down in the present resolution; 11. Affirms that the United Nations Organization, the Specialized Agencies and other international organizations in the United Nations system are required to take such measures as may be necessary to give effect to the terms of Resolution 661 and this resolution; 12. Decides to consider, in the event of evasion of the provisions of Resolution 661 or of the present resolution by a State or its nationals or through its territory, measures directed at the State in question to prevent such evasion; 13. Reaffirms that the Fourth Geneva Convention applies to Kuwait and that as a High Contracting Party to the Convention Iraq is bound to comply fully with all its terms and in particular is liable under the Convention in respect of the grave breaches committed by it, as are individuals who commit or order the commission of grave breaches.

DOC.HEAD: Since Aug. 2 Invasion, Nine Security Council Resolutions Against Iraq
With PM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Security Council has passed nine resolutions condemning Baghdad: Aug. 3 - The Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion and demand the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraq's troops. Yemen, the only Arab member of the council, abstained on Resolution 660. Aug. 6 - The Council voted 13-0 to order a trade and financial embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Cuba and Yemen abstained on Resolution 661. Aug. 9 - The Council voted 15-0 to declare Iraq's annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law in Resolution 662. Aug. 18 - The Council voted 15-0 to demand that Iraq free all detained foreigners, in Resolution 664. Aug. 25 - The Council voted 13-0 to give the United States and other naval powers the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq and Kuwait by halting their shipping. Cuba and Yemen abstained on Resolution 665. Sept. 13 - The Council voted 13-2 to allow humanitarian food aid into Iraq or Kuwait ``to relieve human suffering,'' and said only the council could decide when those circumstances exist. Cuba and Yemen opposed Resolution 666. Sept. 16 - The Council voted 15-0 to condemn Iraq's aggressive acts against diplomatic missions in Kuwait, including the abduction of foreigners who were in the buildings, in adopting Resolution 667. Sept. 24 - The Council voted 15-0 to stress that only its Sanctions Committee has the power to permit food, medicine or other humanitarian aid to be sent into Iraq or occupied Kuwait, in adopting Resolution 669. Sept. 25 - The Council voted 14-1 to expand its economic embargo to include air traffic in or out of Iraq and Kuwait, except for cargos of humanitarian aid specifically authorized by its Sanctions Committee. It also calls on U.N. member nations to detain any Iraqi ships that may be used to break the naval embargo. Cuba voted against Resolution 670.

DOC.HEAD: Calif. Contribution Limits Struck Down; Fund-Raising Free-For-All?
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge struck down campaign contribution limits that California voters approved in 1988. A state election official warned against a ``fund-raising frenzy'' before the Nov. 6 election. A spokesman for the Republican gubernatorial candidate, U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson, challenged Democratic candidate Dianne Feinstein, the former San Francisco mayor, to join him in voluntarily adhering to the old limits. But the Wilson spokesman, Bill Livingstone, wouldn't commit the candidate to the voluntary limit. A Feinstein spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said the ruling may give Feinstein a chance to chip away at Wilson's fund-raising lead. ``If a law is overturned, I don't know that we will feel compelled to abide by it,'' she said. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton ruled Tuesday that the limits unfairly help incumbents. The limits affect campaigns for governor, other statewide offices and some local posts. Two state legislators who co-sponsored the limits said they would appeal the decision. The state Fair Political Practices Commission, a political watchdog agency, said it would ask Karlton to stay his ruling. Commission Chairman John Larson warned candidates not to start a ``fund-raising frenzy.'' Karlton's ruling invalidated Proposition 73, which, among other things, limits individuals to a maximum of $1,000 in contributions to a particular candidate per fiscal year. The measure also limits political action committees' donations to $2,500 or $5,000 per candidate per fiscal year, depending on the size of the committee. The limits are based on fiscal years that start on July 1. Since state campaigns typically span two calendar years, the measure creates three contribution periods. An individual can give a candidate $3,000 over two calendar years. The judge said that helps incumbents because they usually start fund-raising earlier than challengers do. Two of Proposition 73's three authors, Assembly Republican Leader Ross Johnson and Independent state Sen. Quentin Kopp, said they would ask the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to overturn Karlton's ruling. ``The timing of this decision is most unfortunate,'' Johnson said. Former Gov. Jerry Brown, chairman of the state Democratic Party, one of the plaintiffs in the case, said the decision ``strikes down one of the most pernicious campaign laws ever enacted and puts an end to the pervasive state censorship of grassroots activism imposed by Proposition 73.'' Wilson had nearly $4 million at the start of the general election campaign in July. Feinstein had $645,000. Spokesmen for both candidates said they didn't know how much had been raised since July.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Ambassador Criticizes King Hussein For Supporting Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States, in a bluntly worded open letter to King Hussein of Jordan, takes his fellow Arab to task for siding with Iraq in the current Mideast standoff. The ambassador, Bandar bin Sultan Al-Saud, also chided Hussein for failing to protect Moslem holy places and doing little to advance the cause of Palestinian statehood. The ambassador's letter was published on the op-ed pages of The Washington Post and The New York Times in Wednesday editions. Relations between Saudi Arabia and Jordan have soured because of Hussein's attempts to keep good relations with Iraq and his criticisms of the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia following Iraq's takeover of Kuwait last month Last Saturday Saudi Arabia expelled 20 Jordanian diplomats, reportedly fo gathering information on strategic Saudi installations for Iraq. Referring to a televised speech of the King to the American public last week, Prince Bandar asked: ``Wouldn't it be more honorable and truly moving if you had been moved enough by Kuwaiti women and children with tears in their eyes because they lost their country as a result of the aggression of your friend Saddam Hussein?'' He asked the Jordanian king, who has criticized the presence of non-Moslem troops in Saudi Arabia, home to Islam's holiest shrines, ``what you have done to safeguard the Al-Aqsa Mosque and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre that you lost to the Israelis in 1967?'' The prince noted that Hussein has defended the Palestinian people's right to self-determination, but said that Jordan did not give statehood to Palestinians in the West Bank, now under Israeli occupation, when Jordan controlled the area from 1948 to 1967. ``And how would the occupation of Kuwait give our brother Palestinians their homeland?'' Bandar also attacked Iraq's argument, repeated by Jordan, that the Kuwait-Iraqi border is disputed because it was drawn up by colonial Britain: ``Your Majesty, you should be the last one to say that. Not only all your borders, but your whole country was created by the same colonial British.'' The ambassador contradicted Hussein's statements that the situation resembled Europe of 1914, drifting into a world war: ``Your Majesty, the situation today is like the 1930s, when a madman decided to annex his neighbor and the world did nothing, which led to World War II,'' a reference to Hitler's takeovers of Czechoslovakia and Austria. The Saudi leader closed the letter on a strikingly personal tone: ``Your Majesty, I long had great respect and affection for you to have deep respect and affection for your people. But I no longer can feel that you are the same man I knew. I hope that I am wrong. And if I am wrong, please accept my sincere apologies, Your Majesty. But facts are stubborn things.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor to Auction His Radar Detector
DOC.TEXT: After being pulled over by legislators, Gov. George Sinner has donated his radar detector to a charity auction today. ``It grieves me greatly to part with this priceless family heirloom, but I'm willing to make this sacrifice in the interest of promoting mental tranquility for Bryce Streibel and Pete Naaden,'' he said. The two Republican state senators, frequent critics of the Democratic governor, noticed the detector on the dashboard of Sinner's truck when they visited the Capitol two weeks ago. Sinner appoints the chief of the Highway Patrol, and during the Labor Day weekend had called on truckers to alert police to speeders. The governor at first shrugged off the matter, calling the detector ``sort of a sacred, emotional thing'' that had sentimental value as a gift from his children. But on Tuesday, he had a change of heart. The North Dakota Mental Health Association was to sell the radar detector at its annual auction. ``When is the governor's residence going on the block?'' Streibel asked. ``I think that's next.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Solicits Squirt Guns, Comics, Crafts for Soldiers in Saudi
DOC.TEXT:
The Pentagon is looking for a few good toys to cheer up the troops in the Mideast. The brass asked the public Tuesday to donate things like squirt guns, nerf balls, macrame and kites. Not welcome, at least not officially, are magazines with pictures of scantily clad women. Among the items on the official wish list: electronic and board games such as Nintendo and Trivial Pursuit; music and video tapes as well as Arab language tapes; comics; fitness equipment such as jump ropes and stair-climbing machines, and sports equipment such as portable basketball goals, soccer balls, rubber footballs, volleyball nets and horseshoes. Also suggested: writing materials, including Christmas cards, and personal items such as sun visors, insect repellant and sun block. People planning to send items should check first with a Defense Logistics Agency hot line at 703-274-3561.
---
DOC.HEAD: AMA Complains to Bush About Medicare Investigator
DOC.TEXT:
The American Medical Association wants the federal health department's inspector general fired, claiming the former FBI agent has been reckless and unfair in pursuing Medicare and Medicaid fraud. The AMA, in a letter to President Bush, argued that Richard Kusserow has discredited the administration in carrying out his oversight duties at the Department of Health and Human Services. Kusserow was out of town Tuesday and could not be reached for comment. His spokeswoman, Judy Holtz, said the office was surprised by the AMA's action. She said she could not comment, except to say: ``The inspector general's record speaks for itself.'' Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif., chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health, quickly came to Kusserow's defense, putting out a statement shortly after the AMA released its letter to reporters. ``Criticism from the AMA is a red badge of courage to Mr. Kusserow,'' said Stark, who often is criticized by the organization himself. ``Anyone who resists giving the AMA completely free access to the Treasury and the taxpayer's wallet is immediately branded by the AMA as anti-doctor. Dick Kusserow should get a medal for saving the taxpayer fortunes. That he is being criticized today is a sure sign he is doing his job.'' Dr. Robert McAfee, vice chairman of the AMA Board of Trustees, said frustration over Kusserow's actions has built up over the last five years to the point that ``physicians don't trust him any more.''
---
DOC.HEAD: Task Force Studies Immigration Penalties
DOC.TEXT: Harsher penalties should be levied against employers who discriminate against foreign-looking workers to avoid hiring illegal aliens, according to an administration task force. The 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act ``was not intended to be a barrier for persons who are eligible to work, but the evidence shows that many employers are discriminating by adopting exclusionary hiring practices,'' the task force said Tuesday in its report to Congress. Those practices include hiring only applicants who prove they were born on U.S. soil and rejecting legal immigrants who present work-authorization documents issued by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the study said. The task force said fines for discriminating against foreign-looking workers should be commensurate with the penalties for employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens. That would increase the maximum fine for repeated discrimination from $2,000 to $10,000, it said. The task force also recommended streamlining the procedures for employers to check documents that applicants present to prove citizenship or legal status.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plummet In Tokyo, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell more than 1,000 points Wednesday to end at a 32-month low. The dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 1,108 points, or 4.75 percent, ending the day at 22,250.62, the lowest closing level since Jan. 5, 1988. On that day, the Nikkei closed at 21,575.28. The index, which shed 418.51 points on Tuesday, rose about 150 points in early trading before falling back. The dollar closed at 137.40 yen, up 0.70 yen from Tuesday's close. It opened at 136.57 yen and ranged between 136.45 yen and 137.40. Share prices rose early Wednesday morning because stability in bond markets and the New York Stock Exchange's strength reassured Japanese investors, traders said. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.67 points to close at 2,485.64. However, the index slowed down its gains and reversed direction as investors' buying interest did not last, said Haruhito Ichimura, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. ``The decline was not because of massive, panic-selling . . . but the decline below the 23,000-point level must be quite a shock to the market,'' he said. ``Because many investors believed that the 23,000-point level would be the bottom.'' In currency dealings, the dollar strengthened from the opening as a result of the yen's weakness against the European currencies in cross-trading, dealers said. They said continuing uncertainties in the Persian Gulf crisis are supporting the dollar despite a slowdown in the U.S. economy. Some market players see the United Nations' decision to impose an air embargo on Iraq as the last peaceful move the U.S.-led allies can take against Saddam Hussein.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Replaces New York as School-Spending Leader
With PM-School-Pupil-List and PM-School-Teacher-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey led the nation last year in spending an average of $8,439 per pupil, while Utah ranked last at less than one-third that amount. New Jersey, now locked in a bitter struggle over school finances, thus replaced New York as the nation's per-pupil spending leader, according to the National Education Association ranking. New York placed second at $8,094. Utah spent $2,733 per pupil, according to the annual report. ``It's not a pleasant place to be,'' Scott Bean, Utah deputy schools superintendent, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. He pointed out, however, that the Legislature enacted some $130 million in education spending increases last year. Nationwide, spending per pupil averaged $4,890 in 1989-90, up from $4,607 the year earlier. Average teacher salaries reached $31,166, compared with $29,570 the previous year, according to the teacher union's figures. Alaska, with its high cost of living, paid teachers the most on average: $43,153. South Dakota teachers ranked last: $21,300. Connecticut's teachers got the biggest pay boost last year and now rank second. Average pay was $40,461 in 1989-90, up more than $3,000 from $37,343. Spending per pupil actually declined in two states: North Dakota, where it fell to $3,581 in 1989-90 from $3,662 the year before, and in Montana, where it dropped to $4,147 from $4,176. In North Dakota a voter referendum in December repealed three tax increases. Officials differ on whether more money necessarily means better schooling. ``A lot of people say, `Throwing more dollars won't help education.' Well, I'd like to try it just once,'' said Utah's Bean. Will Myers, a school finance consultant who helped compile the NEA statistics, said per-pupil spending bears a strong relationship to class size. Utah had the highest pupil-to-teacher ratio in 1989-90: 23.6. New Jersey's was 13.4, third-lowest among the states for which such statistics were available. Other factors accounting for state-to-state spending disparities include how homogeneous the student population is and the cost of living in a given state. ``Most of the research that deals with spending versus school performance indicates that family background is pretty important,'' Myers said Tuesday. ``When you have a heterogenous population, you probably have a more difficult job bringing students to the same educational level than when you have a homogeneous population.'' ``Utah and New Jersey are in sharp contrast in that respect,'' he said. The NEA survey is based on statistics from state departments of education. The data are regarded as among the most reliable of their kind by education researchers. Other top spenders among the 50 states included: New York, $8,094 per pupil; Connecticut, $7,934; the District of Columbia, $7,407; Alaska, $7,252; Rhode Island, $6,523; Massachusetts, $6,170; Maryland, $5,887; Delaware, $5,848, and Wisconsin, $5,703.

DOC.HEAD: Limousine for Lassie on 50th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: The star was arf-less. The latest Lassie showed up Tuesday in a white stretch limousine for a ceremony on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The occasion, to re-dedicate the star earned by Lassies past, also marked the 50th anniversary of the book ``Lassie Come Home.'' The Eric Knight novel produced numerous movies about the brave and loyal collie. A radio show aired from 1947 to 1950 and a TV series ran from 1954 to 1971. Lassie earned her place in the Hollywood concrete in 1960. The cast and crew of the current syndicated Lassie series starring a 7-year-old collie attended Tuesday's ceremony. Lassie's trainer, Rob Weatherwax, accepted a 3-foot replica of the star from Johnny Grant, honorary mayor of Hollywood. Weatherwax is the son of the original Lassie trainer, Rudd Weatherwax. In all, six male descendants of the original Lassie - a male actually named Pal - have appeared.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Jail Inmates Freed, Some Residents Fearful
DOC.TEXT: Sales of guns and burglary alarms have picked up in the nation's fourth-largest city since the courts ordered the release of more than 270 inmates to relieve overcrowding at the Harris County Jail. All the freed inmates had been jailed on misdemeanors. But for some Houston-area residents, that's no more reassuring than hearing Houston trails Miami, New York, Los Angeles, Dallas and Detroit in crime. At least 31 of the 276 inmates freed on personal recognizance bond since Sept. 14 are already back behind bars, police said. Seven have been charged with felonies, including armed robbery in one case, police said. ``We're just arresting the same people. We're letting them out and arresting them again,'' said Sheriff Johnny Klevenhagen. ``The citizens of Harris County have again been victimized by the system.'' The jail, designed for 4,200 inmates, now has about 6,300, down from a peak of 8,800 a year ago. The early releases were set in motion when the county missed an Aug. 31 deadline set by U.S. District Judge James DeAnda to reduce the population to 6,100. Bill Carter, president of Carter's Country gun shops, reported a 10 percent increase in gun sales. ``There's a lot of talk in the community about the jail releases and we've had a lot of women come in for shooting lessons,'' he said. Harris County blames the state for the overcrowding. Inmates in county jails are supposed to be sent to state prisons once they are convicted of state crimes. But the prisons are overcrowded and slow to take jail inmates. The jail's overcrowding has been kicking around the courts for 18 years, with Assistant Attorney General Robert Ozer guiding the state's case since 1987. Ozer accused county officials of sensationalizing the releases. ``What it creates for the public is a kind of panic,'' he said. ``It appears the system is breaking down, when in reality, some of these people shouldn't have been placed in these facilities to begin with.'' Similar lawsuits over inmate overcrowding also have resulted in the early release of prisoners in other states. James Oitzinger, who represented Harris County inmates in a lawsuit that resulted in the early releases, said some of those set free would have been out on the street anyway in a matter of days. ``To me, it's a great big yawn,'' he said. When the first batch of nearly 80 inmates poured out of the jail Sept. 14, they were confronted by a group called Mothers of Murdered Children waving signs and shouting protests. ``There's a lot of people scared,'' said Freda Baker, co-owner of Baker's Indoor Pistol Range. ``They're worried about their safety. ... They're arming themselves to protect themselves,'' said her husband, C.T. Baker, who reported a jump in the number of people calling for instructions on how to handle firearms. David Wilt, owner of Detection Alarms, said customers who asked for estimates three months ago are now calling back to buy home security systems. The state is aggressively building more prisons, but they won't be open soon. ``I think we all realize Texas has a serious problem - I don't think that's any news to anybody,'' said Harris County Judge Jon Lindsay. ``It's probably a little more acute here in Harris County.''

DOC.HEAD: Child Cases Likely To Number 10 Million By 2000, WHO Says
DOC.TEXT: By the year 2000 at least 10 million children will likely be infected with the AIDS virus, while another 10 million will be orphaned by the immune-stripping disease, the World Health Organization says. Most victims will be in the Third World, where AIDS will become a major child killer, Dr. Michael Merson, a WHO official, said Tuesday. That would reverse progress made in improving health through vaccinations and other child care programs. WHO forecast that HIV, the Human Immunodeficiency Virus that causes AIDS, will spread to 25 to 30 million people by the year 2000. Previous projections of 15 to 20 million did not take children into account, a WHO statement said. The U.N. agency estimates that 8 to 10 million people, including 3 million women of childbearing age, may already be infected with the virus. Merson told a news conference that WHO only recently started compiling statistics on childhood cases because of the upsurge in infection among women, and hence their offspring, was still relatively new. AIDS destroys the body's immune system. The HIV virus is spread through sexual contact, shared syringes and contaminated blood. It often is transmitted from a mother to her unborn child, although occasionally can be spread through the mother's milk during breastfeeding. Merson, head of WHO's anti-AIDS unit, said 30 percent of infants born to infected mothers were HIV-positive, and four-fifths of those young sufferers died before age 5. Of the remaining 70 percent, many were likely to become orphans, placing a huge strain on the scarce resources of poor countries, he said. He added that scientists did not know why so many children escaped infection from their mothers. The WHO statement said that an estimated 400,000 children have developed severe AIDS symptoms since the epidemic began a decade ago. Nearly 90 percent of the cases were in sub-Saharan Africa. The statement said that during the next 10 years, the disease is expected to push up infant mortality rates by 50 percent in parts of Africa. In addition to the young victims, 800,000 adults are also thought to have contracted the disease, the statement said. Merson said that in some urban areas of Central and Eastern Africa, the virus may have affected one in four adults. Only 283,000 AIDS cases have been officially reported to the Geneva-based WHO because of widespread under-reporting by its member countries.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Saddam Hussein Videotape
DOC.TEXT:
The following are excerpts from Saddam Hussein's 75-minute speech to the American people. The English translation comes from subtitles and voice-overs supplied by Iraqi authorities.
On President Bush's policies toward the Iraqi people:
Bush has said to the people of Iraq that the American administration had no quarrel with them. To prove that, he said that the administration had allowed the Iraqis to purchase some of the goods they needed, particularly grains, on the U.S. market. He also said that the U.S. administration had also helped to bring about the cease-fire in the Iraq-Iran war. The U.S. president was not accurate in saying that the U.S. administration had no quarrel with the people of Iraq. We have evidence that President Bush was himself involved in the Iran-gate or Iran-Contra conspiracy against Iraq in 1986 when he was Reagan's vice president. Voices had already begun to be raised in the U.S. and Britain for an economic, technological and scientific boycott to be imposed on Iraq well before the emergence of the current Gulf crisis. Some of the boycott measures against Iraq including the embargo on the export of grains and other commodities to Iraq had already been discussed and adopted by the U.S. and some Western countries before August 2, 1990, the day on which the Iraqi army extended assistance in throwing out the former rulers of Kuwait who had been installed by the former rulers of Kuwait who had been installed by foreign powers to impose a despotic rule on this severed part of Iraq.
On the trade embargo against Iraq, and the United Nations' failure to impose embargoes on Israel or Syria after it moved troops into Lebanon:
