Such measures were never taken against Israel when it announced its annexation of Arab lands and cities in an official and final manner. No U.S. armies have ever been deployed against that regime, nor have we seen an embargo or boycott being imposed against the Syrian regime. ... Yet we see how the armies of the U.S. have been deployed against Iraq and how the valiant Iraqi people have been denied food, medicine and even their children's milk. This has been imposed through a decision taken exclusively by the U.S., contrary to Bush's claim that those measures were taken by international organizations. These international organizations came indeed later only to be used as a cover for measures already drawn up.
On U.S. and British leadership in opposing Iraq:
These measures taken by the U.S. and Britain, including their military buildup in the region, along with the imposition of the economic embargo and boycott, came well in advance of any official international measure. It was the U.S. and Britain who go to the international organizations to take those measures. Indeed, they even forced some countries into participating in those measures against their will. Pressure was exerted on Japan, Germany, Italy and other countries. Pressure in its open form could be seen every day by the U.S. citizen on television or heard or read about in the other mass media.
On Iraq's annexation of Kuwait:
The return of Kuwait to the fold of Iraq, its motherland from which it was long severed, and usurped, like an infant separated from its mother, will further strengthen the Arab nation and Iraq in their endeavor to reassert their role on the human and pan-Arab levels.
On Bush's refusal to open a dialogue with Saddam:
How can Bush know Saddam Hussein or the colleagues of Saddam Hussein in the leadership when he refuses to have a direct dialogue with Saddam Hussein or enter into a direct debate on TV?
On how war with Iraq would be a disaster:
Bush wants to bring back the sorrows of America and humanity by repeating the Vietnam experience, only this time in a more radical manner and more violent and more casualties. Bush, ladies and gentlemen, is sending your sons to war for no purpose save fatal arrogance.
On a solution to the gulf crisis:
The solution is in what we have called. Let us discuss all the issues of the Middle East (at) once - Palestine, Lebanon and the Gulf in the Security Council and with one aim is to come up with universal standards, taking into consideration the specificity of each case.
On the food embargo and Iraqi children:
You should remember that thousands of children in Iraq will die because of malnutrition as a consequence of lack of milk and many of them - and many people will lack - will - their health will deteriorate because of lack of adequate food and medicine and the milk of children.
On the taking of Western hostages:
Those who are speaking about foreigners prohibited from traveling from Iraq, they should remember that the people of Iraq are prohibited from leaving, and they are hostages because they have no way of traveling.
On the air blockade and Iraq-Kuwait unity:
Some of you are speaking about blockading air travel. Have you ever heard - have you heard of such measures? When Bush is told, why are you against union - unity between Iraq and Kuwait, and you did not object to the unity between East and West Germany?
On world opinion against Iraq:
What we worry about is the judgment of God on the final day and the judgment of history and our people. And we respect world public opinion when this world public opinion is based on objective facts. Otherwise, world public opinion is nothing but the result of Satan.

DOC.HEAD: Big-City Crime Claiming More and More Innocent Victims
DOC.TEXT: A high school dropout's dream of putting to use his new college diploma was shattered by a random gang attack. A girl's ninth birthday ended with a stray bullet as she lay on her mother's bed. From New York to Chicago to Milwaukee, big cities are seeking emergency gun control measures as they battle a dramatic rise in violent crimes, many involving random killings of innocent victims. ``It doesn't matter where you are or what you're doing, the lives of people in the inner city ... are at stake,'' said anti-crime activist Ruth Varnado, whose Reclaiming the Streets movement has won praise from President Bush. Milwaukee, a city of 600,000, has seen its murder rate jump by more than half to 18.7 per 100,000 residents between 1988 and 1989. That translated into a record 116 homicides in 1989. Already this year, 115 killings have been recorded. A decade ago, there were fewer than 100 homicides in all of Wisconsin. Of even greater concern is the randomness of three killings in Milwaukee this month. Nine-year-old Shereker Wilkins, whose family recently fled a Chicago housing project, was lying on her mother's bed Saturday night after celebrating her birthday when a stray bullet pierced the bedroom wall and struck her in the head. She died 10 hours later. Her mother couldn't afford the funeral. ``I wanted to get away from the drug dealers, gangs, shootings, the projects and make a new start for my kids,'' said Ruby Wilkins. ``I thought I had moved somewhere where I would be safe.'' A week earlier, a 17-year-old was accused of randomly selecting and executing Charles Davis, 19, to prove in a street gang initiation rite that he knew how to kill. Davis, a high school dropout, had recently earned a degree from Milwaukee Area Technical College and got a job at a lawn mower factory. In the same neighborhood, Tammy Reilly, 17, was killed Saturday by an errant blast from a sawed-off shotgun as she listened to music in a relative's apartment. ``It's going to take a long time for this community to ever heal. They're are just too many scars,'' said Queen Hyler, founder of Stop the Violence, a citizen group. ``I'm not going to sit here and watch them bury another 9-year-old without shaking this city up.'' Ms. Hyler isn't alone in her efforts. City and county officials this week began drawing up emergency measures to enforce gun registration. In Chicago, 628 slayings have been recorded so far this year, 111 more than all of last year. The City Council this week began emergency hearings to seek new ways to control drugs and gangs. In New York City, 16 children have been shot since July 22 and six have died, police said. Mayor David Dinkins has also issued calls for tighter gun controls. In Milwaukee, Police Chief Philip Arreola refused interviews this week and instructed his officers not to discuss the spate of killings. Community activists blame the rising crime rate on double-digit unemployment and inadequate funding for schools, drug rehabilitation and counseling for gang members. ``We said in 1989 if you don't help us on the front side, then you'll have to pay for it on the back side,'' Ms. Varnado said. ``The back side is that our babies are dying.'' Said Ms. Hyler, ``You have to live around the bullets, you have to see the mother's crying, you have to be afraid to come out of your door, you have to see murders. When you're living like that you know what the problem is.''

DOC.HEAD: Traffickers Wound U.S. DEA Agent
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. drug agent patrolling a major cocaine-producing region with Bolivian anti-narcotics police and other American agents was wounded by drug traffickers in an ambush, the U.S. ambassador reported. Police returned the fire and killed at least one of the machine gun-wielding traffickers, U.S. Ambassador Robert Gelbard said Tuesday. The agent was shot in the arm and leg but not seriously hurt. The ambush Monday was the most serious confrontation between traffickers and Bolivian police and U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents in recent years. Poor communications from the remote region prevented the news from reaching official circles until Tuesday. ``The traffickers reacted in a violent way because they are beginning to feel the affects of the U.S. and Bolivian anti-drug operations,'' Gelbard said. Police and agents were on a routine patrol in the Chapare coca-producing region when at least 20 heavily armed traffickers fired on them, the ambassador told The Associated Press. The Chapare is in the center of Bolivia, about 250 miles east of La Paz. Traffickers also fired on U.S.-donated helicopters that were sent in to rescue the wounded agent. At least two Bolivian policemen were missing. Bolivian police units have been mobilized in the area in the effort to capture the traffickers. Bolivia is the second-largest cocaine producer in the world after Colombia. The Chapare, an area the size of New Jersey, produces an estimated one-third of the coca leaves that eventually are made into cocaine paste and further processed into pure cocaine. The DEA has been operating in Bolivia since the early 1970s but its efforts have increased markedly in the region the last five years. There are an estimated 60 U.S. DEA, border patrol agents and military advisers in Bolivia. The ambush took place near the village of Isinuta, a major coca-leaf production and cocaine paste distribution center in the Chapare.

DOC.HEAD: Lookout For Fall's Changing Colors Has Begun
DOC.TEXT: At least once a week, from his vantage point atop Clinch Mountain, Francis Collins files an intelligence report of sorts. He calls state officials to tell them just how red, yellow and gold the forests below his restaurant are becoming. Collins is one of a small band of ``color observers'' who will alert the rest of North Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee when fall color is at its peak. Spectacular foliage may be most closely associated with New England - an estimated 3 million ``leaf peepers'' from across the country visit that region each fall - but it also brings thousands to the southern Appalachians. The three Southern states have formed a loose network of color watchers to help tourists plan their trips. Many of the observers are forestry or recreation officials. Some, like Collins, are volunteers - regular folk with time on their hands and an eye for color: the reddish-orange of the sugar maple, the solid, fiery red of the sweet gum tree, the yellows of the elm, hackberry and tulip poplar, and the splash of green of the fir. Some watch from their front porches, others from their cars and trucks as they drive through the forests on these warm September days and cool evenings. ``As long as I've lived around these hills, you can pretty well guess at it,'' Collins said. ``We're setting right up on top and we can pretty much see the world.'' And the way things are shaping up, now the peak will be the third week of October, Collins said. He guessed now that maybe 15 percent of the leaves have changed on the mountaintop. In lower elevations, a few leaves are turning now. Admittedly, ``there's not a real scientific sample,'' said Bob Miller, spokesman for the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Park officials look at the trees each week from late September to early November to estimate a percentage. Collins has read up on his trees and keeps a close eye on the subtle changes. In a pinch, he can seek some advice from some of the old-timers who come by. Most people helping the state simply know trees. ``The only way I've got to go is the degree of color,'' said James Smith of Rockwood, a grocery-store owner and color observer last year. ``I was raised in the country so I know most of the trees.'' Smith and Collins agreed 1990 has the makings of a good year for color. The summer was hot, there was rain late in the season and fall has arrived with warm days and cool nights. ``It looks like we're going to have a good change,'' Collins said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rejects Keating's Bid for Cut in $5 Million Bail
DOC.TEXT: Financier Charles H. Keating's request to lower his $5 million bail has been denied by a California appeals court. The court, without comment, turned down the request Tuesday from the Arizona developer blamed by regulators for the nation's biggest thrift collapse, the $2 billion failure of his Lincoln Savings & Loan. Keating was indicted last week on charges of swindling investors in now-worthless junk bonds sold through the Irvine-based S&L. District Attorney Ira Reiner acknowledged that $5 million is a high price for freedom, but he added, ``You can't consider Mr. Keating without thinking of Robert Vesco'' - the financier who fled the country while under investigation during the Nixon administration. Keating contends he is broke and can't adequately defend himself from jail. Defense attorney Stephen C. Neal said earlier he would pursue every avenue to get Keating out. The next appeal would be to the California Supreme Court. Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner had set Keating's bail, saying he might flee rather than risk 10 years in prison. Keating's three co-defendants, executives in his empire, got out on bail of $100,000 to $200,000 last week. All four are due in court Oct. 5 to enter a plea.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Texas School Finance System Remains Unconstitutional
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `McCown gave ...' to CORRECT enrollment to 3.3 million sted 3 million.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clements says he will appeal a ruling that the state's method of financing its schools remains unconsitutional. State District Judge Scott McCown ruled Tuesday that the $14 billion overhaul adopted earlier this year in response to a Texas Supreme Court decision still doesn't give schools ``substantially equal'' access to funds. Instead, ``the rich districts are left rich, the poor districts poor,'' he said. McCown gave legislators until Sept. 1, 1991, to again reform the 3.3-million-student system, which relies on state and federal aid and local propery taxes. If a suitable plan is not devised by then, McCown said he may stop the spending of tax money on schools or order how the money can be spent. ``I don't agree with his judgment at all,'' the governor said. ``He's a young judge. Perhaps the Supreme Court in its review will reconsider that opinion.'' The judge ruled that financial inequities between schools are caused by the wide range in property values across the state. ``What the rich districts spend creates educational opportunities for their children that are denied the children of poor districts,'' he said. Rick Gray, a lawyer for poor districts that challenged the new system, was jubilant. ``We think it's a great day for all schoolchildren, and we hope the Legislature will set about the task of fixing the system in the future,'' he said. The overhaul was adopted in June after four special legislative sessions. Among other things, it raised taxes to add $528 million for schools during the 1990-91 year. Poor districts had argued that the new plan was no different from the old setup, which was scrapped by the Texas Supreme Court in a 9-0 ruling last year. Texas is one of a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems in recent years. Others include Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. Clements leaves office in January. The gubernatorial nominees, Democrat Ann Richards and Republican Clayton Williams, both oppose new taxes. ``I think that the people are going to be very interested in knowing exactly how they propose to solve the problem without any new money,'' said Education Commissioner W.N. Kirby.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Schools Working on Plan to Distribute Condoms
DOC.TEXT: New York City is reviving a program to distribute condoms to students because of the continued rise in AIDS and unwanted pregnancies. ``We see both these things as in crisis proportions in certain communities,'' Carmen Rivera, director of Mayor David Dinkins' office of health policy, said Tuesday. City Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez is preparing the proposal with backing from the mayor. James Vlasto, a spokesman for Fernandez, said the details were still being worked out. But Rivera said the condoms would be distributed through health clinics in 20 junior high and high schools, which serve tens of thousands of students. The school system briefly distributed condoms in 1986 but stopped because of opposition from several Board of Education members, including the current president, Gwendolyn Baker. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese also opposed the program. Rivera said most of the seven board members, including Baker, now support the plan. Five of the current board members were not there in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: China Applauds Its Own Diplomatic Rebound
DOC.TEXT: China today applauded its diplomatic rebound from last year's status as an object of world scorn to this year's as respected participant in U.N. deliberations on the Persian Gulf. ``This year our nation's foreign relations have made gratifying progress,'' declared a front-page People's Daily editorial. The newspaper's editorials are written by the top Communist Party leadership and amount to policy statements. China ``is winning more and more friends worldwide and a good international prestige,'' the editorial said. It maintained that this vindicated China's domestic policies, including its violent crushing of a massive student-led movement for democracy in June 1989. That incident, in which hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed, caused the industrialized democracies to freeze high-level exchanges with China and curb soft loans. But the sanctions have recently shown signs of crumbling, due to China's release of hundreds of political prisoners and its cooperation in approving U.N. Security Council resolutions punishing Iraq. The People's Daily said China's foreign policy gains were a ``vivid reflection of our country's independent, self-initiated and peaceful foreign policy.'' ``Since last year, international forces completely hostile to China raised an anti-China tide and brazenly interfered in China's internal affairs, established sanctions against our country and plotted to isolate China. ``China did not knuckle under to foreign pressure and continued to carry out the basic line set by our party of building socialism with Chinese characteristics.'' It indirectly defended the army's June 1989 attack on unarmed protesters, saying, ``Just think, if a nation of 1.1 billion people has daily turmoil and can't manage its economy, how can it gain the respect and trust of other peoples?'' The editorial also pointed up China's renewed interest in its discarded, 1960s role as a leader of the Third World. It said that strengthening cooperation with Third World countries was the basic point of China's foreign policy, and championed the Third World call for a more equal distribution of wealth and power among nations. China's biggest foreign relations gains over the past year have been with non-Western countries. Beijing opened or restored relations with Namibia, Saudi Arabia and Indonesia, and is expected to establish ties with Singapore before year's end. China also recently has made repeated overtures to Japan and the West. It sent Education Minister Li Tieying to Japan and a group of mayors to the United States, while giving warm, high-level receptions toanese and Western businessmen visiting Beijing. Since China cooperated on approving U.N. sanctions on trade with Iraq, there have been indications that its freeze-out by Japan and the West is nearing an end. The Group of Seven leading industrialized nations at a meeting this week in Washington expressed openness to restoring loans to China. Last week Japan sent its first Ccbinet-level minister to Beijing since June 1989 when Education Minister Kosuke Hori arrived for the opening of the Asian Games. Japan also has indicated willingness to restore development aid to China. A bill was submitted Tuesday to the U.S. House of Representatives proposing that China's preferential trade status be canceled. But Congress is not expected to pass the measure, and the White House has indicated it would veto it. END wilhelm

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Hit Lowest Level Since Early 1988; Dollar Strengthens
DOC.TEXT: Share prices nose-dived in Tokyo today, closing at their lowest level since early 1988 due to panic-selling and worries about the Persian Gulf crisis, traders said. The dollar was up against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average dropped 1,108.70 points, or 4.75 percent, ending the day at 22,250.62, its lowest closing level since Jan. 5, 1988. On that day, the Nikkei closed at 21,575.28. ``As soon as the Nikkei fell below the 23,000-point line, individual investors started panic selling,'' said Kozo Hasunuma, a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co. Until Wednesday, the 23,000-point line had been seen as the market's bottom. ``But now there will be no psychological resistance until the 21,000-point level, which is expected to be the next turning point according to the market's past patterns,'' Hasunuma said. He said the market's recovery will be ``very difficult now because there is no positive element to encourage buying by investors.'' The Nikkei index now has lost 8,587.37 points, or about 28 percent, since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Since the beginning of this year, the Nikkei has lost 16,665.25 points, or nearly 43 percent. Analysts say investors are afraid the Japanese economy will be badly hurt if the nation's oil supply is cut off by a deterioration of the gulf crisis. Japan depends on imports for 99 percent of its oil needs, and 70 percent of comes from the Middle East. Total trading today was moderate, with many institutional investors staying on the sidelines as individuals hurriedly tried to dispose of their shares, traders said. An estimated 350 million shares changed hands on market's first section, up from 230 million the previous day. Hasunuma said many individuals were forced to sell their stocks in order to come up with payments for issues they had bought on margin. The Nikkei index, which shed 418.51 points on Tuesday, rose about 150 points in early trading today before falling back. On the foreign exchange market, investors sold the yen in reaction to the decline in share prices, traders said. The yen's fall accelerated toward the end of the day, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The dollar closed at 137.40 yen, up 0.70 yen from Tuesday's 136.70-point finish. The currency began the day at 136.57 yen and ranged between 136.45 yen and 137.40 yen, as $11.34 billion changed hands in spot trading. Tuesday's volume was $8.15 billion. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 80.73 points, down from 80.77 Tuesday and a record closing low. Their yield rose to 8.690 percent from 8.680 percent Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Test Results Fail to Link Suspects to Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Police boosted patrols in the area where five students were slain after crime laboratory results failed to link any suspects to the killings, a newspaper reported today. It wasn't certain, however, whether the test results last week cleared Edward Lewis Humphrey or any other suspects in the stabbing deaths, or if they just failed to support existing suspicions, The Gainesville Sun reported. Nor was it clear whether all tests had been completed, the newspaper said. Police last week announced stepped-up night patrols where the bodies of the five students were found last month. Four victims attended the University of Florida; the fifth was a student at the city's Santa Fe Community College. The beefed-up patrols were ordered after the task force received the results of tests and after the apparent failure of intense searches of woods frequented by Humphrey, an 18-year-old freshman at the university, the newspaper said, citing law enforcement sources it did not identify. Among the items that had been taken by investigators for testing were pubic hair and blood samples from Humphrey and another suspect, Stephen Michael Bates, 30. They are jailed on unrelated charges; neither has been charged in the slayings. Other items collected for testing included semen, blood and a single pubic hair found at one or more of the murder scenes and on a knife found in a milk jug at Humphrey's home in Indialantic, authorities said. Humphrey's lawyer, J.R. Russo, told the Sun he had no knowledge of any test results. Task force members would not comment on lab tests, the newspaper said. A police spokesman did not immediately return a telephone call late Tuesday from The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Police Blame Vendetta by 14-Year-Old Girl for Picnic Poisoning
DOC.TEXT: A 14-year-old girl took revenge on two playmates by inviting them to a picnic and serving them a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and grape drink laced with poison, police say. Neither youngster was seriously hurt. The girl told friends she got the idea of putting rat poison in the sandwich from the movie ``Heathers,'' an R-rated black comedy featuring teen-age murder and a tight clique of popular girls, King County police said. Other girls invited to the picnic and croquet party were aware that a sandwich had been laced with rat poison and some grape drink had been mixed with a household cleanser, police spokesman Tony Burtt said Tuesday. The incident involved girls from at least three families Sept. 16 and was being investigated as a possible criminal assault, police said. Detectives were awaiting results of food tests before deciding whether to seek criminal charges in juvenile court, Burtt said. An 11-year-old girl had a stomach ache after taking several bites of the sandwich and a 9-year-old vomited after sipping the drink, police said. None of the children was identified. The dispute erupted partly because one girl apparently hid a videotape of ``Heathers'' and then claimed another girl had it, the mother of the girl who got the grape drink told the Valley Daily News. ``It's scary because the girl that's supposed to have done all this was a friend of my daughter's,'' the mother said. ``They've been good friends for a year and they used to spend the night at each other's houses.'' The mother of the 14-year-old denied her daughter planned the poisoning. In an interview in today's Daily News, she blamed two other 11-year-old playmates at the picnic. ``At the very least, they were more than just witnesses,'' said the mother, whose name the paper withheld to avoid identifying the children. Police were told the dispute also involved some clothing and jewelry one girl was accused of taking. Two girls told police they were at the 14-year-old's home the day she came up with the plan, officers said. Police said the 14-year-old made peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and put them in plastic bags. Rat poison was hidden in one sandwich, which was cut and wrapped differently so it could be picked from the others. Neighborhood children came to the picnic at a baseball field, where the 14-year-old said she was going to ``pretend to make up'' with one girl, then giv her the tainted sandwich, police said. The teen-ager said it would ``only make her throw up,'' other children later told police. The girls were playing croquet. The movie ``Heathers'' contains two scenes in which teen-age girls play croquet.

DOC.HEAD: One-Third Fewer American Troops in Europe by 1995, U.S. Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The United States expects to reduce its 300,000 troops in Europe by at least a third over the next five years - but does not plan a total pullout, th American ambassador to NATO said today. ``There are very important opportunities for reducing our forces and for restructuring them'' in the changing Europe, William H. Taft IV told journalists at the end of a brief visit to neutral Sweden. ``We expect to see, within the next five years, a reduction of at least a third (of U.S. troops in Europe), from 300,000 to 200,000,'' Taft said. ``If things go well, we could see further reductions.'' He also said that other countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are considering a U.S. request to send ground troops to join American, British, French and Turkish soldiers facing Iraqi forces in the Persian Gulf region. He did not name the countries considering the request. Other NATO countries are West Germany, Belgium, Italy, Greece, Denmark, Norway, Canada, Iceland, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal and Spain. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has said soldiers and airplanes from other nations would be welcome, even if the numbers were only symbolic, in the effort to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Taft said all NATO countries have contributed military vessels to the international armada enforcing an embargo on trade with Iraq, except Iceland and Luxembourg, ``which don't have any.'' He said West Germany sent ships to the Mediterranean. ``We're happy with the positive responses. ... We would like to see the European allies do more,'' Taft said. ``We would not be happy if there's nothing more,'' he said. ``But we haven't given up.'' International cooperation on the Persian Gulf crisis is important because, Taft said, ``We're setting up the new (post-Cold War) order of things, and the world needs to make it very clear that invading a country and taking it over won't be accepted.'' Taft said the ``haphazard'' reaction of European Community members to the gulf crisis had shown that ``political cooperation will have to be effected before it (the EC) can expand to military affairs.'' Taft said the United States supports the ``development of European defense capability'' but foresaw no complete withdrawal of U.S. military forces from Europe despite the fall of Communist governments in Eastern Europe and improved relations with the Soviets. He said no credible politician in the United States had proposed a smaller American presence in Europe than 80,000. ``The United States is not considering, and no serious politicians in the United States are suggesting, withdrawal of all U.S. forces in Europe,'' Taft said. He added that no European country, ``not even the Soviet Union, wants to see the United States disengaged from Europe. ``It is the link the (NATO) alliance provides from the continent with one superpower to another superpower. It's a balancing force, a force of stability,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Mayor, Singer Reportedly Will Wed in Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Bill Boner, whose affair with an aspiring country singer has been good for a lot of snickering, reportedly will marry her on Monday, four days after his divorce from his third wife becomes final. Boner, 45, and Traci Peel, 34, will wed in Hawaii, The Tennessean reported Tuesday, without citing its sources. A Boner spokesman said only that the mayor was on vacation and would return next week. The wedding would cap a love affair chronicled by supermarket tabloids and syndicated television after Peel told the Nashville Banner the mayor's passion could last seven hours. Boner, a Democrat who left Congress in 1986 under the cloud of an ethics investigation, announced in July that he and Peel were engaged. At the time, Boner was estranged but still married and living with his third wife, Betty, and their 4-year-old son. He had already decided not to seek re-election. His divorce becomes final Thursday, The Tennessean reported.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Dots Northeast, West; Fair Skies in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain dotted the Northeast and West early today and fair skies prevailed in the nation's midsection. Showers fell in Pittsburgh and thunderstorms plagued Anchorage, Alaska. Cooler temperatures were expected today in the northern Plains. More warm weather was forecast for the Plains and the Mississippi Valley. Scattered showers and thunderstorms were to continue in the West. Temperatures Tuesday in the Plains were as much as 20 degrees higher than normal for late September. Hail 1{ inches in diameter fell near Salt Lake City and rain-flooded streets in Redding, Calif. The high temperature Tuesday in the Lower 48 states was 102 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Town Gets First Traffic Signal
DOC.TEXT: Residents have decided to call a halt on traffic streaming through this crossroads community in eastern Oregon. They've installed a traffic light - the first in the town's 107-year history. ``This is one of the best things that ever happened to the town,'' Mayor Frank Alvarez said of the three-lens traffic signal at a ribbon-cutting ceremony Tuesday attended by about 70 of the town's 1,615 residents. Though other towns in the region have resisted the need for a red light, Stanfield is happy to have traffic come to a halt, even if only for a moment. ``When you see old people standing on the curb for 45 minutes at a time, trying to get across, you know it's kind of bad,'' City Councilman Bob Swales said. Five years ago, the town earned headlines and a mention by Johnny Carson on the ``Tonight Show'' when it passed an ordinance outlawing public sex by animals.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher In Nervous and Choppy Trading, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher in nervous and choppy European trading late this morning. Gold prices were down, but off their lows reached late in Asian trading. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar was firming as banks moved in and out of short-term positions. ``There's a lot of cross-trading going on, especially in the yen, and this is moving the dollar against the European currencies as well,'' said one trader in Milan. Cross-trading is trading between currencies other than the dollar. The dollar gained in New York late Tuesday, boosted by a number of factors including remarks by a West German finance official who said he didn't see the risk of a free-fall in the dollar. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.70 yen to a closing 137.40 yen. Later in London, it was quoted lower at 137.10 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: -1.5710 German marks, up from 1.5630 -1.3060 Swiss francs, up from 1.2990 -5.2555 French francs, up from 5.2340 -1.7663 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7618 -1,175.65 Italian lire, up from 1,168.25 -1.1560 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1493 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8680, cheaper for buyers than $1.8765 late Tuesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $401.75 per ounce at midmorning, down from $403.25 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $401.25, down from $404.25 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.28 to close at a bid $400.17. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.84 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $4.87.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic Storm Expected to Weaken
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Josephine retained its 40 mph top winds early today, but could weaken and drop back to tropical depression strength during the day, forecasters said. Josephine, which became the 10th tropical storm of the Atlantic hurricane season Monday, was moving west at 9 mph this morning, said the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The system was expected to maintain that course and forward speed for the next 24 hours, the agency said. At 6 a.m. EDT, Josephine was centered near 20.9 north latitude and 38.1 west longitude, or about 860 miles west northwest of the Cape Verde islands. The islands are off the coast of west Africa. Tropical depressions have maximum sustained winds of less than 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes once their top winds reach 74 mph. Josephine was born from the 12th depression of the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Who Went Undercover for FBI Resigns
DOC.TEXT: A legislator who worked undercover for the FBI during a 16-month investigation into vote-buying in the Statehouse has resigned. Rep. Robert Kohn, R-Charleston, was one of nine state lawmakers indicted by a federal grand jury last month on charges of accepting bribes in exchange for their support of a bill legalizing betting on horses and greyhounds. They were indicted under the Hobbs Act, a federal law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or favors. Kohn, 45, who was first elected to the state Legislature in 1975, delivered his resignation Tuesday to House Speaker Bob Sheheen, who had suspended him. The resignation was to take effect today, a few hours before he was scheduled to appear before U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins for a hearing. Kohn has pleaded innocent. On Aug. 16, when Kohn announced he would not seek re-election, he said he had been working undercover for the FBI for several months. ``While some people might question the wisdom of assisting (the FBI) in their investigation, I can only say, `When the FBI wants you to cooperate, you will cooperate,''' he said at the time. Tuesday, a judge issued a gag order and ordered court records sealed in the case of state Rep. Luther Taylor, a Columbia Democrat. Taylor's lawyers argued at a hearing Monday that pretrial publicity had been prejudicial to his case. Taylor pleaded innocent and was scheduled to go to trial next month. The FBI sting employed a former House member-turned-lobbyist, Ron Cobb, who purported to represent an Atlanta organization that supported efforts to legalize parimutuel betting on horses and greyhounds in South Carolina. The indictment alleged Kohn and Taylor met with Cobb and agreed to accept money for their support of the pari-mutuel bill. It also alleged they agreed to recruit other lawmakers to support the bill. Kohn, if convicted, faces a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison and a fine of $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Study Links Smoking With Depression
DOC.TEXT: Doctors may be able to predict a person's tendency to smoke by knowing whether the individual has ever suffered depression, a researcher says. A report in today's edition of the Journal of the American Medical Association says people who have suffered major depression are twice as likely to smoke and half as likely to succeed at quitting. ``People talk about some sort of addictive personality . . . but don't know what makes people more addictive than others,'' said one of the authors, Dr. Alexander H. Glassman, chief of clinical pharmacology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at New York's Columbia University. ``This seems to show that we can predict who is going to be more addictable to a drug.'' Though people sometimes say they smoke to relieve anxiety and tension, the study failed to find a link between smokers and people who had been diagnosed with phobias or panic disorders. It did find that smoking was four times as common among alcoholics, Glassman said. Researchers analyzed data collected from 3,213 people in the St. Louis metropolitan area in the early 1980s as part of a national psychiatric survey. They found that, among those who smoked, 6.6 percent had suffered depression at one time in their lives and that, among those who didn't smoke, 2.9 percent had suffered depression. The study didn't look into whether depression helps prompt smoking, or vice versa. But Glassman said Tuesday he believes the finding ``implies that people who get depressed are somehow more vulnerable to nicotine ... to drugs.'' A smoker was defined as someone who had smoked daily for at least a month at some point in his life. Major depression was defined as a sad or depressed mood persisting for at least two weeks and including such symptoms as sleep disturbance and eating disorders. The study was done by the New York State Psychiatric Institute, Columbia University, the University of Vermont in Burlington and Washington University in St. Louis. Previous studies have linked cigarette smoking and depressive disorders among people who have sought psychiatric care. This study is the first to analyze the rates from the community at large regardless of whether the subjects had ever sought treatment for depression, the study said. The study found that people with histories of depression had a 14 percent success rate in trying to quit, and those without such problems had a 31 percent success rate. Commenting on the study, University of Chicago psychiatry professor David Tobin said the finding was important in identifying subgroups of smokers who may need a more aggressive treatment to quit. Tobin said many smokers will buy a book or go to a group program for a few sessions but won't seek a specialist's help for the emotional upheaval associated with trying to quit. ``They are taking a very difficult problem and not devoting very many resources in terms of time or money,'' he said. ``And if they are depressed on top of it, they are going to try to give up smoking with all that stacked against them. An unrelated study also published in today's journal said smokers who try to quit with the aid of nicotine gum may render the gum useless by drinking colas, coffee and other beverages. Researchers collected saliva from eight male smokers, having half of them rinse their mouths with water and half with coffee and cola after chewing. They found that rinsing with coffee or cola acidified the saliva and virtually eliminated that amount of nicotine which the body could absorb. The study was done by researchers at the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Baltimore, the Albert B. Chandler Medical Center in Lexington, Ky., and the University of Kentucky in Lexington.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Adopts New Law on Religious Freedoms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with later debate, details on provisions for returning churches, human rights panel, ADDS background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet parliament today adopted a new freedom of religion law, easing decades of strict prohibitions on religious instruction at home and in private schools at a time of widespread religious revival. The new law directs political leaders - who had in the past actively discouraged religious services, confiscated churches, repressed religious groups and preached atheism - not to interfere with religious activities. It allows religious groups to set up ``societies, brotherhoods, associations'' and other fraternal groups and specifies that the government will finance neither religious activities nor ``propaganda of atheism.'' But official tolerance for religion has increased dramatically since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. His mother is a practicing Russian Orthodox and last year he acknowledged that he had been baptized as a child. The law, adopted 341-1 with one abstention, says religious organizations can send people abroad for spiritual study and receive foreign students in the Soviet Union. It calls for the establishment of a panel of religious leaders to advise the government on human rights issues and permits the government to continue returning churches for use as religious buildings. Many churches have fallen into disrepair or been used by the government as storehouses, offices and even factories. The law guarantees the right to study and teach religion either individually or with others. But a clause allowing secular facilities to be used for religious instructions after regular school hours touched off a fierce debate and was defeated by one chamber of the legislature. Lawmaker Genrikh Igityan of Armenia argued that ``every educated person must study religion'' and that comparative world religions should be on every curriculum. But Sergei Ryabchenko from the Ukraine said teaching contradictory religious doctrines in schools could turn his republic into ``another Beirut' because of friction between the Roman Catholic and Russian Orthodox churches. The clause was approved by the Council of the Union but defeated by the Council of Nationalities and will have to be resolved by a joint committee. The number of Christian baptisms and reopening of churches has soared since Gorbachev came to power. The head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Alexi II, has met with the Soviet leadership for the first time in more than 40 years and important religious centers like the Pechorsky Monastery of Kiev have been returned to the church. On Sunday, a Divine Liturgy was held in the Kremlin's Uspensky Cathedral, the first full service allowed in Russia's most important cathedral since 1918. Jews are also enjoying greater religious freedom and a revival of Islam in Central Asia is increasing the number of seminary students and mosques. Scores of religious dissidents of all faiths have been freed from jails and prison camps. Religious leaders, including Alexi II, and representatives of the Seventh-day Adventist Church and the Soviet Jewish community, attended today's parliamentary debate. Alexi, addressing the lawmakers, requested permission to set up a publishing house and use its income to repair broken down churches. The legislature had no immediate response. Alexi, wearing a black clerical robe and white headpiece topped with a gold cross, urged the government not to come between the church and the people. ``The Russian church has already experienced attempts on a political basis to destroy the unity of religious life,'' he said. Donations to religious organizations have been and remain tax-free. The new law, however, cuts the tax rate from 69 percent to 35 percent on the profits of enterprises affiliated with religious groups. One ambiguous area of the new law concerns the military. The law says military commanders cannot interfere with the participation of soldiers in religious services during their free time. But Col. Vilyen Martirosyan, a lawmaker from the Ukraine, asked the legislature whether military commanders now will be able to organize services for religious soldiers. A member of the committee that drafted the law said that issue would have to be worked out in the future.

DOC.HEAD: They Dialed Flat Rock, Got USSR Instead
DOC.TEXT: Flat Rock is only 10 miles north of Monroe, but it's long distance by telephone. And until Michigan Bell Telephone Co. fixed a computer mixup, the distance stretched all the way to the Soviet Union. Michigan Bell on Monday switched the Monroe area, 35 miles south of Detroit, to 11-digit long-distance dialing within the 313 area code. But Monroe callers who didn't dial 313 when trying to reach Flat Rock heard this recording: ``Direct service is available to Moscow only. Calls to other areas of the Soviet Union must be placed through your operator.'' Then there were the Monroe area callers who didn't include 313 when dialing Milan and were told: ``Your international call cannot be completed as dialed. Please check the number and dial again.'' That's Milan, Mich., 15 miles northwest of Monroe, not Milan, Italy. Michigan Bell said the recordings were triggered by computer switching problems that were repaired later Monday. Now, callers who don't dial 313 are told what the phone company meant for them to hear: ``We're sorry, it is necessary to dial an area code when making this call. Please hang up and try your call again.'' And don't forget: Dial the operator for those calls to Vladivostok.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christians Battle in Breach of Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with mortars, tanks and rocket-propelled grenades today in one of the most serious breaches of their cease-fire in four months. Police said a woman was killed and another wounded in the flare-up, which occurred at daybreak between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. Thunderous shell blasts jolted thousands of residents from bed in Beirut's Christian sector. They scurried into basements and underground bomb bunkers in the embattled districts of Sin El-Fil and Nabaa, police said. The fighting tapered into sporadic sniping at midmorning. Police said traffic between the Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital was not affected by the hostilities. Each side blamed the other for the violation of the May 17 cease-fire, which halted 15 weeks of savage fighting between Aoun's 15,000 troops and Geagea's 6,000 militiamen for mastery of the Christian enclave north and northeast of Beirut. By police count, at least 1,045 people were killed and 2,798 wounded in the power struggle. The fighting caused an estimated $1 billion worth of damage and forced about one-third of the enclave's 1 million population to flee to safer areas. Aoun lost his sea outlets in the fighting, and Geagea's men now control 80 percent of the Christian enclave. The area covers 310 square miles of coastal and mountainous territory. Today's battle came amid reports that President Elias Hrawi's government, based in Moslem west Beirut, plans to tighten an economic blockade of the zone controlled by Aoun. Several Beirut newspapers said Hrawi's troops, under Gen. Emile Lahoud, might close all inlets to Aoun's zone to ban food supplies for his army. Fuel supplies and money transfers to Aoun's enclave have been banned by Hrawi's government since mid-July in a bid to force the maverick general into submission. Hrawi, Aoun, Geagea and Lahoud are all Maronite Catholics, the largest Christian sect in Lebanon. It has dominated power in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Aoun has refused to recognize Hrawi, who was elected president by parliament Nov. 24 with a mandate to enforce a peace plan brokered by the Arab League to end 15 years of Moslem-Christian civil war. Hrawi, who is backed by neighboring Syria, Lebanon's main power broker, signed into law Friday a package of constitutional reforms giving the 55 percent Moslem majority of Lebanon's 4 million population an equal share of power for the first time since independence. Hrawi called on Aoun to join the peace process or face a military attack. The general said he would cooperate with Hrawi's government ``only when all Moslems and Christian militias that fought in the civil war, including Geagea's Lebanese Forces, were disbanded.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Accused of Plotting to Kill Parents
DOC.TEXT: A University of Minnesota lab technician has been charged with trying to hire an undercover police officer to murder her parents so she could collect a $2 million inheritance. Heidi Steiro appeared Tuesday before U.S. Magistrate Franklin Noel on a federal charge of trying to hire someone to cross a state line to commit murder. She was held without bail, pending a preliminary hearing and detention hearing today before Noel. The 21-year-old Steiro was arrested Friday by St. Paul police and FBI special agents after meeting the undercover officer at a St. Paul hotel. According to an affidavit filed in court by the FBI, an informant told police Sgt. Thomas Dunaski last week that Steiro had offered him money to kill her parents. The informant said he told Steiro that he would not do it himself but would introduce her to someone who would, and he arranged a meeting with Dunaski. At the hotel, Steiro told the undercover officer where her parents lived in Boulder Junction, Wis., and what time they usually go to bed. Steiro told the undercover officer she would pay him $45,000 to kill Richard and Gloria Steiro. She then paid him $1,000 to cover expenses, the affidavit said. As a final precaution, she telephoned her parents to be sure they would be home over the weekend, according to the affidavit. During the meeting with Dunaski, Steiro referred to her parents as her stepparents or adoptive parents, the affidavit said. After her arrest, she acknowledged that they are her natural parents. ``Steiro stated she wanted her stepfather killed because she would inherit about $2 million and because she hates him,'' the affidavit said. Richard Steiro said the charge against his daughter was ``kind of a sad thing. We'll leave it up to the authorities.'' He declined to comment further. He is a former boat dealer in Boulder Junction, which is near the border of Michigan's Upper Peninsula. His wife is a waitress at a local restaurant. They also own a resort in northern Wisconsin. Authorities described Steiro as a former pre-dental student at the university's College of Liberal Arts and a member of the university marching band.

DOC.HEAD: Durable Goods Orders Down 0.8 Percent in August
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for ``big-ticket'' durable goods dropped 0.8 percent in August, continuing the flat performance that has gone on for 18 months, the government said today. The Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods - items expected to last more than three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $127 billion following a revised 2.7 percent gain in July. But excluding defense and transportation, overall orders would have fallen even steeper. Without either category, orders would have dropped 1.6 percent, the department said. Many analysts had expected the overall decline in orders, which have zigzagged throughout the year - up during three months and down for four including a 10.5 percent plunge in January. Durable goods orders are a key economic barometer of manufacturing industry plans for production. A decrease in orders could result in a slump in that sector and subsequent layoffs. In fact, the Labor Department reported earlier that 45,000 factory jobs were lost in August. It was the 16th time out of 17 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post-recession peak in January 1989, the manufacturing sector has lost 455,000 jobs, Labor said. Orders in the key category of non-defense capital goods, often a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize, plunged 11.2 percent to $35.4 billion after gaining 10.1 percent in July. But excluding aircraft orders, the drop would have been only 4.4 percent. The pattern of orders in August was mixed. Both electrical machinery and transportation categories posted gains while non-electrical machinery and primary metals orders fell. Orders for transportation equipment rose 1.3 percent to $35.2 billion, mostly for motor vehicles. Aircraft orders fell about $3 billion. Transportation orders jumped 4.5 percent in July. Electrical machinery orders advanced 2.6 percent to $20.8 billion following a 1.5 percent gain a month earlier.. But non-electrical machinery orders fell 6.1 percent to $21.2 billion after gaining 3.5 percent in July. And orders for primary metals slipped 1.7 percent to $11.6 billion after rising 2.8 percent the previous month. The often-volatile defense category jumped 12.4 percent to $8.4 billion, following a 5.6 percent decline in July. Shipments of durable goods rose 2.9 percent to $128.7 billion in August, most of which was motor vehicles. Shipments had fallen 1.8 percent in July. Unfilled orders edged down 0.3 percent to $499.3 billon after gaining 0.6 percent a month earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Riots Against Job Quotas Across Northern India; Singh Offers To Talk
DOC.TEXT: Student riots against new government job quotas for lower caste groups today spread across northern India, leaving at least five people dead. Prime Minister V.P. Singh offered to meet students, hoping to end the unrest, but authorities also tightened security in New Delhi, mobilized troops and imposed curfews in four other cities. In a continuing wave of protest suicides, a student doused himself with gasoline near New Delhi's police headquarters and lit a match, inflicting burns over half his body before he was taken to hospital. The students, mostly upper caste, believe they will lose coveted civil service positions to less qualified Indians of lower castes, for whom the Singh government has established an affirmative action program reserving nearly half the jobs for them. Three people were killed and 25 wounded by police gunfire near Meerut, 55 miles west of New Delhi, police told United News of India. Two more people were killed in clashes with police in Jammu, 240 miles north of the capital. Residents and housewives in New Delhi joined students in the streets of middle-class neighborhoods in confronting police and shouting anti-government slogans. ``Go ahead students,'' some middle-aged women chanted. ``We are with you.'' One 80-year-old woman was trampled and injured in a stampede when police fired tear gas and charged into a crowd of 2,000 people with bamboo riot sticks, witnesses said. Major roads in the city of 8 million people were blocked by police or by makeshift stone barricades erected by the students. The state-owned Delhi Transport Company ordered its 4,000 buses off the roads after losing dozens of vehicles to arson and stoning. Tourists were told all Delhi tours were canceled, and tours to the Taj Mahal had to leave the city by 5 a.m. before the troubles begin. The trouble has been simmering since Singh announced the quotas Aug. 7. But tensions exploded following the death Tuesday of a youth who set himself ablaze with gasoline in front of thousands of witnesses the previous day. New Delhi witnessed the worst violence since the anti-Sikh riots of 1984 in the wake of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's assassination. Two students died from police gunfire on Tuesday. Another student consumed a fatal dose of poison Tuesday in the city of Hissar, 80 miles east of New Delhi. It brought to four the number of students who have killed themselves by self-immolation or poison in the last week.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Urges Worldwide Protests Against U.S. Forces in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iran has called on Moslems around the world to stage anti-American demonstrations on Friday to protest the presence of the U.S.-led multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. The Islamic Propagation Organization said in a statement that Moslems worldwide should protest ``the filthy presence of alien troops in the Persian Gulf'' and Saudi Arabia, Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency reported today. Iran has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But it has deplored the deployment of U.S. forces to prevent a possible Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia and to enforce a U.N.-imposed economic embargo on Baghdad. The Iranians have been particularly angered at the presence of non-Moslem forces in Saudi Arabia, home to Mecca and Medina, Islam's holiest shrines. ``Would wolves guard the sheep?'' the statement asked, according to the IRNA report, which was monitored in Nicosia. ``Oh Moslems, is it not the time to awake from slumber?'' it asked. IRNA quoted the radical newspaper Jomhuri Islami as saying demonstrations will celebrate Iraq's ``capitulation'' in a recent peace treaty with Iran. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, facing the embargo and the U.S.-led forces, suddenly made peace with Iran last month, formally ending the 1980-88 war and two years of deadlocked peace talks. There will also be jubilation that ``Iraq, which was armed to the teeth by Western countries, has now become a threat to the West and deploys these same armaments against the West and those like Kuwait which financed Iraq's war against Iran,'' Jomhuri Islami said. ``Next Friday the whole country will be filled with the shouts of `Death to America,' proving to the world that in the eyes of the Moslem nation of Iran the United States is the main party responsible for the imposition of war on Iran,'' the paper said. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, considered a pragmatist, is believed to want to end more than a decade of anti-Western sentiments in Iran to attract investment and technology for the country's postwar economy. The protest call is seen as a show of defiance by his vehemently anti-American radicals rivals.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Loses Uncle's Remains
DOC.TEXT: Somewhere between Florida and Pennsylvania, the cremated remains of a man entrusted to the U.S. Postal Service have disappeared. Adelaide Findlay says the urn holding the ashes of her uncle, Earl H. Miller, 94, was mailed to her on July 16 by officials of the Fairchild Funeral Home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The insured package never showed up in Birdsboro, a town of 3,500 about 10 miles southeast of Reading. Miller died July 10 in Pompano Beach, Fla. ``It's been hectic and has worn on my health,'' Ms. Findlay said. ``I'm afraid that waiting for the ashes to arrive is a lost cause. And, I'm not going to sue because that would only upset me more.'' Ms. Findley had planned to inter the remains of her uncle in a plot near his wife, Amelia R. Miller, who died in 1971. But for now, the grave remains empty. ``The last several months of his life were hectic for him. And even in death, it's hectic for him,'' Ms. Findlay said. The funeral home has filed a claim with the Postal Service to begin tracing the package. ``Once they file a claim, the trace would start at the post office branch it was mailed from, and we would check both states' dead-letter branches,'' said Tina Carmody of the Fort Lauderdale post office.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Chief Suggests Long Stay, Shift To Offense If Attacked
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines at ``the tip of the spear'' defending Saudi oilfields were told by their boss today to expect a long desert stay. ``I don't want to hear about any more questions about how long you're going to be here,'' Commandant Gen. Alfred Gray told Marines at a combat support camp in the northern Saudi desert near the main highways to the country's major oil installations. He also said the Marines should be prepared to shift to offense if the kingdom is attacked. Gray, speaking to reporters after his 45-minute pep talk, said he was confident the multinational force in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region could stop any Iraqi offensive. But he refused to say whether the U.S.-led forces were capable of pushing Iraq out of Kuwait, saying the question was speculative. During his speech to the men, Gray said: ``We have a very, very powerful, flexible and most useful force, afloat and ashore, ready to do whatever needs to be done. We're going to play for keeps if that is required.'' For now, he said, the mission was defensive and 13 ships were headed to the region with supplies needed to sustain the Marine force. But should hostilities break out, Gray said: ``We all know the best defense is a good offense.'' Gray's pep talk, delivered through a bullhorn, was full of praise for the Marines, but equally rich with reminders that their stay in the desert is unlikely to end soon. ``How long are we going to be here?'' he asked rhetorically. ``Well, we're going to be here until we get done what has to be done.'' He then essentially ordered the troops not to complain. ``There will be no morale problem ... because I say there will be morale. There will also be no boredom.'' Gray said that under normal circumstances Marines are deployed for six months and then brought home for 15 to 18 months. ``It would make sense if we could hold to that as best we can,'' Gray told reporters. ``But we may not b able to because we have, as I tried to indicate, enormous global commitments. I think they understand that.'' Another complication would be the need to coordinate with the Navy to make sure enough ships were available to make the personnel changes, he said. ``I'm well aware there comes a point when you need a change of scenery,'' he said, suggesting that change could come within Saudi Arabia. ``Let your commandant worry about that.'' Gray reminded the Marines to be on guard against possible terrorist attacks, saying: ``Marines are always the No. 1 target in this part of the world for terrorist attack.'' ``You're the tip of the spear,'' he said. Gray said he believed the American deployment had persuaded Iraqi President Saddam Hussein not to continue into Saudi Arabia after taking Kuwait Aug.2. ``I believe that Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi military fully intended to invade this region of Saudi Arabia,'' he declared. ``They didn't. They've been stopped. ... You've won a big one already and you haven't had to fire a shot.''

DOC.HEAD: Family, Peers Remember Former U.S. Senator
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Sen. John A. Danaher, who died Saturday, was remembered by his family and friends as a fair-minded federal judge, an outspoken senator and a beloved family man. ``His mind was so wide and awesome that I could never reach deep enough to grasp it,'' granddaughter Ann Danaher Connelly told more than 150 family members and friends gathered for funeral services Tuesday at the Church of St. Peter Claver. The former senator and federal appeals court judge died Saturday at age 91 at a convalescent home in West Hartford. A spokesman for the family said he died of complications stemming from a broken hip. During the Catholic service, Monsignor John S. Kennedy said Danaher's career was ``distinguishing and garlanded with the tributes of his peers.'' Born to a prominent political family in Meriden in 1899, Danaher graduated from Yale University and Yale School of Law. From 1921 to 1933, he was an assistant U.S. attorney. In 1935, he was elected Connecticut's secretary of state. He was a Republican U.S. senator for Connecticut from 1939 to 1945. After leaving office, he practiced law with his own firm in Washington, Danaher, Fahey and Poole, before being appointed to the U.S. Court of Appeals in 1954. He retired in 1983. Danaher was prominently mentioned as a potential nominee to the U.S. Supreme Court in 1956 and 1957 when President Eisenhower nominated William J. Brennan Jr. and Charles E. Whittaker to the court. Survivors include Danaher's wife of 69 years, Dorothy King Danaher; two sons, John A. Danaher Jr. of Groton, and Robert C. Danaher of West Hartford; his daughter, Jeanne D. Lennhoff of West Hartford; 13 grandchildren; and 15 great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Hispanics Seeking United Voice in 1992
Retransmitting a0448 to correct category code.
DOC.TEXT: Hispanic leaders are planning ways to present a united political voice in the 1992 presidential election. About 100 Hispanic leaders met Tuesday and resolved not to let divisions within the community sap their political strength, as some say occurred during the presidential campaign two years ago. Led by former San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros; Bronx, N.Y., Borough President Fernando Ferrer; and Denver Mayor Federico Pena, the leaders adopted a blueprint for 1992 and took stands on five pressing Hispanic issues. The leaders plan to establish the National Hispanic Agenda as an organization that can speak on political issues all Hispanics share. ``It represents an attempt to speak with one voice across the differences that divide the Hispanic community - Cubans, Puerto Ricans, Mexicans, Republicans, Democrats, New Yorkers, Floridians, Texans, Californians,'' Cisneros said. As a first step, the leaders urged an adjustment of the 1990 census that appears to have undercounted minorities. They also pressed for passage of the civil rights bill and repeal of the employer sanctions provision in the 1986 immigration law. ``The Hispanic subgroups are now agreeing and supporting issues in a real call for unity,'' said Robert Calderin, director of a conference of New York legislators called Somos Uno, Spanish for ``We Are One.'' ``It's the first time we have had a cohesive group of people working together,'' said David Pena, a Miami attorney who attended the meeting on behalf of the Hispanic National Bar Association. ``Our hope is to develop a shared agenda and be united,'' said Cecilia Munoz of the National Council of La Raza, a Washington-based research and advocacy group. Hispanic leaders want to make sure their political potential is not squandered in 1992, Cisneros said. ``This is the starting of a process that leads to a 1992 policy statement that is useful in the presidential election ... and that has come from a deliberate and systematic dialogue with community organizations all around the country,'' he said. At 21 million, Hispanics comprise the fastest-growing minority group in the country. Demographers estimate Hispanics ill become the largest minority population sometime this decade. The 100 Hispanic leaders at the National Hispanic Agenda meeting represented Republicans and Democrats and groups as varied as the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and the U.S. Catholic Conference. The leaders praised President Bush's executive order, signed Monday, setting up an advisory committee to develop ways to improve education of Hispanics. But they said Bush should make sure young Spanish-speaking children are able to learn in their native language. The leaders also urged Congress to pass legislation giving a statehood plebiscite, or vote, to Puerto Rico and allow Puerto Ricans in the continental United States to participate. Polls indicate a slight majority of Puerto Ricans favor statehood. Bush, who backs statehood for Puerto Rico, has urged Congress to pass legislation mandating that whatever Puerto Ricans decide be implemented by 1993. A bill allowing the plebiscite is pending on the House floor, but a similar Senate measure is mired in committee.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Blasts Soviets on Gulf Stance
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq bitterly attacked its former ally the Soviet Union today and said Arabs would not be friendly toward a country in ``the alliance of American hostility.'' The tirade by the official Iraqi News Agency was in response to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardadze's speech Tuesday to the United Nations. The news agency claimed the Soviets were bribed to make the comments. In another development, Baghdad radio broadcast President Saddam Hussein's message to the American people, parts of which were aired on U.S. television on Tuesday night. Also, officials announced there will be more food rationing starting this weekend because of the U.N. trade embargo imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Trade and Finance Minister Mohammed Mahdi Saleh said the rationing will include rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar and tea. ``In a tone that clearly shows the bribe given by American and its allies the oil sheiks, USSR Foreign Minister Shevardnadze spoke from the United Nations forum in a threatening voice,'' the Iraqi News Agency said. ``We tell Shevardnadze, if you are not concerned about the relations of friendship with the Arabs and want to be dragged into the alliance of American hostility, then the Arabs will not be concerned about the likes of you.'' Shevardnadze, who sits at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's right hand in the Soviet power structure, criticized Saddam as a terrorist threatening the world order and suggested his seizure of Kuwait might call for a war crimes trial. The Soviet minister also raised the prospect of U.N. military force against Iraq if economic sanctions fail to force Saddam to give up Kuwait. ``The United Nations has the power to suppress acts of aggression,'' Shevardnadze said in his speech at the United Nations. During the Cold War standoff between the United States and the Soviet Union, Iraq was a chief Middle East ally of Moscow, which was the main arms supplier to Saddam Hussein's military. The Soviet Union announced it would stop supplying arms to Baghdad after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, but at first was hesitant to back economic sanctions against Iraq. Gorbachev and President Bush agreed two weeks ago in Helsinki, Finland, that additional measures might be required. One result was the U.N. air embargo approved by the Security Council on Tuesday. Baghdad radio denounced the air embargo today and said it was imposed ``on the directives of the hostile policy'' of Bush. Saddam's message to the American people defended the invasion of Kuwait and said it was not without warning. The 75-minute message was featured on newscasts from Baghdad and was to be broadcast on Iraqi television tonight, the Iraqi News Agency said. ``Kuwait constitutes the southern part of Iraq, which was severed by the British in 1913, in preparation for the first world war,'' he said. ``The rulers of Kuwait exploited our preoccupation with the war between us and Iran to expand further at our expense, by using our southern oilfields to acquire new oil wells from which to funnel additional oil for their benefit. ``No warning, however repeatedly stated, could deter them from that course of action,'' Saddam said. Saddam's message was delivered in Washington on Tuesday. Excerpts were aired on the major American networks, and the Cable News Network decided to show the entire message early today.

DOC.HEAD: Three Senators Say They'll Vote Against Souter
DOC.TEXT: Three Eastern liberal senators today announced they will vote against confirming the nomination of Judge David Souter to the Supreme Court, based on his failure to endorse the right to abortion. ``The right of privacy is a basic promise of American life,'' said Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J. ``We should not entrust it to a jurist who cannot agree whether it exists or to whom it applies.'' Bradley was joined by New Jersey Democratic colleague Frank Lautenberg and Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., one of two women in the Senate. Mikulski said that because Souter refused to state his position on abortion, ``we must fear the worst.'' The announcements brought to only four the number of senators to publicly oppose President Bush's nominee. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., on Monday became the first senator to say he would vote against Souter. The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to vote Thursday. No members of that panel have said they will oppose Souter and seven of its 14 members have said they will vote in favor. The nominee, a 51-year-old New Hampshire jurist, also picked up more support today from senators not on the committee. Sens. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., and Terry Sanford, D-N.C., said they favored Souter.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Pay Per Pizza, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0515,0296
DOC.HEAD: Teens Charged To Enter Pizza Hut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to CORRECT that assistant manager started the policy and has left Pizza Hut. Picks up 6th graf pvs: ``There are . . .'
DOC.TEXT: An assistant restaurant manager fed up with hordes of teen-agers at her Pizza Hut locked the doors and collected $1 each from youths unaccompanied by adults, but the national chain ended the policy. Susan Gamlin, manager of the Pizza Hut in Baden, about 15 miles northwest of Pittsburgh, said her assistant instituted the cover charge because unruly teens were disrupting the eatery after football games and high school dances. ``We didn't think a dollar was too much to ask from kids who destroy our dining room every Friday night,'' Ms. Gamlin said. ``The kids dump the salt and pepper shakers, only order bread sticks and water, try to bring in food from McDonald's, don't wait to be seated and then complain about not having a waitress.'' She declined to name the assistant, who no longer works at the restaurant. She would not say whether his departure was related to the incident. Roger Rydell, a spokesman at the chain's Wichita, Kan., headquarters, said it was wrong to collect the fee. ``There are no cover charges at Pizza Hut,'' he said. ``And there won't be any locked doors until we close for business for good.'' Judy Campbell, whose son, Brian, was one of the youths who paid the fee Friday night, said she was ``very upset.'' ``The kids in this area have no place else to go,'' she said. Baden Borough Secretary Sue Blum said she contacted Fire Chief Gene Miketa about parents' complaints. Police Chief Frank Tavern also was investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Some British Women Held Since Invasion Evacuated From Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The last three female crew members of a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait during the Iraqi invasion left for home today along with eight other British women and children evacuated from Iraq. They were among 185 people who arrived in Amman aboard a regular Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad. The 11 Britons left about two hours later on a commercial flight to London. One young woman sobbed uncontrollably when she got off the flight from Iraq and had to be supported by two unidentified British officials as she walked to the airport VIP lounge to await the flight to London. ``You can tell the world we are very worried,'' one of the women told reporters as she wheeled a stroller toward the gate for the flight to Britain. None of the women would talk with reporters about their ordeal in Kuwait or Iraq. However, a British Airways official, who declined to be identified, said the three flight attendants had been held at a camp in Iraq. He said they were driven to the airport in Kuwait by Iraqi authorities for a flight to Baghdad. The British Airways crew members were on a stopover in Kuwait when Iraq invaded Aug. 2. It was not immediately clear why the three flight attendants had not been evacuated earlier. Some of their fellow flight attendants were aboard a special evacuation flight that left Baghdad for Paris, London and Washington on Aug. 31. Two of them told reporters at Baghdad that they had been held along with about 20 other people at a potential military target in Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said that foreign women and children are free to leave Iraq. Western men, however, are being held captive in the country as hostages against a possible American attack. Iraqi officials say some of the Western men have been moved to potential military targets around the country. Western diplomats in Baghdad say they do not know how many people are being held hostage.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Prime Minister Says His Forces Should Keep Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen today rejected a compromise peace proposal from the guerrilla coalition battling his government and said his forces should keep fighting, state radio reported. The proposal Hun Sen rejected concerns the formation of the Supreme National Council that will help guide Cambodia through new elections under a plan approved by the United Nations. Hun Sen turned down a proposal that guerrilla leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk join the council as chairman in exchange for another seat for Hun Sen's government, saying his side also should be given the council vice chairmanship. That ruined hopes that the council would resume meetings soon. The council now has 12 representatives from the warring factions. ``We should continue the fight,'' Hun Sen said, according to a Cambodian radio broadcast monitored in Bangkok. ``The enemies do not yet have the good will to end the war and to support a cease-fire.'' The report said Hun Sen made the comments in a speech to a ``mass meeting'' in front of Phnom Penh's former royal palace. His Vietnamese-installed government is fighting an 11-year-old war against the coalition of three guerrilla groups - the forces of Sihanouk, the Khmer People's National Lieration Front of former Premier Son Sann, and the Khmer Rouge, led by Khieu Samphan. Both sides say they accept the U.N. peace plan, under which the United Nations would administer the country until elecions are held. On Sept. 10, six government members and six guerrilla members formed the Supreme National Council. But its first meeting, held last week in Bangkok, collapsed in bickering over the role of Sihanouk. The guerrillas said the former head of state must chair the council because he is widely considered the central figure in any settlement. On Friday, Sihanouk urged his guerrilla allies to offer Phnom Penh another council seat if Sihanouk joined as chairman. The guerrilla groups formally agreed to that in a meeting Sunday and said they wanted a second meeting of the council as soon as possible. Hun Sen said today he could agree to the proposal only if his government received the seat of vice chairman. Both sides have said the next meeting should decide the chairmanship, appoint a delegation to take Cambodia's seat at the United Nations and then work on other issues including stopping fighting. The United Nations seat is held by the guerrillas, but they are ready to transfer it to the council. The deadline for the presentation of the new credentials is Oct. 18. Sihanouk, who has stayed at his Beijing home during recent negotiations, says he will attend the council meeting after he is elected chairman, spokesmen in his office said.
