Thailand was annoyed by the failure of the first council meeting, and said it will host another meeting only if it is clear beforehand there will be agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Jokes, Stealth Helped McDonald's Hostages Through Ordeal
DOC.TEXT: One worker told jokes; another spied on a gunman from behind an ice machine. After seven hours, they were among 20 people to emerge unhurt from a McDonald's restaurant that had been under seige. The incident began about 5:30 p.m. Monday as assistant manager Ramiro Gironas served up two Big Macs, some french fries and a soft drink to a man with tattooed arms. ``Just like a regular customer,'' Gironas said Tuesday. ``He stood in line and waited to be helped, just like everyone else.'' Police allege the man, Douglas Eric Girard, 32, held 20 people hostage inside the restaurant before he was subdued by sheriff's deputies shortly after midnight Monday. Girard and Frank M. Teresi, 38, allegedly had robbed a nearby Kids' Mart clothing store of $200, police said. Both were booked for investigation of armed robbery and false imprisonment, authorities said. Bail for Girard was set at $500,000. Teresi, already on parole for robbery and being under the influence of a narcotic, was placed on a no-bail parole hold, said police Sgt. John Ortega. As the man gave Gironas change for his food, other McDonald's cashiers spotted a .38-caliber revolver tucked in his back pocket, Gironas recalled. Someone noticed wads of bills in his socks, he said. ``He's got a gun!'' a cashier yelled. Customers dove under tables or fled the restaurant, authorities said. Eleven employees and one customer hid in the basement, and authorities said Girard forced the remaining eight people to lie on the floor. Gironas, 21, herded employees to the back of the restaurant, then sought refuge beside a half-ton ice machine and dialed police. The native of Cochabamba, Bolivia, only recently learned English but reported the gunman's every move to officers. ``All I knew was to take care of my people, my crew,'' Gironas said. ``I'm glad I'm safe and that all my people are safe. . . . I just did what I had to.'' The gunman paced the restaurant, smoking a cigarette and peering out windows, said police Lt. Ron Ingels. He apparently kept the pistol inside a waistband and made no threats, Ingels said. Downstairs, assistant manager Anis Hussain, 25, tried some comedy on his fellow hostages. Hussain, who occasionally crept upstairs to check on the situation, said he hoped his jokes would relieve the stress. ``I was just trying to comfort them and to convince them that everything was going to be fine,'' he said. He added that he drew some chuckles. Both employees said they were spotted by the gunman, but that he never bothered them. ``Clearly, he could see us,'' Hussain said. At 11:30 p.m., special weapons officers urged Gironas by telephone to have the group in the basement leave through an emergency door. Once they were out, SWAT officers, each having studied restaurant floor plans, crept into the restaurant unseen by the gunman, authorities said. Deputies lobbed ``flash-bang'' grenades to disorient the man, and Deputy Jim Harrell leaped over a counter and wrestled the gunman to the ground. Not a shot was fired. ``This is what we train for,'' said Harrell. ``Scared isn't the right word for it. You're just really hyped up. Your senses are really keen.'' Police said they found a .38-caliber revolver stashed in a bathroom. McDonald's officials said the restaurant opened for business as usual at 6 a.m. Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Briefly Banned Book To Top Times' List
DOC.TEXT: The book whose distribution Israel's government tried to stop will be listed as the No. 1 non-fiction best seller in The New York Times' Book Review list of Oct. 7. The list reflects sales for the week ending Sept. 22, the Times said today. The previous week a judge had temporarily barred the book's distribution, but an appeals court struck down his order two days later. The book, ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer,'' written a one-time Mossad employee, Victor Ostrovsky, purports to reveal secrets of the Israeli intelligence agency. Israel had maintained the book's publication would endanger the lives of some of its agents. Bookstores were swamped with requests for the book when it went on sale Sept. 13. It has become the fastest-selling title of its U.S. publisher, St. Martin's Press, which so far has printed 325,000 copies. A ban against distribution of the book in Canada, where Ostrovsky lives, was dropped in Toronto a few days after the New York court action.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan: Will Abide by Air Embargo Against Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Jordan said today it would abide by a U.N. Security Council order to cut off air traffic in and out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. But it permitted an Iraqi Airways flight to land. The regularly scheduled flight from Baghdad carried 185 people, and it was not immediately clear what its cargo hold contained. But Jordanian officials said an initial check of the U.N. resolution indicated the arrival was not a violation of the air embargo. ``The embargo is on cargo shipments only and not passengers,'' said one Jordanian Cabinet minister, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``According to our initial studying of the resolution, we understand that it does not bar human traffic.'' The Security Council voted 14-1 Tuesday to prohibit air traffic with Iraq and Kuwait. Cuba cast the only vote against the resolution. The resolution does not mention passenger planes but says that all planes traveling to and from Iraq should be checked to make sure they are not carrying cargo prohibited by the U.N. trade sanctions. The resolution prohibits the use of force to stop planes, but allows for the detention of aircraft. Under certain conditions, the council permitted humanitarian cargo, including food and medical supplies. An unidentified Jordanian Transport Ministry official was quoted by the state news agency Petra as saying: ``The civil aviation authority and concerned government departments will implement this resolution.'' The resolution also called on all member states to bar flights from their territory to those nations, and deny landing rights to planes coming from Iraq or Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: almost unassailable.
DOC.TEXT: Sept. 21 The Daily Record, Morristown, N.J., on political trust: The Times Mirror survey, ``The People, the Press and Politics 1990,'' ... provides some sobering news - and perhaps an ominous portent - for politicians of every political stripe. The survey charts a continuing erosion of trust and confidence in our two major political parties, a deepening cynicism and economic polarization that ``threatens to subvert traditional partisan politics or block the effective resolution of social and economic issues.'' Respondents to the survey characterized Democrats as incapable of governing effectively, and the Republicans as a political instrument of the rich and powerful. A pox on both houses. What is the impact of all this? Well, one effect has been obvious for years. People have stopped voting. Eligible voters show their cynicism by staying away from the polls. More and more people are being elected by fewer and fewer Americans. Those who do vote re-elect incumbents virtually across the board. People who have really had enough may be more inclined to vote against any and all incumbents regardless of their political stripe. That's what the Times Mirror survey is saying they might do - if they vote at all. --- Sept. 21 Statesman Journal, Salem, Ore., on the budget: The droning noise coming out of Washington, D.C.'s budget negotiations may put the public to sleep, but we'll wake up with a jolt when we see what Congress' inaction has done to us. Unless Congress and the president act before Oct. 1 on a new budget that meets Gramm-Rudman deficit-cutting goals, automatic cuts of about $100 billion will cause layoffs and massive cuts in programs that no one wants to cut. That's when we'll wake up and ask our senators and representatives why we must endure inaction at a time of fiscal crisis in our country. They will reply that no one wants to approve tax increases and cut budgets so close to an election. We reply that if you don't do something, we'll vote you out of office, not for what you did but for what you didn't do. --- Sept. 23 The Sun Herald, Gulfport, Miss., on the budget: The indecisiveness of congressional leaders fumbling around with the federal budget may be the highest form of power politics in Washington, but outside the beltway, it is inflicting cruel economic pain and mental anguish on the federal workers who keep the government running. The victims of this shabby treatment include thousands of government employees. If they were working for a private employer who treated them that way even one time, let alone year after year for a decade or more, those same congressional leaders would be calling televised hearings and passing laws to punish the offending companies. But because it is Congress itself that is causing the misery, there'll be no hearings, no laws, no alphabet agency given the task of assuring no repetitions of the employee mistreatment. ... But Congress has been working on the task since last January, when President Bush released his budget proposal. After eight months, Congress doesn't seem much closer to agreement than when it started. Little time remains before the Oct. 1 deadline for tee Gramm-Rudman automatic cuts to kick in. Negotiators must reach a deal and Congress must ratify it or Gramm-Rudman will mandate cuts of up to 40 percent in domestic and military programs. To prepare for that contingency, the government is planning to furlough employees, that is, put them on unpaid leave. The silver lining in this dark fiscal cloud is the high probability that Congress will not allow the Gramm-Rudman cuts to happen. The members can't stand the political heat. At the last minute, they will find some way ... to keep government operating and avoid the wrath of mistreated employees. ... The saddest part is that voters will undoubtedly re-elect most of those so-called leaders who will, in all likelihood, repeat the sordid performance next year. --- Sept. 22 Shawano (Wis.) Evening Leader on females in the military: If Iraqi troops attack U.S. forces situated in the Saudi Arabian desert, women may be among the first casualties. Although regulations prohibit females from combat, the U.S. forces sent to the Middle East as part of Operation Desert Shield include many women. ... In the Saudi desert, U.S. women are repairing communications, arming attack planes and operating supply lines. Those areas are deemed safe by the military brass. But if the Iraqis would strike against the U.S. troops, those areas probably would be the first to be hit. The uncertain future of the Gulf Crisis has not frazzled the females who are temporarily stationed in the Middle East. Both women and men serve together in the different branches of the U.S. Armed Forces, and the females have noted they want to be treated as equals. ... Policies for military women must be adjusted to meet those changes in the U.S. Armed Forces. If a woman wants to serve and is trained to do so, her superiors should be allowed to use her without a second thought. If females are going to be recruited, trained and sent to a crisis situation, it seems foolish to protect them from injury while male troops are allowed to fight. ``We get paid the same,'' noted a female Army lieutenant who was deployed as part ofestment firm Capital Insight, said trading was volatile, with bonds buffetted by rumors on subjects ranging from the Middle East crisis to the budget deficit stalemate. He said bonds picked up support from Tuesday's rebound in the dollar. The overnight selloff on the Tokyo stock market steered investors into U.S. dollar-denominated holdings, including government bonds, he said. ``The market is just jittery about the Middle East and the budget,'' he said. ``There are a lot of rumors, no facts this morning except the durable goods number which I'm not sure anyone cared about.'' Two Commerce Department reports released today confirmed that the economy lacks vigor. The report on durable goods showed orders to U.S. factories for long-lasting, generally expensive items dropped 0.8 percent in August. Separately, the department reported U.S. personal incomes rose just 0.3 percent in August, the slowest pace in four months, while consumer spending rose 0.5 percent, the lowest in three months. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term issues and intermediate maturities ranged from 1-32 point lower to 1-32 point higher. Long-term issues were unchanged to up 1-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was up 0.39 to 1,136.45 by late morning. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.58 percent as the discount edged 1 basis point lower to 7.35 percent. Yields six-month bills edged down to 7.77 percent as the discount dipped 1 basis point to 7.39 percent. Yields on one-year bills were unchanged at 7.85 percent as the discount remained steady at 7.32 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest banks charge one another for overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Prospective Juror Excused Because She Saw Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with jury selection resuming today. Edits to conform and deletes outdated grafs. Picks up 15th graf pvs: `He asked . . .'
DOC.TEXT: A defense attorney described Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photos in detail to gauge the reactions of prospective jurors at the nation's first obscenity trial of an art gallery and its director. The Contemporary Ars Center and director Dennis Barrie are charged with obscenity and displaying nude photos of children at a Mapplethorpe exhibit. Defense lawyers today rejected a prospective juror as jury selection moved into the third day. Marc Mezibov, the gallery's lawyer, used a peremptory challenge to remove a retiree, who he said was not adequately familiar with the community's contemporary social standards. Eight jurors and two alternates are being sought. On Tuesday, prosecutors used one of their peremptory challenges to dismiss a prospective juror who viewed the Mapplethorpe photo exhibit. Prosecutor Frank Prouty sought to have the prospective juror removed ``for cause.'' Each side is allowed six peremptory removals for which they need to give no reason, and an unlimited number of challenges for cause, in which they must convince a judge that the juror is unbiased. Seven of the 175 photos from the exhibit are the basis for the criminal charges. One photo shows a man urinating into another man's mouth. Others show anal penetration with objects and other homosexual or sadomasochistic images. After describing the seven photographs in detail, lawyer H. Louis Sirkin asked several prospective jurors, ``Are you willing to see those photographs before making a decision as to whether any of them is obscene?'' All answered that they were. Sirkin said later that he didn't describe the photographs for shock value, although he was interested in seeing the potential jurors' reaction. He did not say what he believed the reactions were. ``The jury is entitled to know what the photographs show,'' Sirkin said. ``If they're going to see them, they have a right to know what's in them.'' The American Civil Liberties Union and the Association of Art Museum Directors have said this is the nation's first obscenity prosecution they know of involving an art gallery. If convicted, Barrie, 43, could get a year in jail and a fine of $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000. The Mapplethope exhibit, now concluding a national tour in Boston, drew more than 80,000 viewers during its seven-week Cincinnati exhibition ending in May. The artist died of AIDS last year. Mezibov tried to determine whether potential jurors had opinions about the role of an art museum and the types of photographs that should be allowed to be exhibited. He asked if they would be willing to listen to opinions from art experts from outside Cincinnati, particularly regarding sexually graphic photographs. ``Yes, but I have the right to accept or reject those opinions,'' one man said. Mezibov asked another prospective juror if there should be laws governing what adults are allowed to say. ``I've never seen anything I thought there should be a law against,'' the woman said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Auto Workers Set Strike Deadline
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Auto Workers union today set an Oct. 10 strike deadline for reaching a new labor agreement with General Motors Corp.'s Cnadian subsidiary. The Canadian Auto Workers members last weekend ratified a new contract with Ford of Canada after a six-day strike by about 12,800 workers. It's expected the union will use that contract as a pattern for negotiations with General Motors of Canada Ltd., which has about 36,000 workers covered by the Canadian Auto Workers national contract. Union President Bob White said today that a strike next month at GM's 12 facilities in Canada is possibile. ``We should not fall into a false sense of security,'' White said. GM has said it wants to shut its Scarborough, Ontario, van assembly plant next year and cut 700 jobs from its Windsor, Ontario, trim plant. White said negotiations with GM would focus on saving jobs from those two factories. ``The agreement reached at Ford is an expensive proposition,'' said Rick Curd, vice president of personnel for GM of Canada. The company, he added today, wants improvements in cost-competitiveness, workplace flexibility and worker attendance. In the United States, meanwhile, United Auto Workers union members at GM plants today continued voting on a proposed three-year agreement reached Sept. 17. That pact appeared headed to an overwhelming ratification margin. Voting should be completed by Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: economic assistance?
DOC.TEXT: Sept. 20 Straits Times, Singapore, on U.S. military cutbacks: While the dwindling imperatives of the Soviet threat and the escalating imperatives of a financial crunch do make a reduction of Washington's foreign military commitments inevitable, many Asian countries are worried over how America retreats. They hope that U.S. policy-makers, keeping these fears in mind, will find mechanisms to ensure that their country's shrinking global reach does not trigger off instability in Pacific Asia. Given the fact that an eventual U.S. withdrawal from Clark and Subic Bay appears, in the absence of dramatic geopolitical changes, to be a fait accompli, the question must be whether alternative forms of presence are possible that preserve America's stake in the region. A more limited, perhaps rotational, presence in the Philippines could be one answer; a shift to other permanent bases in Pacific Asia that facilitate the rapid deployment of U.S. forces could be another. Guam and, conceivably, New Zealand are candidates for such a role. Singapore's and Brunei's offer of facilities to the U.S. military, while a contribution to retaining American interest in regional stability, cannot make up for the loss of the strategically far superior sites in the Philippines. A permanent U.S. presence in Asia is thus a necessity, and the shape of that presence must keep in mind the unclear contours of the new world that is arriving. --- Sept. 20 Tass, the Soviet news agency, on a nuclear weapons test ban: The complete ban on nuclear testing would be the simplest and most effective measure for arms control. ... Their termination would stop the creation of new systems of weapons of mass destruction and would prevent upgrading old systems. The Soviet Union more than once stated its readiness for any negotiations that would promote a universal and complete ban on nuclear explosions. ... Moscow, for instance, proposed lowering the yields of test explosions and the maximum number of tests per year. ... The Soviet Union is prepared to resume a moratorium on nuclear explosions on a reciprocal basis with the United States. The Soviet Union has already substantially cut its program of nuclear testing. There have been no nuclear explosions at Soviet test ranges for about a year. There are now particularly favorable conditions for settling the question of nuclear tests. The Cold War is fading into the past. The main obstacles with which the U.S. justified its refusal to agree to complete a ban on nuclear explosions have been eliminated. Washington should no longer be concerned about problems involved in verifying the observance of a ban on explosions. The Soviet Union is prepared to accept any verification procedure. ... The talks in Geneva have approached a stage where their further progress is complicated by differences in the final goals pursued by the sides. The Soviet Union sees the main task to be banning tests, while the U.S. side only seeks to work out measures to monitor their continuation. ... An end to nuclear explosions remains elusive. Is not it time for the U.S. administration to relate its stance on nuclear testing to present-day realities? --- Sept. 25 The Guardian, London, on the Soviet Union: The great debate in Moscow would make a thrilling tale of dialectical passion, if it were not such a desperate affair. The stakes are enormous: the economic well-being and political integrity of the world's second superpower. The arguments on both sides are compelling but not decisive. Either alternative - the slow road of reform advocated by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, or the fast track pressed by economist Stanislav Shatalin - could come fatally unstuck. The central figure, still attractive to us but no longer unchallenged, remains President Mikhail Gorbachev, grappling with a problem which may this time prove too massive for even his skills in political manipulation. If we can forget about the Gulf crisis for a moment, we have to recognize that the crisis facing the Soviet people could explode just as catastrophically if ... Gorbachev takes the wrong path. ... Almost any economic program might improve life for the Soviet people if there were the political will to implement it. ... Gorbachev's adoption ... of special powers both to tackle the economic crisis and maintain public order is a last throw. We wish him luck, but he now needs five aces in one hand to succeed. --- Daily Nation, Nairobi, Kenya, on South African President F.W. de Klerk's visit to the United States: South Africa is looking to the United States to help end its isolation by the rest of the world. The question, however, is whether time is ripe for the United States and the rest of the world to consider lifting the sanctions against Pretoria. We say it is not. President George Bush, who appeared warmer toward de Klerk than he did toward the deputy president of the African National Congress, Nelson Mandela, when he visited Washington in June, must be reminded that apartheid is still very much in place. Bush must be be reminded that Pretoria is no less humane, no less violent, or less racist than it has been in the past.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
No Magical Powers To Save Healer
DOC.TEXT: A traditional healer drowned because his followers thought his magical powers enabled him to breath under water for 48 hours, police said Wednesday. Lovemore Mpofu, 40, drowned during a tribal cleansing ceremonyaat a dam in southwest Zimbabwe, said a police spokesman who was not identified. When Mpofu plunged into the water but did not resurface, his followers believed it to be part of the ceremony, the spokesman said. The followers, who were ``trainees'' of the traditional healer, danced and sang on the banks of the dam for two days as they awaited his return. Relatives of the traditional healer evidently told police they believed he was killed by a mermaid living in the dam. Traditional healers, or n'angas in the local Shona language, are better known in the West as witchdoctors.

DOC.HEAD: It's Time for the Annual Last-Minute Federal Budget Hysteria
DOC.TEXT: It's that time of fiscal year again, the government poised for paralysis and the autumnal sky ready to crash down on the nation's unsuspecting citizens. The stage is set, as usual, for 11th-hour budget chaos. But this round is a little different: many federal programs may actually be cut - by nearly one-third. ``The public doesn't have the slightest idea of what's coming. We're talking about a serious disruption in government service,'' said Stan Collender, director of federal budget policy for the Price Waterhouse accounting firm. Forget eye-glazing phrases like deficit reduction, budget negotiations and Gramm-Rudman sequesters. If Congress and President Bush don't agree on tax hikes and spending cuts by Monday, the government shrinks - drastically and instantly. For anyone who thinks that's a great idea, here are a few things to consider: -The Federal Aviation Administration would have to reduce from 40,000 to 34,000 the flights handled by 41 major airports and close down 250 weather stations at night, forcing cancellation of night flights. -The Agriculture Department would have to lower subsidies for major commodities, lay off chicken inspectors and close for two days a week the local offices where needy farmers get housing and operating loans. -The Department of Health and Human Services would have to cut Medicare payments by 2 percent. Medicare and Social Security checks would be delayed due to personnel cuts. -The Bureau of Prisons would have difficulty running federal prisons on a reduced staff. The Marshals Service wouldn't be able to chase as many fugitives or seize as many criminal assets. Few budget-watchers expect Draconian cuts to last long, if they materialize at all. The White House is hoping the mere threat of such a cataclysm - technically known as a sequester - will force an agreement sooner rather than later. But the choices are not pretty, particularly for those lawmakers facing the voters in five weeks. They can support a budget agreement that doubtless will raise taxes and reduce services. They can resist compromise, triggering the drastic spending cuts. Or they can extend the deadline for the automatic cuts, admitting failure and postponing the inevitable moment of truth. ``Any decision is politically painful - even doing nothing,'' said Collender. This would not be the first time a budget impasse dragged beyond the start of a fiscal year, triggering automatic cuts under the 1985 Gramm-Rudman law. But the scale this year is something entirely new. In 1986, there was an $11.7 billion cut when negotiators could not agree on a budget by the start of the fiscal year. In 1987, the slashes otaled $23 billion, but they were repealed after a couple of months. Last year, after a partial repeal, the cuts amounted to $16.2 billion. Now we're up to $85 billion to start, with more to come in mid-October. ``We're not talking about a flesh wound as we have in the past. We're talking about traumatic injury to vital organs here,'' said Norman Ornstein, a congressional analyst at the American Enterprise Institute. He and others say the budget paralysis is reinforced by an almost total lack of public pressure to get the job done. ``One of the problems is that we've seen sequesters before and they weren't all that bad,'' said Cox. ``Something really awful may have to happen before people realize ... how screwed up we are.'' The budget deadline is only one of three Congress faces next week, the first of the fiscal year. Missing any one of them is an invitation to upheaval. Besides trying to avert the automatic cuts, Congress must also raise the debt ceiling - or the country will run out of borrowing capacity - and pass a temporary spending bill to keep the government going while budget decisions are made. ``You're going to see a spectacle of disruption and acrimony,'' Cox predicted unhappily. But Ornstein said the ritualized last-minute hysteria, messy as it may be, generally produces compromises that have kept the deficit in check. The solution may be to ignore the process, he said, because it stands up to close scrutiny about as well as sausage-making. ``The agreement we get is no less substantial,'' he said, ``but by the time it comes about we're all nauseous.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Suggests Nazis Killed Jews to Give Poland Bad Name
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II suggested Wednesday that the Nazis killed millions of Jews in Poland during World War II because they wanted to disgrace his native country. ``The assassins did all this on our land, perhaps to cover it in infamy,'' the pope said in remarks to Polish pilgrims during his weekly general audience. ``But one can't cover a country in infamy with the death of innocent victims.'' John Paul said Jews ``lived with us through generations, side by side, on the same land.'' ``This people was struck by the terrible death of millions of sons and daughters,'' he said. ``First they were branded with a special mark, then pushed into ghettos, into isolated neighborhoods, then taken to gas chambers to die, only because they were the sons of this people. ``The people which lived with us during many generations, remained with us after this terrible death of its sons and daughters. Together we await the day of judgment and resurrection.'' Three million Polish Jews perished in the Holocaust. At the Auschwitz death camp in Poland, 2.5 million Jews from Poland and other European countries were killed by the Nazis.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Makes News By Paying Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A Norwegian multimillionaire made front page news Wednesday by paying income tax. Complaining about high taxes and hunting for deductions are national pastimes in this welfare state and newspapers frequently expose tax avoidance schemes used by the rich. So when Knut Utstein Kloster, one of the country's richest men, paid more taxes than he owed, it was a news sensation. The shipowner and investor sent a voluntary payment of $130,000 to the Oslo tax office, explaining that ``I want to do my part for the common good.'' Actually, he would not have had to pay any taxes, Kloster told the Dagbladet newspaper. Complicated tax rules had left him no income tax obligation for 1989 since he had invested in new projects. ``It happened against my will,'' said Kloster, who has an estimated personal fortune of $44 million. ``Everyone should pay tax.'' Tax officials told Dagbladet that the voluntary payment was probably the largest ever made in Norway.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Stranded By Flood
DOC.TEXT: The rain-swollen Jamuna River overflowed its banks and stranded 300,000 people, trapping many on levees or on the roofs of their mud and straw huts, a newspaper reported Wednesday. It was the monsoon season's third flood in the Sirajganj district, 65 miles northwest of Dhaka. Previous floods killed 70 people and displaced about 500,000. The Bengali-language daily Sangbad said flooding disrupted road links and washed away paddy crops over a wide area. One village elder was quoted as saying thousands of people needed immediate evacuation. Low-lying Bangladesh suffers floods that kill hundreds of people each year. With 110 million people, it is one of the world's poorest countries, with an annual per capita income of $170.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Plane was Spying for US, Former Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Sweden helped the United States spy on the Soviet Union in the 1950s in violation of this country's policy of neutrality, a former defense agency specialist said Wednesday. John Edin said a Swedish DC-3 plane that disappeared over Soviet territory in 1952 was equipped with sophisticated U.S. reconnaissance equipment the Americans had supplied in exchange for intellegence information. Edin, who is retired, worked as a monitor at the Radio Institute of the Swedish Armed Forces, FRA, from 1948 to 1956. ``Parts of the Swedish defense, especially the FRA ... have had far-reaching cooperation with NATO since the alliance was formed at the end of the 1940s,'' Edin said in an article signed by him and published by the Dagens Nyheter newspaper. He provided no further examples. Evert Dahlen, a spokesman for the armed forces chief of staff, said such cooperation would have required government approval and that he was unaware of any such agreement. ``We never comment on how our intelligence works,'' he added. The DC-3 and its crew were never recovered. The incident became known as the Catalina affair after the Soviets shot down a Swedish air force Catalina aircraft searching for the missing plane. The DC-3 was believed to have been shot down by the Soviets over the Baltic Sea. But Edin said he thought the plane was forced to land in the Soviet Union and the equipment seized.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Commander Tells his Men to Settle in for a Long Stay
LaserPhoto DOD1
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marine Commandant Gen. Alfred Gray told his men Wednesday to dig in for a long stay in the Saudi desert and to stop asking when they would be going home. He also reminded them that if they are attacked ``the best defense is a good offense.'' Gray delivered a 45-minute pep talk to Marines at a combat support detachment not far from the Persian Gulf and the north-south highways the corps is straddling to protect vital Saudi oil installations. He told the men he hoped to be able to stick to the policy of limiting major deployments to six months. But Gray, known for his bluntness, said the tense standoff and logistical problems might prevent normal rotations and he didn't expect any whining. ``I don't want to hear about any more questions about how long you're going to be here,'' he told about 200 Marines gathered around him at the camp, named in honor of Joe Foss, a World War II Marine flying ace who later was governor of South Dakota and chairman of the National Rifle Association. ``How long are we going to be here?'' he asked rhetorically through a bullhorn. ``Well, we're going to be here as long as it takes to get done what has to be done. ``There will be no morale problems ... because I say there will be morale. There will also be no boredom.'' He described the Marines' mission as defensive, but said the U.S.-led multinational forces deployed after Iraq invaded Kuwait were gaining more power every day and ``have everything we need to do whatever needs to be done.'' Gray solemnly reminded his troops that ``Marines are always in this part of the world the No. 1 target of terrorist attacks.'' More than 240 Marines were killed by a suicide truck bomber who blew up their barracks in Beirut in October 1983. The Marines were in Lebanon as part of a multinational peacekeeping force. Gray told the troops there were 13 ships headed to the gulf region with supplies to sustain their deployment in the northern Saudi desert. ``You and the rest of your warrior friends, you're really on the point. You're the tip of the spear,'' he said. For now, Gray said the mission was defense, but he suggested the Marines would quickly go on offense if Iraqi forces attacked. ``We all know the best defense is a good offense,'' he said. ``We have a very, very powerful, flexible and most useful force, afloat and ashore, ready to do whatever needs to be done. We're going to play for keeps if that is required.'' He told the men not to underestimate Iraq's large army, which fought an all-out war with the Iranians from 1980 to 1988. ``We face the potential of a pretty good firefight,'' Gray said. Gray also said he believed the swift American response to Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait had prevented the Iraqis from moving into Saudi Arabia. ``You've won a big one already and you haven't had to fire a shot,'' he said. ``And nobody's had to get patched up.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Pleads No Contest to Dumping Roaches in Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: A woman has pleaded no contest to a contempt citation for dumping thousands of cockroaches in a courtroom to protest conditions at her rented house. Maria Terwen, 67, entered the plea Tuesday. Morgan County Magistrate Donald Sharp did not fine Terwen, but his assistant, Cindy Stotler, said the county could bill Terwen for the cost of spraying the courthouse with insecticide. Terwen dumped thousands of roaches on Magistrate Margaret Gordon's desk during a hearing on a complaint filed against Terwen by her landlord. The landlord had complained that Terwen was $5,400 behind in rent. Terwen said she had no money. Terwen, who has 17 dogs and cats, said there are so many roaches in the house she must shake off her clothes before putting them on and must skim roaches from her cats' milk bowl when she feeds them. Magistrate court officials halted the rent case after the hearing, Stotler said.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Challenger Attacks GOP Senator's Aide
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Mark Hatfield's Democratic opponent is trying to revive his struggling campaign by attacking the Oregon senator's top aide for potential conflicts of interest. Democrat Harry Lonsdale is making an issue of the aide's activities as he attempts to paint Hatfield as a friend of special interests and big business, especially the Northwest's timber industry. Hatfield's integrity may have been compromised because his administrative assistant, Gerald Frank, sat on the board of a failed savings and loan and made more than 50 trips to New York over four years at the Senate's expense, the Lonsdale campaign suggested. Frank also holds stock in at least three timber companies, Lonsdale aides said. Frank and Hatfield deny there has been any conflict of interest or improper use of Senate finances. ``What people are forgetting is that it is not Gerry Frank on the ballot, I'm on the ballot. Let's talk about me,'' said Hatfield, the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee. He was first elected in 1966. ``At the very least it gives the appearance of a conflict of interest,'' said Dan Walter, Lonsdale's campaign manager. ``It illustrates how pervasive special interest and big business is. I don't think it is healthy for the public interest when those interests are so intertwined. It looks like the good-old-boy network is very much alive and well,'' Walter said. Frank, whose prominence in Oregon has led some to call him ``Oregon's third senator,'' has worked for Hatfield for 23 years. Lonsdale's agenda is to ``somehow discredit Senator Hatfield by somehow discrediting me,'' said Frank. ``This was planted (with media outlets) by the Lonsdale people and they have admitted it,'' Frank said. ``Everything has been a matter of public record filed with the Senate in disclosure forms.'' Bill Calder, Hatfield's press secretary, said Lonsdale's effort will backfire because he is ``diverting attention from the issues.'' Frank, 67, a millionaire whose family founded the Northwest's largest department store chain, said he never tried to influence Hatfield regarding any savings and loan institutions. Frank said he served on the board of Salem's American Federal Savings and Loan from 1962 to 1987 because he wanted to make inexpensive housing available in the region. ``It was a family operation,'' Frank said. ``When we got into things other than providing home mortgages, investing in Arizona and Texs, I raised questions of unhappiness with the management of the outfit. I had my fill and quit in 1987.'' Lonsdale said earlier this month that he was not sure that Hatfield had been influenced in regard to S&Ls, ``but his chief of staff has been very deeply involved himself in S&Ls. So I think that it might have been very easy for Mark Hatfield to become complacent about how the S&L bailout was handled.'' He trailed Hatfield by a 63 percent to 27 percent margin in an August poll. ``The man was on the board of a savings and loan while his boss was voting on banking and S&L regulation,'' said Walter. Frank, who lives in Oregon and makes frequent trips to Washington, said he has never traveled for personal purposes at Senate expense. He said he frequently flew out of Los Angeles and New York because the cross-country flights were cheaper than similar flights between Portland and Washington D.C. Frank, who publishes an annual travel guide to New York City that has earned him more than $1 million, said he used personal finances to cover ``every penny'' of travel related to work on the travel guide. Calder said all of the Senate-paid expenses were approved by the Senate Dispersing Office and Senate Rules Committee. Frank said hired investors buy and sell his stocks and he was not aware that he had any holdings in timber companies. He said he has never used his position to try to influence Hatfield regarding any private interests.

DOC.HEAD: Bladder Control Book's Sales Skyrocket After Ann Landers Mention
DOC.TEXT: Sales of a self-help book about bladder control had been slow. Then Ann Landers mentioned it in her column and the book's publisher was flooded with more orders in one day than it got the previous 10 months. The Hopkins Press said Monday's mail brought 18,000 orders for ``Staying Dry, A Practical Guide to Bladder Control.'' It was the largest single-day order ever for a Hopkins book, the publisher said. Landers mentioned the book last week in her daily syndicated column. About 22,000 readers of the column have written for copies of the book so far, the publisher said. ``The thing that kills me about this is that it is literally the book that nobody wanted to hear about,'' said Bob Oeste, promotions manager for Hopkins Press. The book has ``sold more copies in one day than most of our books sell in a lifetime,'' Oeste said. The book, first printed in November 1989, had sold 12,000 copies up until last week, he said. Last week, 3,000 copies of the book sat in storage. On Monday, Hopkins asked a Virginia printer to rush an additional 30,000 copies into print, he said. The book details treatment procedures that are effective for 90 percent of those suffering from incontinence, said Kathryn Burgio, assistant professor of medicine at the University of Pittsburgh, one of the book's authors. Common remedies include exercise of pelvic muscles, medication and surgery. An estimated 10 million people have some form of treatable urinary incontinence, the inability to control the bladder muscles, including one third of people over age 60, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Residents to Determine Fate of 60-Ton Junk Sculpture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in last graf
DOC.TEXT: It's three stories of concrete and junk. It weighs 60 tons and pigeons call it home. But is it art? The owner of the mall in suburban Berwyn where ``Big Bil-Bored'' has stood for a decade still gets angry letters demanding that he tear down the $25,000 sculpture. ``They get real mad at me. I get letters saying, `If you like it so much, why isn't it in your yard?' '' owner David Bermant said Tuesday. The project symbolizes America's throw-away society, said the sculptor, Nancy Rubins. Small appliances and other scrap are embedded in the concrete structure. Even Big Bil-Bored's defenders don't like it, but they say Bermant has the right to display his art on his property. ``It's tacky. But if you consider the tastelessness of Berwyn, (it) fits with Joe Six-pack grunting from bar to bar,'' said resident John Moisant. Bermant hired the Gallup Organization earlier this month to find out if a majority of shoppers at suburban Berwyn's Cermak Plaza Shopping Center think ``Big Bil-Bored'' should stay or go. If ``Big Bil-Bored'' comes down, something even wilder will replace it, Bermant promises. Few malls look anything like Cermak Plaza, located at one of the city's busiest intersections. Bermant has installed 30 pieces around the outdoor center, including ``Spindle,'' a stack of cars impaled on a huge spike in the parking lot, and ``Pinto Pelt'' - in which an artist removed the bodywork from an old Ford Pinto and bolted it to the outside of a building. Bermant wants to put sculptures where they will be seen and give his shopping centers some individuality. He has installed sculptures at five of the 20 centers he has owned across the country. ``What makes it any different from any other shopping center? I've got the same crappy merchants selling the same crappy stuff,'' Bermant said.

DOC.HEAD: German Promises Third World Aid Despite Burden of Unification
DOC.TEXT: Germany will continue to do its fair share in helping Third World countries despite the burden of unification, a top official said Wednesday. Karl Otto Poehl, head of the West German Federal Bank, told reporters covering the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund that ``in the years ahead we will contribute our fair share towards assisting the developing countries, the burden of unification notwithstanding.'' The bank, which works independently of but in close cooperation with the West German government, will become the top financial authority for all Germany when east and west unite Wednesday. Poehl said West German aid to the Third World again increased markedly last year.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Returns To Remodeled Office
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Norm Bangerter returned from a three-week trade mission overseas to an office filled with $95,000 worth of new furnishings, including a custom-made rug with the state seal and a hydraulic table. The Republican governor wasn't sure if he liked the new look, the first remodeling since he took office in 1986. ``I can't decide yet,'' Bangerter said Monday. Gone are a boxy wooden desk and oversize simulated wood-grain conference table, worn vinyl-covered chairs and sofa, soiled textured wallpaper and wall-to-wall carpeting. In their places are items selected by an interior designer hired by the state as part of a $3.5 million Capitol remodeling project. The state official overseeing the project acknowledges the remodeling may not be to Bangerter's taste. ``This isn't a Gov. Bangerter design. This is something befitting the State Capitol,'' said Neal Stowe, director of facilities construction management for the state. ``This has got to be more of a statesman's office. It's not just a simple office where you conduct some business,'' Stowe said. About that hydraulic table: It has a concealed mechanism that allows the governor to raise it to desk height for work sessions or lower it to coffee-table level for informal meetings.

DOC.HEAD: Vandalism Reported At Ryan White's Grave
DOC.TEXT: Authorities plan to offer a reward for information about vandalism to the grave of teen-age AIDS victim Ryan White. Hamilton County sheriff's Deputy Gene Stilts said today the 6-foot-8 monument at the Cicero Cemetery had not been damaged, but greenery around the headstone was destroyed, and statues and a candleholder were disassembled. The vandalism is believed to have occurred Sept. 14. Stits said he had been able to reconstruct the metal and glass candleholder, which is at the base of the monument that bears the words ``Kid of Courage.'' White died April 8 at age 18 following a lengthy battle against acquired immune deficiency syndrome. After winning a legal fight to remain in public schools near Kokomo, his family moved to Cicero, about 20 miles north of Indianapolis. He became an international spokesman for AIDS victims.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO DELETE EXTRANEOUS MATTER AT BOTTOM
White Authorities Cut Electricity Briefly in Two Black Townships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with power restored to townships, police comment on train deaths. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The all-white Pretoria City Council ended a 12-hour cut in electricity to two black townships today. Power had been cut to the townships of Mamelodi and Atteridgeville at 4 a.m. because residents have refused to pay their bills for three months, the council said. Electrical service resumed at about 4:20 p.m. Township leaders met with Pretoria officials today to try to work out a solution. A joint statement issued after the meeting said the city council was convinced an agreement could be reached and agreed to temporarily restore power. It said the outstanding bills must be paid. Residents owe about $2 million in overdue electricity bills, according to the council, which s controlled by President F.W. de Klerk's National Party. Blacks living in the Mamelodi and Atteridgeville townships have withheld payments to protest what they say are high fees and poor services. Some 600,000 blacks live in the townships on the edge of Pretoria, the capital. The electricity cut shuts down light towers in the townships and household appliances such as lamps, refrigerators and stoves. The resulting darkness at night could increase street crime, although police have bolstered patrols to try to maintain order. No incidents were reported today. Brian Currin, director of the Lawyers for Human Rights, said township residents planned legal action against the city council for its ``provocative and politically irresponsible'' decision to cut power. A civic leader later said lawyers were asked to delay any action. Several whites-only city councils have cut electricity recently to neighboring black townships after residents refused to pay their bills to protest services. However, the electricity has been restored within a day or two following negotiations between the two sides. In other developments, police launched a homicide investigation into the deaths of seven people whose bodies were found Monday along railroad tracks between Johannesburg and the Soweto black township. Police Col. Frans Malherbe said the deaths occurred during a panic created by a false alarm that the train was under attack. He said ``criminal elements'' spread the attack rumor to steal passengers' belongings in the confusion. ``People who go about raising these false alarms will almost certainly be charged with culpable homicide,'' he said. Attacks on trains in the Johannesburg area have killed more than two dozen people in recent weeks. Police said today there were no reports of trouble during the first night of a 9 p.m.-4 a.m. curfew imposed to stop violence in black townships around Johannesburg. About 800 blacks have died since fighting began outside Johannesburg in early August between the African National Congress and Inkatha. Both organizations oppose apartheid, but differ on tactics and plans for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: 3-Year-Old Helps Mother Deliver Sister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `He was ..., to CORRECT spelling of trouper. Pick up 5th graf, `Mrs. Mansfield ...
DOC.TEXT: Three-year-old Eric Mansfield will never have to ask his mother how babies are born. He got an early lesson when he helped deliver his sister Tuesday on the kitchen floor of his home after his mother went into sudden labor. The family doesn't have a telephone, so Linda Mansfield couldn't call for help, and no one else was home. But she and her son had little trouble, said her husband, Jack. ``He was tickled pink,'' Mansfield said of Eric. ``He was a super trouper.'' Mrs. Mansfield, 31, and Jennifer, who weighed 8 pounds, 8 ounces, were later checked by a doctor. Mother and baby went back home and were doing well, Dr. Gordon Maxwell said. The birth began shortly after Jack Mansfield had left to go grocery shopping. Their other children, aged 9 and 13, were at school. Mrs. Mansfield, who was due Oct. 2, wa drying dishes when her water broke. ``This was our fourth child, and everything just dropped,'' her husband said. ``She told Eric, `We're having a baby.' '' She instructed Eric to get a baby blanket and sterile scissors and pads, which the couple had arranged as a precaution. Eric remembered hearing his parents discuss the Lamaze childbirth method and offered to bring his mother a toy whistle so she could blow on it. Although he found the sight of the placenta a little unnerving, Eric watched the 30-minute event from beginning to end, his father said. ``She was afraid he would cry and go hide, like little kids do, but he brought the things she needed and stayed right there,'' he said. Mansfield said his wife told Eric what was happening as he watched the birth. He returned home minutes after his new daughter was born. ``I walked through the door and Eric hollered `Daddy, we're having a baby,' '' Jack said. He found his wife lying on the kitchen floor, the baby in her arms. When the two older children came home from school, ``It was better than Christmas to them,'' Jack said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Felt in Six States Along New Madrid Fault; No Major Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th graf, `There have ...' to CORRECT that scientist predicted likelihood of quake, rather than that saying it was definite. ^By STEVE BAKER
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook parts of Illinois, Kentucky, Arkansas, Missouri, Tennessee and Indiana this morning, but no major damage was reported. The quake was felt at at 8:19 a.m. CDT. It registered 4.6 on the Richter scale and was centered along the New Madrid fault 40 miles north of New Madrid, Mo., according to Don Kelly, a spokesman for the U.S. Geological Survey in Reston, Va. New Madrid has been the site of some of the greatest earthquakes in U.S. history. The New Madrid fault line runs from Marked Tree, Ark., to southern Illinois and has hundreds of small quakes every year. Although there were no accounts of damage, the temblor rattled nerves throughout the region, which has been on edge about predictions of a major quake. Kenneth Rutledge, who lives 16 miles east of Hopkinsville, Ky., said he was sitting in his living room when the quake hit. ``I'm telling you it moved me,'' he said. Leonard Nash, who was visiting a farm in Piggott in northeastern Arkansas, said: ``You could feel it and hear things moving in the house. It lasted just a few seconds. ``It didn't excite us too much. It wasn't anything that was that frightening. We just looked at each other, said `Hey, that was an earthquake' and continued our talking.'' Scott Chambers, the director of Emergency Medical Services in Corning, Ark., said he felt the temblor at the local hospital. ``It was about like standing real close to a train track when a train comes by, a little harder than that,'' he said. Three or four cataclysmic earthquakes struck the New Madrid fault in the winter of 1811-12 and were felt as far away as Boston. They have been estimated at about 8 on the Richter scale, which didn't exist at the time. There have been predictions that an earthquake is likely along the New Madrid fault before the end of the century. Recently, a scientist in New Mexico predicted that a major quake could occur in early December, prompting increases in insurance sales and other preparatory measures. Other experts dispute his theory of a tidal trigger to earthquakes but say a major quake in the region is bound to happen eventually. ``I don't think this is a precursor to a larger event,'' Elaine Foust of the U.S. Geological Survey in Nashville said today. ``But we could flip a coin and decide. I'm not God, I can't predict.'' Cecil Whaley, operations officer for the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency in Nashville, also pooh-poohed the five-second shake. ``People who live on solid rock probably did not feel it,'' Whaley said. ``This appears to be normal . . . We have small ones two or three times a week, usually imperceptible.'' In Indiana, a dispatcher said the Evansville Police Department had received about 60 calls from concerned citizens shortly after the quake, but had received no reports of damage. Dan Moran felt the quake at the Evansville Museum of Arts and Sciences, which is featuring an earthquake exhibit this fall. ``Maybe this will help grab people's attention again about the inevitability of earthquakes,'' Moran said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as mesured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number, say from magnitude 5.5 to magnitude 6.5, means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. Some experts say the actual amount of energy released may be 30 times greater. A quake of magnitude 4 can cause moderate damage. A quake of magnitude 5 is capable of considerable damage. Last October's earthquake in San Francisco registered 7.1.

DOC.HEAD: Video Game Set Views Saddam Hussein as a Heavy
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein is the leading scoundrel among the American video game set. The Iraqi president finished ahead of drugs and drug dealers as nominees for dumb or outrageous behavior in a survey of 3,000 readers of VideoGames & Computer Entertainment magazine. More than 1,500 kids nominated Saddam as the leading personality for the 1990 Bonk Award. Drugs and drug dealers were cited by 1,000 respondents and alcohol and smoking each got 500 votes as things that deserved to be ``bonked.'' ``The process of `bonking' Saddam Hussein is therapeutic for children. It changes fear into anger, which gives them much more control,'' said Dr. Robert Butterworth, a child psychologist with Contemporary Psychology Associates in Los Angeles. The award is named after the hero in ``Bonk's Adventure,'' a video game on NEC's TurboGrafx-16 system. Bonk is a caveman who literally uses his head to defeat his enemies and smash through obstacles. NEC sponsored a write-in survey in the September issue of VideoGames & Computer Entertainment, which has a mostly teenage readership. The contest was conceived and booked in June, long before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Kids were allowed to list one person and one thing on their responses. Other personalities cited were Libynn leader Moammar Qadhafi, Donald Trump, Pete Rose, Roseanne Barr, Andrew Dice Clay and Zsa Zsa Gabor. Other things that kids thought should be ``bonked'' included Exxon Corp., gangs and acne.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises and Blast Democrats During Campaign Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comments; EDITS throughout, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, stumping today for Republicans in the Midwest, blasted Democrats in one breath and profusely thanked them in the next. The president said bipartisanship is of the utmost importance as he seeks support for his Persian Gulf policies and the massive U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. ``I'm grateful to the Democratic leadership for the support they have given,'' he told a fund-raising luncheon for gubernatorial candidate George Voinovich. ``We need to ... continue to maintain a bipartisan spirit in support of America's response to Iraqi aggression,'' he said. He reiterated his feeling that politics should ``stop at the water's edge'' when it comes to an international crisis. The words were similar to what Bush has said many times since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But they contrasted sharply with the blistering attack he had leveled against Democrats a moment before when he talked about the budget negotiations. Acknowledging that ``emotions in this budget debate ... are running high,'' Bush launched into a tirade against Democrats in Congress who he accused of blocking an agreement to reduce the deficit. With Monday looming as the deadline to reach a deficit reduction agreement, Bush said that if failure to meet the deadline results in automatic spending cuts, the Democrats will be to blame for the havoc that ensues, including massive government furloughs and disruptions of services. He insisted that it is not his demand for a capital gains reduction tax that is holding up the process. Before leaving Washington, Bush met with Republican congressional leaders who said the president may be willing to compromise on his call for a cut in the capital gains tax. ``Contrary to what you may have heard, the hangup is not capital gains,'' Bush said. ``The hangup is with the Democrats on Capitol Hill. ``It goes well beyond political rhetoric,'' he said. ``It is important to get a solution,'' he said. On the political front, Bush gave Voinovich a resounding endorsement as the candidate who would promote education and law and order and environmental protection. As mayor of Cleveland, Voinovich had taken the city from ``the gloomy dark days of despair'' and brought it into brighter times, Bush said. Recent polls have shown Voinovich with a slight lead over the Democratic nominee, state Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., in the race to succeed Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste. The gubernatorial battle is one of several that is being hotly contested by both parties as the reapportionment of congressional districts looms. From Akron today, Bush was heading to Illinois for a dinner honoring GOP Senate candidate Rep. Lynn Martin, who is in an uphill battle against Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. The president was spending tonight in Minneapolis, where he will attend a breakfast Thursday to benefit the gubernatorial bid of political newcomer Jon Grunseth. Grunseth, a St. Paul businessman, won a six-way Independent-Republican primary this month to face incumbent Gov. Rudy Perpich. Bush will return to Ohio on Thursday for a reception and lunch to benefit Voinovich in Cleveland. Then he will head to Detroit to stump for GOP Senate hopeful Rep. Bill Schuette, who is trying to oust Democratic Sen. Carl Levin. As the November election nears, the president is committing one to three days each week, with larger blocks of time expected at the end, to help GOP candidates. He has used the trips as well to rally support for his huge military deployment in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Orders for `Big-Ticket' Items Fall
DOC.TEXT: Durable goods orders to U.S. manufacturers slid 0.8 percent in August, according to a government report Wednesday that analysts said indicated cutbacks in business investment plans because of Middle East uncertainties. The Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods - ``big-ticket'' items expected to last more than three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $127 billion after a revised 2.7 percent gain in July. Analysts pointed to a 11.2 percent drop, to $35.4 billion, in non-defense capital goods orders, which often are a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize. ``On the surface it seems to suggest that producers are wary about the economic outlook,'' said Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. ``There's no way that ... producer investment won't be affected by oil prices, particularly if they stay above $35 a barrel'' Since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, oil prices have soared from less than $15 a barrel to nearly $40 a barrel. The price shock has further weakened an already sluggish economy that some economists say is slipping into recession. In fact, economist Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers said the durable goods report ``provides further confirmation that the recession began in August. The start of the recession was already in evidence due to falling retail sales and industrial production.'' William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said the decline in both new and unfilled orders means the economy ``will fall into a recession in the fourth quarter.'' Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington was not as pessimistic, pointing to another Commerce Department report Wednesday that showed August consumer spending up 0.5 percent from July, while June and July figures were even stronger than first reported. ``It appeared that spending appeared to be recovering in June and the oil shock didn't make that much of a dent in it,'' Evans said. Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The report also said personal incomes grew 0.3 percent in August. Evans also noted the decline in some durable goods order categories ``was partially offset by a big surge in defense orders, and that was no surprise given what's going on in the Middle East.'' Defense orders, which often are volatile, jumped 12.4 percent to $8.4 billion after a 5.6 percent decline in July. ``My guess is that almost all of that was due to the Persian Gulf,'' Evans said. Excluding the defense category, orders fell 1.6 percent. Both electrical machinery and transportation categories posted gains while non-electrical machinery and primary metals orders fell. Orders for transportation equipment rose 1.3 percent, to $35.2 billion, mostly for motor vehicles. Aircraft orders fell about $3 billion. Excluding the transportation category, durable goods orders fell 1.6 percent. Transportation orders jumped 4.5 percent in July. Electrical machinery orders advanced 2.6 percent, to $20.8 billion, after a 1.5 percent gain a month earlier. But non-electrical machinery orders fell 6.1 percent, to $21.2 billion, after gaining 3.5 percent in July. And orders for primary metals slipped 1.7 percent, to $11.6 billion, after rising 2.8 percent the previous month. Shipments of durable goods rose 2.9 percent, to $128.7 billion, in August, most of which was motor vehicles. Shipments had fallen 1.8 percent in July. Unfilled orders edged down 0.3 percent, to $499.3 billion, after gaining 0.6 percent a month earlier.

DOC.HEAD: New York Film Festival's Sad Tale of Betrayal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``The Sting of Death,'' a movie from Japan featured in the New York Film Festival, is a spare tale of betrayal - how a husband's infidelity permanently stains his wife's soul with grief and jealousy. Director Kohei Oguri's opens his film with Miho, a homemaker and mother of two, and her husband, Toshio, once a kamakazi pilot and now a writer, calmly discussing the consequences of his affair. ``Hey! Do you really want to die?'' he asks. ``Keep your `heys' for someone else. Who do you think I am?'' ``How do you want me to call you?'' ``Have you no shame at all? Call me `dear.' '' This verbal chest thwacking goes back and forth until Toshio defines what Miho is to him. ``You are my wife.'' But Miho is so deeply disturbed by her husband's former mistress that her rage begins to feed upon itself and begets more hatred, until she is consumed by this obsessive self-destruction. The fire soon engulfs Toshio, too, and together they complete a destructive circle. ``An iron pot is pressing my head hard. Hit me,'' Miho pleads. Toshio obediently complies. In an attempt to redeem himself, he offers her complete servitude and fidelity. He tells her that since he tormented her for 10 years with his affair, he will be her slave for the next 10. She accepts this pact, for a while, but soon is undone by the recurring jealousy of the other woman. She sells her kimonos, hires a private detective and discovers the sordid secrets of her husband's philanderings - he bought the other woman underwear, gave her candy, paid for an abortion. Back and forth the couple struggles between saving their marriage and resigning themselves to the pain and emptiness before them. He becomes the picture of contrition, offering her effusive apologies and begging for forgiveness. ``I've thought only of myself after the war,'' he confesses. At times Miho seems to have exorcised the ghost of the other woman and a semblance of domestic normalcy prevails. Then, seemingly from nowhere, she blurts out over dinner that she wants her husband to forever call her by the name of his mistress. One of their two children, who somehow seem oblivious to the suffering of their parents, tells Dad he might as well do as Mom says. This pyschological unraveling forms the bulk of this bleak story, and director Oguri said at a news conference after a press screening Tuesday that he hopes it offers a parable of finding faith in the face of adversity. ``On the surface it is a crisis of a marriage,'' he said through a translator. ``Underneath, it is a crisis of returning to humanity, which leads you to the idea of prayer and the accomplishment of faith.'' ``The Sting of Death'' is marked by its austerity. The camera rarely leaves the four walls of the home and most sets are drenched in soft shades of gray. It's also a quiet film, ambient noise seems to have been edited out so the only sounds we hear is the exchange of dialogue. Oguri leaves his tale of the broken hearts and souls open, without resolving if Miho and Toshio remain together or if they part, either by death or divorce. Asked to speculate on their future, Oguri says he would like to think ``they would have become happy.'' The 28th New York Film Festival opened Sept. 21 with Joel and Ethan Coen's quirky gangster movie, ``Miller's Crossing.'' The 17-day event features 29 films from 14 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Trident Missile Launched from Submarine
DOC.TEXT: A Trident II ballistic missile was launched Wednesday from the submarine USS Pennsylvania as it cruised underwater off Florida, the Air Force said. The successful test was the third of its kind. The exact location of the launch was not released. The USS Pennsylvania is the second Trident class nuclear-powered fleet ballistic missile submarine to carry the Trident II. The test is intended to demonstrate the crew's ability to safely handle the weapons system. The submarine is certified for deployment after each launch. Wednesday's launch was the 31st flight of the Trident II since January 1987. Twenty-eight involved missiles under development, 19 of which were launched from a land pad at Cape Canaveral and nine from the submarine USS Tennessee.

DOC.HEAD: Sessions Defends FBI Stings
DOC.TEXT: FBI Director William S. Sessions on Wednesday reaffirmed his support of the bureau's undercover tactics, including the sting operation which videotaped Washington Mayor Marion Barry smoking crack cocaine. But Sessions acknowledged that a jury's refusal to convict Barry of the charge arising from that sting may have underscored the ``need to be very careful and look very carefully before you elect to use a particular technique.'' The FBI did exercise such caution before it used a former girlfriend of Barry's to lure the mayor to a downtown hotel, where he smoked crack in front of a hidden video camera, the director insisted. Sessions also backed the FBI's use of undercover operations to catch people in the act of other misdeeds, as in the Abscam corruption investigation of a decade ago. That case netted convictions of seven members of Congress. ``When we gather evidence, it is not always simply a matter of walking up and asking the farmer if his eggs are fresh,'' Sessions said. ``There are things you do that will be available to use for evidence in the course of a trial.'' ``For the techniques in Abscam, I would not apologize, nor do I feel they were inappropriate,'' Sessions said. ``Nor do I feel the techniques that were utilized in the case at hand were inappropriate.'' The videotapes of Barry smoking crack ``were not suppressed under the law, they were allowed by the court, they were available to the jury and it did what it wanted to do with it, which is the genius of our system,'' Sessions said. ``If they rejected that on account of that technique, then, of course, that is a price the government ultimately paid,'' Sessions said of the jury's verdict. Jurors deadlocked on 12 counts against Barry, including a cocaine possession charge arising from his Jan. 18 arrest at the Vista Hotel. Barry was convicted of one misdemeanor cocaine possession count and is scheduled to be sentenced Oct. 26. He was acquitted of another misdemeanor possession charge. Prosecutors decided not to retry Barry on the remaining counts, including three perjury charges that the mayor lied to a grand jury by denying that he had used cocaine. Sessions said the verdict's message about FBI undercover investigations of elected public officials ``could take many forms.'' ``It could be everything from a strong affirmation to a caution that ... you need to be careful and look carefully before you elect to use as particular technique.'' ``And that was done in that case,'' Sessions said. On other subjects, the director said: -His health is excellent in the wake of surgery last June for a medical condition he refused to disclose. Sessions acknowledged that he is periodically tested for skin cancer that was removed from his back in 1985. ``I am in good health, I continue to be in good health. I am not worried about my health and I would hope that will actually turn out and continue to be true,'' Sessions said. -The FBI had no indication of Iraqi-sponsored terrorism since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month. Sessions said the bureau is on high alert against any possible terrorist acts and ``we are, of course, hopeful we would be able to avert and avoid any terrorist act itself.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Marines Fly Food to City Where Doe's Lions Prey on Hungry People
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines on Wednesday flew emergency food and medical supplies into the capital, where pet lions of slain President Samuel Doe reportedly were preying on starving people inside his mansion. A cease-fire between four armies in Monrovia held for the fifth day, although gunshots crackled occasionally. The Daily Mail newspaper of neighboring Freetown, Sierra Leone, quoted one of Doe's generals as saying two hungry pet lions of the ousted leader were prowling around the presidential residence in Monrovia, eating people weakened by hunger. Many people sought refuge in the mansion during the height of the fighting among rebel factions and Doe's soldiers. The state-owned newspaper quoted Gen. Henry Chibli said the lions normally ate 275 pounds of meat a day but that Doe had been unable to provide them with food in his last days. Maj. Chris Otulana, a spokesman for a five-nation West African army sent to enforce a truce in Liberia's 9-month-old civilwwar, appealed for more international aid to stop people from dying of hunger and disease. The Marine helicopters carried 1.3 tons of emergency food and medical equipment from Freetown to Monrovia. The supplies belong to the Belgian chapter of Doctors without Borders, which plans to reopen a field hospital in the city. The Belgian doctors were forced to close their operations last month when rebel leader Charles Taylor advanced into the capital and the hospital was hit by rockets and shells. Otulana urged Taylor to open talks with the West African task force ``so we can jaw jaw rather than war war.'' He spoke in an interview with The Associated Press. Taylor has demanded the withdrawal of the West Africans, whom he accuses of wanting to install a puppet government in Liberia. He has declared himself president and is trying to install his own government. He said he will hold elections on Oct. 10 to choose a representative from each of Liberia's 13 counties to join the government, which he has described as a temporary administration that would organize general elections. The West African plan also proposes elections, but says they should be organized by an interim government already chosen by Liberian opposition parties, businessmen and clergymen. Taylor's aides had reported he was to meet Tuesday with Brig. Gen. David Nimley, commander of the remnants of Doe's army, but no meeting took place, according to the French news agency Agence France-Presse. Taylor has made no contact with the West African force or those of rival rebel leader Prince Johnson. Johnson and Nimley have agreed to the West African peace plan. Johnson has said Taylor has no right to call his own elections and that his proposal is unrealistic given the war-ravaged state of the nation. Taylor started the civil war on Dec. 24 when he invadd from neighboring Ivory Coast. Johnson fought alongside him but formed his own rebel faction after the two quarreled. Johnson's forces captured Doe earlier this month and tortured him to death. More than 5,000 civilians have been killed in the fighting. More than half a million Liberians have fled to neighboring states and at least another million of the 2.3 million population is displaced within the country. Monrovia has been without electricity, running water and telephone communications for three months. Few food supplies have reached the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Evening Express to Close, Merge With Press Herald
DOC.TEXT: The 108-year-old Evening Express will close in February, the publisher said. The merger with the morning Portland Press Herald will take effect Feb. 4, said the Guy Gannett Publishing Co. ``While we're very proud of the Evening Express, changing lifestyles have, for the past decade, caused an increased readership of morning newspapers and a corresponding decrease of evening circulation,'' said Jean Gannett Hawley, publisher of the Portland Press Herald and the Evening Express. ``The merger of our two daily newspapers will result in the creation of a single paper with more resources and standards of quality journalism for Mainers,'' Hawley said in a statement Tuesday. The Express had been losing circulation steadily since the early 1980s. Its daily circulation now stands at between 22,000 and 23,000. The closing will leave Maine with only two afternoon dailies - the Journal Tribune in Biddeford and the Times Record in Brunswick, both of which compete with the Press Herald for readers. The new Press Herald will continue to publish Monday through Saturday mornings and include many of the features now contained in the Evening Express, along with additional local news. The company also publishes the Maine Sunday Telegram. The merger will leave the company with 30 fewer positions. But the company said it might not have to lay off any employees because it had held open vacancies this year and is providing an early retirement incentive package. ``By taking this action, we believe we will be a better newspaper for our readers who will get more features and local news and our advertisers for whom our circulation will be unduplicated,'' Steve Braver, the company's general manager, said in a statement to employees. When founded in 1882 by Pembroke native Arthur Wood Laughlin, the Express was one of four Portland dailies and billed itself as ``the only one-cent paper in the state.'' Five years later, the Express was taken over by a company headed by Col. Frederick Neal Dow, son of staunch prohibitionist Neal Dow, whose views were reflected in the newspaper. Dow acquired a competing afternoon paper, the Daily Advertiser, in 1910 and merged it with the Express, which by then had the largest circulation in the city. In the 1920s, Guy P. Gannett acquired and consolidated the city's major daily and Sunday papers, turning them into the crown jewel of a media empire that now includes dailies in Waterville and Augusta, a chain of weeklies in Minnesota and television and radio stations. After forming the Press Herald out of the Daily Press and the successor to the old Eastern Argus, Gannett bought the Express from the Dow family in 1925. The Express' circulation peaked at about 31,000 in the late 1970s. The closing of the Express reflects an industry trend toward declining circulation among many afternoon dailies across the country that have been struggling in a time of changing lifestyles and growing competition from television news.

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Women Complete Course, Could Lead To More Active Role in Society
DOC.TEXT: Question No. 5 on one exam Wednesday for women civil defense volunteers was: ``If you inhale gas from a chemical weapon will it cause burns in the throat?''
