More than 5,000 women completed their first two weeks of training on a first aid and civil defense course many view as the first step in changing the role of Saudi women forever in the strict Moslem society. But training women in a profession that requires not just seeing but touching strangers is a highly sensitive issue in a country where women are not allowed to drive and always wear black headscarves and long black cloaks in public. The changes are being made in response to Iraq's invasion Aug. 2 of neighboring Kuwait and the Saudi monarchy's call for Western forces to help defend the kingdom. ``I feel now I have more of a role in society,'' said Mirvat Mohammed, 25, a computer programmer who took the course. ``If it (war) happens, I'm ready.'' After the government announced in early September that women volunteers would be accepted for civil defense training, the Health Ministry revamped its basic 10-hour first aid course with a war against Iraq's Saddam Hussein in mind. His arsenal of chemical weapons meant adding four hours of lectures on the issue - ranging from how to seal your windows to how to diagnose and treat chemical wounds. The 20-hour course also concentrated on wounds caused by guns, said Dr. Ronda Flemban, a surgeon who taught seven groups of women at the ministry's Health Institute in Jiddah, a Western port. Those trained can use the basic first aid at home but will be called upon in time of war to act as nursing assistants. ``Most people don't know how to act during an emergency,'' Dr. Flemban said. ``As we are expecting anything could happen, most people need to know first aid.'' Women taking the course included housewives, teachers, students and government employees. Amal Fatani, 35, who graduated from George Washington University in economics in 1985, signed up because she could not answer her children's questions about chemical weapons. Daughter Tughreed, 9, and son Faris, 4, were ``very, very afraid,'' she said. ``They asked me what it looked like. What would happen if we closed the doors and windows? This course will give me the chance to give the right answers.'' Those that did well on the 26 questions Wednesday, such as answering yes that inhaling chemical weapons can burn your throat, will get the chance to sign up for a three-month, three-hour a day intensive course. The government expects the response to be huge, especially because more than 13,300 are signed up for the next two-week class that starts Saturday. Hundreds are taking similar course at private institutions. Many women said Saudi Arabia was ill-prepared for an emergency but the threat from Iraq would change that. In a society where men and women are educated separately and rarely mingle in public, the call for women volunteers was viewed as a major social change. ``There will be more exposure of women within the tenets of Islam,'' one newspaper editor said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The government would like to tap that vast resource.'' Leila Barzangi, director of the health institute, said: ``Our religion has always allowed and encouraged women to work as nurses and doctors. But our traditions prevented it.'' Tradition dictated the institute's hallways be virtually cleared of women before the front door was opened for a visiting male reporter. Greeted by a woman with only her eyes showing, he was told to stay away from a window that looked onto the interior of the building. ``It's a sensitive subject because of the religious people,'' Zahrani said. Women, pointing out that men and women work side-by-side in hospitals, said this segregation would disappear instantly in event of a crisis. ``During a disaster no one will even think about it,'' Dr. Flemban said. Women would probably not alter their Islamic dress, but a crisis might put a Saudi woman behind the wheel of an ambulance.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Votes Air Embargo Against Iraq, Occupied Kuwait
LaserPhotos NY6,11,12
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with Jordan announcing it will abide by U.N. resolution against Iraq, quotes. Picks up 4th pvs, `In addition...' Minor editing thereafter to trim and conform.
DOC.TEXT: The decision by the United Nations to extend its trade embargo against Iraq to air traffic amounts to ``an act of war,'' the Baghdad government says. Thirteen of the Security Council's 15 members were represented by foreign ministers during Tuesday's nearly unanimous vote, giving the resolution added symbolic weight. The council warned the Baghdad government of further punitive action and hinted at sanctions against nations that fail to honor the U.N. embargo on trade with Iraq. Cuba cast the only no vote. Jordan, criticized for assisting Iraq by allowing some food and supplies to cross into that country, announced today that it would comply with the U.N. air embargo against Iraq and halt all mercy flights of foreign nationals from Iraq and Kuwait. Foreign Minister Marwan Kasim said in a statement that Jordan would comply with the air embargo, Security Council Resolution 670. Kasim, who also is the deputy prime minister, said, ``Jordan has continued to allow a minimum number of flights by the Iraqi Airways, due to humanitarian considerations, facilitating the movement of foreign nationals from Iraq and Kuwait,'' he said. ``However, those flights will now be terminated in accordance with Security Council Resolution 670,'' he said. In addition to sanctioning the air embargo, the resolution calls for halting Iraqi shipping and freezing Iraqi assets overseas. Both Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze suggested the United Nations could take military action if all other efforts to force Iraq into relinquishing Kuwait fail. War ``is not a desirable option, but it is one of the options contained in the U.N. Charter,'' said Shevardnadze. ``Anyway, I hope that peaceful ways will be found to find a way out.'' In a speech to the General Assembly earlier, he called Iraq's seizure of Kuwait ``a major affront to mankind. . . . The United Nations has the power to suppress acts of aggression. There is ample evidence that this right can be exercised. It will be, if the illegal occupation of Kuwait continues.'' Baker struck a similar note: ``The Charter envisages the possibility of further individual and collective measures to defend against aggression and flagrant violations of international humanitarian law,'' he said. The number of foreign ministers attending the Security Council vote underscored the determination of the international community to compel Iraq to quit Kuwait, which Iraq's Saddam Hussein had his army seize on Aug. 2. Shevardnadze told the General Assembly that people like Saddam - who take hostages on a mass scale, threaten other nations with destruction and are ``guilty of particular ruthlessness in the use of force'' - should be tried by an international tribunal for their ``crime against humanity.'' Since it invaded Kuwait, Iraq has refused to release several thousand Western men and moved some of them to potential military targets for use as human shields against possible attack. Shevardnadze was just one among a string of presidents, foreign ministers and prime ministers who have demanded an immediate Iraqi pullout in speeches to the 45th General Assembly, which began its general debate on Monday. The foreign ministers of Britain, West Germany, Portugal, Canada, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Spain were due to give speeches today. The new Security Council resolution calls on all states to bar from their airspace all passenger and cargo flights to or from Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Only U.N.-approved shipments of humanitarian food aid or medicine are permitted. Iraq's ambassador, Abdul Al-Anbari, stalked out of the Security Council session after vote, saying ``You know, boycotting a country by enforcing a naval embargo as well as an air embargo is an act of aggression, an act of war. ``But up to now we have been practicing self-restraint because we know that if war were to break out, it would destroy everything in the region,'' he said. The resolution - the ninth passed by the Security Council in an effort to force Iraq to quit Kuwait - prohibits use of force in the air embargo but calls for searches and detention of aircraft. The council warned that it would consider ``serious action'' if Iraq continued to flout the will of the international community, hinting at a U.N. military operation. It said countries that try to evade the embargo may themselves face secondary sanctions. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said it was the first time in the 45-year history of the United Nations that so many foreign ministers had attended a meeting to vote on a substantive issue. On only three previous occasions have the foreign ministers of all five permanent members - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, China and France - attended a Security Council meeting. ``Rarely has the international community been so united and determined that aggression should not succeed,'' Baker told the council. ``Iraq has been quarantined because its brutal actions have separated it from the community of nations. There can be no business as usual. In fact, there can be no economic exchanges with Iraq at all,'' he said. Cuba, which was on the receiving end of a U.S. blockade during the 1962 missile crisis, has said it is against any sanctions on Iraq. Earlier resolutions aimed at Iraq authorized ships to implement a maritime embargo and to stop and search vessels that may be violating trade sanctions. They also repudiated the annexation of Kuwait, demanded the release of hostages and condemned Iraqi raids on foreign missions in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Sets Honor Program for Farm Conservation
DOC.TEXT: A nationwide program to recognize outstanding farm conservationists was announced Wednesday by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. The new ``Take Pride in America'' farm conservation program will honor an outstanding farmer in each of nearly 3,000 soil and water conservation districts during a three-year period. Yeutter made the announcement in Amana, Iowa, where he appeared with officials of Goodyear Tire and Rubber, the National Association of Conservation Districts, and the National Association of State Conservation Agencies, cosponsors of the awards program. The Agriculture Department also will step up efforts to improve the nation's water quality, he said. An objective will be to reduce the risk of agricultural chemical pollution of ground and surface water, Yeutter said in prepared remarks released here. The program was described by Yeutter as ``designed to improve coordination among USDA's broad array of water quality programs, and encourage voluntary adoption of agricultural practices'' to improve and protect water supplies. As part of the plan, Yeutter said the department will put Soil Conservation Service and Extension employees from all county offices through ``an intensive training course in methods of preserving water quality.'' Also, he said, many USDA field guides are being ``rewritten to help farmers keep agricultural chemicals out of the water.'' Yeutter, as he has been doing recently, criticized Congress for including higher price supports in farm bills passed by the House and Senate. Conferees are trying to work out differences. But Yeutter has been complaining that some of the market-oriented policies and flexibility of the 1985 law have been abandoned or altered in ways that could hurt farmers in the long run. ``Though Congress is trying to label this new legislation as being farmer-friendly, it looks to us, and to America's farmers, more like Nightmare on Elm Street, Part II, where the heart of America's farm economy could once again be handed to our competitors on a silver platter,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Planes Land in Jordan, Iraq Plans New Round of Rationing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Jordan announcing would abide by U.N. air embargo, U.S. helicopter lands short of carrier in Red Sea, all 17 aboard rescued unharmed. Pickup 5th pvs, `The world...' with minor editing to trim thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With PM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Three Iraqi passenger planes landed today in the Jordanian capital, raising questions about Jordan's support for a new U.N. air embargo against Iraq. Baghdad criticized Washington and Moscow for their role in the U.N. crackdown. The Iraqi planes landing in Amman carried passengers, and it was not known what their cargo holds contained. The planes all returned to Baghdad. But Jordan later today announced it would abide by the U.N. embargo and halt all mercy flights of foreign nationals from Iraq and Kuwait. Foreign Minister Marwan Kasim said in a statement at the United Nations, ``Jordan has continued to allow a minimum number of flights by the Iraqi Airways, due to humanitarian considerations, facilitating the movement of foreign nationals from Iraq and Kuwait.'' ``However, those flights will now be terminated in accordance with Security Council Resolution 670,'' said Kasim, who also is deputy prime minister. In another development, a U.S. carrier-based helicopter carrying 17 sailors was forced to make an emergency landing this morning in the Red Sea, the Navy said. The sailors were all rescued unharmed. The SH-3H Sea King helicopter landed about 5,000 yards from the USS John F. Kennedy, the Navy said in a statement. The anti-submarine chopper was on a routine training mission, the Navy said. Such copters are sometimes used for minesweeping runs but the statement did not identify the training mission and Navy officials were not immediately available for comment. Earlier today, Jordan said Iraqi passenger aircraft were not included in the resolution approved Tuesday by the U.N. Security Council. A Jordanian Cabinet minister said inspections of the Iraqi aircraft began with the third flight today, and a senior aviation official said the U.N. or other officials were free to check the Iraqi cargo holds. The U.N. resolution does not mention passenger planes but says that all planes traveling to and from Iraq should be checked to make sure they are not carrying cargo prohibited by the U.N. trade sanctions. The resolution prohibits the use of force to stop planes, but allows for the detention of aircraft. The world body, in its ninth resolution against Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, also reaffirmed its embargo against Iraqi shipping and the freezing of Iraqi assets overseas to try to force Iraq to withdraw. The United States and Soviet Union both indicated U.N. military action could be in store unless Iraq pulls out. War ``is not a desirable option, but it is one of the options contained in the U.N. Charter,'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told the world body on Tuesday. Iraq's ambassador, Abdul Al-Anbari, called the U.N. actions ``an act of war.'' The official Iraq News Agency today accused the Soviet Union - a former ally - of being bribed by the United States and gulf sheiks. ``We tell Shevardnadze, if you are not concerned about the relations of friendship with the Arabs and want to be dragged into the alliance of American hostility, then the Arabs will not be concerned about the likes of you,'' the news agency said. Baghdad radio denounced the air embargo today and said it was imposed ``on the directives of the hostile policy'' of President Bush. Iraqi officials today announced more food rationing starting this weekend because of the U.N. embargo. Trade and Finance Minister Mohammed Mahdi Saleh said the rationing will include rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar and tea. The lack of prospects for resolution of the nearly 8-week-old crisis led to a 4.75 percent fall this morning on the Tokyo stock exchange, which has dropped 28 percent since Iraq's invasion. Oil prices, which have nearly doubled following the invasion, were trading lower on the New York futures market this morning, with light sweet crude down 28 cents to $37.25 per barrel on contracts for November delivery. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today there is an increasing likelihood that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein will lash out with military force to try to break the U.N. embargo. ``We may have seen in the last 48 or 72 hours the beginning commentary from him that would indicate that the sanctions are beginning to bite,'' Cheney told a conference of economists in Washington. His comments followed Saddam's videotaped message to Americans, broadcast Tuesday and today, that said U.S. gulf forces faced the prospect of bigger losses than those suffered in the Vietnam War. The Defense Department reported Tuesday that about 430,000 Iraqi soldiers are now in southern Iraq and Kuwait, up from 360,000 last week. The U.S. aircraft carrier Independence and its 70 attack jets will soon join other warships in the gulf in a show of force, a U.S. military source in the gulf said today. It would be the first U.S. carrier in the gulf since 1974. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, declined to say when the 1,000-foot Independence would sail in from the Arabian Sea. The Pentagon declined to comment. Officials concerned about vulnerability had been reluctant to send a carrier into the gulf, whose entrance is the narrow Strait of Hormuz. About 165,000 U.S. soldiers are stationed in the Saudi desert and aboard ships in the region. Thousands of Arab and European troops have also been deployed as part of the U.S.-led, multinational force. U.S. Marines defending Saudi oilfields were told by their commander today to expect a long desert stay. Gen. Alfred Gray also said the Marines should be prepared to shift to offense if Saudi Arabia is attacked. Jordan joined Egypt today in saying it will abide by the Security Council resolution calling for an embargo on the aircraft of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. However, three regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flights arrived in Amman from Baghdad today. The first carried 185 people aboard - including 11 British women and children. The two flights that landed later this morning and this afternoon also carried Westerners. Jordanian officials said they were checking on details of the U.N. resolution. ``According to our initial studying of the resolution, we understand that it does not bar human traffic,'' said a Cabinet minister on condition of anonymity. Jordan has been criticized by Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations for being reluctant to support international efforts against Iraq. The Security Council resolution passed 14-1 on Tuesday, with Cuba the only country voting no. In an unusual move intended to give symbolic weight to the resolution, 13 of the 15 countries represented on the Security Council sent their foreign ministers to cast their countries' vote. Ordinarily, countries allow their ambassadors at the United Nations to cast their votes. Only a few supplies have been flown in to Baghdad since the invasion, according to Western officials. The Security Council already has authorized military enforcement of a sea embargo. The air embargo is largely symbolic, since most trade with Iraq is by land and has already been halted. Iraq's only major export is oil. Iraq has sought a way around the embargo by seeking better relations with Iran - its bitter foe in the 1980-88 war - and reportedly attempted to exchange oil for food. Syrian President Hafez Assad reportedly failed during his visit to Tehran this week to persuade the Iranians not to ship supplies to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Rating System May Get New `NC' Rating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMer planned
DOC.TEXT: A new ``NC-17'' movie rating, barring children under 17, will be announced soon by the Motion Picture Association of America in response to the controversy over the X rating, sources said Wednesday. The new rating will prevent children from attending films judged by the MPAA ratings board to be harsher than an R rating, but will carry none of the advertising and exhibition restraints that an X rating guarantees. A spokeswoman for the association was not immediately available for comment. The association said a news conference was scheduled for Wednesday afternoon in New York City. Movies that have been given an X rating can be resubmitted for the NC-17 rating, said one source familiar with the MPAA's decision. The new NC rating will be copyrighted, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The X rating is not copyrighted and is used widely by the adult movie industry. Critics charge the X rating is synonymous with pornography. In recent months, the X rating has been given to a variety of critically acclaimed films, including ``Henry & June'' from Universal Pictures and ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' a Miramax release from Oscar-nominated director Pedro Almodovar. Film companies say X ratings bar them from placing advertisements in newspapers and on radio and television stations. Many theater chains also refuse to show pictures bearing that rating. The last time the ratings were changed was in 1984, when the PG-13 rating was added between the PG and R ratings. One source said the MPAA hopes to call the rating simply NC, but is unsure if that can be copyrighted.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Investigating Franklin Indicts Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Shortly after ...' to CORRECT year of failure to 1988 sted '89; ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury investigating a failed credit union returned two indictments today and concluded that stories of sexual abuse and drug trafficking that arose after the credit union closed were unfounded. Alisha Owen, who testified before a legislative committee that she was a victim of sexual abuse, was indicted on eight counts of perjury. A one-count indictment alleging bank fraud was returned against Sandra Prucha, an assistant to the manager and treasurer of Franklin Community Federal Credit Union. The grand jury issued a three-page report that said it found no credible evidence that any prominent individuals in Omaha were involved in ``any ring of organized activity to sexually exploit minors, transport minors in interstate commerce for sexual purposes, or to traffic in controlled substances.'' Shortly after the Franklin failed in November 1988, allegations of sexualabuse of children and drug abuse among widely known Omaha residents circulated in the community. The grand jury is the same one that issued indictments last year against Lawrence E. King Jr., former manager of Franklin. King, a prominent businessman who sang the national anthem at the 1984 Republican National Convention, is awaiting trial in U.S. District Court on 40 counts charging conspiracy, fraud and filing false tax returns in connection with the November 1988 failure of Franklin. King's wife, Alice, is charged with 12 counts of conspiracy and fraud. The National Credit Union Administration also has filed lawsuits against the Kings seeking to recover some of the $39 million it says was missing from the credit union. The federal grand jury spent 24 months investigating the credit union's failure. U.S. Attorney Ron Lahners declined to comment on the grand jury's report. The federal grand jury today indicted Ms. Owen, 21, for statements she made to the federal grand jury in June. In July, a Douglas County grand jury indicted Ms. Owen on eight counts of perjury for testimony she gave to the grand jury in the state court system. The Douglas County grand jury had said a story of sexual abuse and prostitution told to a legislative committee was ``a carefully crafted hoax.'' The bank fraud charge against Ms. Prucha, 47, alleges that she used expense vouchers to obtain cash and credit, then used the cash and credit for her personal use, Lahners said. The indictment alleges that about $29,000 was involved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Ignore Singh's Plea for Talks, Violence Continues
DOC.TEXT: Students ignored Prime Minister V.P. Singh's offer for talks, and riots spread across northern India on Wednesday in protest of a policy that reserves nearly half of the government's jobs for low-caste Hindus. Police shot and killed seven people in three northern Indian cities, including New Delhi, and imposed a curfew on 10 towns. The army was ordered into several neighborhoods in the capital after protesters clashed with police for the second day. In a continuing wave of protest suicides, a student doused himself with gasoline near New Delhi's police headquarters and lighted a match, inflicting burns over half his body before he was taken to hospital. Singh said he would rather resign than retract his new job policy. ``I cannot barter away the aspirations of the deprived simply to retain my chair,'' he said in a statement. Later, in a speech read on state-run television and radio, he said: ``Nothing has caused me more profound anguish than the decision of some young students to immolate themselves.'' ``I am prepared to take any step consistent with the basic need for social justice to dispel the fears and mollify the feelings of those sections of youth who are apprehensive about their future,'' he said. Singh appealed to students for talks on Tuesday. But a students group leading the protests said Wednesday it would not talk until Singh abandoned the job quotas. They say the policy amounts to reverse discrimination. Wednesday's deaths brought to 34 the number of people killed in suicides and clashes with police since Singh announced the affirmative action program on Aug. 7. The violence escalated on Tuesday after a student died of self-immolation. About 20 more have tried to burn themselves to death. The violence spread to middle-class neighborhoods of New Delhi where residents, including women and children, joined the students in shouting anti-government slogans. Police opened fire in an eastern suburb to quell a mob that surrounded a police station and burned at least four vehicles, news reports said. Press Trust of India said a 22-year-old youth was killed and five other people were injured in the gunfire. Police shot and killed four demonstrators and wounded 25 others in Modinagar, 55 miles west of New Delhi, United News of India reported. Two people were killed in police gunfire in Jammu, 240 miles north of the capital after mobs of upper-caste Hindus took to streets, local government officials said. The protesters damaged at least 100 government vehicles, set fire to 18 other vehicles and set ablaze a government revenue office, a state-run department store and a bank, they said. Upper-caste Hindus say the job policy will ignore educational merit and deprive qualified students of their share of the government's 18 million jobs. The government says the policy will balance the centuries-old inequities the rigid Hindu caste system has imposed on the generally poorer and less educated low castes. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people and are divided into four major heriditary castes that assign a person's social standing and often the economic position. But upper-caste students maintain that many low-caste Hindu have risen above economic deprivation and do not need affirmative action programs. The opponents also call the policy a move to garner votes from the low-castes, who form a majority of Indian voters.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to correct category code
Folk Artists Honored by NEA
DOC.TEXT: Kevin Locke said Wednesday that he's trying to preserve an ancient Sioux tradition - the courting flute. The 36-year-old musician, storyteller and Plains hoop dancer, is one of 13 folk artists receiving $5,000 awards this year from the National Endowment for the Arts for their success in preserving the nation's heritage. The artists - including a mariachi band, a Michigan accordionist, a cowboy poet from Montana and a Hawaiian lei maker - gathered for a congressional reception at a Senate office building. They were selected from 197 people nominated for the national grant by their peers. The NEA has been making the awards since 1982. ``America's deep and varied traditional heritage is one of this nation's greatest treasures,'' said NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer. Locke carried the flute, a long wooden recorder fashioned from cedar with the mouthpiece made into the head of a bird, wrapped in cloth in a long leather tube slung across his shoulder. Locke was raised on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation in South Dakota by an elderly uncle who spoke only Lakota and learned the traditional courting songs from elders. By the 1960s, the tradition of the Plains and Woodlands Indian courting flute had been all but lost as the last musicians with the skill died off without passing it to a new generation. ``It is an important role,'' said Locke, who's working on a doctoral degree in education at the University of South Dakota. ``I see that they are a bridge between our ancestors and the people of today.'' The other artists honored were: Howard Armstrong, an Afro-American string band musician in Detroit; Natividad Cano, a mariachi musician from Monterey Park, Calif.; Giuseppe and Raffaela DeFranco, southern Italian musicians and dancers from Belleville, N.J.; Bun Em, a Cambodian silk weaver from Harrisburg, Pa.; Maude Kegg, an Indian beadworker from Onamia, Minn.; Marie McDonald, the lei maker from Waimea, Hawaii; cowboy poet Wallace McRae from Forsyth, Mont.; Art Moilanen, a Finnish accordionist from Mass City, Mich.; woodcarver Emilio Rosado from Utuado, Puerto Rico; Robert Spicer, a Dickson, Tenn., square dancer; and Doug Wallin, a Marshall, N.C., ballad singer.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, 70 Other World Leaders Attending Children's Summit
DOC.TEXT: Children are dying from abuse, neglect and disease at a rate of 40,000 a day worldwide, the head of the U.N. Children's Fund said Wednesday in a bid to raise awareness of the plight of the young. This weekend, President Bush and about 70 other heads of state or government will gather for a summit at U.N. Headquarters to adopt a declaration placing children foremost among their national priorities. James Grant, head of the U.N. Children's Fund, said the declaration ``will be seen as marking a historic transformation in the way the world deals with the children.'' ``We have always, in all our religions and cultures, given children a first call on the resources of the family,'' Grant said. ``But what is happening now is an extension of this concept to the responsibilities of the nation-state to support the family.'' The U.N. General Assembly adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child last November. Grant said that as of Wednesday, 43 nations had signed and then ratified the convention. Ratifying nations must guarantee the survival of children, their protection and development. More than 100 countries have signed on, indicating their intention to have their legislatures ratify the convention, Grant said. The United States has done neither. Conservatives in Congress have criticized the convention because it forbids the death penalty for people younger than 18, and because it does not define a fetus as a child and thus give it special protections. World leaders will meet Sunday to debate the needs of children, then adopt the declaration and an accompanying action plan. The plan calls for a one-third reduction in infant mortality by the end of the decade; access for all couples to family planning information and services; prenatal care for all pregnant women; reduction in the rate of low birth weight to below 10 percent; a 95 percent reduction in measles deaths; and immunization of 90 percent of young children against childhood diseases. Grant said ``40,000 children die every day, two-thirds of them from largely preventable causes, such as from not being vaccinated against six killer diseases or the dehydration from diarrhea, for which we now have a low-cost remedy.'' The six deadly childhood diseases are diarrheal disease, malaria, tetanus, whooping cough, measles, and respiratory infections. The other third of the deaths are caused by neglect, abuse, war, poverty, starvation, and diseases for which there is no known cure, such as AIDS. ``In 1988, 250,000 civilians died in southern Sudan because of civil war, with the great majority of those being children,'' Grant said. ``Civil conflict, the problems in the front-line states, like Mozambique and Angola, all of these contribute. ``But what's clear is that two-thirds of the child deaths we have today are from readily preventable causes.'' Leaders expected to attend the weekend U.N. summit include Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. The meeting will cost $3 million, all or most of which is being paid by donations from governments, private organizations and individuals, Grant said.

DOC.HEAD: Dating Services Not Amused by Bank Ads Comparing Singles to Zeros
DOC.TEXT: A man who matches singles for a living isn't amused by a bank's light-hearted ad slogan, ``We handle more zeros than a dating service.'' Jeffrey Ullman, president of the Encino-based Great Expectations dating service, led a protest Tuesday outside Santa Monica Bank, urging customers to close their accounts. ``Since Santa Monica Bank believes that single people are zeros, we're asking all people, single and married, to reduce their bank accounts to zero,'' said Ullman. He was joined by about three dozen protesters, including executives of two other dating services. Officials of the eight-branch bank wouldn't comment, referring questions to their ad agency, Team One Advertising. ``It's a little bit of humor that's meant to bring a smile, not an attack by dating services,'' said Pat Robertson, vice president of account services. ``We're just playing on zeros in terms of monetary sums. ``It's just a comment on contemporary society that we've all had a zero date.'' Robertson added that the slogan will be replaced at the end of the month, but not because of pressure from the dating services. ``We change them every month. We take a generic term on society and have a little tongue in cheek with no attempt to be mean-spirited,'' she said. Last month's ad, for instance, poked fun at the materialistic side of society. It stated: ``Money isn't everything (Yeah right).''

DOC.HEAD: US, Peru Fail To Agree On Military Aid To Fight Drug Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Efforts by the United States and Peru to agree on terms for a military aid program to fight drug smuggling have broken down, the State Department said Wednesday. As a result, Peru must forego $35.9 million in aid, which will be earmarked instead for Bolivia and Colombia, said deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. The two countries were unable to overcome their differences in advance of the weekend deadline imposed by the United States. The deadline coincides with the end of the U.S. fiscal year. Boucher said the U.S. and Peruvian governments have stated that the drug problem is of ``vital importance to both our countries, and we will continue to work together to solve it.'' But the Washington Post, quoting unnamed officials, said Peruvian negotiators had acted in bad faith. One official said the Bush administration was going to ``seriously reexamine'' its relations with Peru with respect to drugs,'' according to the Post. Boucher said the opinion expressed in the Post was not an official view. The aid package was to have been used as part of overall plan to encourage Peru to step up its efforts to curb drug smuggling. Peru is a major source of coca leaf, from which cocaine is made.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Restores Provincial Assembly, Move Supports Bhutto Comeback Bid
DOC.TEXT: A six-judge panel restored one of Pakistan's four provincial assemblies Wednesday, reversing an order by the army-backed caretaker government that ousted prime minister Benazir Bhutto. The decision to reopen the Northwest Frontier Province assembly, reported by Pakistan's official news agency, bolstered Ms. Bhutto's attempt to win back her post. Hundreds of police surrounded the provincial assembly building in Peshawar, a dusty city on the border with Afghanistan. The caretaker government immediately appealed the Peshawar High Court decision, and a Bhutto supporter said the Supreme Court justice barred the restoration until the appeal is decided. Bhutto supporters were angered by the quick Supreme Court move barring the legislature from reopening. ``I didn't think they could do this, it would look so bad,'' said Amna Piracha, a lawyer and a former member in Ms. Bhutto's government. ``The message I got today ... was that the constitution and law are not respected by this caretaker government,'' said Iftikar Gailani, Ms. Bhutto's former law minister and lawyer for the ousted provincial assembly Gailani demanded the resignation of the caretaker government in Northwest Frontier Province. ``Morally and constitutionally they do not exist. The government should resign,'' he told a news conference in the capital of Islamabad. Bhutto supporters also expected the lower court decision would strengthen Ms. Bhutto's case against President Ishaq Khan, who used his constitutional powers Aug. 6 to dismiss Pakistan's National Assembly, or powerful lawmaking lower house of Parliament. Parliament's dismissal ousted Ms. Bhutto from her job as prime minister. ``The Peshawar decision is a real psychological boos,'' Piracha said. ``It clouds all the dissolution orders.'' A spokesman for the army-backed caretaker government, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said each dismissal order will have to be decided individually. The provincial assembly, governed by Ms. Bhutto's left-of-center Pakistan People's Party, was dismissed within hours of the National Assembly. Governors of the Northwest Frontier Province and Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sindh ordered the dismissial of the provincial legislatures. Ishaq Khan sacked Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government on charges of rampaging corruption, political ineptitude and nepotism. No reasons were reportedly given for the sacking of the provincial governments. Ms. Bhutto, who was campaigning in the southern Sindh for general elections later this year, was not immediately available for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Student Performance Low and Stagnant Last 20 Years
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year summary of the nation's educational achievements released Wednesday by the Education Department shows student performance is low and not improving. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos described the report by the National Assessment of Educational Progress - popularly called the Nation's Report Card - as ``a compendium of disappointment'' and as ``a guide for corrective action.'' Cavazos stressed that the study revealed significant discrepancies between what researchers indicate is most effective in improving educational performance and what students report about activities in the classroom and at home. The report includes data from reading, writing, mathematics, science, U.S. history, civics and geography assessments conducted in 1986 and 1988 and trend results by the congressionally mandated project over the last two decades. Most of the data show that ``our present education performance is low and not improving.'' Top educators called for radical changes in the way education takes place in America, and less talk and fewer studies from policymakers. ``The report clearly shows the recent rhetoric from the bully pulpit has had a zero effort on student achievement,'' said Gordon Cawletti, executive director of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum. Key findings of the report were: -Students can read at a surface level, getting the gist of material, but do not read analytically or perform well on challenging reading assignments. -Few students write well enough to accomplish the purposes of different writing tasks, and most do not communicate effectively. -Students' grasp of the four basic arithmetic operations and beginning problem solving is far from universal in elementary and junior high school; by the time students near high-school graduation, half cannot handle moderately challenging material. -Only small proportions of students appear to develop specialized knowledge needed to address science-based problems, and the pattern for falling behind begins in elementary school. -Students demonstrate an uneven understanding of the Constitution and American government and politics; their knowledge of the Bill of Rights is limited. The study, released one day before the first anniversary of the Education Summit that resulted in the six national education goals, also showed that the performance gap between white and minority students has remained large, even though there is some improvement by black and Hispanic students.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Face Tuition Woes at Private Kindergartens, Too
With AM-College Costs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The $20,000-plus pricetag at top-flight colleges may be daunting to some, but consider the parents trying to scrape together tuition for some of the nation's pricier private kindergartens. The Dalton School in New York City charges each of its 80 kindergartners $10,380 this fall, compared with $9,600 last year. At Beverly Hills Montessori School, in Beverly Hills, Calif., there are 10 children in kindergarten, each paying $405 a month. Last year's rate was about $380. Tuition at the Latin School of Chicago for the 63 youngsters attending half-day kindergarten is $5,750. Tuition last year was $4,615. In Dallas, White Rock North School costs $265 a month this year, up from $250 last year. Enrollment is at 80, same as a year ago. Hillcrest Private School, also in Dallas, charges $365 a month this year, up from $350. It enrolls eight youngsters. The Brearley School in New York costs each of its 45 kindergarten girls $8,300, up from $7,900 last year. Cape Cod Academy in Osterville, Mass., charges kindergarten-through-6th-graders $7,050, up from $6,750 a year earlier. Of course, some 3.1 million other children around the country attend public kindergarten for free - not counting taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Bahrainis Change The Names Of Sons Called Saddam
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least two Bahraini families have won court approval to change the names of sons named after Iraq's Saddam Hussein, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The daily Akhbar Al-Khaleej said one child was renamed Ibrahim and another Khalaf at the request of the parents. Some children were named Saddam when he was widely regarded as an Arab hero in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. However, after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, many Persian Gulf Arabs felt the name Saddam ``has become a synonym of disgust and anger,'' the paper said. ``So a number of citizens have sought legal measures to change names of children named after the despot,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Missing Man Captivates City, Ends Tragically
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: For one week the plight of Earl Hutchins, an inner city family's partiarch who disappeared while suffering from Alzheimer's disease, unified residents of a crime-torn neighborhood. And though the community's search ended tragically - Hutchins' body was found Tuesday in a harbor - neighbors hope their effort may have a lasting effect by forging a new unity in Milwaukee's inner city. ``It was a very large search,'' Moses Jordan said. ``It got together very quickly. That was the first time something happened - that I remember - like this.'' The 79-year-old Hutchins, robbed of his memory by the disease, disappeared from his north side home Sept. 19. His family immediately began distributing fliers and organizing search parties. By Friday, more than 100 volunteers had been enlisted in the search, which spread to suburban areas. Several members of Alderman Michael McGee's Black Panther Militia, a group formed this year to force change through the threat of violence, led the effort. ``The Hutchins are an old family in Milwaukee,'' said Jerrel Jones, a black community leader and spokesman for McGee. ``They have millions of relatives. It was like a family member of the community being lost.'' McGee has promised to use his group beginning in 1995 to stage violent, terrorist attacks if conditions for blacks - most of whom live in impoverished neighborhoods on Milwaukee's north side - don't improve. While much of the attention on the inner city this year has focused on a drastic increase in violent crime - Milwaukee set a new homicide record Tuesday with 116 killings - the search for Hutchins demonstrated a more important trend, Jones said. ``There's a growing unity in the community,'' Jones said. ``That (search) enhanced it because it was an issue everybody could agree on.'' Police were also impressed by the community effort. ``We were really pushing to find this man because of his illness and his age,'' Inspector Ronald Mehl said. ``We didn't want him wandering the streets because, as you know, we do have some problems on our streets. ``We definitely appreciate all the help. ... It's the first time I can remember when that many people were involved.'' The search ended Tuesday when Hutchins' body was found in the Milwaukee harbor, miles away from his home. An autopsy was being conducted Wednesday and police refused to speculate whether foul play was involved. ``I wanted a different ending,'' said one of Hutchins' five daughters, 49-year-old Maxine Jeter. ``We were planning a big reception - planning to invite all these people who helped - when daddy came home.'' Posters had been distributed throughout the city, radio and television statons broadcast information about the search and a Milwaukee office supply store had donated 20,000 fliers. Hundreds of volunteers canvassed neighborhoods looking for any trace of the man. And although the search ended, mystery remains as to why Hutchins left home. Was he a victim of crime or confused? ``That's what got me,'' said Jordan, 70, a longtime friend of Hutchins. ``He had a lovely family. Two boys and five girls. He was well thought of. He will be missed, too.'' While police unravel the mystery, Hutchins' family can at least relish the outpouring of friendship from their community. ``We're so proud of the media and all the cooperation we've received,'' said Shirley Warren, 51, another daughter. ``We're proud to be Milwaukeeans.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Returns Home to Criticism on Both Sides
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk flew home Wednesday with support from President Bush for his efforts to end apartheid, but South African politicians criticized his U.S. trip. De Klerk was to arrive Wednesday night to a festive welcome at Jan Smuts International Airport. During de Klerk's three-day trip to Washington, President Bush praised him for what he called South Africa's ``irreversible'' progress toward creating a non-racial democracy. Bush, however, said South Africa still must free all political prisoners and eliminate the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance before economic sanctions could be lifted. South African political leaders from opposing sides criticized aspects of de Klerk's trip. African National Congress spokesman Thebo Mbeki said U.S. officials were wrong in calling progress toward ending apartheid irreversible. He said sanctions should be continued. ``Sanctions have been an important element in bringing us to where we are now,'' Mbeki said in a speech at the University of Pretoria. ``I won't contest that de Klerk is irreversibly committed to change. This does not mean the process itself is irreversible.'' Andries Treurnicht, head of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, said de Klerk humiliated South African whites by bowing to U.S. pressure to change. He said Bush's conditions for ending sanctions were uncalled for. ``In other words, further humiliation and concessions are demanded before the great America would be satisfied,'' Treurnicht said. ``This is not the way to treat a sovereign state such as South Africa.'' The Conservative Party advocates continued white dominance and rejects de Klerk's moves toward negotiating power sharing with the black majority. The white-led government and the ANC began peace talks in May aimed at full-blown negotiations on a new constitution. Winnie Mandela, wife of ANC leader Nelson Mandela, told a business group Wednesday night that South Africa needed a growing economy to smooth the transition of political change. Her comments were conciliatory compared with recent statements to black groups in which she said armed struggle remained a possibility if negotiations failed. Vicious street fighting between black factions in townships around Johannesburg has strained relations between the government and the ANC, the nations' largest black opposition movement. About 800 blacks have been killed since Aug. 12 in warfare pitting Xhosas and other ANC supporters against Zulus linked to the conservative Inkatha movement. The violence has eased recently following periods in which dozens of blacks died daily. Police imposed a 9 p.m.-to-4 a.m. curfew Tuesday night in some of the most turbulent townships. Black leaders criticized the curfew as a violation of rights, and some groups called for supporters to defy it. No incidents were reported. Residents who provide written proof of nighttime employment or ticket stubs to concerts, movies and soccer games are exempt. Police said journalists covering the curfew also must provide written proof of employment. In other developments, police began an investigation into the deaths of seven people whose bodies were found Monday along railroad tracks between Johannesburg and Soweto township. Police Col. Frans Malherbe said the deaths occurred during a panic created by a false alarm that the train was under attack. He said ``criminal elements'' spread the attack rumor in order to steal passengers' belongings in the confusion. Attacks on trains in the Johannesburg area have killed more than two dozen people in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Workers Refuse to Hand Over Privatized Busineses
LaserPhotos MGA-1,2
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista workers on Wednesday refused to surrender four of the 16 businesses the conservative government had returned to pre-revolutionary owners. Workers at the El Caracol food processing plant said they refused to let Magelda Campos inside when she showed up with a government order granting her ownership. ``She left this enterprise in shreds, never giving a thought to the workers, and we have struggled to make it productive again,'' said Ronaldo Rodriguez, local secretary general of the Sandinista National Workers Front. He said workers want the government to give El Caracol to them. The plant has 130 employees. The Sandinistas confiscated hundreds of private businesses including restaurants, car dealerships and factories during more than a decade of revolutionary rule that ended with their defeat in the Feb. 25 elections. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's government inherited about 400 state enterprises when it took office on April 25, and she promised to privatize the economy. Mrs. Chamorro, who flew to New York on Wednesday to address the United Nations during the General Assembly's annual session, said Sandinista unrest would not stop her from returning Nicaragua to a free enterprise economy. In a televised speech Tuesday night, she accused the Sandinistas of staging ``a new sabotage attempt'' against her government. ``I will not allow it,'' she said. After their electoral defeat, the Sandinistas vowed to ``govern from below'' and block any attempts by the Chamorro government to dismantle their leftist state. Sandinista workers paralyzed Managua in May and again in July with strikes. Spokesmen for workers at the Camas Lunas bed factory and the Sovipe small appliance plant in Managua and the Prego soap plant in Grenada, 30 miles away, also said they would not hand over their factories. ``The return of this enterprise was done only on paper; we are not going to return anything,'' said Brenda Escoto, the local union leader at Camas Lunas, which has 80 workers. A Sovipe worker told the conservative Radio Corp. station that not all her co-workers were opposed to privatization. ``But Sandinistas wielding sticks chased out other workers who opposed the takeover of the enterprise,'' said the woman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Meanwhile, about 1,000 people marched to the government complex to protest rumored layoffs of 9,000 educators nationwide. The government has denied the rumors. The demonstration was peaceful apart from a few attempts to break through the police cordon at the government complex, where more than 2,000 officers were on hand. Education Minister Sofonias Cisneros had denied the layoff rumors Monday and blamed ``extremists'' - a reference to the Sandinistas - for circulating them. He said more than 600 new teachers had been hired since Mrs. Chamorro took office.

DOC.HEAD: Quest to Solve Mystery of Missing Fliers Plagued by Doubters
DOC.TEXT: A former air traffic controller is positive he has unraveled the secret of Flight 19, five Navy torpedo bombers that vanished in 1945 and fed the Bermuda Triangle legend, but getting proof is going to be expensive. Jon Myhre's solution was videotaped for a segment on NBC-TV's ``Unsolved Mysteries'' on Wednesday. But doubters include the Navy, Smithsonian Institution, six publishers who rejected his book manuscript and People magazine, which held Myhre's story after buying exclusive rights to his account. ``I've given it my best shot. I've done everything I can do,'' said Myhre, of Lantana, who has spent his life savings of more than $100,000 to plot and pursue Flight 19's five Grumman TBM Avenger torpedo bombers. ``I know I'm right. I'm just not in a position to prove it.'' Myhre has videotape, shot from a mini-submarine in July, of an upside-down Avenger sitting in 390 feet of water about 35 miles off Cape Canaveral, but he doesn't have its serial number. The plane, just 2{ miles from where Myhre predicted Flight 19 went down, was originally spotted during the search for debris from the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, but it was ignored then. Flight 19's disappearance became part of the legend of the Bermuda Triangle, an area where ships and planes supposedly disappear under mysterious circumstances involving UFOs, magnetic fields and other such phenomena. Flight 19 even figured in ``Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' in which first the planes and then the men were returned by aliens. Myhre's answer to the puzzle came with a flash eight years ago when he read the final radio transmissions from the warplanes, which took off from Fort Lauderdale for a training flight over parts of the Bahamas on Dec. 5, 1945. The squadron leader's reported that both of his compasses were out of order. At one point, the squadron leader plotted a northeasterly course based on the assumption he had somehow reached the Florida Keys, on the opposite side of Florida. Myhre thinks that was part of the Bahamas' Abacos chain. At another point he reported he was over an island and no other land was visible. Myhre, who has flown the region for years, believes that was isolated Walker's Cay. By re-plotting the flight from Walker's Cay, using the Navy transcriptions of the flight's radio reports, Myhre came up ith a location where he thought Flight 19, its planes out of fuel, may have ended. The spot was east of Cape Canaveral. The Avenger he filmed was found 2{ miles away. Myhre learned of the plane spotted during the Challenger search from news reports. This summer, with $25,000 raised by two partners, he hired a small research submarine and located the wreckage. He was unable to locate a complete aircraft serial number on the upside down wreck. Footage of the Avenger shows the last three digits - 209 - of a five-digit Navy service number on the left wingtip. Flight 19's lead airplane number was 73209, and Navy records show only two other Grumman TBM Avengers with service numbers ending in 209, and neither was lost at sea. ``The only thing we didn't get was a positive ID on the plane's serial number,'' Myhre said, but raising the Avenger could cost $250,000. The plane's landing gear is extended, leading some to suggest that plane was lost while trying to land on an aircraft carrier instead of the squadron's suspected ditch. But Myhre insists he has the right plane and knows where the others are. ``The other planes are further north in much deeper water, I'm certain,'' he said. ``This was just the first to ditch. And the tragic thing about it is he was only about seven minutes from land. If they'd just kept going west ...''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Identifies 83 Potential Leaks on Columbia
DOC.TEXT: A NASA investigative team has identified 83 potential sources of Columbia's dangerous hydrogen leaks, and exhaustive testing is expected to pinpoint the problem, the space agency said Wednesday. The list of suspect parts was narrowed to 83 during an analysis of Columbia's engine compartment, said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. Hydrogen flooded the section during fueling last week, thwarting NASA's fourth attempt to send the shuttle on an astronomy mission. ``Any combination might actually be the culprit,'' Lenoir said. Workers will remove insulation from each suspected part and then flush helium through the system, Lenoir said. If no leaks are found, the process will be repeated with a different crew and equipment ``to try to be absolutely sure we haven't missed anything,'' he said. If helium does escape, the test will be repeated in an attempt to ``really understand what that's telling me at that joint so I can maybe make some correlations for the future,'' Lenoir said. So far, Columbia's leaks have appeared only when the shuttle's external tank is filled with highly flammable liquid hydrogen at super-cold temperatures, which might cause shrinkage of a metal part and form the leak. The non-flammable helium normally used in testing is room temperature. ``We know from our previous experience that our helium test has not found some of these leaks we thought it should have, and we want to know why,'' Lenoir said. The external tank will be filled with liquid hydrogen for a special fueling test around mid-October, after Discovery's upcoming flight. Discovery is scheduled to lift off Oct. 6 with a satellite that will study the sun's polar regions. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to perform a second tanking test on Columbia in November to see if all of the leaks have been plugged. About a dozen TV cameras will be placed inside the engine compartment for both tests. ``I'm hopeful we will have gone through this entire sequence and have Columbia back in a flying sequence'' in December, Lenoir said. ``We have specifically not laid that onto our engineering team. They're not driven by schedule. They are to go out and find the leak, find all of the leaks, and then we can get on with it.'' NASA plans no tanking test for Discovery, the only shuttle in which hydrogen leaks have not been found. Such a check would take five days. A tanking test will be performed on Atlantis before its early November flight. Hydrogen leaks were detected in fuel lines between the orbiter and its external tank during a similar test in late June.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troop Withdrawal Ahead of Schedule
DOC.TEXT: More than half the Soviet troops stationed in Czechoslovakia since the Red Army crushed the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reform movement have returned home, a military official said Wednesday. Gen. Svetozar Nadovic, a Czechoslovak coordinator of the troop withdrawal, said at least 40,500 soldiers and officers from an estimated force of 73,500 have left, taking with them 800 tanks, 62 aircraft and 57,882 tons of ammunition. By the end of the year, only one Soviet motorized regiment should be left in the nation, he said. ``That means that Czechoslovakia will have full sovereignty by the end of the year - that's encouraging,'' said Svetozar. He said the pullout is ahead of the schedule outlined in a February agreement between Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. That pact foresees a complete Soviet pullout by July 1991. After the Soviets put down Alexander Dubcek's attempts to create ``Socialism with a human face'' in 1968, Moscow kept about 1,220 tanks, 2,505 armored vehicles, 77 combat planes and 146 helicopters in Czechoslovakia. Since revolutions ousted Communist governments across Eastern Europe last year, Soviet troops began leaving other Warsaw Pact nations such as Hungary and East Germany, which Monday formally announced its withdrawal from the alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Rappers Perform Benefit for Injured Soul Singer Curtis Mayfield
DOC.TEXT: A thousand people turned out for a benefit by rap music stars for soul singer Curtis Mayfield, who was seriously injured in a stage accident last month. Rappers such as Tone Loc and Ice-T joined in the benefit at the Palace nightclub in Hollywood on Tuesday night. The event raised $25,000 for Mayfield, who is paralyzed from the neck down, Capitol Records said Wednesday. Mayfield was about to appear in concert on Aug. 13 in New York City when a gust blew a light scaffold down on him. Tone Loc and Ice-T said they were greatly influenced by Mayfield's 1972 ``Superfly'' soundtrack and expressed hope that he would ``stay strong.'' The concert also starred rappers Eazy E, Mellow Man Ace, the Uzi$Bros, C.P.O., and King Tee. Most of the artists had joined Mayfield on a new soundtrack album, ``The Return of Superfly,'' released Aug. 21. Tone Loc said every rapper can identify a little with what happened to Mayfield because ``all of us have been on many stages, and this could happen to us.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 9-12 ``Rep. Lee'' etc. with additional comments and poverty threshold
DOC.HEAD: Poverty Rate Unchanged
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau says 31.5 million Americans, or 12.8 percent of the population, lived in poverty last year. That was virtually no improvement over 1988, even as median household income was up slightly because of an unexplained bulge in the income of black households. The poverty rate had previously declined since 1983, when it reached a high of 15.2 percent. In 1988 it was 13 percent, and the bureau said the slight dip to 12.8 percent in 1989 was not statistically significant. Daniel H. Weinberg, chief of the Housing and Household Economic Statistics Division of the bureau, declined to speculate on what the figures for 1990 will show when they become available next year. The report, he said, ``does not tell us anything about the current situation.'' However, Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center of Budget and Policy Priorities, a private research group, predicted the poverty rate will go up with the apparent end of the economic recovery of the 1980's. ``Our guess is that 1989 is the end of the trend,'' Greenstein said. ``The likelihood is overwhelming that when the 1990 figures come out, poverty will have started back up.'' ``What struck us were two principal things: no significant progress in reducing poverty and that the gaps between both rich and poor and the wealthy and the middle class hit the widest plane in more than 40 years,'' Greenstein said. ``The share of the national income going to the three-fifths of the families in the middle of the income spectrum was lower in '89 than in any year since Census began collecting those data in '47,'' he said. ``The share going to the poorest fifth was tied for the lowest of any year since '54, while the shares going to the wealthiest fifth and the richest 5 per cent were higher than at any point since 1947.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, commented,``At 12.8 percent, the poverty rate is still very high, especially this far high, especially this far into an economic expansion. And the gap between the rich and the poor is widening, when it should be shrinking.'' Census Bureau standards provide that a family of four making less than $12,675 a year is classified as poor. The standards have come under criticism from both liberals and conservatives. A study released last year by the Joint Economic Committee indicated the poverty threshold might be raised as much as 50 percent if it were adjusted for changes in family needs and spending patterns such as the increase in the share of income taken up by housing costs. Robert Rector, welfare and poverty policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation, said the report ``dramatically overstates the extent of true poverty'' because it does not count non-cash government benefits such as food stamps and Medicaid as income. In an article published Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal, Rector said, ``Evidence is mounting ... that the Census Bureau's poverty report dramatically understates the living standards of low-income Americans.'' In addition to the official poverty rae figure, the bureau released calculations based on other experimental methods that showed different results, some higher and some lower. The official definition of poverty was developed by the Social Security Administration in 1964 based on Department of Agriculture research on what people spend on food. It counts income in money only. By using an experimental formula that counts Medicare, Medicaid, school lunches, food stamps and other benefits, the Census Bureau arrived at a rate of 10.4 percent. Weinberg said substitution of the experimental standards would not change the trend in poverty rates. Greenstein also said, ``Our sense is that the trend is pretty clear, no matter how you measure it.'' The report said Americans' median household income rose 1.3 per cent in 1989, to $28,910, after adjusting for the rise in consumer prices. The increase followed two years in which median income had been unchanged. Black household income was up 5 percent to $18,080, but median incomes in white and Hispanic households did not significantly change. Nor did the median income of black families or that of black men. Weinberg said the bulge for black households, which resulted in the overall increase in median household income, appeared to be the result of gains in income for black professional women living alone or with a roommate. He had no explanation for this, and said it could be the result of an anomaly in the sampling. The report was based on a survey of 58,000 U.S. households in March. It showed that per capita income in 1989 was $14,060, an all-time high. The figure was up 1 percent from 1988, which was also a record. Median household incomes increased in the Northeast and West, but remained unchanged in the South and Midwest. The report did not include state-by-state figures. The median earnings of all women working year around, full-time, increased 1.8 percent to $18,780, while the earnings of men decreased by the same percentage to $27,430. Weinberg said he did not know the reason for this. It brought the ratio of female-to-male median earnings to 68 percent, a record, and up from 66 percent a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Nurse Tells How She Contracted HIV Virus From Patient
DOC.TEXT: One of the first nurses in the nation to contract the AIDS virus from a patient revealed her identity Wednesday, saying she wants to remind all health care workers how important it is to take precautions. ``If this can happen to me, in a small rural hospital in the Midwest in the middle of the night in 1986, it can certainly happen to anybody in 1990,'' Barb Fassbinder told reporters. Also Wednesday, a weekly newspaper in Monona, a small town in northeastern Iowa, published a letter from the former nurse explaining how she contracted the human immunodeficiency virus. ``We want to emphasize that I do not have the full-blown disease of AIDS but do have a few relatively minor health problems as a result of the infection of the HIV virus,'' she said in her letter to the Monona Billboard. Ms. Fassbinder, 36, stopped working at the hospital in February 1989 because of health problems and now gets worker's compensation benefits to pay for medical care. The hospital also made a settlement agreement that remains confidential, the family's lawyer said. The mother of three told reporters she believes she contracted the virus in August 1986 during an unsuccessful attempt to resuscitate a patient at Memorial Hospital in Prairie du Chien, Wis. She said a doctor told her to remove an intravenous tube from the patient's arm that wasn't functioning properly. She said she applied pressure for 10 minutes with her left index finger shielded only by a small piece of gauze - all that was in reach. She said the patient's blood apparently mingled with her own through some small cuts she got while gardening. It wasn't until December 1986, when she made a routine blood donation, that the virus was detected. Ms. Fassbinder wasn't notified of the results until January 1987. The case was one of the first three documented instances in the United States of such infection of a health care worker. The national Centers for Disease Control cited it as an example of why health workers must take precautions against being infected. Ms. Fassbinder said the burden of living with the secret had become too much and that she hoped some good could be accomplished by talking openly about AIDS and HIV infection. ``We also need to emphasize that the HIV virus is very fragile outside the human body and can only be transmitted in a few very specific ways, none of which includes social or casual contact or even living in the same household,'' she said. She added that her husband, Dave, 43, and her children, Eva, 13; Joel, 10; and Emily, 7, are infection-free. She said she was gratified by the support of friends and neighbors who allow their children to continue to play at her house. But things aren't entirely the same, said her husband, who is a commercial honey producer. ``I really long for normalcy again,'' he said. ``I wish we were back when Barb was working nights, and I'm complaining that she's working too much.'' Ms. Fassbinder, who tires easily and suffers from chronic throat infections, declined to discuss her future. ``I don't like to talk prognosis,'' she said. ``It serves no purpose. I feel good today and I'm happy.''

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Restaurants As Well As Supermarkets Should Disclose Nutrition
DOC.TEXT: Proposals to require food manufacturers to disclose the nutrition content of their products should be extended to restaurants, a committee of experts recommended Wednesday. The Institute of Medicine panel also said nutrition labeling also should be required for fresh and frozen meat and poultry. Food-labeling proposals on Capitol Hill and by the Food and Drug Administration already include many of the provisions the panel recommended for packaged food, seafood and produce. But neither the pending legislation nor the draft regulations addresses meat, poultry or restaurants. The institute is an affiliate of the National Academy of Sciences, the congressionally chartered private body established to provide scientific advice to government agencies. The National Restaurant Association quickly registered its opposition to the committee's recommendations, saying most fast-food and full-service restaurants already provide nutrition information voluntarily. ``As restaurant operators we firmly believe our customers have a right to know what nutrients are in the foods they eat,'' said association President Mike Hurst. ``Our concern is not with providing such information. Rather, it is with how the information is conveyed.'' Officials at the Department of Agriculture, which regulates meat and poultry, had said they were waiting for the report before making any labeling proposals. Jim Greene, a spokesman for the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said officials had not yet read the report but ``we plan to evaluate the specifics and plan what course to take in the near future.'' At the Food and Drug Administration, spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the agency planned to consider nutrition-content disclosure for restaurants some time in the future, but ``grocery stores are our higher priority.'' The FDA, part of the Department of Health and Human Services, last July proposed regulations that would require nutrition labeling for nearly all packaged foods and fresh produce and seafood. Under its proposal, labels would have to show the number of calories from fat, the amount of saturated fatty acids, cholesterol and total dietary fiber. Listing of some vitamins would become optional and serving sizes would be standardized. Currently, about 60 percent of supermarket foods have nutrition information of the label, much of that done voluntarily. Labeling is not required except when a manufacturer makes a nutrition claim or adds nutrients. The institute's committee noted that Americans spend about 43 percent of their food money on meals eaten outside the home. This is expected to amount to about $156 billion this year. The experts applauded the efforts of some restaurants and fast-food chains that have begun providing nutrition information voluntarily, but they said these efforts should be required by law. ``All restaurants serving standardized menu items should be required to provide easy consumer access to nutrition profiles of standard menu items, either by posting the information or printing it on containers,'' said Richard A. Merrill, committee chairman and a law professor at the University of Virginia. Other restaurants should have nutrition information for items on their menus available for consumers on request, he said. Hurst said a National Restaurant Association survey last year showed that three-quarters of the 39,000 restaurants polled offer nutritional information to patrons who request it. The institute's recommendation would be impractical and ineffective, Hurst said. Printing nutritional information on containers would be expensive and burdensome for fast-food restaurants because many of their containers are multi-purpose, he said. Requiring full-service restaurants to have nutritional information on hand would also be costly and time-consuming, especially for establishments that change menus daily, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Teaches To Be Creative
DOC.TEXT: ``Never say never,'' President Bush tells thousands of public and private school teachers joining by satellite Wednesday night in a special project to spur creative thinking among educators and students. Bush's message was videotaped to launch what was described as the nation's first live, simultaneous broadcast to a giant satellite link of educators in more than 2,200 locations. The two-hour ``Great Invent America! Think Link,'' was produced through an alliance between business and education. Workshops and a businessman roundtable discussion were used to inspire teachers - mostly of kindergarten through eighth grade - to teach inventive thinking in their classrooms. ``It takes a special kind of independence to invent something new, a Yankee spirit that made this nation great,'' said Bush in the one-minute message. ``That same never-say-never spirit brings us together tonight. ```As Abraham Lincoln once said, `A child is a person who is going to carry on what you have started. He will assume control of your cities, states and nations.' The fate of humanity is in a child's hands. Through your efforts, our nation's children will be given the opportunity, the inspiration, and the challenge to create a better future for all Americans,'' the president said. The satellite feed was from K-Mart Corp.'s headquarters in Troy, Mich. Invent America! is a national education program and student invention competition designed to stimulate creativity and develop problem-solving skills in the nation's 31 million school children. Bush launched the program in 1987, and now serves as honorary chairman. ``Young people today need to understand the importance of innovation in all aspects of life,'' said Polaroid Corp. President I. MacAllister Booth. ``Encouraging student inquisitiveness in the classroom is the key. Society cannot do enough to help our teachers meet that challenge.'' Karen Willoughby with the Fairfax County, Va., schools said she has found that Invent America! teaches students to be critical and innovative thinkers. The program also raises students' self-esteem, encourages library and research skills, motivates children to learn and experiment with scientific methods and helps teachers to integrate curriculum, she said. ``It's encouraged that teaching thinking skills should happen across the curriculum and throughout the year and not at just one time,'' said Willoughby. ``Invent America! is just a wonderful program to get kids to think. That's the basic thing.'' Program Chairman J. Morgan Greene said Invent America! orchestrated the national training session in response to the fears of many educators and business leaders that students will not be equipped to compete in the future because they are not being taught creative, problem-solving skills. ``This one single event (places) in the hands of educators the training and materials they need to make an immediate and positive impact on millions of Americans students,'' said Greene. For the seminar, Polaroid Corp. provided $2 million in cameras, film and curriculum materials to the participating teachers. LEGO Dacta also provided free classroom resource materials.

DOC.HEAD: ``Coach'' Producer Apologizes for Insulting Buffalo
DOC.TEXT: The executive producer of the television show ``Coach'' apologized for insulting Buffalo during a promo that ran on national television at halftime of Monday night's football game. In the promo, actor Jerry Van Dyke, who plays an assistant coach in the ABC-TV series, said the Buffalo Bills would lose no matter what the final score of their game against the New York Jets was. ``Even if you (Buffalo) win, you lose,'' Van Dyke said. ``You still have to go home to Buffalo.'' The line prompted dozens of outraged telephone calls to WKBW-TV, ABC's Buffalo affliate, and the station's newscasters denounced the remark on the air the next day. Barry Kemp, the series' chief writer and executive producer, said the line was ``a thoughtless slip.'' ``I apologize to the people of Buffalo. It was uncalled for,'' Kemp told The Buffalo News. ``I will figure out some way of making it up to Buffalo. We'll put something positive on the show to make it up.''

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Helped Organization Seeking to Prove Power of Prayer
DOC.TEXT: Mung beans, yogurt and prayer have become an unlikely factor in Colorado's governor's race. Republican gubernatorial candidate John Andrews has acknowledged that he spent two years working for an organization that performed experiments designed to scientifically prove the power of prayer. The experiments included prayer sessions with mung beans and yogurt, among other things. Andrews, who faces Gov. Roy Romer in the Nov. 6 general election, sought to play down his involvement during 1987 and 1988 with Spindrift Inc., saying it ``didn't command a high priority with me.'' He said Tuesday he later decided to spend his time on higher priorities ``like public policy in Colorado.'' Spindrift is an organization that studies parapsychology, a discipline Andrews described as ``a recognized field on the edge of exploring new knowledge.'' Spindrift's goal is to ``explain the relationship between prayer and healing through the experimental test,'' said Bill Sweet, of Mount Prospect, Ill., the group's president. ``People for thousands of years have believed in the power of prayer, but they've had no proof.''
