In one experiment, 14,000 mung beans were divided into two groups. One was prayed over and the other was not. According to a Spindrift brochure, nearly twice as many sprouts were counted in the group that was prayed over than in the group that was not the target of prayers. In another experiment, trays of rye grass were correlated with jars of yogurt and potted plants. ``The plants were promised ... more light and the yogurt was promised milk if more of `their' seeds germinated than control seeds did,'' according to a book about the experiments, ``Cathedral of the Mind.'' ``And,'' it added, ``their seeds did do better than control seeds.'' Andrews, who was the group's general secretary during his two years there, said he became involved with the group in an effort ``to help some friends do some networking.'' He said he thought he could help them find grants and ways to evaluate their experiments. ``All I was doing was using my experience in marketing and research,'' said Andrews, who is on leave as executive director of the conservative think tank Independence Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Could Cite Untested Legal Theory in Picking Who to Furlough
With AM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may rely on an untested legal theory to decide which federal programs should be cut sharply next week in case no deficit-reduction agreement is reached, administration aides said Wednesday. One official acknowledged that the administration is concerned about invoking such authority because Congress is jealous of its constitutionally protected role as guardian of the federal purse strings. This official reasoned that any short-term political gain from bypassing Congress on the spending cuts might be outweighed by a resulting deterioration of relations between the two branches. However, some legal scholars say that if the president is looking for a way to force spending reductions, he might find authority in two 1980 advisory opinions by Benjamin Civiletti, attorney general near the end of the Carter administration. The essence of Civiletti's opinions was that ``a president has inherent authority to protect human life and property'' even when Congress has not appropriated money for such purposes. John Sununu, Bush's chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, told Senate Republicans on Tuesday that the Civiletti option is under active consideration. The maneuver could be used as early as Monday. That is Oct. 1, the first day of the 1991 budget year, and Congress has yet to enact any of the required 13 annual appropriation bills. A ``continuing resolution,'' which would keep federal spending flowing until Oct. 20, is making its way through Congress. Bush, however, has promised a veto because one section of the resolution would delay $85 billion of mandatory spending reductions - called a sequester - also until Oct. 20. Bush says that delaying those cuts would reduce pressure to write a package of spending reductions and tax increases that would slash the deficit by $500 billion over five years. He indicated he will accept no delays in the arbitrary cuts until a deficit agreement is imminent. If by Monday morning Bush has refused to sign the continuing resolution, there will be no money to run most federal programs. Nor will there be any money to ``sequester.'' That is when the Civiletti option might be used. The president, invoking his authority to ``protect human life and property,'' could decide that Defense Department workers should come to work and that the Justice Department should stay home. Foreign-aid spending could be frozen, national parks could be shut down and egg inspectors could be furloughed but the Internal Revenue Service could be ordered to keep collecting taxes. Thus, the president would have spent federal funds despite the constitutional requirement that any spending be approved by Congress. ``This is an area in which there are no cases,'' Alan Feld, a Boston University School of Law professor who has written on the Civiletti opinion and the federal anti-deficiency law in which it is rooted, said in an interview. ``All we've got is the bare statute,'' Feld said. ``The attorney general's opinion is the most authoritative construction of that at this moment. But it could be wrong. It is just the advice the president is getting.'' Aides to some Republican senators said there was considerable concern among Republicans about the president's acting in such a fashion, even though they were reluctant to criticize the proposal while a deficit agreement was being negotiated. Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee and ardent defender of congressional authority, was more blunt. ``On the face of it,'' he said, ``this appears to be nothing more than a thinly veiled attempt to selectively apply the sequester.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to delete Bjt tag
Jeanne White Says Congress Breaking Promise to Honor Her Son
DOC.TEXT: The Ryan White emergency AIDS bill is just ``the symbol of an empty promise'' from Congress, the boy's mother said Wednesday. The disaster-aid measure, named for the Indiana teen who died in April after becoming a national AIDS spokesman, authorized $600 million in emergency AIDS spending for the nation's hardest-hit cities. However, the bill was severely undercut when a Senate subcommittee proposed actual spending of only the first $110 million in the coming year, deferring the rest until after Oct. 1, 1991. ``My family and I were honored when Congress chose to place my son's name on the bill,'' Jeanne White said at a news conference at the capitol. ``But now the act, with no funding, is at best the symbol of an empty promise.'' Mrs. White urged members of the Senate to endorse an alternative introduced by Sens. Brock Adams, D-Wash., Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Alfonse D'Amato, R-N regulated by the agencies, said Jim Greene, a spokesman for the inspection service in Washington. ``Obviously, if you don't have federal inspectors, you can't operate your plant,'' said Gene Meakins, vice president of public relations for Monfort. That could cause ripples throughout the industry, such as a backlog of cattle at feed yards and higher consumer prices, company officials say. Harry Siegelman, group vice president of cattle procurement for Monfort, said Wednesday the company won't buy cattle for the week of Oct. 8. ``We are planning on not killing that week, the way it stands right now with inspection,'' he said. Monfort, based in Greeley, Colo., has a Garden City plant that employs 1,270 people. Dave Bartel, a spokesman for Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., said earlier this week that if a budget agreement isn't reached, Kassebaum has promised a continuing resolution to keep the present arrangement with meat inspectors until there is an agreement. Officials at IBP, which owns a 2,700-employee plant near Garden City, said they were working through the American Meat Institute in Arlington, Va., to ensure a furlough doesn't happen. ``We're not aware of any slowdowns at this point,'' said Gary Mickelson, manager of communications. He said it wasn't the first time the industry has faced the possibility of a budget-related furlough of inspectors, but they were always averted before. ``We're hopeful this will be the case this time,'' Mickelson said. Rich Parker, director of information for the American Meat Institute in Arlington, Va., said members of Congress have been told that furloughs could hurt the industry. ``There's a possibility you could see a shutdown but we don't think it will happen,'' he said. Five giant packing plants in southwest Kansas, including Monfort and IBP, employ more than 8,200 people. The state ranked first in the nation in 1989 for the number of cattle slaughtered, at 6.2 million head killed.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says Odds of Iraqi Military Strike Now Rising
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Wednesday the odds are mounting that Iraq will launch a military strike in response to U.N. economic sanctions. Cheney told a conference of business economists that the Bush administration had foreseen that a key danger point in the standoff with Saddam Hussein would arise once the international sanctions began crippling the Iraqi economy. ``We may have seen in the last 48 or 72 hours the beginning commentary from him that would indicate that the sanctions are beginning to bite,'' Cheney said. The U.N. Security Council voted to mpose an economic embargo against export-dependent Iraq on Aug. 6, four days after the Iraqi army invaded Kuwait. On Tuesday the Security Council extended the embargo to include air shipments. In a televised address to Americans broadcast Tuesday, Saddam criticized the United States and the United Nations for punishing his economy in response to the occupation of Kuwait. Saddam said U.S. forces deployed in the Persian Gulf area faced the prospect of bigger losses than were suffered in the Vietnam War. Saddam also said this week that he would destroy the Middle East's oil fields if war broke out. ``We have always operated on the assumption since we started this exercise in early August that there result of the U.N. embargo, which is being enforced by a multinational naval fleet in the Persian Gulf, the Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. The Pentagon also reported that Iraq has increased its troop strength in Kuwait and southern Iraq to 430,000 soldiers. The United States has about 165,000 forces in the gulf area.

DOC.HEAD: City University of New York Cuts Classes, Drops Teachers, Limits Students
DOC.TEXT: City University of New York, faced with $42 million in budget cuts, has canceled 2,000 classes, dropped 670 teachers, slashed library hours and limited enrollment, officials said Wednesday. Vice Chancellor Jay Hershenson said cuts were being handled ``in a way so that the core academic programs are protected and guarded.'' He said class sizes had increased, however, but he didn't know by how much. Officials said the budget woes were exacerbated by a 2.6 percent increase in the number of students, bringing total enrollment at CUNY's 11 four-year colleges and seven two-year community colleges to 200,121, the highest in 14 years. The overall increase in students came as the state reduced its contribution to CUNY's four-year colleges by $29 million, to more than $800 million, and the city cut its contribution to community colleges by $13 million, to $160 million. As a result, officials said they had to limit freshman enrollment to those who applied by the Aug. 6 deadline, rather than extending it as they have in past years. That resulted in 3,000 to 5,000 freshman applicants being denied admission, Hershenson said. To make ends meet, officials canceled 2,000 classes taught by adjunct teachers and dropped 670 adjunct teachers, 270 at the senior colleges and 400 at the community colleges. Adjunct teachers are hired on a semester-to-semester basis rather than under a continuing contract. CUNY also cut library, financial aid counseling and other services by 93,387 hours, Hershenson said. The university's budget this year is $1.1 billion. Tuition is $1,250 a year for a full-time student.

DOC.HEAD: House Overturns Supreme Court Ruling on Offshore Oil Leasing
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Wednesday to strengthen coastal states' power over offshore oil drilling. The bill, approved 391-32, would overturn a 1984 Supreme Court decision that allowed the federal government to sell offshore oil leases without checking to see if drilling complied with state's plans for its coast. ``Back in 1972, we made a bargain with the states,'' said Rep. Walter Jones, D-N.C., chairman of the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, who sponsored the bill, a revision of the Coastal Zone Management Act. ``If they developed coastal zone management programs which met federal standards and received federal approval, we promised that federal agencies would adhere to these programs. ``The problem is that federal agencies have not lived up to this bargain.'' The Supreme Court decision stemmed from a lawsuit filed by the Interior Department under President Reagan against California for trying to stop oil drilling. The justices ruled that lease sales for drilling on the outer continental shelf did not directly affect the coastal zone and therefore was exempt from California's management program. The decision has led to other uses of coastal areas by federal agencies that sometimes oppose states' management programs, said Jones' office. Jones' bill establishes a new rule that says any federal activity, including off-shore oil and gas leasing, which affects any natural resources, land uses or water uses in a coastal zone, would be subject to state review. The bill says that if the state finds the federal activity to be inconsistent with its plan, it may ask a federal court to halt the activity. A similar bill is awaiting floor action in the Senate. However, the Bush administration opposes overturning the 1984 Supreme Court decision and has threatened to veto the legislation. The coastal management program includes the U.S. territories and states on the oceans and the Great Lakes. It is voluntary, however, and five states - Indiana, Georgia, Minnesota, Illinois and Texas - do not participate. Non-participation means the states do not get federal grants associated with the program or protection from offshore oil drilling if this version of the bill becomes law. Jones' bill also requires states participating in the management program to develop a water quality strategy to clean up and prevent further pollution of coastal waters. ``Increasingly, our nation's population is concentrated along the coast,'' said Jones during debate on the bill. ``I don't need to remind my colleagues of the environmental problems which we are facing because of this growth.''

DOC.HEAD: Senior Vice President of American Newspaper Publishers Association Dies
DOC.TEXT: Thomas C. Fichter, senior vice president and chief financial officer of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, died Wednesday. He was 51. Fichter was a patient at Fair Oaks Hospital since collapsing while jogging near his Oakton, Va., home on Sept. 21. Fichter, who had been with the organization for 29 years, also was treasurer of the ANPA Foundation and chairman and president of ANPA's Credit Bureau, Inc. ``Tom's contribution to newspapers cannot be measured in numbers alone,'' said ANPA president Jerry W. Friedheim. ``He loved newspapers and newspaper people, and they greatly appreciated his work on their behalf.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Will File DC Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson said Wednesday that he is ``an honorable taxpayer'' and that he will file a District of Columbia tax return for 1989, even though it may not be legally required. Jackson, who is running for the symbolic job of ``shadow'' senator from the district, a post for lobbying Congress for D.C. statehood, said he has instructed his accountant to file with the city a part-year tax form for last year. Jackson's decision came after The Washington Times reported Wednesday that the two-time Democratic presidential hopeful did not file a local tax return last year, even though he moved his family to the nation's capital and registered to vote here in August, 1989. City tax officials said that even if Jackson had filed the form, he likely would be entitled to a tax credit and would not owe the city any money. Both Jackson and a city official agreed that the law governing his filing requirement is murky. ``We discussed the matter further with local tax experts. They suggested that the law is vague,'' Jackson's office said in a statement. ``If, through a difference in interpretation, he has failed to meet a technical requirement in the district, that requirement will be met immediately by filing a 1989 part-year D.C. tax form.'' Jackson's accountant, Lester McKeever of Chicago, originally determined that Jackson was not obligated to file a district return. Edward Many, acting associate director for audit, compliance and investigation for the city's finance and revenue department, said that residents who move to the district are required to file a tax form for that year only if they live in Washington for at least 183 days of the year. Jackson's office said his move to Washington was made official on Aug. 3, when he switched his voting registration from Chicago. On that date, there were 151 days left in the year. But another part of the city tax code stipulates that if the person is permanently moving to the district, he must file the part-year form for that year regardless of when the move takes place. In the statement, Jackson identified himself as a permanent resident.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Novelist Albert Moravia Dead at 82
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Moravia, one of Italy's most widely read authors who was censored by both Fascist and Vatican authorities, died of a heart attack at his home Wednesday. He was 82. Moravia's books, many exploring alienation and disillusionment with modern society, had been translated into all major languages and inspired at least eight movies. In recent years he cut back on his prolific writing schedule, but made frequent appearances on televison talk shows and contributed travel pieces to newspapers. An autobiography, in the form of an interview, was due out within weeks. ``Moravia was ageless, with his mental lucidity and constant presence in the literary and cultural life of our time,'' said Valentino Bompiani, who published Moravia's works for more than 50 years. Moravia had been pronounced in good health by a doctor two days ago. He died seconds after being striken by the heart attack, said his doctor, Antonio Severini. Moravia and his Spanish wife, Carmen, were married in 1986 when she was 32. Moravia's body was taken to the Campidoglio, or capitol hill, where Senate President Giovanni Spadolini and Rome Mayor Franco Carraro were among the mourners. Funeral services were set for Friday, and burial will be at the Moravia family tomb in Rome. Another major postwar Italian author, Italo Calvino, died in 1985. Italy's Umberto Eco has gained attention in the United States for several novels, including the bestselling ``The Name of the Rose.'' Moravia's novels, often with sexual themes, upset Fascist authorities in the 1930s and Roman Catholic censors in the 1950s. ``La Romana,''' about a prostitute's vain search for love in postwar Rome, won Moravia world fame. It was first published in Italian in 1947, and its English edition, ``The Woman of Rome,'' sold 1 million copies in the United States and made him the best-known Italian writer to many Americans. Another major work, ``La Ciociara,'' was set in World War II when the Allies fought their way from the beaches south of Rome on the way to liberating the Italian capital. Film director Vittorio De Sica turned the 1957 book into the movie ``Two Women,'' with Sophia Loren in an Oscar-winning role. In 1952, the Vatican declared all Moravia's novels and stories immoral and placed them on its Index of Forbidden Books. The list was abolished following the 1963-65 Second Vatican Council. Born Alberto Pincherle in Rome on Nov. 28, 1907, Moravia spent much of his childhood suffering from a crippling bone disease. He often said his approach to life and his writing was largely molded by the boredom of his youth. In 1925, while still on crutches, he began his first novel, ``The Indifferent Ones,'' which portrayed the decline of Italy's middle-class in the first years of Fascism. He paid to have the book printed in four languages. While critics assailed the work, it sold quickly. From October 1934 to May 1935, Moravia was in New York lecturing at Columbia University. His encounter with American culture and values struck him deeply, and Fascist authorities began to regard Moravia with suspicion. In 1941, the censor seized ``Fancy Dress Party,'' about a grotesque dictator in an imaginary South American country. Later, Moravia was forbidden to write at all. In 1941, he married writer Elsa Morante. Their marriage ended in 1962. The next year Moravia began living with Dacia Maraini, a young author and prominent feminist. When the Germans occupied Rome in September 1943, Moravia, of Jewish ancestry and listed as subversive by Fascist police, tried to cross the Allied lines to Naples. Instead, he spent nine months hiding with peasants in the mountains. His wartime experiences were the basis for ``Two Women'' and other works. Moravia's most prolific years were from 1941 to 1960, during which he wrote eight novels and several collections of stories, including ``Roman Tales'' and ``New Roman Tales.'' After ``Empty anvas'' in 1960, Moravia concentrated on short stories, essays, film reviews and accounts of his travels, especially in Africa. In 1970, he shocked the literary world with the novel, ``The Two of Us,'' a dialogue between a sexually hyperactive scriptwriter and his genitals. Some critics described it as Moravia's surrender to alienation. ``A Ford worker is as alienated as Stalin's subjects; the employee as the employer,'' Moravia once said. ``Vulgarity and irreality affect contemporary man.'' Moravia's concern over nuclear arms led him to visit Hiroshima, Japan, and thrust him into politics. In 1984, he was elected to the European Parliament as a representative of Italy's Independent Left party.

DOC.HEAD: Seafood Consumption at Record Pace
DOC.TEXT: Americans are eating a record amount of seafood, including farm-raised catfish and other products, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Per capita consumption was estimated at 15.9 pounds in 1989, a 5 percent increase from the revised average of 15.2 pounds in 1988 and slightly more than the previous high of 15.7 pounds in 1987. ``Seafood consumption has risen in eight of the last 10 years and is up 24 percent since 1980,'' the department's Economic Research Service said in its report. Catfish continues to lead in U.S. aquaculture production, rising 16 percent last year and an additional 11 percent in the first seven months of 1990, the report said. The volume of catfish processed in 1990 is expected to total between 370 million and 385 million pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Taxing Texas or Rich Americans Would Be Unfair, Critic Says
DOC.TEXT: Slapping taxes on wealthy Americans and Sunbelt states to cover the savings and loan bailout would be unfair, a financial industry consultant said Wednesday. But consumer advocates and members of Congress disagreed, saying people who had profited from government policies that caused the crisis bear a disproportionate responsibility for fixing the problem. Bert Ely, a conservative advocate of federal deposit insurance reform, told a task force established by the House Banking Committee that all taxpayers should shoulder the cleanup burden. The thrift crisis resulted from defects in the insurance program, which benefits the entire nation by keeping the banking system afloat, he said. ``Attempting to impose this loss, particularly in a punitive manner, on select groups of taxpayers would be unfair and counterproductive for the economy,'' Ely said. ``Our fellow citizens can smell that something is rotten in the state of America,'' said Rep. Joseph Kennedy II, D-Mass. ``They demand that they not be stuck paying for fiascos they neither caused nor profited from.'' The task force is studying who should pay the hundreds of millions of dollars needed to rescue the ailing thrift industry. Kennedy testified in favor of legislation he introduced that would levy a 7.5 percent surtax on unearned income, such as interest and dividends, of people earning over $100,000 a year. Corporations earning over $75,000 a year would pay a 5 percent surtax. And a provision that forgives taxes on appreciated capital gains at death would be abolished. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., asked for support of a bill he introduced as chairman of a caucus representing 18 Northeastern and Midwestern states. Noting that many of the failed thrifts are state-chartered, he said carelessness and lax regulation by state governments were a little-noticed cause of the S&L crisis. His bill would establish a formula for determining which states caused an ``excessive'' share of the problem. The governments of those states would be required to pay into a special fund for the thrifts they charter to remain eligible for federal deposit insurance. Texas would pay the biggest bill: $2.8 billion. Thrifts in that state account for 72 percent of the S&L losses, but Texas currently stands to pay only 6 percent of the cleanup costs, a study by the Northeast-Midwest Coalition says. ``Texas encouraged a massive construction boom and, by abusing the federal deposit insurance system, has levied a tax on our citizens to pay for it,'' Wolpe said. ``If that isn't a transfer of wealth, I don't know what is.'' Ely, however, said the regional disparity had been ``vastly overstated.'' For example, although Texas benefited from local construction projects financed by S&Ls, many of the materials came from outside the region, he said. Task force chairman Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., also voiced uneasiness about punishing Texas. ``Before we get into a new civil war, I want to make sure we do something that's workable,'' Vento said. Meanwhile, the Congressional Budget Office released a study of deposit insurance reform options that appeared to support the idea of broad-based taxpayer responsibility for the bailout. Deposit insurance funds ``were never expected to cover catastrophes and the (thrift) collapse represents an extraordinary or catastrophic situation,'' said Banking Committee Chairman Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, who requested the study.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Hailed for Persian Gulf Support, Blasted for Budget Stance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Bush in Chicago. Picks up 7th graf pvs `On the ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush offered faint praise for Democrats on Wednesday for standing by him on the Persian Gulf crisis, after blasting them for foot-dragging on a budget accord. Speaking at a luncheon for Republican gubernatorial candidate George Voinovich, Bush said he was ``grateful to the Democratic leadership for the support they have given'' to his response to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. ``We need to ... continue to maintain a bipartisan spirit in support of America's response to Iraqi aggression,'' the president told his audience. Bush praised Democrats for agreeing that politics should ``stop at the water's edge.'' Later, in Chicago, Bush met at the airport with a group of Chicago-based Air Force reservists who had just returned from Saudi Arabia. He was attending fund-raisers for Rep. Lynn Martin, who is challenging Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. The president, on a two-day swing through Midwestern states to speak on behalf of Republican candidates, said the United States ``will not give in to intimidation'' and that U.S. forces will be brought home ``as soon as possible, when the job is done.'' Bush also complained to his partisan audience that he was tired of ``one Democrat after another knocking my socks off on Capitol Hill'' on capital gains and other tax issues. On the budget, Bush said Democrats, not Republicans, are to blame for the current impasse. ``The hangup is not on capital gains. The hangup is with tee Democrats on Capitol Hill,'' Bush declared. Bush gave Voinovich a resounding endorsement as the candidate who would promote education, law and order and environmental protection. He said that as mayor of Cleveland, Voinovich had taken the city from ``the gloomy dark days of despair'' and brought it into brighter times. Bush also planned stops in Minneapolis, Cleveland and Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Encouraging Flight Crews To Work As a Team
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration, concerned about signs of poor performance in recent air disasters, is encouraging changes in flight training to prompt flight crew members to work as a team, the agency said Wednesday. When it first proposed the change early last year, the FAA cited studies showing that more than 60 percent of fatal airline accidents were caused by breakdowns of communication in the cockpit rather than mechanical failures or lack of pilot skills. The FAA said then it was clear that in many cases flight crews did not work well together and therefore did not make use of all the resources at hand during a crisis. The new FAA rule allows airlines the option that airlines use Cockpit Resource Management training to emphasize crew coordination. According to the FAA such advanced training focuses on communications skills, coordination and decision-making. ``This is a bold new approach to the training of flight crew members that is sorely needed and one which I believe will enhance safety and improve cockpit efficiency,'' said FAA Administrator James B. Busey.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Puts Campaign Promise In A Contract
DOC.TEXT: A Republican U.S. House candidate is promising not to serve more than eight straight years in Congress and he's offering to pay South Dakota voters $10,000 if he breaks the pledge. Don Frankenfeld, a Rapid City businessman, said that he if serves longer than eight years, he'll pay $10,000 in damages to anyone with whom he signs a contract pledging to limit his service. Frankenfeld on Tuesday signed the first such contract with his Minnehaha County campaign chairman, lawyer Richard Gregerson. Frankenfeld said he'll sign a similar contract with any South Dakotan who makes a $1 campaign contribution. ``I am attempting through legal means to make my promise ironclad,'' Frankenfeld said. The Republican is running against Democratic incumbent Tim Johnson. Frankenfeld said his promise will hold in 1998 if he wins this year and is re-elected in the next three elections.
DOC.HEAD: Rinfret Says GOP Wants Him To `Shut Up, Go Away'
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret on Wednesday refused to attend a GOP unity session and accused party leaders of trying to pay him to ``shut up, go away and run a dismal campaign.'' The civil war within the state's Republican Party continued after Rinfret refused to show up for a meeting that Republican Sen. Roy Goodman said was called to ``talk about the unity of this party.'' Instead, a Rinfret aide distributed copies of a letter Rinfret sent to J. Patrick Barrett, chairman of the Republican Committee, and GOP county chairmen. In the letter, Rinfret said he originally planned to attend the political powwow but that events in the last 24 hours ``have made my attendance a political impossibility.'' ``The legislative leaders of the Republican-controlled Senate have tried to buy me off with a handful of money,'' Rinfret wrote. ``Yesterday, I was offered a grand total of $40,000 to shut up, go away, and run a dismal campaign for governor.'' Rinfret was at his Manhattan headquarters and an aide said he was not available for comment. Rinfret had threatened to quit the race against incumbent Gov. Mario Cuomo in a flap over financing. He accused the state GOP leadership of hoarding a $3.25 million campaign warchest for their own benefit. On Wednesday, Rinfret continued his attack on Goodman and other state GOP leaders, saying in the letter they should be forced to ``totally endorse and politically and financially support my candidacy for governor.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Retaliate for Ouster from Beijing Asiad
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Qatari newspaper Al-Sharq reported Wednesday that 10 star players from Kuwait's national soccer team were killed fighting Iraqi occupation troops in the Kuwaiti resistance. It did not say when the athletes died, and said the names of the players and the clubs to which they belonged were witheld for security considerations. Al-Sharq, quoting an unidentified Kuwaiti refugee, also said Iraqi occupiers retaliated for Kuwait's successful ouster of the Iraqi team from Asian games by plundering the premises of the Kuwait Football (soccer) Federation. It said all contents were destroyed and all trophies were taken away, including the gold cup of the Persian Gulf champion that Kuwait won in February. The Asiad, now being played in Beijing, is the Asian equivalent of the Olympic games. The Olympic Council of Asia expelled Iraq before the games started at Kuwait's request. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed it days later.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Strong Despite Oil-Price Shock
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs `But the ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT second reference to July to June
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Durable Goods
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending rose 0.5 percent in August, the government said Wednesday in a report indicating personal consumption remained reasonably strong despite the Persian Gulf oil-price shock. ``I thought consumption would take more of a hit from the energy shock, but it didn't,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington. The Commerce Department said spending totaled $3.69 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up $16.7 billion from a month earlier. It was the smallest advance since last May, when spending was unchanged from April. The department also said personal incomes rose 0.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.68 trillion, a $13 billion increase over July. It was the smallest increase since a 0.2 percent gain in April. But the department revised the spending increases upward from 0.5 percent to 0.6 percent in July and from 1 percent to 1.2 percent in June. ``The upward revisions in June and July showed that consumer spending ... appeared to be recovering in June and the oil shock didn't make that much of a dent in it,'' Evans said. ``It indicates that consumers are taking a relatively healthy attitude despite recent evidence in consumer surveys suggesting otherwise,'' added Gilbert Benz, an economist with Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Many analysts have expressed concern since it advanced just 0.2 percent at an annual rate in the second quarter, as measured by the gross national product. Benz noted that when consumer spending is adjusted for inflation, it posted a 0.1 percent decline. ``It's the result of the oil shocks we've seen in August and that continue in September,'' he said. Inflation, as measured by the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index, rose 0.8 percent in August. The department said the savings rate last month - savings as a percentage of disposable income - was 4.3 percent, the lowest since a 4.0 percent rate in September 1989. The rate was 4.5 percent in July and 4.6 percent in June. Americans' disposable income - income after taxes - increased 0.2 percent, down from a 0.5 percent gain in July. When adjusted for inflation, it fell 0.3 percent. A key component of the income category - wages and salaries - rose $700 million, a small fraction of the $16.2 billion increase the previous month. On the spending side, the $16.7 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, was down from a $20.6 billion gain in July. Spending on durable goods - ``big-ticket'' items expected to last more than three years - totaled $480 billion, down $5.9 billion from July. It was the first decline in durable-goods spending since a $7.7 billion drop in May. Non-durable-goods spending, however, rose $11.7 billion to $1.2 trillion following a $1.6 billion gain in July. Spending on services was up $11 billion to $2 trillion after an $11 billion gain the previous month.

DOC.HEAD: Trounson Named First Civilian Chief Editor of Stars and Stripes
DOC.TEXT: W. Robert Trounson, deputy business editor of the Los Angeles Times, has been named the first civilian chief editor of Pacific Stars and Stripes, the U.S. military newspaper said Wednesday. Trounson, a 1954 journalism graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, has worked for the Los Angeles Times for 23 years. In 1974-75, he studied Japanese history, politics, language and art at Stanford University under a journalism fellowship. He was a copy editor and news editor at the Stars and Stripes from 1963-67. The newspaper said Stripes ombudsman Philip M. Foisie recommended naming of a civilian chief editor last January after studying allegations of censorship at the paper, including charges by staff members that senior editors had killed stories critical of the military or of host countries. It said the editor in chief's position was previously held by the paper's senior military officer, who now holds the title of commander-publisher, with editorial control delegated to the civilian chief editor. The newspaper is edited in Tokyo and in Europe. ``The naming of Bob Trounson as the first civilian editor of Stripes shows our commitment to provide top-quality news service for our American readers overseas,'' the newspaper quoted Marine Col. Walter S. de Forest, Pacific Stars and Stripes commander-publisher, as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Musical Renaissance Planned for West Virginia's Carnegie Hall
DOC.TEXT: While New York's famous Carnegie Hall celebrates its 100th birthday, its little-known counterpart in southern West Virginia is patching a leaky roof and trying to start its own musical renaissance. ``I think that Carnegie Hall has great potential as not only a cultural but also as an economic factor,'' said its executive director, Vivian Conly. The Greenbrier County building bearing steel baron and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie's name was built in 1902 as part of a women's college, the Lewisburg Female Institute, Conly said. Carnegie donated $33,000 to James Lang, an institute trustee, when several buildings on the campus were destroyed by fire. Lang and Carnegie were from the same area of Scotland, according to hall records. The donation was used to build a 500-seat theater and performing arts center. The Greek Revival-style building is across the street from a colonial church in this town of 3,600, site of a major Civil War battle. The hall lay dormant for many years after the women's college closed in 1972 and was sold to a state mental hospital. The building was condemned in 1983, but a citizens' group raised the money to turn it into a performing arts center. The center, with 450 member families, is operated by a staff of four with a budget of $214,000, said Conly, who became executive director last year. She said she quit her job as advertising director of The Greenbrier Resort to take on ``a new challenge'' - the hall's attempted comeback. The venue has won praise from performers and patrons for its intimate setting. ``It's a wonderful place to see people because you can see the expressions on their faces,'' Conly said. The hall's performances once were primarily classical but now include gospel, jazz, bluegrass and folk music, artistic programs director Mary Leb said Wednesday. The Vienna Boys' Choir, the West Virginia Sympony and Taj Mahal have all performed there. A local theater group performed ``Steel Magnolias'' a few months ago and another play is tentatively lined up for next year. But the four-story brick building is in need of extensive refurbishing, including a new roof, new lighting, electrical wiring and plumbing, Conly said. Some $125,000 has been raised toward a $150,000 roof-repair project. Fund-raisers also hope to bring in revenue from fall classes taught in the building's art studios and classrooms. Subjects include painting, sculpture, gardening, calligraphy and French. ``For many reasons, it wasn't closely maintained over the years,'' Conly said. ``It needs a tremendous amount of restoration.''

DOC.HEAD: November Ballots Will Feature Famous Offspring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs with Udall comment after 19th graf, ``That's the
DOC.TEXT: Political offspring are meeting mixed success as they try to follow in their parents' footsteps in this year's elections. In New Mexico, Tom Udall, son of former Arizona congressman and secretary of the interior Stewart Udall, is running for attorney general against a freshman legislator who says he doesn't think the Udall name is helping his opponent. In California, Kathleen Brown, daughter of one former governor and sister of another, tells voters, ``I'm a different shade of Brown.'' In Minnesota, Ted Mondale, son of former Vice President Walter Mondale, is challenging a state senator who says the younger Mondale has ``no background of any kind other than that he's worked in his father's campaigns.'' Mondale and his opponent, two-term state Sen. Phyllis McQuaid, both describe their race as a close one. ``You take a name as well-known in Minnesota as Mondale, it's clearly very much of a threat,'' Ms. McQuaid said in a telephone interview.. But, she added, ``If his name was Ted Brown, no one would take the race seriously based on his lack of experience.'' Her remark recalled another candidate's jab at a political neophyte nearly three decades ago. When Edward M. Kennedy ran for senator from Massachusetts in 1962, state Attorney General Edward J. McCormack Jr., his rival for the Democratic nomination, jeered ``If your name was simply Edward Moore instead of Edward Moore Kennedy, your candidacy would be a joke.'' Kennedy was 30 at the time, two years younger than Mondale is now. He beat McCormack, went on to be elected and is still in the Senate. His son, Patrick, is running for a second term in the Rhode Island legislature. Mondale, whose father was Minnesota attorney general and a U.S. senator before becoming vice president and running for president, said the family name can be a handicap as well as an asset. ``There are those I think that probably want to punish you because they feel that everything you have gotten in life has been handed to you,'' he said. ``I guess you have to go the extra mile to show who you are and what your background is and what you want to do.'' Ms. Brown's father, Edmund G. Brown, and her brother, Edmund Jr., both served as governor of California. ``Having grown up in a political family, I pledged I would never get into politics,'' she said. Now, at 44, with two terms on the Los Angeles Board of Education behind her, she is the Democratic nominee for state treasurer, challenging Republican incumbent Thomas Hayes. When it comes to fundraising, she said, ``I think there is a credibility that I have as a candidate walking in the door because of my family name, but I think once I am in that door, nobody is going to give money to me if they don't think that I am a credible and viable candidate in my own right. It doesn't matter what your name is, people are not in the business of throwing money away on bad horses.'' Udall, the nephew of Rep. Morris K. Udall, D-Ariz., won a lively contest for the Democratic nomination for attorney general of New Mexico and is leading his opponent, state Sen. William Davis, in the polls. An Albuquerque Journal poll found that 87 percent of the people knew who he was, compared with 18 percent for Davis. Davis, a first-term state senator, attributed Udall's big edge in name familiarity to his previous races for Congress and a lively primary for the attorney general nomination. ``That's the real issue, not his dad's or his uncle's name,'' he said. ``Those connections help him get money, but I don't think they help him much in name identification. I don't think we pay that much attention to Arizona politics in New Mexico.'' Udall said, ``I ran in a very high profile hotly contested race in 1988 and we came within 5,000 votes of taking an open congressional seat. That race, I think had an awful lot to do with my standing today. I remember when I got in that primary in 1988, my name identification and my standing in the polls was about 3 percent.'' ``There is no doubt that people know the Udalls and know my father's service to the country, and they also ask about it many times on the campaign trail,'' he said. ``It's usually out of admiration for what they have done.'' Honolulu attorney Matthew Matsunaga, son of the late Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, did not fare so well in his political outing. Matsunaga, 31, campaigned for Congress partly on the basis of his long residence in Washington and said the network of contacts made by his father would help him. He finished third in a three-candidate field in Saturday's primary. ``Having a name like Matsunaga created a lot of publicity and that's what helped with name recognition,'' he said. ``The advantage of having a father who was a very popular politician is that many people are inclined to vote for me simply because of my father,'' Matsunaga added. ``The disadvantage, of course, is people who claim that I am simply capitalizing on my father's name. Some people expect a lot more of me.''

DOC.HEAD: Discrimination Found in Refusal to Rent to Drug Treatment Group
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Wednesday found an apartment management company guilty of housing discrimination because it refused to rent units for use by recovering drug addicts. The jury found that Southern Management Corp., had violated the Fair Housing Act by refusing to lease the apartments to a drug treatment program operated by Fairfax County., Va., and awarded $36,280 in damages. The civil case is one of the first brought by the Justice Department to enforce a 1988 amendments to the fair housing law that bar discrimination against recovering alcoholics or drug addicts. The department's civil rights division has also filed discrimination suits against communities for blocking group homes for mentally retarded persons. In the Virginia case, the government presented evidence that Southern Management refused to rent three apartments to the county-run Crossroads drug rehabilitation program because it did not want recovering addicts living in the units. Recovering addicts who successfully complete a one-year treatment program move to a group home or apartment for four to six months, said Justice Department attorney Paul Hancock. The jury awarded $10,000 in compensatory damages and $26,280 in punitive damages. As a result of the judgment, the Justice Department could seek a court order barring further discrimination by the company. Two other suits were filed in Virginia apartment management companies on the same day. One has resulted in a consent decree and the other is awaiting trial, Hancock said.

House Democrats turned back a GOP effort Wednesday to rein in lawmakers' use of free mailing privileges in election years and weaken the role of union political action committees in financing their campaigns. On a 225-194 largely party-line vote, the House rejected a Republican motion telling negotiators on campaign finance reform to accept Senate proposals to reduce gifts to a candidate from a single PAC from $10,000 to $2,000 and disclose how much each congressmen spends on franked mail. ``This is the last chance to get on a stage leaving Dodge that might actually reach some destination instead of heading for a veto and politics as usual,'' said Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan. The vote was on a motion to the appointment of 28 representatives to a conference committee that will attempt to iron out differences between House and Senate versions of campaign finance reform legislation. The Senate appointed its negotiators last week. Both the House and Senate passed largely Democratic bills just before the August recess that would establish ceilings on how much candidates would spend and lawmakers concede their is little chance that any measure will become law this year. President Bush has said he would veto any bill with taxpayer financing of congressional campaigns even though money raised though presidential races are already funded through voluntary checkoffs on tax returns. Bush and most other Republicans also adamantly oppose spending ceilings on grounds that GOP challengers need all the money they can raise to offset the name recognition of incumbent Democrats, who hold majorities in both the House and Senate. The Senate in July conceded to Bush's demand that PACs be outlawed, even though lawmakes in both parties acknowledge that the Supreme Court will likely rule such a ban an unconstitutional infringement of free speech. Included as a fallback position in its bill was a provision reducing from $10,000 to $2,000 how much a PAC could contribute to a single candidate for both the primary and general elections. The bill approved by the House last month would allow candidates to get only half of their campaign funds from PACs. PACs of unions and other organizations that get their money in donations of $240 or less could continue giving up to $10,000 per election. But PACs raising their money though individual donations greater than $240 - chiefly corporations - could spent only $2,000 per candidate. The Senate also would forbid lawmakers from using free mailing privileges in years they are up for re-election. For senators, that's just one year out of every six, but for representatives it's every other year. In their effort to change the House's position Wednesday, Republicans ignored the Senate language on no free mail in election years. But they called for adoption of other measures in the Senate bill that would require the reporting every three months of how much each congressman spends on franking. ``Every even-numbered year, we have to approve hiring a virtual army of part-time employees at an extra cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars just to move out newsletters,'' said Roberts. Postal Service records show that House members' use of the franking privilege to mail out newsletters free rises substantially in election years, a practice that Republicans contend is unfair to challengers. For example, the Postal Service estimates its cost of delivering franked mail from House members was $44.3 million in 1987, rising to $77.9 million in 1988 and falling back to $57.2 million in 1989. This election year, the Postal Service estimates it will have to spend $78.9 million delivering mail for incumbent representatives, even though the House appropriated $40.7 million for it.

DOC.HEAD: More Record Highs In Northern Plains, Record Lows In Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Overnight temperatures were low across the East on Wednesday, with a third day of record lows in the Southeast, and record heat continued on the northern Plains and upper Mississippi Valley. The air was cool overnight from the lower Great Lakes and New England all the way into northern Florida. Record lows were 64 at Lakeland, Fla.; 44 at Meridian, Miss.; and 44 at Montgomery, Ala. Records were tied in Columbus, Ga., 50; Hollywood, Fla., 67, and Macon, Ga., 47. But temperatures over the Plains and Mississippi Valley remained unseasonably warm. At midday, temperatures were as much as 10 to 15 degrees higher than normal for late September. Records were tied at Grand Island, Neb., 93, and Lincoln, Neb., 94, and tied - 78 - at International Falls, Minn., the town on the Canadian border that calls itself the Nation's Icebox. Temperatures across the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 50 at Truckee, Calif., to 94 at Lincoln, Neb.; Manhattan, Kan., and Palm Springs, Calif. During the afternoon, showers and thunderstorms extended from western and southern New York state across eastern and southern Pennsylvania and over New Jersey, Maryland and northern Virginia. Showers and thunderstorms also spread from northwestern Kansas across northeastern Colorado, western Nebraska, southwestern South Dakota, east-central Wyoming, and over eastern Idaho. Elsewhere, showers and storms were scattered along Florida's northeast coast. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 33 at Alamosa, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Unilaterally Withdraw 40,000 Troops From Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 14th graf pvs, In its, to clarify that House bill also specifies 50,000 cut in U.S. forces in Europe.
DOC.TEXT: The United States will begin withdrawing 40,000 troops from Europe next month and start closing down their units in January, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Wednesday. Cheney said his decision was made in consultation with the NATO allies and was in anticipation of a 23-nation Conventional Forces in Europe agreement being reached by year's end to substantially reduce troops and military equipment across Europe. ``We have to begin the drawdown now to respond in an orderly way to changing security requirements and declining defense budgets,'' Cheney said in a statement. The unilateral pullout of troops from Europe is the largest by the United States since the mid-1960s, when the administration of President Lyndon Johnson restructured the U.S. commitment to Europe. The decision, while not directly related to the buildup of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf area, would give the Pentagon extra flexibility in fielding troops to spell some of the more than 165,000 American troops now in the gulf region. The defense secretary said he ordered Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to remove 30,000 Army and 10,000 Air Force members from Europe, starting in October. The United States has about 300,000 Army and Air Force personnel in Europe. Lt. Col. Rick Oborn, a Pentagon spokesman, said the affected units in Europe would be deactivated and the soldiers and airmen would be transferred to other areas. Cheney said that to allow planning time and to ease the logistics strain, no units will be deactivated before Jan. 1. He said it normally takes three to four months to close down a military unit once the deactivation order is issued. Under the current U.S. proposal at the conventional forces negotiations in Vienna, U.S. and Soviet forces in Europe would be reduced to 195,000 for each side. The Soviet Union says it plans to remove all its troops from Europe by the mid-1990s. In a speech to a conference of business economists Friday, Cheney, while not mentioning the withdrawal of troops from Europe, said the Pentagon was ``beginning to adapt to the new world that we are now fortunate enough to live in in terms of reduced U.S.-Soviet hostilities.'' He said the United States would have ``years of warning time'' of an impending Soviet attack in Europe, giving plenty of time to return U.S. forces to the area. Cheney said details on which units will be closed down and a timetable for the withdrawals will be announced later by the headquarters of the U.S. Army Europe and U.S. Air Force Europe. In its version of the fiscal 1991 defense authorization bill, the Senate called for a cut of 100,000 in worldwide U.S. forces, including 50,000 in Europe. The House version of the bill calls for a total cut of 129,500, including 50,000 in Europe. On Capitol Hill, Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama, the ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, said Cheney's action is ``prudent damage limitation'' in light of the deeper cuts adopted by the House and Senate. ``There's a freight train called personnel cuts barreling down on the department of Defense, so Dick Cheney has done the right thing by taking steps now to try to soften the blow on people in the year ahead,'' Dickinson said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Calls Home Made Easier for Gulf Troops
DOC.TEXT: Beginning Oct. 3, American military personnel in Saudi Arabia will be able to connect directly with U.S. long-distance operators to make calls home, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Wednesday. AT&T said its USADirect service enables callers to deal immediately with AT&T operators stateside, thus avoiding possible language problems with international operators. Callers need dial 1-800-100 and an AT&T operator will complete the call to anywhere in the United States. During an introductory period, AT&T will allow U.S. military personnel in Saudi Arabia to make free three-minute calls to the United States. The service will be available at most phones from virtually all U.S. military bases in Saudi Arabia. ``We want to give all those who are serving in Saudi Arabia a chance to call home,'' said Frank Ianna, AT&T vice president for marketing international communications services.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Food Rations to Foreigners Will Stop on Monday
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq told diplomatic missions in Baghdad that starting Monday, it will no longer provide them with food rations for distribution to their communities, diplomats said Wednesday. Tens of thousands of non-Arab foreigners are still in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. About 6,000 of them are Westerners. They are banned from traveling, and some are held at key installations and potential targets in the event of an attack to retake Kuwait by multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. The diplomats quoted a Foreign Ministry memorandum as saying rations will be suspended as of Monday, Oct. 1, because the latest U.N. Security Council resolution imposing an air embargo on Iraq was expected to create major food shortages. The memorandum was delivered to all non-Arab missions. The Trade Ministry announced another stage of food rationing due to U.N. sanctions imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It said Iraq's 17 million people had already received food rations for September and that October's ration distribution would begin on Saturday. The trade and finance minister, Mohammed Mahdi Saleh, said rationing will include basic food supplies including rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar, and tea. ``We received a memorandum explaining that the government's priority is to feed the Iraqi population,'' a Western diplomat said. He spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, as did other diplomats who confirmed receiving the memorandum. They said they contacted Arab diplomats who told them they had not received any such notice. Officially, Arabs residing in Iraq have rights equal to Iraqi nationals in accordance with the pan-Arab ideology of the ruling Baath Party. The diplomats said that in September, they received rations for distribution to their communities. These included rice, flour, sugar, tea and cooking oil - items that had become sparse because of U.N. sanctions. The diplomats said they did not know how much foreigners would suffer after the latest decision, because most people had stockpiled basics.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Officials Will Push Boat People To Go Home
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Vietnamese boat people will be encouraged to fly home voluntarily or face deportation under a major United Nations' policy switch, diplomatic sources said Wednesday. ``They will offer the boat people dignity now or deportation later,'' said a Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The diplomat said it would be the first time U.N. officials threatened deportation to boat people, who often travel in overcrowded and unsafe vessels to reach the British colony. Previously, U.N. officials did not try to influence boat people and only accepted volunteers to return home. About 54,000 boat people remain in Hong Kong camps, with 9,000 classified as refugees for resettlement in the West. The other 45,000 are either waiting to be screened for determination of their status, or have been classified as non-refugees and set for repatriation. Jamshid Anvar, chief of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees for Asia and Oceania, informed diplomats of the new policy, sources said. Britain, Vietnam and the United Nations signed an agreement last week that says that in addition to volunteers, boat people who ``did not oppose'' being sent back to Vietnam would also be flown home. An official at the U.N. refugee office in Hong Kong confirmed the meeting took place, but declined further comment and said Anvar was not available. Under the agreement with Britain and Vietnam, the United Nations agreed to monitor returning boat people to ensure they do not face political persecution or unnecessary economic hardship. Anvar told the diplomats Britain has given the new agreement about three months to succeed. If it fails, Britain could begin forcible repatriation of boat people in 1991, Anvar was quoted as saying. The colonial government forced 51 boat people home in December but suspended the program after international condemnation. In late July, Secretary of States James A. Baker III told Southeast Asin nations the United States still opposed forced repatriation but could accept the new category of ``those who do not object.'' So far, 4,349 Vietnamese boat people have returned from Hong Kong under a voluntary repatriation program that began in March 1989 with U.N. support. Hong Kong stopped automatically allowing boat people to stay in June 1988. Since then, more than 49,400 have arrived, including nearly 5,000 this year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Taps Stockpile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; minor editing, adds byline
DOC.TEXT: The White House, claiming there was `no justification'' for the recent run-up in oil and gasoline prices, announced Wednesday that president Bush had decided to sell 5 million barrels of crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The decision to tap the nation's oil reserve as a cannon shot against soaring prices was announced by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said the decision to put 5 million barrels on the market was a ``test'' and the president would take ``additional steps to stabilize energy prices.'' The reserve contains 590 million barrels of crude oil. It has never been used apart from a 1-million barrel test sale in 1985 that was not aimed at influencing prices. Fitzwater said he expected prices to decline under the government's sale, but he did not say by how much. Prices have jumped to about $39 a barrel from $21 before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Fitzwater said Bush was taking the action to head off ``those who might seek profit by subverting the sanctions'' against Iraq. ``There is sufficient oilto meet current needs,'' Fitzwater said. ``Oil markets have simply not taken into account additional production coming on stream.'' Industry experts have estimated that production in other countries has restored about two-thirds of the 4.8 million daily barrels of oil production removed from world markets by Iraq's takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the world embargo against Iraqi-Kuwaiti oil. The United States uses more than 17 million barrels a day, about half of it imported. Fitzwater quoted Bush as saying there was ``no justification for the intensive and unwarranted speculation in oil futures'' that has driven the price about $39 a barrel in the United States. Fitzwater said this was the first time that the oil reserves, which have been held in salt domes along the Texas and Louisiana coasts, have been tapped for usage since they were established in 1975. He offered no estimate of how much prices would decline as a result of the sales, but he did say, ``I would expect it would have a downward impact.'' ``Should the oil situation deteriorate,'' Fitzwater said, the president was ``prepared to bring additional oil on the market'' from the reserve. While insisting there is no oil shortage in the United States ``at this time,'' Fitzwater said, ``this test is to make sure the system works.'' The spokesman said, ``Frankly, there is no way to justify'' price increases that sent oil soaring from $24 a barrel to $39 a barrel over the past week. ``We need to make it clear that we do have oil available to put on the market,'' Fitzwater said. In remarks prepared for a political fund-raising dinner, Bush said his action was needed ``because it is especially important that America is economically healthy and militarily strong.'' Fitzwater said the president felt the move was especially important as the nation neared the heating oil season. Bush said bids would be taken by the Energy Department for oil and should be awarding contracts within 15 days and delivering oil in 15 to 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: Panel: Rural Areas Not Prepared for AIDS Epidemic
DOC.TEXT: More money is needed to educate small-town doctors and their patients about AIDS, a national panel on rural health said Wednesday. AIDS caught rural towns unprepared, said Robert A. DeVries, acting chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Rural Health. ``There has been a sense that AIDS would not strike rural America,'' he said. ``We've now seen a 37 percent increase in the number of rural AIDS cases in one year compared to a 5 percent increase among urban populations,'' he said, citing U.S. Centers for Disease Control statistics for 1988-89. ``I think we see a surprised, relatively unprepared community of people,'' said DeVries, a program director for the W.K. Kellogg Foundation of Battle Creek, Mich. The committee, which advises Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan, ended a three-day meeting Wednesday. Among the AIDS-related recommendations adopted by the panel were suggestions that the federal goverment fund studies to collect and distribute data on the incidence of acquired immune deficiency syndrom in rural areas. Other recommendations included a toll-free hot line to provide information on AIDS to the rural health care community. ``People living in cities have had 10 years to learn about AIDS, how to treat it and how to protect yourself from getting it,'' said Pat Taylor, a program analyst for Office for Rural Health Policy. ``People in rural areas are just starting to learn. ``Some of the attitudes remind you of 50, 60 or 70 years ago when people used to keep members of their family who were mentally ill in the attic,'' Taylor said. The group also said an existing CDC program that provides information on social services and federal benefits for AIDS patients should be expanded. ``It's such an urban-orientated issue now,'' said Jerry Coopey, a senior analyst for the rural health policy office. ``There's a great deal of money going for AIDS in places like Chicago, Washington or New York. But rural areas are being affected too. We just want to get our fair share. The recommendations will be reviewed before being submitted to Sullivan at year's end in the advisory committee's annual report, DeVries said. The advisory group interviewed three AIDS patients, including Michael Goff, a 33-year-old former social worker. Goff, who was diagnosed with AIDS two years ago, told the group that rural AIDS patients face challenges never considered by their city counterparts. ``In this state, I do see people who are so afraid of what the public is going to find out, they don't get treatment or they do not seek benefits or they do not complain when they are discriminated against,'' he said. He said he formed a support group out of loneliness after his diagnosis.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Group Files Complaint Against Annunzio Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A Republican political organization charged in a formal complaint Wednesday that the campaign of Rep. Frank Annunzio failed to identify 20 contributors as officials and spouses of a Gaithersburg, Md., bank. Annunzio, an Illinois Democrat, called the accusations ``the product of my desperate opponent.'' Annunzio, who has served 26 years in the House, is chairman of the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions, and No. 2 Democrat on the full committee. The Chicago lawmaker faces Republican state Sen. Walter Dudycz in November. The complaint by the National Republican Congressional Committee, the political organization of House Republicans, was filed with the Federal Election Commission. U.S. election law says a campaign treasurer must make a ``best effort'' to obtain the name, address, occupation and the employer of a contributor. The complaint cited a Sept. 22 story by the National Journal, which said 20 of Annunzio's contributors were officials and spouses of Standard Federal Savings Bank, of Gaithersburg, Md. The Annunzio campaign, the complaint said, was ``able to obtain the name of the employer of every other individual who contributed during this period.'' Each of the 20 persons made two $200 contributions during 1990, for a total of $8,000. ``Mere probability makes it extremely unlikely that fully one-fifth of those contributors ... could, by coincidence, both work for or be directly associated with a single institution - and be the only 20 of one hundred for whom employers name was unavailable,'' said the complaint. Annunzio said he has ``done nothing wrong. ``I am prepared to go before any government body ... to answer any questions,'' said Annunzio. ``I have nothing to hide.'' The FEC is obligated to launch a preliminary inquiry into any complaint not initiated by its own staff. The election law sets maximum penalties of $10,000 for willful election law violations and $5,000 for less serious violations. Earlier this month, after news stories appeared about the contributions, Annunzio said there was nothing wrong with the donations - even though he was opposing a proposal that could have hurt the institution. On March 28, Annunzio's subcommittee held a hearing on the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. proposal, which involved mortgage servicing agreements. The proposal would have adversely affected Standard's business. The FDIC dropped it after Annunzio's hearing - which included testimony against the plan.

DOC.HEAD: Tutu Says Media Misrepresent South African Tribal Violence
DOC.TEXT: Bishop Desmond Tutu said Wednesday that news reports misrepresent tribal violence in South Africa's black townships when they focus on the ``black on black'' angle. ``The violence is mainly for political reasons over ideological political turf,'' the anti-apartheid activist said at Brown University, which presented him with an honorary degree. ``We're no more divided than any other normal community,'' he said. Tutu wondered aloud why the strife in Northern Ireland wasn't characterized as ``white on white,'' as the ``black on black'' violence is in South Africa. About 800 blacks have died since fighting began outside Johannesburg in early August between the African National Congress and Inkatha. Both organizations oppose apartheid, South Africa's policy of racial separation, but differ on plans for the country's future. ``This is the frustration of people who have been deprived for so many years,'' said Tutu, who won the Nobel Prize for peace in 1984 for his work against apartheid. ``The cost may be slightly higher than we thought.'' Tutu also questioned President F.W. de Klerk's commitment to his stated goal of ``one man, one vote'' for South Africa. But he said de Klerk, who met with President Bush on Monday, ``must be given considerable credit for his courage'' in trying to move the country away from apartheid. But Tutu said the world looks more to African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela as South Africa's spiritual leader. He contrasted the adulation given Mandela when he visited the United States earlier this year with de Klerk's lower-profile visit with Bush on Monday. ``It's as different as chalk and cheese,'' he said. Tutu also reiterated his call to Bush to retain economic sanctions against South Africa. ``It indicates whether you are on the side of the oppressed or the oppressor,'' he said. The president has indicated he might lift the sanctions if the government releases political prisoners and lifts the state of emergency in black townships. The bishop also said he had no qualms about accepting honors from Brown University, which has $635,000 invested in South Africa. Tutu has turned down similar honors from schools that had South African investments. But Robert Reichley, Brown's vice president of university relations, said Brown has reduced its investments from $33 million in 1984, and half of the remaining $635,000 is held by the school on behalf of others, including alumni. Asked if that amount was significant, Tutu replied: ``I would think that would be debating how many angels dance on the point of a needle.''

DOC.HEAD: Allies Raise Questions About U.S. Fund-Raising Drive
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 17 grafs new with details of the discussions, picks up 13th graf pvs, For his part
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-led task force met Wednesday to discuss providing billions of dollars in economic assistance in the Persian Gulf crisis but failed to resolve several disputes that are plaguing the fund-raising plan, officials said. The talks, which involved more than 65 officials representing over 20 nations, were held to launch the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group. President Bush announced formation of the group in a speech Tuesday. A senior U.S. Treasury official, who briefed reporters after the meeting ended, said the countries were in strong agreement that economic assistance to seriously affected countries was a critical element in the campaign to isolate Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. However, he conceded that the organizational session adjourned without resolving such key issues as how much money would be needed or even which countries would qualify for the funds. The issue of how much each donor country would be asked to contribute was also left undecided, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It was not our purpose at this first meeting to settle numbers,'' he said. ``The purpose of this meeting was to try to reach agreement on certain issues dealing with process and procedure.'' The official said a working group of lower-level officials headed by Assistant Treasury Secretary Charles Dallara would meet again within a few days to lay the groundwork for resolving some of the outstanding issues at a second meeting of the coordinating group, scheduled for Oct. 12. The October meeting will be chaired by Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford. Bush unveiled the coordinating group in a speech at the opening session of the IMF-World Bank meetings, saying the informal panel was needed to organize the fund-raising effort. Cees Maas, deputy finance minister of the Netherlands who participated in the discussions, said the group agreed on the goals but that there were no specific commitments made on amounts to be donated. ``We agreed that this has to be done quickly and that coordination is necessary,'' he said. Before the meeting began, British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said he had heard figures ranging from $8 billion to $18 billion for the amount of money being sought. U.S. officials, however, put the American request in a more narrow range of $13 billion to $15 billion. Some European countries contend that this amount is too high and should be scaled back to about $9 billion. The U.S. plan would target the assistance to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. The administration fears that without substantial aid the resolve of those key ``frontline'' states to support the campaign against Iraq might crumble. However, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait reportedly objected to the inclusion of Jordan in the aid package. Both countries have criticized Jordan for being reluctant to support the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. The U.S. official who briefed reporters said the issue of aid to Jordan was not resolved at the meeting. He said some countries are pushing on the other side to expand the definition of frontline states to include countries other than Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. That issue was also left unresolved, he said. For his part, Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto stressed that the proposed assistance package drawn up by the United States should be viewed only as a starting point for discussions and the final details would come only after donor nations had time to review the proposal. Japan has already pledged $2 billion for the economic assistance package and another $2 billion to support the U.S. military buildup in the Mideast. Publicly, no finance minister was willing to criticize the makeup of the U.S.-proposed steering committee, which will have both its chairman and vice chairman come from the administration. Brady will serve as chairman and his deputy will named by the State Department. The World Bank and the IMF were to supply technical support. Both agencies have pledged to supply billions of dollars from their own resources to help cushion the shock to poor nations from the doubling in world oil prices and other economic fallouts such as a flood of refugees from Kuwait and Iraq. In a speech to the IMF-World Bank annual meeting Wednesday, Brady appealed for a ``united economic front'' against Saddam. ``The economic strength represented by all of you in this room must be mobilized to demonstrate collective resolve and make clear our intention not to yield to aggression,'' he said. The nations participating with the United States in the crisis coordinating group included Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and South Korea. The group also was to include representatives from the 12-nation European Community and the Gulf Cooperation Council of Persian Gulf countries.

DOC.HEAD: Test Results Reportedly Fail to Link Suspects to Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Police patrols have been increased where five slayings occurred in this college - town reportedly after laboratory tests failed to link evidence with anyone on the list of suspects. The Gainesville Sun said it's uncertain whether the test results actually cleared any suspects in the stabbing deaths, or if they just failed to support existing suspicions. Sgt. Dick Gerard, a spokesman for the 150-member joint task force investigating the slayings, refused to say whether any of the lab results pointed to a specific suspect or cleared any suspect. ``We will not discuss any piece of evidence,'' Gerard said Wednesday. He said analysis of evidence is continuing and it may be four to six months before all the lab work is completed. Police are still interested in two identified suspects, Edward Lewis Humphrey and Stephen Michael Bates, Gerard said. Both are jailed on unrelated charges and neither has been charged in the Gainesville deaths. ``Mr. Humphrey is one of the individuals we are looking at,'' said Gerard, who repeated the same sentence, inserting Bates' name. The spokesman said he doesn't use the word suspect when discussing the case. Earlier, police said they had a pool of eight suspects. Gerard said the pool fluctates daily and could be as high as 30 or 40. Since the slayings in late August, police have frequently cautioned that the killer may still be roaming the streets of Gainesville. Four of the victims attended the University of Florida; one was a student at the city's Santa Fe Community College. Police declined to comment on the newspaper's report Wednesday that patrols in southwest Gainesville were increased in part because crime lab results did not implicate a suspect. The newspaper quoted unidentified law enforcement sources and also cited the apparent failure of intense searches of woods frequented by Humphrey, an 18-year-old freshman at the university, for the increased patrols. ``We are continuing to urge students and others to be extemely careful. Since arrests have not been made and no charges have been filed, we should assume that this is not solved in any way,'' said Art Sandeen, vice president for student affairs at the University of Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Life Sentence for Teen-ager Involved in Cult Murders
PAINESVILLE, Ohio (AP)nce for Teen-ager Involved in Cult
DOC.TEXT: - A cult leader's son who aided his father in the ritualistic murder of four family members should be sentenced to life in prison, a jury recommended Wednesday. Prosecutors had asked the jury to recommend the death sentence for 19-year-old Damon Lundgren, who wept when he told jurors Tuesday he didn't want to die. After four hours of deliberation, the jury recommended that Judge Paul M. Mitrovich sentence Lundgren to life without a chance of parole for at least 20 years on each of four aggravated murder counts.
