Jurors didn't specify if the sentences should run concurrently or consecutively. Mitrovich set sentencing for Oct. 5. The same jury convicted Lundgren on Sept. 18 of four counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping in the April 17, 1989, shooting deaths of Dennis Avery and his three daughters. He was acquitted in the slaying of Avery's wife, Cheryl. The Averys were bound, gagged and shot to death, then buried in a barn in Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. Lundgren's father, Jeffrey Lundgren, admitted to the killings. He said he was a prophet who was directed by God to kill the Averys because of their altering beliefs in the cult he founded. He has been sentenced to death. His wife, Alice, was sentenced to five life terms for conspiracy, complicity and kidnapping in the Avery deaths. According to trial testimony, Damon Lundgren helped wrestle to the ground and bind Dennis Avery before he was shot and served as a lookout while the other four were shot.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Parental Notification Rule for Teen Abortions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 12 grafs update with failure of vote to limit debate; picks up 9th graf pvs, The Senate accepted
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Wednesday to require federally supported family planning clinics to notify parents of teen-age girls who seek abortions. The action came on an amendment to a bill renewing federal family-planning assistance, which emerged as the latest battleground in the political war over abortion. The bill was already under a veto threat, however, and the vote was one in a series of conflicting and confusing Senate actions that left the bill facing an uncertain future. A vote to limit debate fell 10 short of the necessary 60 votes, diminishing prospects of any further action on the bill itself. The Senate approved by a large margin another amendment Tuesday evening that would nullify Bush administration regulations prohibiting the family planning clinics from offering any information or counseling involving abortion. The result was a Senate bill that contained provisions pushed by both anti-abortion and abortion-rights forces. In the House, meanwhile, a similar version, extending the life of family planning services provided through Title X of the Public Health Service Act of 1970, was approved by the Energy and Commerce Committee without any of the controversial Senate provisions on abortion. The clinics offer family planning and health services to the poor. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., subcommittee chairman and an abortion-rights advocate, said he would push for enactment of a bill without the Senate's abortion provisions as a way to avoid a presidential veto. ``I think our best chance to reauthorize Title X is to send a simple continuation of the program,'' Waxman said. The family planning act's authorization expired in 1985, but services have been funded by Congress each year since then through so-called continuing resolutions, or catchall spending measures. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., the bill's sponsor, said the action on parental notification means the Senate turns ``our back on millions of teen-agers.'' But Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, suggested Democrats had only pushed the bill to force President Bush's veto and said the services would again be funded regardless of the bill's outcome. ``Nobody is going to be denied those funds,'' Hatch said. The Senate accepted the parental notification amendment, offered by Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., on a unanimous voice vote after narrowly defeating a motion to table, or kill, the amendment. That key vote against tabling was 54-43. The requirement for parental notification applies only to organizations that receive federal money to provide family planning services to the poor, in cases where girls under age 18 seek abortions. Those organizations are prohibited from using federal money for abortions, but Armstrong said more than 30 perform abortions at the same clinic that provides federally supported family planning services. ``In almost every jurisdiction you have to have the permission of your parent .... to give blood,'' Armstrong said. ``But there is a surgical procedure for which that is not required, and it is abortion.'' Armstrong was thwarted in his first attempt to offer the amendment Tuesday evening. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., used parliamentary means to block a direct vote on Armstrong's amendment, but on Wednesday Armstrong succeeded in attaching his language to an unrelated amendment. ``There are no funds, no funds whatsoever, that are involved in abortion,'' Kennedy said, referring to federal money. The Senate's vote Tuesday night to nullify the administration's prohibition on abortion counseling provided abortion-rights advocates with a surprisingly large 62-vote majority. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., an abortion opponent, voted with abortion-rights advocates in support of the amendment, producing an initial 63-35 vote. But more than an hour after the vote was taken, Dole asked that his recorded vote be changed to ``no.'' Dole, who arrived late for the vote, simply made a mistake, said his press secretary, Walt Riker. ``He just made a mistake when he voted,'' Riker said. Doug Johnson, lobbyist for the anti-abortion National Right To Life Committee, said he had expected to lose by about a 60-40 vote. ``There were a couple of guys who screwed up and were confused,'' Johnson said. ``... That didn't help having the Republican leader confused.''

DOC.HEAD: UDC Students Occupy Buildings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Students upset over the acquisition of a controversial sculpture and other matters took over two buildings at the University of the District of Columbia on Wednesday and demanded a meeting with the board of trustees and the mayor. The students also are demanding removal by Mayor Marion Barry of 11 of the 15 trustees, according to Mark Thompson, spokesman for the student group. Thompson said some issues have been neglected by the board. ``We need to get rid of the board of trustees,'' he said. Barry was ``very sympathetic and in fact emphatic with our demands,'' Thompson said. A Barry spokeswoman said the mayor was waiting to see whether the students and university officials can work out an agreement. ``The mayor is not going to get involved at this time,'' Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley said. ``He wants to see if they can reach some kind of accommodation. He is watching the situation closely, however.'' The 200 demonstrators took over the main administration building and a nearby building housing the university radio station, bookstore and several offices and classrooms. They met briefly with interim President Miles Fisher IV in his office and agreed to leave the third floor of the building after officials said they could remain on the first two floors. University spokesman John Britton said the takeover was peaceful. Thompson said students had no desire to ``brutalize our beautiful institution.'' Thompson said the demonstration had the support of a majority of students on the campus. `We are a strong unified group. If they (other students) are not inside with us, they are outside supporting us.'' Evening classes were cancelled on the main campus, but classes were scheduled for the Mount Vernon Square campus several miles away downtown, and officials were trying to get in touch with the 15 trustees, Britton said. The students turned down a chance to meet with the chairwoman of the trustees, Nina Hardon Long. ``It was too late. It's tragic she had to wait until something like this happened to call a meeting,'' he said. The students had sent a list of 20 demands to the board on Monday, including one calling for the resignation of Ms. Long and two board colleagues. Ms. Long was instrumental in acquiring ``The Dinner Party'' by feminist artist Judy Chicago, a ceramic sculpture depicting the history of women in 39 dinner table settings, many containing a representation of female genitalia. The students protested that the acquisition threatened student and other university programs since the House of Representatives voted to reduce the university's operating budget by the $1.6 million the board voted to spend in renovating a library to house the work. The Senate did not make a similar reduction, and a conference committee will have to produce a reconciliation of the two versions. No university money was spent on the sculpture itself, which was a donation. Students had also said earlier they were upset with high turnover in the faculty and top administration, and that they had no voice in the decisions made by the trustees.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Said Ready To Sell $7.5 Billion In Weapons To Saudis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds detail throughout, Levine comment, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided to sell $7.5 billion in new weaponry to Saudi Arabia in immediate response to the Persian Gulf crisis, and to ask Congress' consent for another $14 billion next year, sources said. The package, which was to be submitted formally to Congress late Wednesday or Thursday, includes M-1A tanks, TOW anti-tank missiles, Bradley fighting vehicles, trucks and armored personnel carriers, said congressional and administration sources, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Also included are Patriot anti-missile batteries, although far fewer than the 20 or so originally proposed, and some Apache ground-attack helicopters, the sources said. Items in the package are those which are either in current U.S. stocks, can be delivered quickly, or must be ordered soon to meet Saudi defensive requirements in the standoff with Iraq, the sources said. Weapons which will take longer to deliver or which meet future Saudi force needs, such as F-15F fighter planes, will be in the package Bush will send to Congress in January, they said. The administration split the arms sale into two parts after supporters of Israel on Capitol Hill complained that the original request for some $21 billion in weaponry was too large and was being pushed through too quickly. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., a staunch supporter of Israel, said informal assurances he had received led him to believe the new package would pass congressional muster. ``This is a significant improvement'' over the original $21 billion package proposed by the administration, Levine said. ``This is what should have been proposed in the first place.'' Levine said lawmakers concerned about Israel's security support Bush's military moves to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But the earlier, larger arms sale proposal appeared to be an attempt ``to use the crisis as justification for sending items not needed for the crisis,'' Levine said. At the same time, the administration has been discussing a new package of military aid to Israel and senior officials have promised to maintain Israel's qualitative military advantage over neighboring states. Israel's backers said that they expect little objection in Congress to the administration's new proposal because of strong bipartisan support for President Bush's policy in the Middle East and Saudi Arabia's clear defensive needs.

DOC.HEAD: Round-the-Clock Peace Vigil to End Gulf Conflict Enters Second Month
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to CLARIFY that group previously indicated it would continue vigil. SUBS penultimate graf, `One of...', to CORRECT that Lowry didn't quit but was defeated in Senate bid. ^With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE4
DOC.TEXT: A small group Wednesday marked one month of a round-the-clock peace vigil, and pledged to stay at the city park until the Persian Gulf crisis is peacefully resolved. The ``PeaceWorks Park Vigil'' began spontaneously Aug. 26 when activists attending a peace-oriented concert at Gas Works Park decided they had to do something about the heightening tensions in the Middle East. The group of 20 agreed to keep up the 24-hour vigil, even if it meant sacrificing work and family life and giving up the amenities of indoor living. ``The reason we're still here is that the situation in the gulf today is just as bad as what motivated us to start the vigil in the first place,'' said Joseph Mabel, one of the spokesmen for the group. The ``vigilists,'' as they call themselves, say the group has numbered as high as 240 and as low as two or three at any one time. Participants trade shifts, and they say there has always been someone present. The group discussed how to prevent hangers-on from diverting the purpose of the vigil and how to keep members participating when winter weather comes. Visitors to the popular park on Seattle's Lake Union pass by a makeshift camp with rugs, recycling bins, bicycles, canned foods and a small library of peace-oriented books. The group is united in a call for an end to U.S. military involvement in the Persian Gulf, but beyond that statement each participant speaks individually. However, most share the belief that the Bush administration has sent U.S. troops to the region for cheap oil, rather than for any lofty ideal such as creating a stable world order. Vivian McPeak compares the U.S. policy to that of ``a junkie ready to fight anyone for his next fix.'' Added Karen Hill, ``This is a war of businessmen and bankers, but businessmen and bankers are never the casualties.'' Some in the group call themselves pacifists. But not John Hatch, who recently left the military after seven years of service. ``I personally wouldn't mind if the U.S. cleaned Saddam Hussein's clock and got out of there,'' Hatch said. But he said he doesn't believe that's possible, and fears the United States will become bogged down in a long, bloody war. Hatch, who decided to quit his job as a janitor to participate, said the group's number is increasing as passers-by learn of the vigil and join up. One of the visitors Wednesday was former Rep. Mike Lowry, D-Wash., who lost a Senate race after 10 years in Congress before becoming a Seattle University professor of political science. ``We need to be asking ourselves, `Is it worth it to send our young people off to die for cheap oil?''' Lowry said. ``There are things worth going to war over. To go to war over oil is wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Jordan's Rift with Saudi Arabia Deepens
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The diplomatic war in the Persian Gulf escalated on another front Wednesday - between Jordan and Saudi Arabia. Jordanian newspapers called Saudi officials ``warmongers'' who outdid Israel and the West in acting against Arab interests. The newspapers were reacting to Saudi Arabia's cutting off oil supplies to Jordan and expelling more than 30 Jordanian Embassy employees on charges of spying for Iraq. Officials in Amman sought to play down the division, hoping it will heal. But many Jordanians expressed bitterness and defiance. ``Let them drink their oil. We do not need them,'' said Ali Tobassi, a Jordanian waiting at a bus stand Tuesday. ``We will sweat to earn our daily bread and we prefer to starve rather than take their money.'' Jordan's Arabic-language daily Al-Rai said the Saudis seem to consider opposition to foreign troops in the gulf to be directed at them and sought ``to punish us in terms of halting oil supplies and accusing our embassy staff of espionage.'' ``This means the sister state of Saudi Arabia has virtually decided to declare a real war against the Jordanian and Palestinian people,'' it said. A multinational military force, including tens of thousands of U.S. troops, has assembled in the Saudi desert following Iraq's blitz takeover on Aug. 2 of the small oil sultanate of Kuwait adjoining Saudi Arabia. Jordan has supported Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in the confrontation, but said Wednesday it will halt all flights to and from Iraq to comply with a U.N. air embargo. Jordan's conservative Arabic-language Ad-Dustour was particularly incensed by remarks Tuesday by Saudi Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal that force was the sole option for getting Iraq out of Kuwait. It said in a front-page editorial, ``Saud al-Faisal has outdone the warmongers of Israel, Britain and even the United States in their campaign against Iraq.'' Saudi Arabia ordered 20 Jordanian diplomatic personnel out of the country on Saturday and 12 more on Tuesday. Jordan indignantly reported the move on national radio, and recalled its ambassador in protest. Saudi Arabia took the measures to express outrage over Jordan's pro-Iraqi stance and at what it saw as Jordanian attempts to undermine its government. Prince Bandar bin Sultan al-Saud, the Saudi ambassador in Washington, wrote an open letter to Jordan's King Hussein deploring what he called a defense of Iraq's ``horrifying acts of rape and destruction'' in Kuwait. Jordanian officials chose their words carefully in response. ``We do not understand why our brethren in Saudi Arabia are lashing out at us,'' said one senior official. ``I am sure that this is a misunderstanding which will be sorted out and I hope that will be soon.'' ``I am sure all these differences will be solved,'' said a senior Foreign Ministry official, who, like the other official, spoke on condition of anonymity. He denied that Jordanian officials in Saudi Arabia had spied on military installations. Western diplomatic sources, speaking privately, said evidence existed that some Jordanian Embassy employees acted individually on behalf of Iraq without the knowledge or permission of their government. Some officials in Amman first refused to acknowledge that Saudi Arabia, long a source of huge monetary grants to Jordan, had actually expelled Jordanians. But the reduction of Jordan's diplomatic staff to eight drove Amman authorities to going public. Jordan recalled Ambassador Naser Batayneh ``to protest such a Saudi action which is seen as inexcusable,'' said a Foreign Ministry statement read on the official Jordan Radio. The Saudis appeared especially angered over a pro-Iraqi conference in Amman last week that urged the overthrow of oil-rich Arab rulers and attacked Riyadh for allowing deployment of Western forces to protect it against possible Iraqi aggression. Last week, Saudi Arabia cut off oil supplies to Jordan, claiming Jordan owed $46 million in oil payments. Jordan denied it. The conservative, English-language daily Jordan times declared: ``Jordanians cannot be perplexed by these Saudi actions. . . . Be that as it may, Jordan will not give in and will continue to advocate its beliefs that what is going on in the Arabian peninsula and around it is extremely dangerous, particularly to Saudi interests and the Arab people at large.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Adopts New Law on Religious Freedoms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to show overwhelming initial approval to law and INSERTS 1 graf after 22nd pvs `But a...' to ADD that committee scheduled to go into session Monday to iron out final provisions. Picks up 23rd, `Patriarch Alexi...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature formally ended decades of religious repression on Wednesday, giving overwhelming initial approval to a law on freedom of conscience at a time when Soviets are flocking to churches in record numbers. ``Our people suffered to get this law,'' said Mikhail Kulakov, a leader of the Soviet Union's Seventh Day Adventists, who have been persecuted for evangelical activities. The law forbids the government from interfering with religious activities, improves the legal status of religious organizations and gives Soviet citizens the right to study religion in homes and in private schools. The Soviet constitution has long guaranteed freedom of worship, but in the past the Communist Party's ideological opposition to religion as the ``opiate of the masses'' made that guarantee hollow. In practice, the government discouraged religious services, closed churches and synagogues, imprisoned religious leaders and preached atheism. ``The most important thing for us is not only that the law is passed, but that it begins to work,'' said Adolph Shayevich, Moscow's chief rabbi. Peter Reddaway, an expert on Soviet religion at George Washington University in Washington, said in a telephone interview ``there is reason for optimism the law will be respected.'' He noted that official tolerance for religion has increased since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. Gorbachev's mother is a practicing member of the Russian Orthodox Church, and last year he acknowledged he was baptized as a child. ``The authorities have been loosening restrictions for a couple of years, and now they're putting it in writing,'' Reddaway said. He said Western experts estimate that a quarter of the 285 million Soviet people practice religion, and the number is rising fast. Among signs of religious revival are increasing numbers of seminarians and the reopening of churches that were used as storehouses, garages and even factories. Three years ago, Gorbachev held talks with the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, the first such meeting in more than 40 years. In December, he met Pope John Paul II at the Vatican. Bibles are no longer confiscated at Soviet borders, holiday church services are shown on television and religious publications are flourishing. On Sunday, a Divine Liturgy was held in the Kremlin's Uspensky Cathedral, the first full service allowed in Russia's most important cathedral since 1918. Jews are also enjoying greater religious autonomy, including freedom to study Hebrew, which previously had been suppressed. The Ukrainian Catholic Church, outlawed by Josef Stalin in 1947, has come out from underground and reclaimed some of its property. Under the new law, it can apply to local authorities to regain lawful status. In Soviet Central Asia, where Moslems predominate, attendance at mosques has risen and copies of the Koran are in heavy demand. The new law, which passed 341-1 with one abstention, says the government will not ``restrict the study, financing or propagandizing'' of religion. It was not a roll call vote and the identity of the person who abstained was not known. Atheism remains the doctrine of the Communist Party, but the law prohibits the government from funding either religious activities or atheist propaganda. It allows religious groups to set up societies and send people abroad for spiritual study. In the past, religious organizations had no clear legal standing and were unable to makecontracts or represent themselves in court. Under the new law, they have the same status as individual citizens. But a clause allowing public schools to be used for religious classes after regular hours set off a fierce debate and was defeated by one chamber of the legislature. While the bill was easily passed into law, a legislative committee is scheduled to go into session on Monday to settle provisions still in dispute - principally the public school issue and taxation of donations to religious organizations. Patriarch Alexi II, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, urged the legislature to ensure that government officials do not come between the church and the people. ``The Russian church has already experienced attempts on a political basis to destroy the unity of religious life,'' said the patriarch, who wore a black robe and majestic white headdress topped with a gold cross. Shortly after the 1917 Revolution, many priests were shot and the Bolsheviks began an anti-religious propaganda campaign. During World War II, Stalin revived the church to help lift morale and patriotism. But in the 1950s, Premier Nikita Khrushchev undertook a major anti-religion campaign, closing approximately two-thirds of the Orthodox churches, seven out of 10 seminaries and the majority of monasteries. Khrushchev's ouster in 1964 ended the campaign, but there was no significant restoration of church property or religious rights under his successor, Leonid Brezhnev. Reddaway said the Soviet Union has about 50 million Moslems, 30 million Russian Orthodox believers, 6 million Catholics, 2 million Jews and 1 million Baptists. But he said the percentage of Moslems who practice their faith is uncertain.

DOC.HEAD: Proponents of Invalidated Ballot Measures Cry Foul
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of voter initiatives Wednesday blamed calculating opponents and bungling bureaucrats for a court ruling that threw five of the measures off the ballot. A judge Monday tossed five of the 11 statewide initiative measures off the Nov. 6 ballot because of a technicality. The state is appealing the decision. One of the measures would have allowed tax credits for parents who send their children to parochial schools. Jim Andersen, canvassing director of Oregon State Public Interest Research Group, said Oregonians overwhelmingly favor his group's initiative to ban some non-recyclable packaging. ``Now, because of bureaucratic inefficiency and a well-organized and powerful opposition, hundreds of thousands of people's votes across the state will have no value and that's not right,'' he said at a rally. He noted that Oregon was the first state to implement the initiative process 88 years ago whereby voters can get issues on the ballot by petition. Marion County Circuit Judge Richard Barber ruled the measures invalid Monday because they don't contain statements on their estimated financial effects. The statements weren't included because of an earlier court ruling saying state officials missed a deadline for formally approving them. Opponents of the measures argued it was illegal to allow them to appear on the ballot without the financial statements. Another ballot measure invalidated by the ruling would shut down Oregon's only nuclear power plant, about 40 miles northwest of Portland, until waste disposal requirements are met. Anti-nuclear activist Lloyd Marbet told the rally that Trojan nuclear plant operator Portland General Electric Co. perpetrated a ``clear manipulation of the political rights of this state,'' when it participated in the attempt to have the measures invalidated. A spokesman for the utility, Steve Sautter, has said the company feels it is important for voters to know the economic impact of shutting down the plant. Other measures affected by the ruling would limit property taxes to 1.5 percent of value and establish a jobs program for welfare recipients. The education measure would have allowed tax credits of up to $2,500 a year each for pupils at private schools, including church-supported schools, and for children taught at home. Backers of that measure didn't attend the rally, which drew just a few dozen people. In Salem, a spokesman for House Speaker Vera Katz said Wednesday a special legislative session is among options being considered to get the measures back on the ballot if the ruling stands. ``We're absolutely not, at this point, pushing for a special session,'' said the spokesman, Dan Field. ``We certainly hope this thing will be resolved in the courts. If it's not, the Legislature should be prepared to consider all options. That may or may not include a special session.'' The Legislature would have authority to refer the measures to the ballot or could pass a law saying the measures will be on th ballot despite the foulup.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Accepts Responsibility for World War II Crimes
DOC.TEXT: The German people will never forget the suffering their country brought on Europe, and particularly the Jews, during World War II, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Wednesday. Addressing the 45th General Assembly one week before East and West Germany will be reunited, Genscher said, ``In this historic phase the Germans are filled with a sense of history and responsibility. ``They are not being carried away with nationalistic exuberance. ``We will not forget the endless suffering that was brought upon the nations of Europe and the world in the name of Germany.'' ``We commemorate all the victims of war and tyranny,'' the West German minister added, ``and we recall especially the untold suffering inflicted upon the Jewish people. We are aware of and accept our responsibility. ``We Germans are uniting in the determination that none of this must ever be allowed to happen again. He thanked the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union for their swift cooperation in completing the reunification treaty with Germany, a nation divided into capitalist West and communist East after World War II. The treaty was signed on Sept. 12. Genscher then declared, ``We Germans want nothing other than to live in freedom and democracy, in unity and peace with our neighbors. ``We reaffirm our renunciation of the manufacture, possession and control over nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. ``The united Germany has no territorial claims whatsoever against other states and will not assert any in the future. The inviolability of national borders is a cornerstone of Europe's peaceful order. ``The united Germany will confirm the existing German-Polish border in a treaty that is binding under international law.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Helicopter with 17 Aboard Ditches in Red Sea; All Saved
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A carrier-based helicopter carrying 17 American sailors had to ditch in the Red Sea during a training mission Wednesday, but all aboard were rescued unhurt, the Navy said in a statement. It said the SH-3H Sea King anti-submarine helicopter, carrying four crew and 13 passengers, splashed down about 5,000 yards from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy. Such copters are sometimes used on minesweeping runs, but the statement did not identify the training mission and Navy officials were not immediately available for comment on the 8:30 a.m. crash. The statement said the sailors were given medical examinations after being rescued and all found to be in good health. It said the helicopter stayed afloat for about two hours after the crash, but sank before it could be hauled from the water. Cause of the accident was being investigated. The Kennedy is among the warships enforcing economic sanctions on Iraq and assisting in the defense of Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Marlon Brando Courting Multimillion-Dollar Bids for His Memoirs
DOC.TEXT: Publishers are lining up to offer millions of dollars for the rights to an autobiography by Marlon Brando, according to the reclusive actor's adviser. ``He is writing and many publishers are making bids for the rights,'' attorney Belinda Frixou was quoted in Wedneday's Los Angeles Times. She refused to say how much he'd been offered. Warner Books' Ellen Herrick said her firm's $2 million offer already has been rebuffed. Officials at Viking Penguin and Pocket Books, Simon & Schuster's mass-market publications division, said they are in the competition. In a recent interview with Daily Variety columnist Army Archerd, Brando said he wouldn't hold back in writing about his tumultous career and private life. ``I have no inhibitions,'' the 66-year-old actor said. ``There isn't anything I won't go into. Whatever doesn't kill you makes you stronger.'' Frixou said Brando isn't writing his memoirs to raise money to pay legal fees for his son, Christian Brando, who goes on trial on murder charges next month. The actor put up his Los Angeles estate last month to secure his son's bail. The younger Brando is charged with the shooting death last May of his half sister, Cheyenne's, lover, Dag Drollet. He told police the shooting was an accident. The elder Brando is writing his memoirs without the help of a ghostwriter, Frixou said. ``He's doing it totally himself, he's a very good writer and has done scripts before. ``There've been so many different books about him, unauthorized biographies, that it is about time to set the record right and give everybody the correct version,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Tibetan Leader Says Independence Lacks Attention of Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The spiritual leader of Tibet said Wednesday the international outrage following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is absent with the Chinese occupation of his mountainous homeland because it lacks oil. ``There are also some big differences between 40 years ago and today,'' he said, referring to the Chinese takeover. ``Even if the gulf crisis had happened a few years ago, the situation would be different.'' The Dalai Lama and many of the 6 million Tibetans believe the area should be an independent nation. China claims Tibet is a part of its territory. The Dalai Lama, 55, was invited to Canada by the country's small Tibetan community. He has lived in exile in Dharmsala, India, since he fled Tibet with some of his followers after a failed uprising in 1959. The 14th Dalai Lama in a line that dates to the 14th century, he is considered a god-king to his people. In 1989, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his work. An acknowledged ``half-Marxist,'' he said the doctrine has failed because it is too rigid. ``It can work against human nature and that is why it declined and collapsed'' in Eastern Europe, he said. ``I think a new age is beginning,'' he said, noting the changes in Europe the past year came from ``an essentially non-violent peoples' movements,'' he said. ``I think it is quite safe to say the next century will be more harmonious.'' In 1987, he proposed a five-point peace plan to the Chinese as a first step toward resolving the status of Tibet. In 1988, he proposed a self-governing Tibet working ``in association'' with China. But the Beijing government has not taken the plan seriously, particularly since the crackdown on pro-democracy protesters last year, he said. ``They are only interested in my return. I told the Chinese government that my return is not the main issue. The main issue is the 6 million people of Tibet,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, European Community Jointly Denounce Iraqi Invasion
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and the European Community on Wednesday jointly denounced Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait and said they are ready to consider applying more pressure on the Baghdad government. Their joint statement was released after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met with Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis of Italy, current chief of the EC. It read, ``The European Community and its member states and the Soviet Union urge the Iraqi authorities to allow immediately all foreign citizens who so desire to leave Iraq and Kuwait. ``Time does not work for the aggressor. It will only strengthen the determination of the international community to repeal the aggression and to fully restore Kuwait's sovereignty.'' The Soviets and 12-nation EC vowed to cooperate fully to see that the trade embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait is enforced, and said they are ``also prepared to consider additional steps consistent with the U.N. Charter.'' Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III noted Tuesday that such steps could mean letting a U.N. military operation resolve the situation. The Soviet Union and European states also expressed their resolve to work together to help settle other Middle East conflicts, such as the Israeli-Arab confrontation, the Palestinian problem, and the Lebanese civil war. Their statement said efforts should be made to ``curb the arms race and to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction'' in the Middle East. The Kremlin and EC stand ready to help nations in the region ``in establishing a comprehensive structure in the region and in drawing up to that end a set of rules capable of fostering peace, tolerance, stability, economic cooperation and development,'' it added.

DOC.HEAD: Pirates Hijack Cypriot Ship, Steal Cargo
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. organization expressed concern Wednesday at the skill of sea pirates who last month stole a cargo of 2,000 tons of sheet steel worth about $1.8 million from a vessel off Thailand. Abhy Ankar, information officer of the International Maritime Bureau, said pirates in Southeast Asia ``are definitely becoming more professional. In this case they were very well-prepared.'' The bureau is based in London and investigates maritime crime. Ankar said pirates in the region usually targeted Vietnamese boat people - refugees fleeing communist-ruled Vietnam - but the bureau was also looking into attacks on commercial vessels. Ankar said the Cypriot-registered ship Marta was raided on Aug. 8, 24 hours after it left Bangkok for Busan, South Korea, with a cargo of steel. He gave this account: Four attackers with pistols and metal bars began firing on the ship at around midnight. They seized control and handcuffed the crew, then repainted the ship's funnel and changed the vessel's name to V-Tai. They replaced the Cypriot flag with one of a different nationality. The pirates told the crew - Dutch captain, two European officers and four Filipino ratings - their lives would be spared. The ship, then off the Thai-Cambodian coast, kept south for two days until it reached a pre-arranged position. The crew then was locked in a cabin and the cargo was unloaded into what the crew believed was a motorized barge or small vessel. The pirates stayed aboard, forcing the crew to sail toward Bangkok. After two days the pirates took a lifeboat and supplies, drugged the captain and took him hostage, and destroyed the Marta's communication equipment. The rest of the crew were told to sail to Bangkok. The Marta went aground near Bangkok harbor and a Thai naval patrol vessel picked up the crew. The pirates later handed the captain over to a fishing vessel.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando Tearfully Denounces Prosecution Effort to Bring Daughter In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Baby's name, Tooke, is cq in 10th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA5
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando burst into tears outside a courthouse Wednesday after accusing prosecutors of hounding his ailing daughter to testify at her brother's murder trial. The actor's display of emotion came at a brief news conference following a hearing at which a judge refused to reduce the first-degree murder charge against his son, Christian. The younger Brando is accused of fatally shooting his half-sister's Tahitian lover, Dag Drollet. The portly actor said he was offended by the prosecution's unrelenting efforts to force his daughter, Cheyenne, to return from Tahiti as a witness. He noted she recently gave birth to a son and said she has suffered severe injuries and a nervous breakdown. ``Cheyenne has suffered enormously,'' Brando said. ``She's been beaten physically. ... She's suffered a head injury where her face was smashed and she had to have her face remade. ``She's suffered a nervous breakdown,'' he continued. ``She's had to be in a sanitarium under a doctor's care and for that man (the prosecutor) to keep chasing my daughter is unspeakable. As a father, I am deeply offended.'' Brando's comments concerning Cheyenne's facial injuries refer to a car accident in which she was severely injured last year. But the reference to beatings was unclear and when he was asked whether he meant to suggest that her dead lover had beaten her, Brando refused comment. Christian Brando's lawyers have suggested that Cheyenne, 20, complained of such beatings to Christian on the night that Drollet, 26, was shot to death at Marlon Brando's estate in the hills above Los Angeles. Marlon Brando, 66, appeared composed until he was asked about Cheyenne's baby boy, born shortly after the May 16 killing. ``Tooke is doing fine,'' he said of the baby. ``He's healthy and strong. Cheyenne is doing her best. ...'' At that point Brando's eyes filled with tears, he lowered his head and began crying. He then rushed away. Superior Court Judge Robert W. Thomas upheld a Municipal Court judge's ruling that there was sufficient evidence to support Christian Brando's prosecution on a charge of first-degree murder. He scheduled a hearing for Monday to consider a prosecution request to delay the scheduled Oct. 9 trial date while authorities continue their legal efforts to bring Cheyenne Brando back to the United States to testify. Christian Brando, 32, who is free on $2 million bail, accompanied his father and a brother, Miko, to the courthouse. At the news conference outside, he was reticent, but was urged forward by his father. ``I'm just glad to be here,'' he said. ``I just want to go through with this and prove my innocence.''

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Still Apart On Arms Pacts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: RETRANSMITS a0767 to CORRECT keyword, US-Soviets sted Soviet, adn category code
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union were unable Wednesday to iron out their differences on unfinished treaties to reduce conventional and long-range nuclear weapons. But the Soviets hinted at progress and another round of high-level talks was set tentatively for Thursday afternoon. ``We're at a point where the issues are rather technical,'' a senior U.S. official said. Failure to reach agreement on the accords could force postponement of a 34-nation summit meeting in Paris in mid-November, interrupt the easing of East-West tensions in Europe and delay a trip to Moscow in December by President Bush. The pivotal talks were held by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in a mid-town hotel about a mile from the United Nations where they voted on Tuesday to impose an embargo on cargo shipments by air to Iraq and occupied Kuwait. The aim is to force Iraq to withdraw from the oil-rich emirate in the Persian Gulf, which it seized Aug. 2, sending tremors through world oil markets and touching off hoarding and price rises. ``On quite a few questions there is progress,'' Shevardnadze said at the conclusion of the meeting, which took nearly four hours. He did not specify which questions he had in mind. ``But in order to carry these thru to the end we'll have to meet again,'' he said. The senior U.S. official who briefed reporters later under rules that shielded his identity said Baker and Shevardnadze had recommitted themselves to completing the two treaties by the end of the year. He said they ``laid out some ideas,'' which he declined to describe, and would take them up again at their second meeting. Asked if any of the remaining issues had been resolved, the official replied: ``They are still unsettled.'' In a drive to complete the treaties, U.S. and Soviet negotiators met separately from Baker and Shevardnadze, continuing discussions they began last week in Washington. The Soviet group is headed by Viktor P. Karpov, a deputy prime minister and veteran arms specialist, and the U.S. delegation by Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew. Shevardnadze suggested a lot of work remains to be done. ``There are so many problems,'' he told reporters through a Russian translator. Baker said they also dealt ``a good bit with cooperation'' at the United Nations and added: ``We ran out of time, quite frankly.'' At the United Nations the two superpowers are working in tandem to tighten the economic screws on Iraq by denying the President Saddam Hussein's government all trade except for humanitarian food supplies. A senior U.S. official briefing reporters on condition of anonymity said the Soviets had backed away from any attempt to link the Persian Gulf crisis to other area problems such as the Arab-Israeli dispute and the future of the Israeli-occupied territories. Also, he said the Soviets ``want to give a new impetus to the proliferation issue'' and agreed to work more closely with the United States, once the Gulf crisis is over, to halt the proliferation of nuclear and chemical warfare technologies in the region. Baker began the meeting thanking Shevardnadze for a strong speech at the United Nations on Tuesday condemning Saddam and for the way the Soviet foreign minister chaired the Security Council session. Shevardnadze said he was operating under a ``directive'' from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to break the deadlock in the negotiations over reducing non-nuclear arsenals in Europe. He said the two sides had ``to find a solution.'' Two weeks ago, when Baker was in Moscow, they decided to jettison any attempt to limit the size of U.S. and Soviet troop concentrations in Europe under the treaty. They also considered abandoning limits on non-nuclear aircraft, as well, but deferred a decision. The question is whether all land-based aircraft should be included, as the United States proposed, or whether planes the Soviets say have defensive missions should be exempted from restrictions. Another unresolved issue is whether any single member of NATO or the Warsaw Pact should hold no more than 30 percent of permitted weapons, as the Bush administration proposes, or be allowed up to 40 percent, as Moscow favors. Also, the two sides have not agreed on verification procedures. Last week, R. James Woolsey, the chief American negotiator, said the United States would seek postponement of the Nov. 19 Paris meeting if agreement was not reached on a draft treaty in time. ``It's hanging in the balance,'' Woolsey said in Brussels. He said once a draft was ready the negotiators would need four to six weeks to translate about 200 pages of text and another 200 pages of data into six languages. ``We can't wait until midnight on Nov. 18 to decide things,'' he said. The treaty would impose ceilings on tanks, anti-aircraft artillery, helicopters and armored personnel carriers. Negotiations between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's 16 members and the seven-nation Warsaw Pact began in February 1989 after more than 15 years of negotiations on a similar accord ended in failure. East Germany, where some 350,000 Soviet troops are stationed, dropped out of the Warsaw Pact on Monday and will merge with West Germany, a NATO member, on Oct. 3. The oviets have agreed to withdraw the troops in phases. Bush predicted in May 1989 that the new treaty would be concluded within six months to a year. Also lagging is a treaty to reduce by about 30 percent U.S. and Soviet stockpiles of long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines. Bush hopes to sign the treaty at a Moscow summit with Gorbachev in December. But three key issues are unsettled. They are: -The kinds of restrictions to impose on the 154 heavy, ground-based SS-18 intercontinental missiles the Soviets will retain under the treaty. -Whether the Soviet Backfire bomber is to be classified as a strategic weapon and counted against the bombers the Soviets can retain under the treaty. -The restrictions to be imposed on U.S. and Soviet transfers of weapons barred under the treaty to allies - from the United States to Britain, for instance.

DOC.HEAD: Two Women Charged in Child-Selling Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Two women were arrested on felony child-selling charges Wednesday after one allegedly paid $3,000 for the other's newborn, officials said. Authorities were investigating whether one of the women, Nellie Cutright of nearby Mayport may have been involved in other child-selling cases over the past nine years. Ms. Cutright, 45, was held in the Duval County Jail on $50,000 bond on one count of child-selling and one count of insurance fraud, Assistant State Attorney E. McRae Mathis said at a news conference. Virginia Underwood, 25, of Pensacola, was charged with child-selling for turning over her newborn daughter, Kayla, to Ms. Cutright for $3,000 when the baby was born about a month ago, Mathis said. Ms. Underwood, who surrendered to authorities and is cooperating with investigators, has been released on her own recognizance, he said. Her whereabouts could not be determined Wednesday by The Associated Press. Pensacola is 360 miles west of Jacksonville. Prosecutors charge Ms. Cutright, wife of a Navy sailor, checked Ms. Underwood into Memorial Medical Center in Jacksonville under her name. When Ms. Underwood had her baby, she was paid $3,000 for giving the child to Ms. Cutright. Hospital bills and expenses were paid by the military's insurance under the false impression that it was Ms. Cutright who had the baby, Mathis said. The baby, which was with Ms. Cutright at the time of her arrest, has been placed in state custody, Mathis said. Mathis said investigators found blank and altered birth certificates, photographs and altered military dependent identification cards in Ms. Cutright's home in government housing near Mayport Naval Station. The documents ``lead us to believe that there was some sort of ring going on in which a number of children have been sold or otherwise transferred from their natural mothers to other people.'' Mathis said investigators are looking into alleged child-selling activity in Florida, Missouri, Virginia and Texas extending back as far as nine years at prices as high as $25,000. The child-selling and insurance-fraud charges are third-degree felonies punishable by up to five years in prison, Mathis said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Held in Grisly Death of American
DOC.TEXT: Several soldiers were being held in connection with the decapitation of an Illinois man who ran a tourist lodge in Guatemala, an army spokesman said Wednesday. Col. Carlos Fernando Duran said the soldiers were at the Santa Elena military base in the northern province of Peten. He refused to say how soliders were being held, but several local newspapers and a television station reported there were four. Michael Devine, 49, was found slain on June 9 two miles from Poptun, a town about 240 miles northeast of Guatemala City near the border with Belize. The Belleville, Ill., man owned the Xobel de Poptun Inn. He also worked as a tourist guide and transported goods for ranches in the area. Duran said the soldiers were being held on the order of a judge in Flores, the provincial capital. He did not say if other suspects also were being sought. Earlier this month, President Vinicio Cerezo said in a letter to U.S. Ambassador Thomas Strock that ``people linked to the security forces could be responsible'' for Devine's death. The president said he had changed the posts of military authorities ``so that for no reason can obstacles to development of the investigations or judicial process crop up.'' Also this month, the U.S. State Department issued a travel advisory for Guatemala, citing ``indiscriminate terrorist attacks,'' crime and fighting between the armed forces and rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Planes Land in Amman Despite Embargo, Jordan Says They're The Last
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with threats against foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait, oil to be sold from U.S. reserves, arms to be sold to Saudis, details. CORRECTS Tuesday to Wednesday for Jordan's airplane remarks. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,IST1,AMM1,3,LaserColor AMM103
DOC.TEXT: Three Iraqi passenger planes landed in Jordan on Wednesday, but Jordan said later it will halt all flights to and from Iraq to comply with a U.N. air embargo. Iraq accused Washington of bribing Moscow to back the U.N. sanctions. New threats meanwhile emerged against foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait. Diplomats in Baghdad said the government told their missions it will no longer provide food rations for distribution to their communities as of Monday. They said an Iraqi memorandum sent to all non-Arab missions blamed the air embargo imposed Tuesday, saying it was expected to create major food shortages. Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. About 1,000 Americans and 5,000 other Westerners are among tens of thousands of non-Arab foreigners stranded by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of the oil-rich sultanate. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said in New York on Wednesday that Iraq has threatened the death penalty for anyone hiding foreigners in diplomatic embassies. He said he rejected the threat as ``repugnant'' and also rejected an Iraqi demand for names of people given sanctuary in the embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait. Baker said the Iraqi note was delivered to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. In Washington, Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat denied Wednesday night that Iraqi officials made any such threats. In a sign that U.N. sanctions are hurting Iraqis, Baghdad announced Wednesday it would extend rationing to rice, flour and cooking oil. The West was also feeling the economic impact of the crisis. Oil prices have jumped to about $39 a barrel from $21 before the invasion. Saying ``no justification'' existed for the run-up in oil and gasoline prices, the White House announced President Bush had decided to sell 5 million of the 590 million barrels of crude oil in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Earlier Wednesday in Washington, Iran's minister of economic affairs and finance, Mohsen Nourbakhsh, asked nations with huge oil stockpiles to help restore stability to oil markets by tapping their strategic reserves. But Bush was not acting in response to that request. The United States reportedly planned ``a show of force'' by sending its first aircraft carrier into the Persian Gulf in 16 years, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney warned that an Iraqi military strike was increasingly likely. Cheney told a conference of business economists in Washington the Bush administration had foreseen a key danger point in the standoff with President Saddam Hussein would arise once sanctions began crippling Iraq's economy. ``We may have seen in the last 48 or 72 hours the beginning commentary from him that would indicate that the sanctions are beginning to bite,'' he said. Congressional and administration sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush has decided to sell $7.5 billion in new weaponry to Saudi Arabia in immediate response to the crisis, and to ask Congress' consent for another $14 billion next year. About 165,000 U.S. soldiers are stationed in the Saudi desert and aboard ships in the region. Thousands of Arab and European troops have also been deployed as part of the U.S.-led multinational force, assembled to deter any Iraqi thrust against Saudi Arabia and its vast oil holdings. U.S. officials encountered reservations Wednesday by allies on a fund-raising campaign to collect the billions of dollars needed in the gulf crisis. Representatives of some of the 20 American allies met in Washington. A West German official said some European countries questioned whether a new U.S. goal of $14.5 billion in aid for nations facing Iraq overstated the need. Saudi officials questioned whether Jordan, criticized for being reluctant to oppose Saddam, should get aid. The new air embargo was tested Wednesday by the Iraqi landings in Amman, Jordan. Passengers aboard the regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flights landing there included nine expelled French diplomats and 11 Britons stranded by the invasion. It was not known what the cargo holds contained. The planes all returned to Baghdad. Jordanian officials first said the passenger aircraft were not included in embago resolution passed Tuesday by the U.N. Security Council. But Foreign Minister Marwan Kasim later said in New York in a statement at U.N. headquarters that Jordan would comply fully with the embargo and halt passenger flights to and from Iraq, including freedom flights for Westerners. Baghdad's official news agency accused Moscow - a former ally - of being bribed by the United States and gulf sheiks to oppose Iraq. It said the tone of a tough U.N. speech Tuesday by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze ``clearly shows the bribe given by American and its allies the oil sheiks.'' Iraqi officials announced new food rationing will begin this weekend. Trade and Finance Minister Mohammed Mahdi Saleh said sugar and tea also will be affected by the new restrictions. The government already closed fast food restaurants and many pastry shops because they use large amounts of sugar. Bakeries still open make only bread, which has been rationed since Sept. 1. The Security Council already has authorized military enforcement of a sea embargo. The air embargo is largely symbolic, since most trade with Iraq is by land and has already been halted. Iraq's only major export is oil. Also on Wednesday: -Cheney ordered 40,000 troops removed from Europe within a year to respond to declining defense budgets. The decision has no direct connection to the U.S. deployments in the gulf area. -U.S. military sources in the gulf said the carrier Independence was expected to sail into the gulf within the next few days, bringing it within 500 miles of Iraq. The carrier, with 70 attack jets, would be the first such U.S. warship in the gulf in 16 years. -A carrier-based SH-3H Sea King helicopter carrying 17 sailors ditched in the Red Sea during a training exercise but all were rescued unhurt, the Navy said. The copter sank after landing about 5,000 yards from the carrier John F. Kennedy, it said. -U.S. Marines defending Saudi oilfields were told by their commander to expect a long desert stay. Gen. Alfred Gray also said the Marines should be prepared to shift to offense if Saudi Arabia is attacked. -In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Iraq had rounded up at least seven more Americans, bringing to about 100 the number being detained. Many have been taken to military and industrial complexes to deter a potential U.S. military attack. About 1,000 Americans remain in Kuwait and Iraq, denied permission by Iraq to return to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Rating System Gets New `NC-17' Rating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-9, bgng `Films now...,' with 5 grafs to ADD explanation of old X rating, expected effect of change on pornography. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `For months...
DOC.TEXT: The X rating was eliminated Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America in favor of a new NC-17 rating that bars children but does not carry the commercial stigma of the X. Filmmakers hope the new rating, effective immediately, will carry none of the advertising and exhibition restraints that an X rating guaranteed. They maintain that the X rating had become synonymous with hard-core pornography, and served no purpose in evaluating artistic films best suited for adults. The R rating, which bars unaccompanied minors from certain films, remains intact, as does the PG-13, PG and G ratings. ``It's a great step,'' said Philip Kaufman, director of the X-rated Universal Pictures film ``Henry & June.'' The historical drama, which features some explicit sex, was set for a ratings appeal next week and will be the first recipient of the new NC rating, which would bar children under age 17. ``I'm just really delighted that we can show this film uncut in America and show the film the way I made it,'' Kaufman said. ``It is not intended as a prurient film.'' The old X rating meant no children under 17 allowed, but states had the option to set a higher age cut-off. Under NC-17, states also will have that option, says William Kartozian, president of the National Association of Theater Owners, who predicted that a few will raise the rating to NC-18. It was unclear whether newspapers and television and radio stations, which tend to reject advertisements for X-rated films, would be more inclined to carry ads for movies bearing the NC-17 mark. The new rating will be copyrighted, the MPAA said at a New York news conference. The X rating was not and is used widely by the adult movie industry. Films that got an X rating from the MPAA will be switched to NC-17 at the request of the film's owner. The new NC-17 rating cannot be used by porno producers unless they submit their films to the MPAA for review, which they never do because it costs money. Most theater chains refuse to show X-rated films, regardless of artistic merits. Kartozian predicted most of those theaters will show NC-17 movies. For months, a variety of directors and film producers have sought a change in the ratings system. Other X-rated films aimed at mainstream moviegoers included ``Hardware,'' ``Frankenhooker,'' ``Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer,'' and ``Life is Cheap ... But Toilet Paper is Expensive.'' The announcement marks a significant about-face by the MPAA. Its president, Jack Valenti, had maintained during months of complaints that the procedure worked. ``It's fair to say we've received justifiable criticism,'' Valenti said Wednesday in New York. ``It's no one's fault, but the X rating has a patina, a complexion which frankly we never intended it to have. By renaming it NC-17, we hope we will convey to the movie world there are any number of reasons for a film to get this rating. ``We hope this will clarify that we are not making judgments on X-rated films,'' Valenti said. ``I wanted to make sure if a change was made, it was reasonable, sane, wise and beneficial to the parents.'' Coupled with the new rating, the association also will provide theater owners and critics with more detail on films with an R rating and why exactly they received it: sex, violence, language. Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax Films, was especially relieved by the decision. Several of Miramax's recent releases have been rated X. They include ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover'' and ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' from Oscar-nominated director Pedro Almodovar. ``I think this is a great step forward,'' Weinstein said. ``Miramax is delighted to have played a significant part in the battle against censorship in America. This just goes to show that being tenacious without waving the flag can get the job done.'' Before the announcement, Valenti had been adamant in his defense of the previous system. He said the ratings continued to provide useful guidelines to parents. ``If you add another category, you're asking the rating board to make judgments about artistic integrity,'' Valenti said in July. He maintained Wednesday that he had not compromised. The last time the ratings were changed was in 1984, when the PG-13 rating was added between the PG and R ratings. That change was prompted by ``Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom.'' A number of films during recent years have been rated X, but the frequency of the rating became newsworthy as critics and theater chains pressed for a new rating category. Other X-rated films have included 1969's ``Midnight Cowboy,'' 1973's ``Last Tango in Paris,'' 1969's ``if...'' and 1971's ``A Clockwork Orange.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Lawmaker Pleads Guilty in Statehouse Probe
DOC.TEXT: A former state lawmaker admitted Wednesday that he sold his vote and tried to persuade other lawmakers to take bribes. Robert Kohn was one of 10 lawmakers caught in the web of an FBI investigation of the South Carolina Statehouse. The Republican from Charleston pleaded guilty to one conspiracy count, the fourth lawmaker to plead guilty. Kohn is cooperating with investigators and resigned his seat as part of a plea bargain. The conspiracy count carries a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison and a fine of $250,000. During a hearing before U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins, prosecutors showed a videotape of Kohn pocketing $2,500 on a yacht off Hilton Head Island last April 14. Kohn admitted the money came from lobbyist Ron Cobb, although Cobb is not seen in the picture. Cobb was working undercover for the FBI, agent Mike Clemens testified, and met with Kohn last fall. They discussed Kohn's support of a bill allowing voters to decide whether they wanted to allow pari-mutuel betting. Kohn promised to support the bill for $10,000. He also said he would try to get other lawmakers to sell their votes, Clemens said. He said Kohn accepted $2,500 from Cobb on Jan. 16 and another $2,500 on the yacht. A legislative effort to move the bill to a vote failed earlier this year. Kohn, 45, had been a state representative since 1975. He declined comment because of a gag order imposed by the judge.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Calls For Better Assessment of Priorities
DOC.TEXT: EPA Administrator William Reilly called Wednesday for a re-examination of the nation's environmental priorities to focus more attention on the areas of greatest risk. Reilly, in an address to the National Press Club, said limited resources to deal with the vast number of environmental issues facing the country must not be wasted on low-priority items. He released a report by the agency's Science Advisory Board which concluded that too many agency decisions are made because of publicily perceived health risks, and not risks based on scientific research. The report said, among other things, that EPA should ``attach as much importance to reducing ecological risk as it does to reducing human health risk.'' The advisers grouped problems into high, medium and low risk areas. Oill spills, groundwater pollution and radioactive isotopes pose relatively low risks, they said. Pesticides, acid rain and surface water pollution were examples of what they said were medium-risk areas. The high-risk group consisted of four problems: global warming from the ``greenhouse effect,'' depletion of the ozone layer, loss of biological diversity and extinction of species and destruction of natural environments such as rain forests. Reilly and his predecessors have expressed chagrin that the agency, at congressional direction, spends billions of dollars every year on cleaning up toxic waste dumps - which among other things pollute groundwater - and much less on more serious environmental and health risks. ``We must do a better job in setting environmental priorities,'' said Reilly. He urged a ``broad, robust national dialogue'' involving the EPA, Congress, industry and the public on what areas pose the greatest risks and where government resources should be directed. ``Are we spending all our money on the right things?'' Reilly asked. Too often in the area of environmental protection, the government has not, he suggested. ``As we gear up to deal with the environmental problems of the 1990s and beyond, I think the time has come to start taking aim before we open fire,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Flights Canceled Because of Refuelers Strike
DOC.TEXT: The two major domestic airlines canceled more than 200 flights Thursday as a nationwide strike by airport refuelers moved into its second day. Ansett Airlines spokesman Peter Young said fewer than 70 flights were scheduled, about 30 percent of normal. The percentage for the busiest route, Melbourne-Sydney, was slightly higher. Australian Airlines said its flights were similarly affected. The refuelers gave airlines dispensation to fly to and from Tasmania because of economic problems in the island state. Flight cancellations left plans of an estimated 20,000 travelers in doubt. Bus and train bookings were heavy. The refuelers struck at midnight Tuesday in a manning dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Aid Package Announces as Protests Continue
DOC.TEXT: A special agriculture assistance program was unveiled Wednesday following the latest demonstration by farmers protesting low-priced meat imports and other issues. The centerpiece of the package is a $270 million fund to assist farmers in debt because of foreign competition or the prolonged drought in France. Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet also said special protection would granted to farmers above age 55 to ensure they are not put out of business for non-payment of debts. Earlier Wednesday, riot police used tear gas to drive back about 500 sheep farmers throwing eggs, tomatoes and bottles outside a fairgrounds where Premier Michel Rocard was to address a communications forum. About 1,000 police officers blocked protesters from entering the grounds in the south-central town of Valence. Some farmers tried to drive tractors through the barriers. Others set fire to tires to block the entrance to a local government building. Rocard, who flew into the fairgrounds by helicopter, said in his speech that protesters give themselves a bad image and complicate efforts to aid their industry. In recent weeks, angry French farmers have staged dozens of demonstrations nationwide and hijacked livestock trucks carrying imported animals. Hundreds of cows and sheep have been killed and, in some cases, burned alive.

DOC.HEAD: Belt Stops Bullet In Drive-By Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A highway worker's belt stopped a bullet from injuring him in a drive-by shooting, police say. Garland police spokesman Allan Peck said Thomas Duane Purcell, 30, of Mesquite, was struck by a bullet about 2:20 a.m. Wednesday. ``Highway department employees were picking up newspapers that had been dropped by a truck. In the process, one of the workers was resting, sitting on the guardrail in the median,'' said Peck. Purcell heard a crack and a whiz, and was knocked off the guard rail. He was shot in the back, but the bullet only penetrated his belt, Peck said. Purcell didn't require medical treatment, police said. No arrests have been made.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Investigating Credit Union Indicts Two
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury investigating a failed credit union concluded Wednesday that stories of sexual abuse and drug trafficking that arose after the credit union closed were unfounded. The grand jury returned two indictments and said in its report that it found evidence of obstruction of justice in its investigation of the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union. Shortly after Franklin failed in November 1988, allegations were circulated about sexual abuse of children and drug abuse among prominent Omaha residents. The grand jury report said it didn't find any credible evidence that any prominent individuals in Omaha were involved in ``any ring of organized activity to sexually exploit minors, transport minors in interstate commerce for sexual purposes, or to traffic in controlled substances.'' ``Hopefully, this will place to rest the concerns and the rumors that have been circulating in our community this past year,'' said U.S. District Judge Lyle Strom, who dismissed the grand jury. Indicted were Alisha Owen, 22, who testified that she was sexually abused as a minor, and Sandra Rhode Prucha of Omaha, former assistant to the manager and treasurer of the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union. Ms. Owen, who was indicted ealier on perjury charges by a county grand jury, was charged with eight counts of lying to the federal grand jury. Ms. Prucha was accused of one count of bank fraud. The grand jury is the same one that issued indictments last year against Lawrence E. King Jr., former manager of Franklin. King is awaiting trial in U.S. District Court on 40 counts charging conspiracy, fraud and filing false tax returns in connection with the November 1988 failure of Franklin. King's wife, Alice, is charged with 12 counts of conspiracy and fraud. The National Credit Union Administration also has filed lawsuits against the Kings seeking to recover some of the $39 million it says was missing from the credit union. The federal grand jury spent 24 months investigating the credit union's failure. Its report said it found evidence to believe there had been an obstruction of justice but not enough to charge anyone but Ms. Owen. The federal grand jury indicted Ms. Owen for statements she made to the federal grand jury in June. In July, a Douglas County grand jury indicted Ms. Owen on eight counts of perjury for testimony she gave to the grand jury in the state court system. The Douglas County grand jury had said a story of sexual abuse and prostitution told to a legislative committee was ``a carefully crafted hoax.'' The bank fraud charge against Ms. Prucha, 47, alleges that she used expense vouchers to obtain cash and credit, then used the cash and credit for her personal use, Lahners said. The indictment alleges that about $29,000 was involved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Found Dead After Holding 13 in Restaurant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede and 9th graf to CORRECT hostages to 13 sted 12, according to police. Picks up 10th graf, `He kept...'
DOC.TEXT: A man armed with a high-powered rifle stalked his wife inside a fast-food restaurant Wednesday, trapping the woman and 12 workers for more than three hours before killing himself, police said. The hostages, including a pregnant employee, left the restaurant basement unharmed after police fired tear gas. ``It is our belief at that time that the gunman took his own life,'' said Ken Robertson of the Hamilton-Wentworth police. The gunman's name was not immediately released by authorities. The incident began about 12:20 p.m. EDT when the man fired several shots at his wife outside a McDonald's restaurant in a southern section of Hamilton, about 30 miles southwest of Toronto. The woman ran into the restaurant, followed by her husband. ``Needless to say, pandemonium broke loose,'' Robertson said. Patrons and about 30 employees ran from the restaurant after the gunman entered. Police said the wife and employees hid in sections of the restaurant's basement, which houses regional offices of McDonald's. The gunman tried unsuccessfully to find his wife among the locked offices. ``He kept saying `Where is she? Where is she?''' said Trish Obermeyer, one of those in the basement. ``And then he left us because she wasn't there. He really didn't want anything to do with us.'' Police reached some of those trapped inside by telephone, telling them to leave through a side door after tear gas canisters were fired. Police cordoned off a half-mile area around the restaurant. It was the second hostage incident at a McDonald's this week. On Monday, a gunman believed to have robbed a clothing store held 19 hostages for seven hours in La Verne, Calif. The alleged gunman was arrested and no one was injured.

DOC.HEAD: Steven Star, Consultant, Author and MIT Professor
DOC.TEXT: Steven H. Star, a media consultant, author and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, died of lung cancer Tuesday, at his home. He was 51. A member of the Sloan faculty since 1983, Mr. Star was director of the Marketing Center at MIT and, since last year, editor in chief of the Sloan Management Review. His death was confirmed by school officials. He was the co-author of ``Organization Strategy: A Marketing Approach'' in 1970, senior author of ``Problems in Marketing'' in 1977 and co-author with Glen L. Urvan of ``Advanced Marketing Strategy'' which is due out this month. From 1965 to 1978, Mr. Star taught at the Harvard Business School. He was also a consultant who specialized in corporate strategy and marketing, especially in the news media. ``Steve may have been the most brilliant analyst of his generation of the business and the journalism of newspapering,'' said William F. Woo, editor of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. A native of Chicago, Star graduated from Northwestern University in 1960 where he was a Phi Beta Kappa. He earned a master's degree in history at Harvard University where he was a Woodrow Wilson Fellow and received an MBA in international business and a doctorate in marketing from the Harvard Business School. Star was the founder and faculty chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers Association-International Newspaper Marketing Association seminars. He also taught marketing in the advanced management program at Oxford University in England. He leaves his wife, Brenda, and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Heavenly Help: Homeowners Call on St. Joe
DOC.TEXT: A devilish real estate market has homeowners trying an age-old religious custom - they're burying statues of St. Joseph. That's what purveyors of religious goods believe, and they say sales prove it. ``I can't keep them in stock and the importers can't get them fast enough,'' said James Borger, owner of J&H Church and Religious Goods of Bellmore on New York's Long Island. ``People are a little bit embarrassed to admit that's what they're doing, but that is what they're doing,'' said Borger, who queries his customers. St. Joseph, husband of Mary, the mother of Jesus, has long been looked upon as the patron saint of families, said Rev. James Coen, of the Catholic Information Center in Washington. Joseph's presence in the real estate market dates back centuries when a group of European nuns looking for property to build convents would place a medal of St. Joseph on prime land and ask the saint to intercede. Legend says it worked. ``I don't know who's pushing the story these days, but I know there's been an increase'' in sales, said Will Comellas, manager of the Alba-Cornerstone religious gift shop in Manhattan. Practioners aren't not all Catholic, either. ``A couple of months back I had a man from the Jewish faith come in, he said it was worth a try,'' Borger said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officers Reportedly Targeted in Investigation of 43 Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A task force investigating the slayings of 43 women in San Diego County is targeting six current and former police officers, two newspapers reported Wednesday. The Metropolitan Homicide Task Force is investigating officers who may have associated with slain prostitute Donna Gentile or her missing friend Cynthia Maine, the Los Angeles Times and The San Diego Union said. Gentile and Maine both were prostitutes and police informants, had served time in jail and were romantically involved with at least one member of the San Diego police force, the newspapers reported. Gentile was found slain in 1985, shortly after she testified against two police officers. Maine disappeared in early 1986, three months after gaining early release from jail by agreeing to provide information on several officers, the newspapers reported. ``The task force is trying to find out where (Maine) is, but they believe she's dead,'' a source told the Times. ``They are thinking it's more than a coincidence that these six officers had some involvement with one prostitute who is dead and one who is missing.'' Surveillance has been conducted on several officers and authorities eventually expect to talk to them to determine if they are linked to some of the killings of 43 women, mostly prostitutes, whose bodies have been found in remote parts of San Diego County since 1985, the Union said. Investigators have said they believe some, but not all, of the slayings may have been committed by the same person. The only person arrested so far in any of the cases is Alan Michael Stevens, 48, a Southern California drifter charged in the 1988 death of Cynthia McVey. His trial is set to begin Monday. Task force spokeswoman Bonnie Dumanis confirmed the Maine investigation but wouldn't elaborate. ``We are talking to anyone who has known or been associated with Cynthia Maine, but I wouldn't say we're investigating anyone in particular,'' Dumanis said Wednesday. Gentile was killed shortly after she testified before a city Civil Service Commission about police misconduct. She was found with rocks packed in her mouth, suggesting to detectives that she was killed because of her testimony. Maine, the daughter of a former San Diego police officer, was sent to jail in September 1985 for writing bad checks. While there, she agreed to provide information against several police officers in exchange for early release, said Maine's sister, Lori Helle. She was released from jail in November 1985 and disappeared three months later. Maine's mother, Lynda Coleman, said her daughter worked undercover for police at Solar Turbines Inc. in drug investigations.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pushes Trade Pact With Mexico
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 9-10: ``Sen. Lloyd,'' Bentsen commment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress on Wednesday for a streamlined process to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico, the nation's third-largest trading partner. The agreement would be aimed at removing tariffs, quotas and other trade barriers between Mexico and the United States. A free-trade treaty already is in force between the United States and Canada. Canada also has asked to participate in the U.S. negotiations with Mexico to achieve a trade treaty applying to all three countries. Bush said the administration would explore the possibility of a three-nation accord and inform Congress of his recommendations.
