In a letter to the Senate Finance Committee and House Ways and Means Committee, Bush formally notified lawmakers of his intention to open trade talks with Mexico. He said that Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has undertaken ``dynamic, market-oriented reforms.'' ``We see substantial opportunities for mutual benefit in further lowering impediments to bilateral trade in goods and services and to investment,'' the president said. The notification gives Congress 60 legislative days to decide whether or not to deny Bush's request for so-called ``fast-track' negotiating authority. Because of the congressional calendar, the 60-day period should run out sometime next spring. If the fast-track process is authorized, the United States would begin negotiations under rules that would prevent the Senate from being able to amend any treaty that results. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, who chairs the Finance Committee, signalled a certain reluctance to embrace the fast-track, no-amendment process. ``Never before have we negotiated a free-trade agreement with a country so different from us economically,'' he said. Bush said that if the United States decides to expand the talks with Mexico into a three-nation negotiating process, it would not affect the validity of the trade agreement with Canada. Last year, the United States exported $24.97 billion in goods to Mexico and received $27.19 in imports, for a deficit of $2.2 billion. Mexico has the world's eighth largest oil reserves, and a free-trade pact with the United States could spur oil production.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Hall Opens Centennial Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Carnegie Hall opened its centennial season Wednesday with the same piece of music that opened the very first concert in the hall on May 5, 1891. Beethoven's ``Leonore Overture No. 3'' was performed expertly and with restraint by the Los Angeles Philharmonic, conducted by its former music director, Andre Previn. The off-stage horn was crisp and the flute soloist was excellent. Carnegie Hall is celebrating its 100th anniversary for the next seven months, ending with a May 5 concert by various soloists and the New York Philharmonic. That will fulfilling the wish of Carnegie's executive director Judith Arron that American orchestras open and close the season. Before Wednesday night's program began, a fanfare brought the audience into the hall and the Los Angeles Philharmonic played a pre-concert ``Star-Spangled Banner'' in Arturo Toscanini's orchestration. After the ``Leonore,'' the orchestra played two pieces by Americans, written some half century after Carnegie Hall opened but not avant-garde. Itzhak Perlman was soloist in Barber's 1939 ``Concerto for Violin and Orchestra.'' Hearing this piece, melodic and attactive to the ear, makes one wonder why it isn't programmed more often. Lush violins are saved from sounding like movie music by the good taste of the melodies. Perlman's tone went from silver, shimmering like leaves in an aspen grove, to warmly mellow. The second movement had an elegant pastoral melody played by solo oboe. In the pizzicato of the third, Perlman swung his shoulders in time to what he was playing. Some parts of the third movement had fast Russian rhythms. After intermission, Schuman's ``Symphony No. 3'' from 1941 was played. When it finished, William Schuman, who was 80 in August and has been composing for 50 years, took a bow from a box. Coming right after the Barber piece, which seems to flow naturally, the symphony's changes of mood seem to lack coherence. But it gave the brass and percussion their chance during the evening to be loud and even for the violins to be robust. It was a big-finish, half-hour fanfare to Carnegie Hall's centennial season. The audience, many of whom had bought $1,000 tickets and were continuing on to a dinner dance at the Metropolitan Club, gave the opening night concert a standing ovation.

DOC.HEAD: Infamous Sinner Radar Detector to be Auctioned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with device sold. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Sinner's radar detector, which he jokingly called a ``family heirloom'' after it brought him public derision, was sold for $200 Wednesday night at an auction. Kevin Cramer, executive director of the state Republican Party, bought the Democratic governor's fuzzbuster at the North Dakota Mental Health Association's annual fund-raising auction at a Bismarck hotel. Last week, Republican state Sens. Bryce Streibel and L.L. ``Pete'' Naaden, who often criticize Sinner, complained about the radar detector, although they are legal in North Dakota. They hired a photographer to take a picture of it in Sinner's pickup truck. They pointed out that the governor had called on truckers to alert police to speeders. At first Sinner shrugged off the flap, calling the detector ``sort of a sacred, emotional thing'' that had sentimental value as a gift from his children. But he changed his mind Tuesday amid a welter of publicity. Time magazine listed Sinner's statement as its ``excuse of the week.'' ``It grieves me greatly to part with this priceless family heirloom,'' Sinner said, ``but I'm willing to make this sacrifice in the interest of promoting mental tranquility for Bryce Streibel and Pete Naaden.'' Sinner is gaining experience with auctions, Streibel said, recalling the governor's March sale of his official Lincoln Town Car as a symbol of his willingness to cut state spending. ``When is the governor's residence going on the block?'' Streibel asked. ``I think that's next.'' Cramer said he said he isn't sure what to do with the device, but he promised he won't use it to evade police radar.

DOC.HEAD: Owner Sentenced to 37 Months in Offshore Sinking of Lobster Boat
DOC.TEXT: A fishing company owner was sentenced Wednesday to 37 months in prison and ordered to repay $295,000 to an insurance company for masterminding the sinking of one of his lobster boats 80 miles out at sea. James P. Garbo and his company, Garbo Enterprises, also were fined $10,000 each for the 1988 sinking of the Sophie G, a 72-foot steel-hulled boat Garbo had tried unsuccessfully to sell. All four men aboard the boat were rescued. ``This was a foul crime,'' said U.S. District Judge Jose A. Cabranes. ``No one should doubt the seriousness of this offense, nor the bad character that was at the root of it.'' Garbo, 35, of North Stonington, was convicted June 15 of conspiracy, mail fraud and destruction of a vessel. He sniffled and wiped away tears as his mother - for whom the sunken boat was named - tearfully asked Cabranes for leniency. ``He's been a devoted son all his life,'' Sophie Garbo told the judge. ``He has a young family. Please, I beg you for leniency.'' Garbo declined to speak on his own behalf in court and later refused to comment as he left the courtroom. Garbo's lawyer, Jeremiah Donovan, asked Cabranes for leniency. He portrayed Garbo as a hard-working, compassionate man dedicated to his job and his family. He said that Garbo, a fisherman for 20 of his 35 years, is ``absolutely financially ruined.'' ``We're not talking about somebody who had every advantage in life,'' Donovan said. ``This is not a case of white-collar crime. Rather, it's a case of yellow-slicker crime. ``What happened here was terrifically out of character,'' Donovan said, adding that Garbo used ``absolutely awful bad judgment.'' Garbo faced a maximum of 35 years in prison and fines of up to $2.7 million. Using federal guidelines, Cabranes sentenced Garbo to 37 months. He also ordered Garbo or his company to repay the $270,000 insurance policy he collected from United States Fire Insurance Co., as well as $25,000 in other costs the insurance company incurred. Garbo was ordered to surrender Dec. 3 and begin serving his sentence at a minimum-security federal prison camp. The Sophie G sank in calm seas Dec. 30, 1988, in the Atlantic Ocean 80 miles south of Shinnecock, N.Y. The captain of the ship, Ronald Pont, of Stonington, testified that he sank the boat at Garbo's request. Pont has pleaded guilty to conspiracy and destruction of a vessel and is to be sentenced Oct. 11. Garbo claimed during the trial that Pont had sunk the boat on his own and then tried to blackmail him. But a former captain of another Garbo boat testified that Garbo had offered him $10,000 to sink that vessel. Garbo insisted the offer was made only in jest. Another Garbo boat, the Heidi Marie, was lost in the Atlantic in November during stormy weather. All five crewmen were lost. The government has said it does not suspect foul play, but relatives of the dead fishermen have filed negligence lawsuits against Garbo.

Iraq's ambassador has called ``an act of war'' the U.N. vot extending to the air the embargo on trade with his country, a slap whose sting was backed by damning speeches in the General Assembly. Thirteen of the Security Council's 15 members were represented by foreign ministers during a near unanimous vote Tuesday to give the resolution added symbolic weight. The council warned the Baghdad government of further punitive action and hinted at sanctions against nations that fail to honor the U.N. embargo on trade with Iraq. Cuba cast the only no vote. In addition to sanctioning the air embargo, the resolution called for halting Iraqi shipping and freezing Iraqi assets overseas. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Gay and Arab. They are two words rarely spoken in the same breath, and almost never in the conservative Middle East, but Ramzi Zakharia hopes to change that. A year ago, Zakharia founded the Gay and Lesbian Arabic Society and discovered other Arab-Americans in the homosexual community who wanted to define a distinct gay Arabic identity. ``The result was very positive. A lot of people wrote, `Well, it's about time,''' Zakharia says. Zakharia rented a post office box, started a newsletter and began to hold monthly meetings at people's houses around Washington. Today, there are chapters in San Francisco, Detroit, Los Angeles and New York, as well as a scattering of contacts in Middle Eastern countries, including Lebanon, Morocco, Egypt and Yemen. ---= MILWAUKEE (AP) - A high school dropout's dream of putting to use his new college diploma was shattered by a random gang attack. A girl's ninth birthday ended with a stray bullet as she lay on her mother's bed. From New York to Chicago to Milwaukee, big cities are seeking emergency gun control measures as they battle a dramatic rise in violent crimes, many involving random killings of innocent victims. ``It doesn't matter where you are or what you're doing, the lives of people in the inner city ... are at stake,'' said anti-crime activist Ruth Varnado, whose Reclaiming the Streets movement has won praise from President Bush. Milwaukee, a city of 600,000, has seen its murder rate jump by more than half to 18.7 per 100,000 residents between 1988 and 1989. That translated into a record 116 homicides in 1989. Already this year, 115 killings have been recorded. A decade ago, there were fewer than 100 homicides in all of Wisconsin. ---= HOUSTON (AP) - Sales of guns and burglary alarms have picked up in the nation's fourth-largest city since the courts ordered the release of more than 270 inmates to relieve overcrowding at the Harris County Jail. All the freed inmates had been jailed on misdemeanors. But for some Houston-area residents, that's no more reassuring than hearing Houston trails Miami, New York, Los Angeles, Dallas and Detroit in crime. At least 31 of the 276 inmates freed on personal recognizance bond since Sept. 14 are already back behind bars, police said. Seven have been charged with felonies, including armed robbery in one case, police said. ``We're just arresting the same people. We're letting them out and arresting them again,'' said Sheriff Johnny Klevenhagen. ``The citizens of Harris County have again been victimized by the system.''

DOC.NOTE: $Adv03
For Release Wednesday PMs, Oct. 3 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Serbians Strive to Hold onto Kosovo Heartland
DOC.TEXT: The playground at Vladimir Ilyich Lenin elementary school was quiet as classes began this year. A few Serbian boys kicked a scuffed soccer ball while ethnic Albanians huddled around schedules posted on the wall. The mood was ominous. The kids didn't mix. The school, in Pristina's high-rise Dardania suburb, is split by the bitterest of Yugoslavia's many ethnic disputes. The division between Serb and Albanian touches everything in Pristina and the surrounding Kosovo province, and appears irreparable. ``Tensions are rising very fast and our Serb colleagues and ourselves, well, we don't even say `hi' anymore,'' said Sefia Hassani, a young ethnic Albanian who teaches English. Serbia's Communist leadership appears ready at all costs to hold onto the southern province that it administers and Serbs revere as the sacred heartland of their medieval empire. The Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people, are demanding political autonomy. ``In all of Eastern Europe, Stalinism is dead or dying - here it's having a renaissance,'' said Ibrahim Rugova, an Albanian who heads the Kosovo Democratic Union, a political party recently legalized by Yugoslavia's federal government. ``We are trying to find a peaceful solution but the Serb government isn't ready to negotiate, it just uses repression,'' he charged. Relations between the two ethnic groups in Yugoslavia's poorest province have been deteriorating for more than a decade. Serbs brand Albanians murderers and rapists. They say more than 220,000 Serbs have been chased off their land since 1966. More than 60 ethnic Albanians have died in Kosovo in occasional clashes with police the last 18 months. Albanian leaders say more than 600,000 have been investigated for ``politicial crimes'' since 1981. When Kosovo's parliament unilaterally declared the province sovereign on July 2, Serbian authorities in Belgrade promptly dissolved the assembly, closed Albanian-language media, fired about 15,000 ethnic Albanian workers and took control of police and local administration. Albanian leaders called a one-day general strike Sept. 3, the day before school started, paralyzing shops and factories. Authorities threatened to fire strikers, and locked managers and workers out of their stores when they returned. Belgrade television also announced a group of outlawed Kosovo deputies from the dissolved parliament was detained Sept. 7 for meeting secretly and declaring the province Yugoslavia's seventh republic. ``Serbia cannot stand by and watch someone declare the secession of (Serbia's) territory. To protect it, we are prepared to use all legal means,'' said Momcilo Trajkovic, Serbia's deputy premier and Kosovo governor. He said dissolution of parliament and the takeover of Pristina's media prevented open war in Kosovo, because ``no leadership in Serbia could have convinced the Serb nation not to fight for their territory.'' But in nearly a month since then, four more ethnic Albanians have been killed in two incidents, two in a shootout with Serb police that raided the village of Palatna north of Pristina in search of arms, and two others after allegedly firing at police at a roadblock. This emotional conflict is rooted deep in history. Kosovo Polje, or the field of blackbirds, was the site of a bloody battle in 1389 that pitted the Orthodox Serb Empire and its Christian allies against Ottoman Turks. Nowadays Serbs accuse Moslem Albanians of nationalism tinged with Islamic fundamentalism, separatism, and plotting to merge Kosovo with neighboring Albania. ``Serbia is currently an irrational regime, it is reacting like a wounded beast - it knows it's dying but it won't die without a fight,'' said Veton Surroi, a prominent Albanian leader. Nationalism is running high in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic with more than 9 million people. Radio, television and Politika, the once-respected Belgrade daily, now toe the hard-line of Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic. General elections in Serbia are expected by early next year. But Western observers say Milosevic's Communists, now renamed the Socialists, likely will win and continue to avoid democratic reform if they can play on Serbs' nationalist fears. Croatia and Slovenia, Yugoslavia's most Western-oriented republics where center-right governments have already replaced Communists, are worried that the Kosovo crackdown will drag Yugoslavia into international isolation as the West makes economic aid increasingly dependent on democracy and human rights. ``Unless they get rid of the Kosovo problem, Yugoslavia can't hope for any major international aid coming in,'' said one Western diplomat in Belgrade. According to Rugova, ``Only economic sanctions and diplomatic pressure from abroad can change Serbian policy on Kosovo.'' That pressure is mounting. A delegation of U.S. congressmen headed by Sen. Robert Dole, R-Kan., visited Pristina in August and said it was disturbed by ``fresh evidence that the Serbian authorities are engaged in a systematic pattern of violating the human rights of Albanians.'' But the Serbian government, though strapped for capital as Yugoslavia tackles the painful transition to free-market economics, is defiant in the face of growing Western criticism. ``Even if we are subjected to economic sanctions, we will not give up striving for our territorial integrity,'' said Trajkovic. In addition to firing Albanians from state-controlled jobs, Serb authorities are also trying to resettle Kosovo with Serbs from other parts of Yugoslavia. They plan to introduce a Serbian school curriculum in the province that will replace teaching of Albanian history and literature with Serbian classes.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Insular Mormons Edge Into Interfaith Cooperation
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mormons, who generally have kept aloof from other Christian communities, are gradually - and in expanding ways - moving into working association with them. To some extent, the past shunning has been mutual. Steps toward alleviating it represent a quiet mending of a rupture in America's social-religious fabric. For most of its 160 years, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon) has avoided links with the other religious groups, which, in turn, have kept a cold shoulder toward Mormons. But on both sides, leaders are showing a growing impulse for contacts and efforts toward better understanding and are increasing moves for cooperation, although some distrust lingers and some people oppose the trend alltogether. ``Some Mormons don't want it,'' said Mormon theologian Roger R. Keller of Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. ``Some of the others are suspicious of Mormons. But we've begun to break through the shell of isolation.'' As misconceptions and scurrilous notions about each other are diminished, ``more interchange becomes possible,'' he said. ``I hope we are standing at the crossroads of genuine dialogue.'' Such dialogue has flourished for years among Protestant, Roman Catholic, Anglican, Eastern Orthodox and Jewish groups, reducing old prejudices and distortions about one another. But Mormons, who were denounced, persecuted and driven westward in their early years, generally had stayed apart from that inter-religious companionship and teamwork until recently. Dallin H. Oaks, a member of the church's ruling Council of 12, said the change is toward working together ``on matters of common interest'' and the church now is involved in several such projects. ``I think the outlook for our being involved with others is good,'' he said. ``And I think other groups need us, and we need other groups.'' Oaks, a former law professor, president of Brigham Young University and Utah Supreme Court justice, said that ``traditionally our church has been very distant from other churches.'' Considering the past persecutions of Mormons, he added, ``It is is easy to understand why the Latter-day Saints' relationship with other faiths has been a strained and suspicious one.'' But as the American-born denomination has grown - now totaling 4 million U.S. members and 7 million worldwide - it has entered into several interfaith ventures in the last decade. ``We are more mature as a church,'' Oaks said. ``We feel less threatened by others. We're willing to forget some old persecutions and some old history and meet people on the basis of mutual respect and mature self-interest.'' Among such recent moves by Mormons was their joining in 1988 with 22 faith groups - Protestant, Catholic and Jewish - in the National Interfaith Cable Coalition, producing religious and values-oriented programs on the VISN television network. In 1986, Mormons became part of the Religious Alliance Against Pornography, a wide ecumenical cross-section. In 1984, they affiliated with Religion in American Life, involving most major U.S. denominations in seeking to stimulate weekly worship. Also in the mid-'80s, Mormons entered into inter-religious relief work, including aid to the homeless. They contributed about $5 million to relief efforts in famine-ravaged central Africa, much of it through Catholic Relief Services and the American Red Cross. Oaks, as a former educator, had experienced ecumenical cooperation in the Association of Presidents of Independent Colleges and Universities in the 1970s, and has since encouraged that trend in the church. So far, such connections have been on non-doctrinal matters, and Oaks emphasized that the church disapproves any discussions aimed at changing doctrines. That, however, isn't the aim of inter-church doctrinal talks. It is, rather, to explain their concepts to each other, to overcome misperceptions of one another and to achieve fuller mutual understanding. ``It is not only enriching, but develops one's own Christian understanding,'' said Keller, a former Presbyterian minister turned Mormon, with advanced degrees from Princeton Theological Seminary and Duke University. ``There needs to be more forums for conversations,'' he said. While differing on some points and without seeking to change or convert one another, benefits come in ``just getting to know and appreciate one another,'' he said. Mormons hold some distinctive beliefs, but like other Christians, they regard the Bible as holy scripture, honor Christ as God's divine son, uphold his teachings and believe in salvation through his atoning death and resurrection. Through candid dialogue, participants learn from each other, Keller said. ``Out of the depth of spirituality, I can learn so much from my Protestant and Catholic brothers and sisters. We need to sit down in front of the fireplace with a hot cup of cider and talk,'' he said. ``I really believe God guides his children to truth, as the spirit works in them, and hearts are opened up. The only way to know it happens is people of faith sharing with each other from the deepest recesses of their souls.''

DOC.HEAD: Hoof Beats, Sticky Candy and Kids' Quarters
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Ron Kottemann's days are measured in hoofbeats and 12-inch lengths of taffy. His wages are quarters, paid out mainly from small, sweaty palms. His shop is a four-foot by six-foot swaying box perched on high wooden wheels. ``There's no better way to make a living in the world. They can keep all their desk jobs,'' said the Roman Candy man. In the narrow wooden wagon drawn by Rosie the mule, Kottemann makes and sells the hand-pulled Italian taffy just as he grandfather did. While Rosie tows him through the streets of New Orleans, he boils up the sweet, yellow globs, adds vanilla, strawberry or chocolate, then kneads and pulls it into glistening, sticky rope. ``My grandfather started this. In those days, everybody had a wagon. It wasn't a big deal. You'd see all sorts of wagons going around town with people selling stuff. The world changed, but we didn't,'' said Kottemann, 41. Well, some changes, but only small ones. The price has gone up. Roman Candy sticks that sold for a nickel when Sam Cortese started making them in 1915 now go for a quarter. Kottemann has also added a second wagon that is permanently stationed at the Audubon Zoo and he sells to about 20 stores wholesale. ``People tell me I should modernize,'' Kottemann said. ``They say I should get rid of Rosie and the wagon and get a truck. But if I did that it would become a two-man operation. I'd need someone to drive and someone to make the candy. This way, Rosie drives and I make the candy. She responds to voice commands, so I hardly ever have to even touch the reins. We're the perfect team.'' Kottemann takes Rosie from her stable behind his uptown New Orleans home around 9 a.m. and goes to work. ``Usually five days. Sometimes six, once in a while seven if I need the money. I try not to work on Sundays and almost never on Monday. That's a real dead day for business,'' he said. He stops for business in various parts of town each morning - downtown some days, outside the parks on others, occasionally in the French Quarter. ``I like to go into the Quarter, but only if there are a lot of local folks there. The tourists think the wagon is cute and they take a lot of pictures, but they don't know what Roman Candy is and they don't usually buy. Lots of smiling, not many sales, that's the tourist trade for me,'' he said. He changes locations in the afternoon. Every day, during the school year, he sets up outside a school before the closing bell. ``Things started changing about 10 years ago,'' Kottemann said. ``I used to spend most of the days just driving through different neighborhoods. It used to be that Mama was home with the kids. Now Mama and Dad are both at work and the kids are in day care. I can drive through a neighborhood now and not see a soul before 4 or 5 o'clock.'' Kottemann started working on the Roman Candy wagon with his grandfather when he was in the eighth grade. By the time he went to college and then to the Army, he knew he wanted to carry on the business. Cortese died in 1969, as Kottemann entered the service. The candy wagon was off the street for three years, the only shutdown in 75 years. When Kottemann was discharged, the wagon began to make its rounds again. He sells an average of 600 sticks of candy a day, and with his zoo wagon and his store accounts, Kottemann said he makes a good living for his family: ``It probably wouldn't support a big group, but it's plenty for us.'' The future? At this point, Kottemann's not sure. Crime is his biggest concern. Kottemann said he's not worried about his candy wagon being robbed; he's afraid it will get so dangerous to live in town that he may have to move. ``That would really hurt. As it is now Rosie's stable is right in the back yard. It's been there for 100 years. I just unhitch her, feed her and go in the house. If we move and she's stabled somewhere else, that means I'd have to go there on my days off to take care of her. It would mean commuting back and forth. It would really change things,'' he said. It's a faroff worry, however. For now, and for the foreseeable future, it'll be business as usual at the Roman Candy wagon. ``I make a good living, and if I want to take off and go to my son's little league game or anything else, I just do it. How many executives do you know who can say that?''

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Hit By Economic Slump, Nation's Insurance Capital Struggles
DOC.TEXT: A decade of noisy construction in downtown Hartford has given way to eerie silence. In one five-day period, Hartford ranked near the bottom of a national survey of economic growth in urban areas, a once-popular restaurant across the street from City Hall unexpectedly shut down permanently, and, in an emotional blow to the entire downtown, Sage-Allen & Co. announced plans to close its 101-year-old department store on Main Street. ``I was devastated,'' Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry said of the Sage-Allen closing. ``I said `Wow!' ... It's the end of an era.'' And there have been other setbacks. Two of Hartford's largest downtown hotels shut down completely, taking 40 percent of the city's hotel rooms with them. And West Hartford-based Colonial Realty Co., which owns several of the city's biggest office towers, was forced into involuntary bankruptcy proceedings. At one point, things got so bad that a group of merchants held a press conference downtown to announce that, contrary to rumors, they were staying open. Business owners and city officials can take some comfort in knowing that other large cities in Connecticut - and across New England - are experiencing similar downturns in construction and retail activity. But in Hartford, where civic groups have struggled for years to coax people into a central business district dominated by insurance giants like Aetna Life & Casualty and The Travelers, the economic slump has brought on a bout of civic soul-searching. ``Right now, we have lost the soul of the city,'' said Brad Davis, a radio talk show host who has worked in the city for three decades. ``The only thing that's going to save the city is to bring back its soul,'' he said. ``People have got to be shown that we have an identity. We're not Boston, and we're not New York. But we've got our own identity.'' Hartford, a city of 130,000 and the hub of a metropolitan area of 750,000 people, faces the same problems as many other U.S. cities - the flight of whites and the middle class to the suburbs, the perception of high crime, parking and transportation. Efforts to revive downtown have met with some success. Union Place, a glitzy corridor of nightclubs and restaurants near the city's renovated railroad station, is packed with young people several nights a week. A new retail row has sprouted on Pratt Street, an intimate side street in the center of the city. And several civic groups are dedicated to breathing new life into downtown. ``When things get a little tougher, you have to pull together,'' said Tana Parseliti, whose family has run Frank's restaurant in the heart of downtown for 46 years. Still, on many nights, downtown restaurants scramble for business after office workers desert the area. Few people live in the city's center. The district's only hardware store closed recently, and there hasn't been a movie theater downtown in years. The corporations that dominate Hartford's downtown exist almost as self-contained communities, complete with their own cafeterias, health clubs and coffee shops, and connected by skywalks. ``A person can come in off the highway, go into one of these corporations, and never come out until they leave town,'' said Perry. ``We need a mixed city. We don't just need businesses and the poor. And that's a national struggle for cities. It's not just a Hartford struggle.'' Buoyed by the growth of its large corporations, Hartford, the state's capital, boomed in the 1980s. High-rises sprouted - and sprouted; a developer announced plans to build the tallest building in New England, a skyscraper stretching 888 feet, 8 inches. But when the region's economy slumped, downtown office vacancy rates soared and the building stopped, leaving the city pockmarked by vacant lots. After a protracted struggle against conservationists, developers destroyed the city's first skyscraper, the 77-year-old Hartford Aetna building, this spring to make room for a 45-story bank tower. But construction of the new tower has been delayed, and the site now is marked by a giant crater, idle construction equipment and several boarded-up storefronts. At the other end of Asylum Street, the glass-and-steel Parkview Hilton that symbolized the new look of Hartford in the 1950s has been shut down since New Year's Eve. Unable to find a buyer, the hotel's owners scheduled an auction in early June, but then decided to raze the building to make room for what they hope will be an office tower. Hanging over the city's economic uncertainty are fears that United Technologies Corp. may take its corporate headquarters out of Hartford. The defense giant has announced plans to move its headqarters, probably within the city, but has not disclosed a final decision. Shortly after Sage-Allen announced it would close its downtown store, 70-year-old Minnie Wright made a decision of her own. The store's closing would change her shopping habits, she said. After shopping at the downtown store for five decades, she now would take the bus to a West Hartford mall to shop at the Sage-Allen there. ``All the stores are going out there,'' she said. ``Who's coming in here?'' She shook her head as she reminisced about downtown when it bustled with department stores, cafeterias and five-and-dimes. ``It looks like it's on the way out,'' she said. ``Completely out.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Conference on Children Seeks to Reduce Child Mortality
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In the greatest assemblage of world leaders ever gathered, the World Summit for Children meets on Sunday, shadowed by crisis that threatens the peace and peace dividend that seemed at hand when it was conceived. The leaders of more than 70 governments are to sit at one gigantic, United Nations conference table - there are places for 74 - to talk about the world's children, their needs and what can be done to meet them. Only the heads of governments can participate; no stand-ins or deputies at the table. The summit census nearly doubles what was the record 38 world leaders who met at the United Nations on its 40th anniversary in 1985. President Bush will be in New York for the Sunday summit, and is to speak briefly. Since there are to be about 30 speeches, they are limited to a maximum of 5 minutes each. Every orator has been forewarned. ``These most powerful people in the world are getting together to deal with the problems of the most vulnerable people in the world,'' said Jay Ross, a spokesman for the United Nations Children's Fund. ``That carries a message.'' The statistic cited over and over in preparation for the summit: every day, about 40,000 children under age 5 die of starvation or diseases that could be prevented. ``It is the greatest condemnation of our times that more than a quarter of a million small children should still be dying every week of easily preventable illness and malnutrition,'' said James P. Grant, the UNICEF executive director, in the 1989 annual report that gave rise to the summit plan. Indeed, until Aug. 2, it seemed that the 45th General Assembly of the United Nations, the first of the post-Cold War era, could concentrate on that and other chronic world problems. Then Iraq invaded Kuwait, igniting the first major crisis of the new era, and the U.N. became the crucial forum in the world response to Baghdad, voting to impose a trade embargo and authorizing the use of force if necessary to make it stick. Iraqi diplomats tried, futilely, to link the embargo with the summit on children, asserting at one planning session that it would lead to starvation of their young, and that the summit should say so. It won't. Nor will Iraq be participating on Sunday. Saddam Hussein had said he would send his government's health minister, but aides were not invited to participate, only to watch. There were echoes of other, more familiar complaints, dating from Cold War times as summit planners put together a ``World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children.'' The statement, due for ceremonial signing by the summit participants on Sunday, lists war, aggression, and foreign occupation among the causes of the suffering of children. A Cuban diplomat proposed amending the statement to include colonialism as another cause. A British aide said that it should list totalitarian dictatorships instead. Both amendments were scrapped. With the ebbing of Cold War, the statement says, ``significant resources could be released for purposes other than military ones,'' and the needs of children should be a priority claim on those resources. That's the peace dividend argument. It runs head-on into the deficits plaguing the United States and the economic crisis wrenching the Soviet Union. The summit statement also promises ``a global attack on poverty,'' seeking more aid, trade, debt relief and economic growth for the developing world. At this point, the industrial nations are struggling against an economic slump of their own, worsened by the sharp increase in oil prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis. It urges every nation ``to reexamine its current national budget'' and its foreign aid commitment to give priority to programs to cut child mortality and hunger, and to make primary education available to at least 80 percent of the world's children by the year 2000. The summit declaration seeks those goals and more, acknowledging that they are ambitious and will take extraordinary, worldwide effort. In that quest, the fact that Sunday's meeting is being held may be more important than anything said there. It puts the problems of children on a world stage, at least for a day. The challenge now will be to translate one day at the summit ino a drive that will last the decade. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: C-Span To Celebrate 10th Year of Call-Ins
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 10 years ago, C-SPAN began its first call-in show. Alas, there was a power failure, despite the fact that C-SPAN is in Washington, D.C., where even reporters think they have power. Something went poof ``and the lights all blew, the power blew,'' C-SPAN chairman Brian Lamb recalls. Repairs were made in five minutes, but for a while, ``it was bizarre, guerilla television.'' On Oct. 7, C-SPAN will celebrate its 10th year of call-ins with the same four guests - journalists on the communications beat - discussing how today's issues in the communications industry compared to those of 1980. Back then, a viewer from Yankton, S.D., was the first caller to C-SPAN, a non-profit company originally created by the cable television industry to provide gavel-to-gavel coverage of House proceedings. Lamb doesn't recall the first caller's name. But that's understandable. He estimates that about 100,000 viewers have dialed in since then to grill guests or have their say on the hot issues of the day. The callers he does remember range from an 11-year-old Mississippi schoolgirl to Gary Owens, the free-spirit announcer from the old ``Laugh-In'' series to former President Reagan, who has called twice. The audience and callers - C-SPAN currently serves nearly 51 million homes in the U.S. - no longer are only Americans. That changed in 1988. Now, its two 90-minute weekday call-in shows in the morning and early evening, plus additional ones held after such events as a presidential speech, are carried via satellite in 26 other countries, mainly in Europe. Viewers there also can phone in, although only two lines are set up for their calls, compared to eight for domestic dialers. In all cases, each dialer foots the cost of the toll call. The topics discussed usually are national and international matters, such as the federal budget, Social Security, highway safety, legal issues and, in recent weeks, the Persian Gulf crisis and the savings and loan mess. The majority of guests tend to be federal officials and House and Senate members. When he was vice president, President Bush was a guest. His vice president, Dan Quayle, also has been on, fielding questions. It may be heresy, but Lamb says print journalists, not the electronic kind, are the show's second-largest group of guests. His reasoning: ``Television fills in a blank or two, but if you go to the backbone of where people get their information, it's in the newspaper.'' Like their radio cousins, television call-in shows have become so rampant they give common a bad name. But C-SPAN's are unique in two regards. One is that they have no ``star'' hosts. The shows never say in advance who the hosts will be. There are 10, three of them journalists. The rest, including Lamb, are C-SPAN staffers for whom hosting is a secondary job. On any given day, for example, the host could be Bruce Collins, C-SPAN's chief attorney, or Susan Swain, its senior vice president for programming, Lamb says. ``We want people to tune in for the issues and the guests instead of the hosts,'' he says. As in 1980, all the calls are live. There is no seven-second delay - a common device of call-in shows now - to let the host dump a dialer who might fancy himself the next Andrew Dice Clay. ``We've always tried to make this as real as possible so that the audience won't feel any kind of technical interference between them and the guests,'' Lamb says. The show does periodically hear from those who are none too tightly wrapped, he says, ``but that is not the norm by any stretch of the imagination.'' But, he concedes, ``If the moon is full - and this is not an exaggeration - you can have a very unusual program.'' It is the nature of life that hosts of television talk shows often are guests on other television talk shows. Phil Donahue does it all the time. Although Lamb is a no-name, relatively speaking, as a call-in show host, he, too, has been a guest, twice, on a national television call-in show - Larry King's show on the Cable News Network. Each visit induced high anxiety, he says: ``It's much easier being a host than a guest. You're in control when you're the host. When you're the guest, you're totally at the mercy of the host. ``So I have a great appreciation for how we can screw things up.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... CABLE FOOD FOR THOUGHT: Robert Wussler, who once headed CBS-TV, then was a top executive for cable maestro Ted Turner, thinks there could be megabucks when and if Hollywood decides to air hit movies on pay-per-view cable while the films still are in theaters. Wussler, president of Comsat Video Enterprises, told a cable industry lunch here this week that he thinks this may happen in 1995 or 1996. One hot picture, he predicted, ``in one night will gross $100 million'' from a pay-per-view showing.

DOC.HEAD: `America's First Superhighway' Turns 50
DOC.TEXT: The Pennsylvania Turnpike's goal when it opened 50 years ago was to provide a fast way over and through the Appalachian Mountains. What it gave America was a faster way to the future. The 160-mile, four-lane ribbon of concrete became the precursor of the United States' interstate highway system, conquering 2,800-foot hills with slopes, wide lanes, rest areas and exit ramps that became the standard for today's superhighways. It opened Oct. 1, 1940. ``When the federal government was developing the interstate system, they had us as an example,'' said Neal Wood, chief bridge engineer on the highway and the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission's unofficial historian. ``When we had a good design, they used it. When one was bad, they changed it,'' Wood said. The turnpike was, and still is, an engineering marvel. The original section snaked its way from Irwin, near Pittsburgh, to Middlesex, near Harrisburg, through seven tunnels and across scores of bridges. The road's groundwork, both literally and figuratively, had been laid a half-century earlier by the New York Central Railroad. William Vanderbilt started tunnel work and grading on a ``South Penn'' route to compete with the Pennsylvania Railroad, which ran through Altoona. Both railroads were convinced to ease their competition for fear both would go out of business. ``On one telegram's notice, work was stopped, everyone was paid off, accounts were settled and the line was abandoned,'' Wood said. In the 1930s state lawmakers and lobbyists joked about erecting a truckers' highway on old bridge pilings across the Susquehanna River. That ``joke'' has since been recognized by the American Society of Civil Engineers as a National Civil Engineering Landmark. Highway systems to that time weren't systems at all, but roads that meandered from town square to town square. When the original section of the Pennsylvania Turnpike was opened, it bypassed 939 cross streets, 12 railroad crossings and 25 traffic signals along U.S. 11 and U.S. 30, the old Lincoln Highway. ``This became more than a way of getting across Pennsylvania. It was a tourist attraction,'' Wood said. The U.S. Bureau of Public Roads had predicted only 715 cars would travel the turnpike each day in 1940. Other government studies predicted toll roads would never work. But in the highway's first four days, 6,000 cars traveled the turnpike each day. On Oct. 6, 1940, the turnpike got its first dose of Sunday drivers, when 27,000 clogged the artery. ``Attendants at three of the interchanges ran out of passenger-car tickets and resorted to handing out light-truck tickets or handwritten notes,'' according to a history of the turnpike. Many communities had shunned turnpike workers during construction, fearing towns would die once the highway opened. But many prospered. ``When they build a bypass around a community, the economic impact is not that great,'' said Robert Barnoff, visiting professor of civil engineering at Bucknell University. ``What they lose in gasoline or hamburger sales, they usually get back by attracting industry with their better transportation system.'' Even before the original section opened, the turnpike planned expansion to Philadelphia and the Ohio state line. Three more extensions opened by 1957. Currently, the turnpike commission is building two more offshoots: to the Greater Pittsburgh International Airport and around Greensburg. Another new section is planned from Pittsburgh south to Morgantown, W.Va. With no recent toll-road precedents, early turnpike employees had to improvise. Lee Rishel was asked to train the toll collectors, but didn't know how much they were supposed to collect. ``What they did at toll bridges and tunnels was collect at the point of entry and let people cross. There were no toll roads like this, with eight intermediate exits, so we had to come up with a fare schedule,'' said Rishel, 78. Rishel's committee determined that automobile drivers should pay a penny per mile and that truckers should pay a little more. How much more was difficult to determine. ``At first we had a mess with the classification,'' he said. ``We classified by vehicle size, but it was a cause of complaint among truckers because a truck hauling feathers was paying the same as a truck hauling steel.'' In 1955, the turnpike began assessing trucks by weight. In 1956, with the start of the interstate system, the turnpike's image began to change. The highway went from being an industry standard for excellence to a standard of how highways shouldn't be built. ``There are four lanes of traffic, two in both directions, and a narrow divider,'' Barnoff said. ``They had a lot of head-on collisions, and at the speeds they were traveling you had some big ones. Lots of fatalities.'' The first speed limit, 70 mph, wasn't posted until the highway was open 6{ months. Concrete barriers along the medial strip were completed in 1969. The fatality rate on the highway now is among the lowest in the nation among turnpikes, 0.8 per 100 million miles driven. The rate for all rural interstates is 1.6 per 100 million miles, according to turnpike figures. But cars still shine headlights across the lanes at a distance of 10 feet. And there isn't much room for improvement. ``The growth that's occurred across the roadway fence makes it difficult to convert our highway to what people are accustomed to,'' Martin said. ``Our success has been our limitation. We've pinned ourselves in by development.''

DOC.HEAD: Banks Tremble Ahead of `Lost Friday' Onslaught
DOC.TEXT: Tellers are gathering, clerks are stocking deposit and withdrawal slips and security people are lengthening the line dividers as banks brace themselves for another ``Lost Friday.'' More than 80 million workers who are paid weekly, biweekly and bimonthly will get their checks on the same day - Sept. 28 - and most will make a stampede for the bank. ``It's a massive problem,'' Brace Pattou, a spokesman for Harris Bank in Chicago, said of the event, which will occur just four times this year. To cope with the convergence of customers, Harris takes former tellers who do other jobs in the bank and puts them behind the counter. The bank also issues white carnations to lobby managers to make them ``visible and accessible when people have problems'' or, more likely, become impatient over the long lines, Pattou said. Other banks forbid tellers from taking lunch breaks during peak noontime hours as transactions at the windows and automatic teller machines jump as much as 50 percent. One way to avoid the mayhem is for employees to have their companies deposit their paychecks directly into their bank accounts. The practice is embraced by nearly all Japanese businesses and most Europeans. But in the United States only 17 million checks are deposited directly, according to figures from the National Automated Clearing House Association, a Herndon, Va.-based trade group. Direct deposit is safe and efficient and relieves busy workers of a trip to the bank simply to dump money into an account. ``Why take the risk or lose time dealing with a paycheck,'' said Elliott McEntee, clearing house association president and chief executive. But corporations and banks stand to reap big benefits themselves. The clearing house association estimates employers could save anywhere from 10 cents to 23 cents on every paycheck that is deposited directly. Furthermore, the association estimates that conservatively, companies would increase productivity by up to $5 billion a year because employees would no longer need to take time out to visit their financial institutions. A recent study by the automated clearing house trade group found the average employee spends eight to 24 hours each year going to the bank during working hours. For banks, which have long been criticized for trying to keep average customers at arms length, direct deposit would mean fewer in-person visits to the teller window - or 60 cents saved per deposit transaction. That could translate to tens of millions of dollars in weekly savings for the financial institutions, according to the association. Then there is the issue of float, the time between the deposit of a check in the bank and payment. Businesses, which earn interest until checks are cashed, will lose some of their float advantage with direct deposit. But McEntee stresses that advantage will be more than made up in productivity savings. The association has spent over $2 million in the past two years on a marketing campaign designed to encourage direct deposit among bank customers. McEntee plans to make a personal pitch to American Airlines' executives this week. So far, the campaign has been met with reasonable success. McEntee figures that 100,000 companies are offering direct deposit to some or all employees, double the number three years ago. Still, many people are reluctant to rely on an all-electronic pay system. ``It is clear from market research that some consumers want a paper check,'' McEntee said. It provides ``a sensation of security - people think the paper check is good, but electronic payment is more secure,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: After more than three years of study and debate, the way has been opened for admission of women to the Cantors Assembly, an organization of about 400 cantors of Conservative Jewish congregations. Women ``will add new voices and new strength to our organization,'' said Cantor Samuel Rosenbaum of Rochester, N.Y., executive vice president of the assembly. Judaism's Conservative wing began ordaining women as rabbis in 1985, and its Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan began investing women cantors in 1987. But not until this month were assembly snags cleared to admit them. The Reform wing of Judaism has accepted women as cantors and rabbis for about 15 years. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Women's Ordination Conference, which seeks admission of women to the Roman Catholic priesthood, congratulated American bishops on their decision to postpone indefinitely action on a proposed pastoral letter on women. Alluding to criticism of the proposed letter by various women's groups, WOC board member Andrea Johnson said she hoped its sidelining was a sign the bishops were ``reclaiming their American democratic roots.'' --- TUPELO, Miss. (AP) - An interdenominational TV monitoring organization, Christian Leaders for Responsible Television, is urging a one-year boycott of Burger King because of the amount of sex, violence and profanity on shows it sponsors. --- LAKE JUNALUSKA, N.C. (AP) - On a recent visit in South Africa, delegates of the World Methodist Council found a ``new climate of hopefulness'' for an end to apartheid, the council's general secretary says. The Rev. Joe Hale said an ``atmosphere of good will'' prevailed in the group's discussions with President F.W. de Klerk, in contrast to a stormy meeting in 1987 with then President P.W. Botha. At the end of the 75-minute meeting, he said, de Klerk commented: ``We are looking for a solution to South Africa's future that will stand the Bible's test for honesty and justice.'' --- EVANSTON, Ill. (AP) - Representatives of 13 Protestant denominations met here to explore possibilities of working together to reduce health-care costs and improve services. Futher discussions are planned on specific areas of cooperation. --- GENEVA (AP) - Jane Dempsey Douglass, a theology historian at Princeton University in the United States, has been elected president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches by the group's executive committee. The first woman to head the worldwide organizaion, she replaces the Rev. Allen Boesak of South Africa. He resigned after disclosure of an extra-marital affair with a woman television producer. The alliance includes 157 Reformed, Presbyterian and Congregational denominations with membership of about 50 million in about 80 countries. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Church leaders of various denominations marked the official publication date Sept. 27 of the New Revised Standard Version of the Bible with a celebration of hymns, preaching and prayer. The translation, a product of 15 years work by an interdenominational committee headed by noted Bible scholar Bruce Metzger, has been available in bookstores since May. Some publishers have begun third printings. --- WAHINGTON (AP) - Noting the role of the United Nations in opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, U.S. Roman Catholic bishops say the United States should promptly pay its current and back U.N. dues totaling $661 million. Archbishop Roger Mahony of Los Angeles, head of the bishops' international policy committee, asked the Senate appropriations subcommittee to appropriate funds to meet ``all U.S. obligations'' to the United Nations. Citing the United Nations' performance in the current Mideast crisis, in recent monitoring of elections in Nicaragua and Namibia, in mediating peace talks in El Salvador and in facilitating withdrawal of foreign troops from Afghanistan and Angola, Mahony said: ``It is time for the United States to resume the cooperative role in the U.N. it once played.''

DOC.HEAD: Court To Decide on Medicating Prisoner To Allow Execution
DOC.TEXT: Michael Owen Perry's medicine could restore his sanity, but it has one enormous side effect: It could speed his death. Perry is a prisoner on Death Row, and his fate will be argued Tuesday before the U.S. Supreme Court. The state of Louisiana wants to force him to take psychiatric medication; if he is legally sane, he can be executed. Perry's lawyers argue that forcible medicating would be a cruel and unusual punishment that ignores Perry's rights to avoid unwanted medication. The American Medical Association and the American Psychiatric Association say treating Perry to aid in his execution would turn the healing art on its head. Perry's sentence should be commuted to life in prison, they suggest. ``We're saying the cost here, which is really a fundamental realignment of the role of medicine, is a very high cost, and the state's interest in the difference between capital punishment and life imprisonment without parole doesn't justify that cost,'' said attorney Joel Klein. The state says giving him the drug is simply a necessary step for carrying out a death sentence, a justifiable limitation on a condemned man's liberties much like strapping him into the electric chair. Besides, the state is required to provide medical care, and the medicine is good for him, Louisiana says. Perry, 35, suffers from schizoaffective disorder, causing him delusions, hallucinations and disordered thinking. He was sentenced in 1985 for shooting his parents and three other family members to death. Louisiana's supreme court affirmed the conviction and the sentence but suggested a review of Perry's mental competence to be executed. There is a tradition in Anglo-American law that people should not be executed while insane. This doctrine, which dates back to medieval times, was adopted by the U.S. Supreme Court in a 1986 decision. ``Insanity'' is a legal term, not a medical one. In this case it refers to mental illness so severe that the prisoner is not aware of the impending punishment and why he is to suffer it. The Louisiana court ruled Perry was sane, but only while on medication. It also ordered that Perry be medicated even over his objection. After the state supreme court refused to hear a challenge to that decision, Perry's lawyers appealed to the federal high court. Lawyers for both sides declined to be interviewed on the record, but their Supreme Court briefs lay out their arguments in detail. Lawyers for Louisiana say the death sentence wiped out any legal power Perry would have to refuse the medication. Forced medication would not be a ``cruel and unusual'' punishment because Perry would benefit medically from it, the state says. ``Common sense dictates that the State does not violate the Eighth Amendment by doing something good for a prisoner.'' In fact, Louisiana is required to medicate Perry because the Supreme Court has declared that deliberately ignoring a prisoner's serious medical need itself constitues cruel and unusual punishment, the brief says. Perry's attorneys say the forced medication would be unconstitutional punishment rather than treatment. The court order gives no consideration to Perry's medical needs nor physician judgment, they say. The order also ignores the ``very real'' prospect of serious side effects, raising the prospect of taking a ``drooling, incontinent and tremulus'' man to the execution chamber, they wrote. In any case, Perry's lawyers say, Perry's response to medication is sporadic and unpredictable, making it impossible to say whether he would be competent on the day of his execution. ``With this instability and unpredictability, how is Michael's execution to be carried out?'' the lawyers asked. ``Can the state wait until a `good day' and execute Michael? Can Michael be executed if his `good days' outnumber his `bad days' by some amount? What amount? And what happens if the date set in the death warrant is a `bad day?' '' The AMA and psychiatric association, meanwhile, say the death sentence does not outweigh Perry's interest in avoiding unwanted medication, an interest especially great ``when the injection sets the prisoner directly on the road to execution.'' Involuntary medication was not part of Perry's sentence, nor is it generally authorized by confinement, the associations argue. Prior court decision support the idea that involuntary medical treatment is not permitted if it runs against a person's medical interests and is not necessary to treat a condition that may harm other people, they say. As for the argument that the medication would help Perry, any benefit ``would be both fleeting and purchased at the cost of his life,'' the associations said in a brief. Outside observers are split on their reaction to the case. Dr. Gary Glass, an associate psychiatry professor at Temple University and lecturer in law at Villanova University, said he personally hopes that the court would not allow execution of a person who is incompetent when not treated. But his ``utilitarian, practical'' answer is that nobody should be allowed to make a competent decision to avoid execution by becoming legally incompetent, he said. If a death sentence is imposed Tuesday. Brightman, Lloyd Webber's second wife, originated the role of Christine in both the London and New York productions of ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' Before joining the New York cast of ``Aspects,'' she will perform in a concert tour of ``The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber'' from Oct. 8 through Nov. 4. Lloyd Webber announced in July that he was ending his six-year marriage to Brightman and that he had become close friends with a 27-year-old businesswoman, Madeleine Gurdon. --- TORONTO (AP) - Nichelle Nichols says she wasn't particularly interested when her friend Gene Roddenberry insisted that she audition for a part in his new science fiction television series. That was in 1966. Even now, Nichols considers ``Star Trek'' to be ``just an interruption in my singing career, a nice interlude.'' Still, while Nichols is best known for her role as Lt. Uhura, she has never abandoned her musical career. Her one-woman show, ``Reflections,'' opens Thursday in Toronto. Nichols, born in Chicago in 1936, was discovered by Duke Ellington, toured with Lionel Hampton and danced with Sammy Davis Jr. Eventually, she was playing successful engagements in European nightclubs. Next thing she knew, she was decoding subspace communiques from Starfleet Command. In ``Reflections,'' Nichols pays tribute to a legion of legends, some of them old friends, including Eartha Kitt, Lena Horne, Leontyne Price, Mahalia Jackson, Pearl Bailey and Sarah Vaughan. But Trekkies need not fear. She and the old Enterprise crew ``are still family,'' she says, and she's looking forward to ``Star Trek VI.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Frederica von Stade's celebrity and career as an opera singer are not marital assets that can be measured and shared with her estranged husband, a judge has ruled. Manhattan Judge Walter Schackman rejected the claim of von Stade's husband of 18 years, Peter Elkus, who said he sacrificed his career to nurture hers as her voice coach, manager and adviser. Schackman said Elkus' contribution's to his wife's career will be an issue to be decided with others at the couple's divorce trial. Von Stade, 45, a mezzo-soprano with the Metropolitan Opera, married Elkus in 1972 and the couple separated in 1988, court papers show. They have two teen-aged daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Upstart Company Offers Products for Commuters
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mabel Yee was just another frustrated commuter stuck in the middle of her stop-and-go crawl to wrk, when an idea hit her like an antsy driver following too close. ``I thought, `Gosh - there must be some option to just sitting here . . . This is stupid. There must be something to do,' '' she said. Eighteen months later, Yee has found lots for commuters to do. Her company, Commuter Products Corp., sells dozens of products to keep drivers busy, safe, relaxed, fed or just plain entertained. Driven mad by traffic? Yee offers relief with a massaging car seat, stress-reduction tapes, stereo headrests and an electronic message board that tells tailgaters to back off. No time for breakfast? Keep a croissant fresh in a compact refrigerator and pop it into an envelope-style, foil-lined oven that plugs into the cigarette lighter. The Road Hog apron and lap tray will keep the gray suit and red tie clean. Every minute counts? There are portable fax machines, travel desks and note boards that clip onto the steering wheel. Comuter Products also offers gadgets for before or after a commute. Among them: an under-the-pillow alarm that literally shakes up a sleeper without disturbing anyone else, a multi-pocket folder to organize glove box rubble, and a Car Finder that turns on the lights and honks the horn of your car from 200 feet way. Prices range from $4.95 for a tiny clipboard that attaches to a window with suction cups to $1,595 for the PortaFax. Yee declined to reveal sales figures or say if her company was making money, but she said response so far has been enthusiastic. ``I didn't have any of this! I had to go looking for a piece of paper . . . jot it down and still had to drive,'' said Yee, 38, who quit her job in marketing and sales for Xerox Corp. to start her company. Yee said commuters are a huge group of consumers that have been virtually ignored. ``There are business markets, sports markets, but no one seems to think of commuters,'' she said. The average Californian, for instance, now spends 45 minutes commuting each way to work, and the average ``speed'' is 35 miles per hour - expected to coast down to 17 miles per hour by the end of the century, according to Yee. ``Auto manufacturers just look at the car - how fast does it go, what about the tires, how to make it pretty,'' she said. ``We look at the person inside the car saying, `Get me out of here!' '' Yee sells to that trapped soul through her ``Love to Commute'' catalogue, drawing customers worldwide. ``We actually had a guy call us on a cellular from New Jersey'' and place an order from his car, she said.

DOC.HEAD: `The Race to Save the Planet' - Local Heroes Make for Global Change
DOC.TEXT: One of the best things about PBS' thoughtful new series, ``The Race to Save the Planet,'' is that it doesn't try to sugarcoat the bad news. And just describing the global environment means plenty of bad news. The 10-hour series is running weekly, starting last Thursday; it also is running marathon style, two hours a night for five nights beginning Sunday. ``The Race to Save the Planet'' shows the state of the world's environment and the interconnectedness of its problems that threaten it. The series is an antidote to despair. It's sad and scary, but it's neither shrill nor naive. ``We thought it was time for a series to attempt to show that there is a way forward,'' said executive producer John Angier, a co-founding producer of PBS' distinguished science series, ``Nova,'' in 1975. ``Really, the television audience and the magazine-reading public have probably had quite enough of doom and gloom and there were other stories to tell,'' he said. ``The structure of the series is such that it kind of goes from the bad news to the good news.'' What a lot of bad news there is. Humanity, the series notes, has been adversly affecting its environment since the Neolithic Revolution, when we changed as a species from hunter-gatherers to farmer-herders. Our first experiments with agriculture were dismal flops, exhausting the land with overcultivation, overgrazing and deforestation. The Neolithic Revolution's basic lesson was that desert can always return. And may yet. A few thousand years later, efficient agriculture created the next great human leap forward. The Industrial Revolution's basic lesson: Surplus food from fewer farmers means more people can go to work in factory towns. That revolution's crowning achievment (once you got past the smog) was to fling our species into space. And once we got out there, we looked back at our cradle and saw a big, blue jewel, spinning in space, alone and unique. That powerful image of the planet - along with smog, dead lakes and tainted springs - helped create the Environmental Revolution. The first Earth Day was in 1970; the first global conference on the environment in 1972. That revolution's basic lesson: You're running out of time and space. You can breed yourself to starvation, you can asphyxiate or poison yourself, you can drown in your own dung heap. It's later than you think. ``In a way, human history with respect to the environment is a series of experiments, and on many occasions the experiments have not worked,'' Angier said. ``The big difference between now and 10,000 years ago is the scale. ``Now the scale is global. It comes down to a question of room. Once there was room to make mistakes; now we've come to the end of the planet.'' Our destruction of the rain forest - which ecologists call ``the lungs of the planet'' - is just such an experiment. It was chillingly reported on PBS' excellent ``Frontline'' series by Adrian Cowell, ``The Decade of Destruction,'' and Bill Kurtis' ``The Rain Forest Imperative'' on cable's A&E (repeating in December). We lose about 1{ acres of rain forest each second. We still don't know how many species of plants and insects exist, and yet we're discarding entire species each day. We literally do not know what we're losing. ``We human beings are part of this terrifically complicated biological scheme that we're only just beginning to glimpse the workings of,'' Angier said. ``What we don't know is the extent to which you can chip away at that biological scheme before it collapses and can't support us, human life,'' he said. ``All the biologists can tell you is that this is a really dangerous game, and we don't know what we're dealing with.'' ``The Race to Save the Planet'' moves from from the macroclimate's global warming and thinning of the ozone, to the microclimate, analyzing the sources of air pollution in Los Angeles and water pollution in Europe's Rhine River. Each of the environmental issues the series tackles becomes a story with a human face. Economic development in the Third World creates environmental disasters; preserving its wildlife takes second place to human hunger. The ``Remnants of Eden'' segment shows a bloody-muzzled leopard in a Kenyan game park gazing at gridlocked busloads of tourists. Angier says he gets irritated by TV wildlife shows with beautiful animals at work and prey. ``What the camera didn't show you,'' he said, ``is it's almost always in a nation that's struggling with great poverty and hunger.'' The western world's economic development decimated its wildlife and deforested Europe, The same thing is happening in the Third World, he said, and the pace is accelerating. The series is honest. It came up against the economic realities of alternatives to fossil fuels, and concluded that biomass, cogeneration, 100-mpg cars and other alternatives become practical only when oil is too expensive. That frank assessment was balanced, however, by a visit to the remarkable, energy-conserving residents of Osage, Iowa. They're ordinary people who have learned how economical and comfortable it is to use energy efficiently. The series also looks at the Green Revolution, how it almost went belly-up in Indonesia thanks to a new, high-yield rice that was plagued by insect infestation. And, with world population expected to double in 60 years, the series looks at how different governments are dealing with burgeoning populations. ``Population is kind of the silent guest at the table for every one of these issues,'' said Linda Harrar, a ``Nova'' producer who conceived the series when it became obvious there was too much material for the science show. ``The Race to Save the Planet'' was filmed in 30 nations on all seven continents. It reiterates the hard choices we face as a species, and that environmental solutions ultimately derive from individual behavior. It demands leadership from our politicians and shows us local heroes whose work may help bring about global change. That's the secret of ``The Race to Save the Planet:'' It's not so much about nature as it is about people. ``The planet itself is going to do just fine without us,'' Angier said. ``It's the people that are the problem, and their place on the planet. ``Nature's going to go on no matter what we do - in some form or other.'' It just won't be that big, blue jewel, spinning alone in space. And we won't be there to wave goodbye.

DOC.HEAD: A Diary of Three Weeks With a National Guard Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``soilders'' in the Sept. 5 entry is cq
With LaserPhotos
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: National Writer Fred Bayles spent nearly three weeks with the 14 men of the National Guard's 265th Quartermaster Detachment as they mobilized, trained and deployed to Saudi Arabia. In a diary of those days, Bayles traces the men's activities from a rousing sendoff from their small hometown in South Carolina to their arrival in the Middle East. ---

The 14 members of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment aren't professional soldiers. Henry Harris, a retired schoolteacher, is the oldest at 51; Mark Rooker, a college sophomore, is 20. The rest work in construction or at the local correctional facility, or drive trucks. Eight are married, and nearly all have children. But the 265th is a second family. A majority have been in the unit 16 years or more. Like any family, there are rivalries and grudges and arguments. There also is camaraderie. Sgt. Earnest Deloach, an 18-year veteran, had his gripes about being mobilized. His income plunged, he missed his son's 16th birthday, he limped along through training on a pulled hamstring. So it was a surprise to hear him say he didn't have to go. ``I could have gotten out of it,'' he says, covered with sweat on a beach by the Persian Gulf, ``but my guys were going.'' --- THURSDAY, AUG. 30: The 265th arrives for training at Fort Stewart, Ga., with little fanfare. The night before, a huge crowd showed up in the heat of Allendale, S.C., to send them off. The turnout beat attendance at the last county fair. Fort Stewart is empty. Much of the 24th Infantry already is gone. All that's left are yellow ribbons and signs along the road bestowing God's blessings on the departed soldiers. The 265th, a water purification unit, spent the past week packing pickup trucks and completing inventories and assorted paperwork, including wills. Quarters are in the post's National Guard section: old cinderblock barracks with wooden roofs and not much else. Bare bulb lighting, no plumbing, no fans to stir the heavy damp air. ``These accommodations will seem luxurious once you get to Saudi Arabia,'' says a lieutenant colonel as a way of welcome. --- FRIDAY, AUG. 31: Paperwork day. The men get new dogtags and identification cards as temporary members of the regular Army. Pay vouchers have to be filed, medical records checked. The men are inoculated for meningitis and typhoid. Each step is long and boring. Sitting, waiting, in the rows of folding chairs at the processing center, Sgt. Herman Roberts complains of stomach pains. Sgt. Ronnie Jackson, commander of the 265th, starts to hector him like one half of an old married couple. ``How come every time we go on a trip you get gas?'' he asks loudly. --- SATURDAY, SEPT. 1: NBC (nuclear, biological, chemical) training. Films of bunnies, goats and pigeons thrashing around and dying from nerve agents. Sgt. Ernie Deloach shakes his head as each victim succumbs. After awhile, the films become predictable and the men begin to nod off in the darkened room as animals die on screen. Excerpts of classnotes: ``Don't lay down if exposed to choking agents: your lungs will fill with fluid. ... Nerve agent warning signs: runny nose, headache, drooling, twitching ... '' Someone asks if there's going to be a test on the information. ``The test is going to be when you hit land over there,'' says the sergeant-instructor. -- TUESDAY, SEPT. 4: PT (physical training) every morning now at 6 a.m., led by Capt. Robert Appiah. ``Side straddle hop,'' he says and the men answer in a shout, ``SIDE STRADDLE HOP!'' Most keep up, with the requisite amount of cheating on pushups and situps. Running is the killer. The group does three miles, then groans as Appiah turns them around to pick up stragglers. ``Make them run,'' they shout. Ulysses Calhoun is gung-ho for the first two miles, taunting the others. After that he is gasping with the rest. ``My overdrive kicked in, and then it kicked out again,'' he explains. One running cadence: ``They say in the Army, the women are mighty fine; I went out with one late last night, she looked like Frankenstein; Oh Lord I want to go, Oh how I want to go; Oh Lord I want to go (four-beat pause) HOME!'' --- WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 5: Lectures from a chaplain on Islam and Arab culture. Chaplain pronounces it AYE-RAB. What not to do: Don't point or make the A-okay sign, it's considered giving somebody the evil eye. Don't show the bottom of your foot, it's considered an insult. Don't do anything with your left hand, it's the ``sanitation hand'' in the AYE-RAB world. And of course, don't drink, eat pork or look at the women. ``I believe we're going to the wrong place,'' says Sgt. Hullie Cohen. ``You can't do nothing.'' The men get a special delivery envelope of drawings from the Hampton, S.C., Elementary School. Included is this note: ``To the soilders, from Summer Pope, God Bless. The sun is hot, but just remember we love you.'' --- FRIDAY, SEPT. 7: Range day. The novelty of firing new M-16s wears off quickly in the heat and humidity. Each man must zero in his weapon, a process of shooting, trudging to view the result, trudging back to the firing pit, adjusting the sights and then doing it all over again. Everybody feels better at the night range. It's cooler, and tracer fire laces satisfyingly through lit targets. Night fire invigorates the men. Don Graham kids about fathering another child (he has seven). Willie Badger sings in a clear tenor to the tune ``When Johnny Comes Marching Home'': ``They handed me an M-16, hurrah, hurrah. They handed me an M-16, hurrah, hurrah. They handed me an M-16 and made me into a killing machine. And we'll all be dead by the summer of `92.'' --- WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 12: Training over, the men pack and repack the trucks waiting for the word they are going. Old trucks with outdated purification units are to be put in storage. The men will get new units in Saudi Arabia. ``Goodbye ladies,'' Sgt. Bill Bostick says to the trucks as we drive past the motor pool. The men poise for group pictures. ``Say Saddam Hussein,'' Deloach says, mugging for the camera. The men go over for a last set of shots. Badger backs into the room, eyes averted. ``I can't take needles,'' he says. ---
