DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: he says.
DOC.TEXT: FRIDAY, SEPT. 14: The unit ships out today. Families gather at the barracks in the morning to say goodbye as 2{-ton trucks drive by honking their horns. Drivers shout ``Good luck.'' The scene is oddly festive, sort of like family day at a summer camp. Overheard conversations: Cohen's wife: ``I'm used to it with Hullie, he's been gone before. But this is different. There wasn't a chance for war.'' Curtis Young's mom: ``I told him when he signed up that sooner or later this day would come.'' Harris, who avoids MREs (Meals, Ready to Eat rations) whenever possible, gets six cans of cocktail weiners from his wife. ``I don't even like weiners,'' he grumbles. ``I guess I'll learn to love `em.'' --- SATURDAY, SEPT. 15: The C-141 appears as a bright light in the eastern sky and taxis up to the hanger to load the trucks and take on fuel. The men file aboard, cram into uncomfortable web seats and try to sleep for the next nine hours to Spain. It is cold and cramped, but most are able to fall asleep. Three hours layover at Torrejon. The men crowd around two sinks in the bathroom to shave and brush their teeth. Definitely different graffiti on the walls. One example: ``Marine TOW - Death on a leash.'' --- SUNDAY, SEPT. 16: We land in Saudi Arabia at 3 a.m. local time. Jet lag only complicates reactions as F-15s take off overhead on a sheet of flame and a roar. We get on a Saudi bus for the ride to Cement City, a marshalling area for new troops. We wonder about a separate enclosed section at the rear of the bus and realize it is for women. When we stop on the side of highway at dawn to fix a flat, other traffic pulls to the side and the drivers get out to kneel and pray. ``This is for real,'' says Bobby Youmanns. --- MONDAY, SEPT. 17: The dress code is simple here in Cement City. Everywhere you go, you are to take your M-16 and carry your gas mask and canteen. To the makeshift showers. To the latrines. Badger, Calhoun and Cohen draw guard detail at the front gate. Two are up front to stop any cars, another backs them up from concrete barriers a few dozen yards away. M-16s aren't loaded, clips in pockets. Sitting between the barriers is a LAW, a small rocket that can stop a truck. Calhoun puts some grape-flavored beverage additive to his bottled water to cut the flat, mineral taste. I suggest it would taste better if we could add some rum. ``Yeah,'' he brightens. ``We could call it Grum.'' --- WEDNESDAY, Sept. 19: Racing from camp to a mess hall and a hot meal at the air base, the canvas top rips off the back of the pickup and pummels the men. It's dangerous; the whole top of the truck could come away. They pound on the rear window with rifle butts. ``We're going to be killed,'' shouts Harris, but he's laughing. The truck finally pulls off for a quick repair. We get to the mess hall at sunset, as calls to prayer echo through the sultry night air. There is a huge crowd of GIs lining up for dinner. Youmanns, Cohen, Young and the others pile out. I follow to say goodbye; I have to go back home. Each one of the men files past and shake hands as if we're part of some martial reception line. --- The men of the 265th still are in Saudi Arabia. They could be there for the next five months, doing their job of purifying water, worrying about their families, thinking about home. At home, their families wonder and worry. Lillie Deloach misses her husband. ``I've had a headache since he left,'' she says. Adele Harris is happy to hear news about hers. ``I went down to the the post office and got a card from Henry. It just made my whole week.'' But mail is slow, and telephone calls are impossible. To overcome the loneliness, the families plan to meet and share what news they have. ``Hullie said you've got to be strong,'' says Estella Cohen. ``It's hard because I'm used to him here taking care of things. But if they can take it being over there, I guess we'll have to take it waiting for them at home.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 30

DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy nearly came to a standstill in the second quarter, edging up a feeble annual rate of 0.4 percent, the government said. Many of the nation's top economists believe a recession is imminent - if not under way already. While White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said ``we don't believe we are in a recession right now,'' he acknowledged Tuesday's Commerce Department report on the gross national product ``is certainly cause for concern. It's not good news.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Michael Milken's lawyers have revealed their strategy to keep him out of prison, portraying the convicted financier as a repentant, misunderstood genius who has benefited society and should be allowed to work with ghetto youth in a ``purposeful punishment.'' In a sentencing proposal released Tuesday, less than a week before a federal judge is scheduled to announce Milken's punishment in the biggest securities fraud case in history, the defense offered new insights into Milken's character. The 44-year-old former junk-bond wiz for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. pleaded guilty to six felonies in April, capitulating to government pressure after insisting he was innocent for nearly four years. --- UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. (AP) - A huge Japanese electronics concern said it is negotiating to buy entertainment giant MCA Inc. in a deal valued at $7 billion, the latest move in Hollywood globalization. The proposal announced Tuesday by Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. also demonstrates anew the foreign craving for American trophy holdings. The merger, if completed, would mirror the 1989 acquisition of Columbia Pictures Entertainment by Japan's Sony Corp. for $5 billion, which includes the assumption of debt. Matsushita makes video equipment and audio and visual components under the brand names Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil prices dipped as traders took profits from their dramatic surge and awaited developments in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude fell 72 cents to $37.53 per barrel Tuesday for November contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The drop pulled oil a little farther from the $40 mark that many traders view as the next target. It represented just a partial retreat from Monday's rise, which had pushed prices up almost $3 per barrel. --- DENVER (AP) - One major witness was allowed to testify in secret and one refused to appear voluntarily as a hearing began on conflict-of-interest allegations against Neil Bush, the president's son. Outside, the federal courthouse was surrounded by news media, security officers and protesters on Tuesday. The only thing missing was the center of all the attention. Neil Bush, 35, did not show up for the first day of what is anticipated to be a four-day proceeding before administrative law Judge Daniel J. Davidson. Officials said Bush had to be present only when he was to testify. --- MIAMI (AP) - Eastern Airlines trustee Martin Shugrue urged President Bush to help minimize the damage Iraq crisis-triggered fuel hikes are doing to the airline industry and to his carrier's hopes for survival. ``The airlines cannot support the increased cost. Eastern cannot support the increased cost,'' Shugrue said at Florida International University on Tuesday. ``And the public cannot tolerate the increased burden in air fares.'' Shugrue called on the Bush administration to form a task force of officials of the airlines, oil companies, his administration and Congress to study and recommend actions on oil prices. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Moody's Investors Service downgraded the credit rating of Chase Manhattan Corp., citing concern about the deterioration of the bank's real estate loan portfolio. Moody's, one of the two major credit rating agencies, said Tuesday that Chase's announcement Friday that it would halve its dividend this quarter and boost its bad-loan reserves were positive steps for the nation's second-largest bank. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Nearly half the samples in the nation's principal agricultural seed collection are in danger, and the collection's administration must be overhauled, says a National Academy of Sciences study. The genes contained in the 232,210 samples in the National Seed Storage Laboratory in Fort Collins, Colo., have been used to develop new varieties of corn, wheat and other important crops. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Nearly all U.S.-produced foods and 96 percent of imported foods tested last year met government standards for pesticide residues, the Food and Drug Administration said. In its annual study of pesticide residues, the FDA said Tuesday that most of the violations found during the regular testing involved pesticides being used on types of produce for which use of the chemicals is not allowed. The violation rate in regular testing was about the same as for the three previous years for both domestic and imported foods, the FDA said. ---

The stock market rallied Tuesday as institutional investors snapped up blue-chip issues, but analysts dismissed the advance as insignificant. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 32.67 to close at 2,485.64. previous session, when it settled at a 14-month low. The dollar advanced against all major currencies except the Japanese yen. Gold prices pulled back slightly. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower, and grains and soybeans were mixed. Long-term bonds were higher.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: ... future lawsuits.
ON THE GOVERNMENT'S CASE
DOC.TEXT: The (government's) factual presentations are grossly distorted; its discussion of legal principles and applicable law virtually non-existent. . . . Indeed, in its zeal to enhance Mr. Milken's punishment, the government's sentencing memorandum is inconsistent with portions of its own plea agreement and with the representations the government made to the court at the time of Mr. Milken's plea. . . . First, the government's memorandum confirms that there is no evidence linking Mr. Milken in any way to a significant number of the alleged acts which the government asks this court to consider. . . . Second, the government has provided a highly selective version of its own evidence on a host of other transactions which it urges this court to consider. . . . The government's sentencing memorandum also seeks to punish Mr. Milken for acts which do not constitute crimes. . . . it even blames Mr. Milken for the fact that in December 1989 - one year after the government banished Mr. Milken from Drexel and barred any Drexel employee from even talking to him about anything directly or indirectly relating to business - Drexel, which was then led by John Shad, the former chairman of the SEC, paid large bonuses to its employees.
DOC.HEAD: THE BURDEN OF PROOF
DOC.TEXT: To accept the government's position would subject Mr. Milken to punishment on charges that the government had agreed previously to dismiss with prejudice, and would impose on this court the obligation to issue extensive findings of fact and conlusions of law on all matters that would have arisen had Mr. Milken actually proceeded to trial. To attempt to resolve these matters without full evidentiary hearings would violate due process. But to hold such hearings, which could last as long as a trial, would be contrary to sound principles of judicial administration and would be inconsistent with the essence of the plea agreement. . . . The sentencing stage is not the time to conduct new trials on new offenses.
DOC.HEAD: ON COMPARABLE CASES
DOC.TEXT: Unlike its typical sentencingmemorandum, the government here does not analyze the relevant sentencing precedents in this district. The reason is obvious: The government's recommendation that Mr. Milken receive ``a substantial period of incarceration'' cannot be reconciled with these precedents. . . . only three of the nearly 100 securities law violators sentenced in this district who pleaded guilty received prison sentences greater than one year and one day. . . . By every relevant indicator, Mr. Milken has fully and unconditionally accepted complete responsibility for the crimes he committed.
DOC.HEAD: ON INSIDER TRADING
DOC.TEXT: We would have expected the government to acknowledge that he was no Ivan Boesky, Martin Siegel, Dennis Levine or even Robert Freeman. . . . No matter how unjust, it must brand Mr. Milken an insider trader to justify its own investigation. Yet its four isolated allegations of insider trading are easily refuted by documents and testimony currently in the possession of the government.
DOC.HEAD: HIS BUSINESS RELATIONSHIPS
DOC.TEXT: The government charges that Drexel provided unlawful gratuities to money managers and other institutional fiduciaries, principally in the form of lucrative investment opportunities. . . . Michael Milken's business was not based on improper inducements to anyone. . . . The government's theory of wrongdoing presumes a world in which no one ever recommends a security to a client or tries to make money for a client, if the client works for an institutional customer.
DOC.HEAD: ON SAVINGS AND LOANS
DOC.TEXT: In a balanced sentencing memorandum, given the public clamor over the savings and loan crisis, we would have expected the government to disclose forthrightly that it does not contend that Mr. Milken was responsible for the financial collapse of any savings and loan. Obviously, although the government does not publicly exonerate Mr. Milken in its 215-page memorandum, it makes no claim, and presents no evidence, linking Mr. Milken to today's savings and loan crisis.
DOC.HEAD: ON BOESKY DEALINGS
DOC.TEXT: To understand the true nature of the transactions between Boesky and Mr. Milken . . . it is necessary to understand the complex relationship between a securities salesman and his or her customer. . . . Scorekeeping by brokers of profits, lossses and favors for accounts is common in the industry. So are efforts to make up losses. . . . The government's principal evidence in support of its position are the handwritten ledgers it has attached to its sentencing memorandum, and Boesky's payment of a $5.3 million fee to Drexel . . . But a careful review of the ledgers and of their origins reveals that far from being the memorialization of a Boesky-Milken illegal arrangement, the ledgers were nothing more than an artifice used by both sides to gain an advantage through scorekeeping.
DOC.HEAD: OBSTRUCTION OF JUSTICE
DOC.TEXT: The government's allegation that Michael Milken obstructed justice is as unfounded as its other allegations. To begin with, much of what the government characterizes as ``obstruction'' is not obstruction at all. During the immediate aftermath of the service of grand jury and SEC subpoenas at Drexel, there was unquestionably confusion, fear and paranoia. But confusion, fear and paranoia are hardly illegal and were surely justifiable under the circumstances. . . . Under these circumstances, behavior that might otherwise seem silly or even paranoid - furtive conversations or warnings about who might be an informant - are perfectly understandable. And they are not illegal.
DOC.HEAD: ON DREXEL, MILKEN'S WEALTH
DOC.TEXT: Beyond urging this court to sentence Mr. Milken for additional crimes in the absence of factual or legal support, the government asks the court to punish Mr. Milken for the demise of Drexel and for his wealth and his status in the community. These charges have no place at sentencing, and do not befit the government. . . . As a result of Drexel's collapse (in bankruptcy court), Mr. Milken has personally lost more than any other individual investor. . . . The government's sentencing memorandum includes no fewer than 25 references . . . to Mr. Milken's wealth and power in the first 25 pages alone. . . . Just as such appeals to passion or prejudice are forbidden at trial, they are equally offensive at sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: A Brief Look at Milken's Life, Career and Plea-Bargain Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Here is a snapshot of Michael Milken, the deposed junk-bond king who faces sentencing in the largest ever securities fraud case against an individual:
DOC.HEAD: PERSONAL:
DOC.TEXT: Born on the Fourth of July in 1946, Milken grew up in Encino, Calif. As a boy, he helped his father, an accountant, prepare tax returns for clients. Milken graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, majoring in business administration, and married high-school sweetheart Lori Anne Hackel. He went on to receive a master in business administration degree from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.
DOC.HEAD: CAREER:
DOC.TEXT: Milken was hired full-time by Drexel's bond-trading department in 1970 after working in its Philadelphia office during business school. A rapid success, Milken was generating a substantial amount of the firm's profits through his high-yield bond trading. In 1978, the firm allowed Milken to move the high-yield bond department to Beverly Hills, Calif. Drexel used junk bonds to finance hundreds of small companies in the 1980s, reaping hundreds of millions of dollars in fees. Junk bonds later were used to finance a wave of corporate takeovers. Milken used some of his earnings to start charitable foundations that he and his brother, Lowell, also a Drexel employee, endowed with hundreds of millions of dollars.
DOC.HEAD: CHARGES:
DOC.TEXT: After being linked in the press in late 1986 to an illegal stock trading network led by admitted felon Ivan Boesky, Milken and Drexel became the main targets of the government's insider trading probe. They were charged with civil fraud and other allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1988, and Drexel that winter agreed to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $650 million in penalties. Milken, his brother and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg were indicted in March 1989 on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering related to insider trading and other alleged securities violations in a series of takeover deals from 1985 to 1987. Milken vowed to fight the charges. Milken resigned from Drexel in June 1989, and set up a consulting and investing firm.
DOC.HEAD: PLEA:
DOC.TEXT: In a reversal, Milken agreed in April to a plea bargain with prosecutors rather than go to trial. Friends said he saw no end to the ordeal otherwise. Plus, the government agreed to drop all charges against Lowell Milken. On April 24, 1990, Milken entered guilty pleas to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. Prosecutors said his agreement to cooperate with investigators could help in other prosecutions. Specifically, Milken pleaded guilty to conspiracy, aiding and abetting the filing of a false statement with the SEC, securities fraud, aiding and abetting net-capital requirements, mail fraud and assisting the filing of a false tax return. ``I realize that by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me. I am truly sorry,'' he said tearfully in court. Sentencing by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood was set for Oct. 1. Milken faces a maximum of up to 28 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Milken Case
With AM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of important developments in the prosecution of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond chief Michael Milken: May 12, 1986 - The Securities and Exchange Commission charges Dennis Levine of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. with making $12.6 million in profits from illegal trading on inside information since 1980. Levine is arrested. Nov. 14, 1986 - Stock speculator Ivan Boesky pays $100 million to settle charges of insider trading on information supplied by Levine in 1985 and 1986. He also agrees to cooperate with investigators and to plead guilty to a single criminal charge. Boesky later is sentenced to three years in prison. Late 1986 - Published reports link Michael Milken to an illegal insider trading network led by Boesky. Sept. 7, 1988 - The SEC accuses Drexel, Milken and three others of violating a wide range of securities laws, most in connection with Boesky. Dec. 21 - Drexel agrees to plead guilty to six felonies and pay a record $650 million in fines and restitution to settle the biggest securities fraud case in history. Drexel also must settle related SEC charges and cooperate with the government investigation. March 29, 1989 - A federal grand jury indicts Milken, brother Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Lee Newberg on 98 counts of racketeering and fraud largely based on information supplied by Boesky. Potential penalties and fines total about $12 billion plus possible prison terms. April 7 - The Milkens plead innocent. Newberg enters an innocent plea later. April 13 - Drexel and the SEC announce a settlement of the civil fraud case that subjects the firm to federal monitoring for three years and forces it to sever ties with Milken. June 15 - Milken resigns after 19 years at Drexel to form his own consulting firm. Lowell Milken quits to return to practicing law. Sept. 11 - Drexel pleads guilty to six felonies and begins paying more than $650 million in fines, penalties and interest. Feb. 13, 1990 - Drexel's parent company files for federal bankruptcy court protection after failing to meet short-term debt payments. The securities firm, once the nation's fifth-largest, starts laying off its 5,400 employees. March 19 - Prosecutors promise to bring a new indictment with broader charges against Milken by the week of April 16. April 4 - Boesky is released from federal custody after completing two years of a three-year term. April 19 - Four months of negotiations intensify between the government and Milken for a possible plea bargain to settle the case as a deadline looms for the new indictment. April 20 - Milken capitulates, agreeing to plead guilty to six felony counts and pay fines and restitution totaling $600 million under a plea agreement with prosecutors. He faces a maximum 28 years in prison. April 24 - Milken formally enters his plea before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood. Sentencing is scheduled for Oct. 1. Sept. 24 - Prosecutors and defense lawyers agree to release edited versions of pre-sentencing memos to Judge Wood. The government says it wants Wood to consider other alleged wrongdoing by Milken before deciding his punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Compromise on Program Trading
DOC.TEXT: Senate passage of a stock market reform bill that expands the Securities and Exchange Commission's powers was reached after congressional staffers hammered out a compromise on program trading. The compromise bill, passed on a voice vote Tuesday, will allow the SEC to regulate the controversial computer-driven trading strategy during times of extreme market turbulence, known as volatility. ``Volatility frightens away the investors American firms need to compete and grow,'' said Sen. Donald Riegle Jr., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee which oversees the SEC. ``The reforms the Senate enacted today take aim at excess volatility, letting the SEC stop such practices before they do their damage,'' he added. The legislation is expected to move to the full House within a few days. If passed by the House, the bill would then go to President Bush for his signature. ``This legislation strengthens the SEC's oversight of our securities markets and the participants in those markets,'' said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., one of the bill's original sponsors. The bill was worked out between the staffs of the Senate banking Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee over the last month. ``The talks were very cordial,'' said a House committee aide. In addition to the program trading curb, the compromise market reform bill contains provisions passed separately by both the House and Senate. One expands the authority of the SEC chairman to shut down the securities markets, with presidential permission, in times of market emergency. Previously only the president could order a trading halt. Other provisions: - Require large securities traders to report their market positions to the SEC. - Mandate coordinated clearance and settlement of stocks, options and futures contracts between the SEC and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. - Require the Treasury Department, Federal Reserve Board, the CFTC and SEC to report annually to Congress on their efforts to protect the integrity of the markets. - Give the SEC authority to assess the financial health of the parent holding companies of broker-dealers. The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the one-time junk bond giant of Wall Street, was precipitated in February by the failure of its parent holding company, which SEC officials have complained they had no authority to monitor. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said he was ``very pleased with the Senate passage of the market reform bill'' and looked forward to ``the continuing congressional process.'' The original House version, the Securities Markets Reform Act passed in June, contained a provision giving the SEC authority to limit program trading ``during periods of extraordinary market volatility'' - the sharp climbs or drops in stock prices. The original Senate version, the Market Reform Act passed last month, did not have a program trading provision. Critics of program trading, the rapid-fire transactions through computerized buy and sell programs of enormous blocks of stocks, blame it for worsening the 1987 stock market crash and the 190-point market drop last Oct. 13. They are especially critical of one form of program trading, index arbitrage, in which speculators try to take advantage of small, brief price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in the other. Critics say that strategy andthe volatility that often seems to accompany it have driven small investors out of the stock market. But industry groups including the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities Industry Association have said their studies have not shown program trading to be the cause of the 1987 crash and suggested other ways to control market volatility.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Down, But Not Much Against Strong Period
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: U.S. car and truck makers turned in surprisingly strong mid-September sales figures, down 5.6 percent from last year, leading to speculation among analysts that the Mideast crisis has yet to affect showroom traffic. The 10 major U.S. automakers reported Tuesday their car and truck sales for the Sept. 11-20 period fell to an average daily rate of 35,810 vehicles compared with a rate of 37,948 during the same time last year. A 42.3 percent increase in the sales of cars by Japanese companies was offset by a 7.5 percent decline in cars made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. The Big Three held 85.7 percent of the car market in mid-September. ``On the whole, it was a pretty good number,'' said auto analyst David Healy of Barclays de Zoete Wedd investment bankers in New York. ``I didn't expect them to come anywhere close to last year.'' Car sales were down 2.6 percent and truck sales were off 10.5 percent. The decline in truck sales led Healy to wonder if the effects of rising gasoline prices stemming from the Iraq's invasion of Kuwait may begin showing up in dealerships soon. ``If cars are down 2 percent and trucks are down 10 (percent), maybe there is a little shying away from gas-guzzling trucks,'' he said. Analysts speculated the sales rate may have received a jolt from wheeling and dealing that goes on in showrooms this time of year as dealers switch over from 1990 models to 1991 versions. Last year at this time automakers offered big incentives to shrink bloated new-vehicle inventories. This year, inventories are lower, lessening the need for incentives. ``An amazing performance,'' economist Tom Webb of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va., said of the mid-September sales rate. ``Even skittish consumers are finding the model year closeout bargains too good to pass up.'' Chrysler's truck sales fell 18.5 percent, partly because of a lack of incentives on the vehicles and patience by consumers waiting to see the redesigned 1991 models, company officials and analysts said. ``A lot of people probably know that there is a new minivan coming so they're not flooding the showrooms,'' said auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. So far this year, car and truck sales by the 10 companies were down 4.6 percent, with car sales off 5.4 percent and truck sales down 3.1 percent. Ford said a 7.9 percent decline in its truck sales and a 7.3 percent drop in its car sales during mid-September combined for a 7.6 percent decline in vehicle sales. For the year, Ford's cars and trucks were selling at a pace 9 percent slower than last year. GM said its truck sales declined 16.3 percent from last year and car sales dropped 6.4 percent, combining for a 10 percent fall in vehicle sales. The automaker's sales so far this year were running 4.8 percent behind last year. Chrysler, which has been struggling with weakening sales nearly all year, said its mid-September car sales were down 18.5 percent from last year and truck sales were off 12.1 percent, combining for a 15.1 percent decline in vehicle sales. Through Sept. 20 of this year, Chrysler's car and trucks sales declined 15 percent compared with last year.

DOC.HEAD: Japan-MCA Merger Would Wed Two Top Entertainment Companies
With PM-Matsushita Profile, PM-MCA Profile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Organisation in 27th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s proposed $7 billion acquisition of entertainment conglomerate MCA Inc. would yield a fully-integrated company combining two top players in entertainment hardware and software. The new multinational enterprise, if formed, would marry the maker of Technics, Panasonic and Quasar audio and video equipment with MCA's broad strength in movie, record and television production. By purchasing MCA, Matsushita would control not only premium film producer Universal Studios, but also a valuable film library, MCA Records, Universal Television, powerful MCA-Universal Home Video, MCA's growing theme park franchise, a cable television unit, a publishing group, a concert and sports merchandising arm, movie theaters and a 49 percent share in movie theater chain Cineplex Odeon. ``The long-term advantages are that when you make hardware you can benefit from the software producer's success,'' said Jeffrey Logsdon, an entertainment analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities. ``There's an insatiable consumer demand for entertainment software.'' Matsushita says MCA is one of the companies with which Matsushita is involved in talks; and MCA, in a statement, confirmed it is ``in discussions with a major international company regarding a possible negotiated acquisition of MCA.'' Two MCA board members said in interviews that they could neither confirm nor deny that a deal with Matsushita was being discussed. MCA President Sidney Sheinberg did not return telephone messages. In Tuesday's edition, The Wall Street Journal said Matsushita was offering between $70 and $80 a share for MCA stock, or a range of about $6.7 billion to $7.5 billion for the conglomerate. Stock in MCA Inc., which struck a 52-week low of $34.12{ in trading Monday, surged $19.25 Tuesday, or more than 57 percent, to $53.75. Other entertainment stocks also advanced in trading, with Paramount Communications up $3.12{ to $34.75 a share. The Journal said Matsushita wants to keep MCA management in place. More than a quarter of Matsushita's revenues are generated by sales of video equipment. Audio and electronic components combine for another 22 percent of revenues. The surprise is not that Matsushita finally decided to make such a move - other foreign investors have been moving through Hollywood as though it were a swap meet - but that it is considering a company as massive as MCA. Matsushita had sales of about $44.4 billion last year, and is the world's 25th largest publicly held company in the world, according to a Morgan Stanley survey in June. In 1989, MCA's revenues were $3.4 billion with an income of $191 million. While it looks small in comparison, MCA is in fact a sprawling, strapping enterprise. The Matsushita purchase exceeds Sony's acquisition of Columbia Pictures Entertainment for $5 billion last year. Columbia was - and still is - a struggling studio with limited assets, and has yet to become a significant motion picture force since the buyout. MCA, on the other hand, is a vital concern. Foreign purchase of U.S. entertainment enterprises makes sound financial sense. Entertainment is the United States' second leading export, accounting for a net positive trade balance of approximately $5 billion. The continuing deregulation of the European television and the boom in overseas VCR sales (almost 60 percent of Japanese homes have VCRs) have created a nearly insatiable need for U.S. programming. If completed, the MCA buyout would surely renew criticism of Japanese control of American assets that surfaced last year in the deals for New York's Rockefeller Center and Columbia Pictures Entertainment. The Japanese had been keeping a low profile in such transactions until a Tokyo golf tycoon purchased the Pebble Beach golf resorts in California for about $950 million. The merger also might face regulatory barriers. MCA owns independent television station WWOR in Secaucus, N.J., which a foreign company would be prevented from owning. Michael Ovitz, the head of the talent agency Creative Artists Agency Inc., has represented Matsushita in its attempts to find a software counterpart. A CAA spokesman said Tuesday it was premature to speculate if Ovitz would have any role in the new enterprise. Although MCA's Universal Pictures is not Hollywood's top film studio - that honor is shared currently by Disney and Paramount - many of its recent releases have been huge box-office hits. In 1982, Universal released the highest-grossing movie ever, ``E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial,'' and the film went on to set records at the nation's video stores in 1988. The company has also reaped large profits from 1973's ``The Sting,'' 1975's ``Jaws,'' 1985's ``Back to the Future'' and 1988's ``Twins.'' Current and upcoming Universal releases include ``White Palace,'' the X-rated ``Henry & June,'' ``Darkman,'' ``Child's Play II'' and ``Kindergarten Cop.'' MCA Records carries the popular teen vocalist Tiffany, as well as the sultry star Sheena Easton and young soul singer Bobby Brown. Universal Television produces the shows ``Murder, She Wrote,'' ``Quantum Leap,'' several ``Columbo'' movies, the comedies ``Coach,'' ``Major Dad'' and ``Uncle Buck'' and the dramas ``Over My Dead Body'' and ``Law & Order.'' Universal Studios Hollywood was the nation's third most-popular theme park in 1989, drawing 5.1 million visitors. MCA has an agreement with Nippon Steel to explore Japanese theme-park ventures, and a co-venture with Britain's Rank Organisation to develop theme park ideas for France or England. Rank bought half of Universal Studios Florida in early 1989 in a deal valued at $150 million. The theme park is partially owned by Cineplex Odeon Corp. of Toronto, of which MCA owns 49 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Giant Began as Talent Agency
Also in Wednesday AMs report.
With PM-MCA-Matsushita, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The proposed takeover of MCA marks the latest chapter in one of Hollywood's great success stories - the rise of MCA from jazz band booker to colossus of the entertainment industry. On Tuesday, Matsushita and MCA Inc. said they were in talks for a possible merger valued at about $7 billion. MCA's transformation was stage-managed over the company's 65-year history by a Chicago eye doctor, the late Jules Stein, and a one-time movie usher from Cleveland, Lew Wasserman. Stein laid the groundwork for MCA's dominance of the band business and emergence as the top agency for movie talent. Wasserman pushed the corporation into television and movie production, tourist attractions and a myriad of enterprises. Though he deals in billions and is the confidant of presidents, particularly former client Ronald Reagan, Wasserman has run the MCA empire with a silken glove. He eschews interviews and self-promotion; his biography in the Motion Picture Almanac lists only his title as MCA chairman. Until 1959, MCA was known principally as The Octopus because of its far-reaching influence as a talent agency. Then the company took a giant step, buying the venerable, faltering Universal Pictures (the Justice Department forced MCA to exit the agency business or face anti-trust charges). Universal Pictures had been created by Carl Laemmle, known as Uncle Carl because of his penchant for hiring relatives. He was a pint-sized scrapper who left the clothing business in Oshkosh, Neb., to open a nickelodeon in Chicago in 1906. He soon built a theater chain, then launched his own production company, challenging the motion picture trust, which demanded royalties for use of Thomas Edison's inventions. The star system was started in 1910 when Laemmle lured Florence Lawrence away from Biograph with a salary of $200 a week. He also hired little Mary Pickford. In 1912 Laemmle gathered in other independent companies to form Universal Pictures. ``I hope I'm not making a mistake going out there,'' said Laemmle in a rare moment of self-doubt as he moved his film-making to California. He paid $165,000 for a ranch on the north side of the Hollywood Hills and opened Universal Studios in 1915. Irving Thalberg became studio manager in 1919; at 20 he was too young to sign the paychecks. Universal flourished in the 1920s with such stars as Lon Chaney and Mae Murray and directors such as John Ford and Erich Von Stroheim. The studio specialized in westerns and horror. Classics included Chaney's silent ``The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' and ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' and the talkies ``Dracula'' and ``Frankenstein.'' The Depression staggered Universal, and in 1936 Laemmle was eased out of command. In troubled times, stars seemed to emerge to save Universal from ruin. In the 1930s it was soprano Deanna Durbin. In the 1940s, funnymen Abbott and Costello. In 1946, the studio merged with the Independent International Pictures to become Universal-International. The new management tried to upgrade the studio's reputation with dramas like ``A Double Life'' and ``All My Sons.'' But the staples remained the Ma and Pa Kettle and Francis the Talking Mule series and sex-and-sand epics with Maria Montez and Yvonne DeCarlo. Again the company faltered, and in 1952 Decca Records gained control, restoring the original name. But Universal couldn't weather a failing box office, and in 1959 it acquired a new owner, the Music Corporation of America. Stein, besides practicing medicine, played in local jazz bands. He decided musicians needed an agency to strike them better deals with hotels, ballrooms and speakeasies. By the 1930s, MCA represented most of the name bands in the swing era. And Stein set his sights on bigger game: Hollywood. Stein's chief aide, Lew Wasserman, proved a dynamo as head of MCA's Hollywood office, and soon the agency represented a long list of stars, including Joan Crawford, Errol Flynn and Alfred Hitchcock. As the major studios shunned television as an upstart competitor, MCA rushed in with its Revue Productions, grinding out series like ``M Squad'' and ``Wagon Train.'' When Ronald Reagan's film career faded, Wasserman found him work as host of ``General Electric Theater.'' Under Wasserman's guidance, MCA-Universal flourished in the 1970s and 1980s. The company became the biggest supplier of television entertainment. Universal Studios Tours grew to a major tourist attraction. The feature film division sometimes faltered, but Steven Spielberg emerged from television to direct the mega-hits ``Jaws'' and ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial.'' MCA Records also created huge profits. MCA-Universal has produced Academy Award winners (``The Sting,'' ``The Deer Hunter,'' ``Out of Africa''), controversy (``The Last Temptation of Christ'') and especially profits. The latter made it highly attractive for a takeover or buyout, as confirmed on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Offers Software Edge to Electronics Giant Matsushita
DOC.TEXT: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., which got its start with a break-through automatic rice cooker, is looking to bolster its consumer electronics business while moving into higher-profit industrial areas, analysts say. The company's products could stock an entire appliance store and then some: radios, tape recorders, refrigerators, air conditioners, video-cassette recorders and more. Some of its most widely recognized brands are Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. Matsushita Electric confirmed it is negotiating to buy entertainment giant MCA, which has a vast library of movies and television programs, in a deal valued at around $7 billion. With its 163 consolidated subsidiaries, Matsushita Electric forms Japan's third largest corporation and commands the largest share of Japan's home electronics market. A Morgan Stanley survey in June ranked Matsushita the 25th-largest publicly-held corporation in the world. It is also known to insiders as the ``Matsushita bank,'' reporting holdings of over $10 billion in cash assets alone last year. Total sales topped $41.6 billion. The influence of legendary founder Konosuke Matsushita is felt in virtually every Japanese home where an automatic rice cooker takes the drudgery out of preparing the nation's staple food. Matsushita, a man who never went to high school yet became Japan's most famous entrepreneur, popularized the electric rice cooker in the 1950s in keeping with his corporate philosophy: ``To manufacture items of good quality for daily use in abundant supply, thereby enriching and improving life for everyone.'' That comment in 1932 came a little less than 15 years after the 23-year-old Matsushita left his employer to capitalize on his own electrical switch invention. Today, the Matsushita empire has spawned nearly 500 related firms operating in 36 countries. During the 37 years it has operated in the United States, Matsushita has built 12 factories, established seven sales companies and a research facility and employs some 10,000 people. But the company is now facing a crossroads. Over 60 percent of its sales have been concentrated in low-growth consumer products such as refrigerators and video-cassette recorders. Compared to other Japanese electronics makers, it is having difficulty making the jump to more profitable industrial sectors, analysts say. It has also been unable to come up with a new hit product to take the place of the wildly successful VCR, reflecting the company's strength in manufacturing capability over inventive prowess. Boris Petersik, an analyst for Barclay de Zoete Wedd Securities Ltd., notes that Matsushita's mere size - including its 25,000 affiliated retailers in Japan - has proved a burden to shifting its resources. The group plans to change, however. It developed a long-term plan six years ago to focus on seven areas of high technology including computers, semiconducters and communication technology. By 1992, the company hopes those areas will account for 40 percent of total sales. This year, the company has been investing huge amounts - some 400 billion Japanese yen ($3.2 billion) - in crystal displays, computers and semiconductors. It is also trying to develop profitable movie and television cameras for professional use, Petersik said. But Matsushita has had a hard time cracking Sony's dominance on the professional market as well as its lead in the consumer market for VCRs. Sony now has the rich video software resources it purchased last year in its $5 billion acquisition of Columbia Pictures Entertainment, he said. ``They don't want to lose completely on consumer products,'' he said. The MCA acquisition, if it goes through, would both give the company access to software to keep its consumer-products sales healthy and to studios where it could introduce its professional products. ``Software is going to be the critical factor'' in the video market, Martin Beresford, senior analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd., said of the Japanese company's possible MCA purchase. A company spokesman in Tokyo said MCA is only one of the companies with which Matsushita is involved in talks, but said nothing had been decided. He said he could not comment further. The acquisition also would indicate that the company is recovering from the death last year of the 94-year-old company founder, according to Petersik. Revered as a visionary of Japanese business, Matsushita was also one of Japan's richest men, leaving an estate valued $1.7 billion. And he was among Japan's most generous individuals. In a country where charitable contributions do not qualify for tax breaks, he established his own non-profit foundation, opened his factories to the handicapped and endowed cultural institutions and a private school for training future leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Resigns From Company He Founded
DOC.TEXT: Financier Alan Bond resigned Wednesday as chairman and director of Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., the company he founded that has fallen victim to financial problems stemming from a heavy debt load. Bond Corp. said in a statement that two other directors, Tony Oates and Peter Mitchell, also resigned as senior executives. It said Peter Lucas had accepted an appointment as the new chairman of the board of directors. The company said Bond ``has been considering this course of action for some time.'' Bond, Oates and Mitchell will act as consultants to the company until its proposed brewery sale and capital restructuring is completed, Bond Corp. said. A spokesman said that after the restructuring and brewery sale were completed, Bond, Oates and Mitchell would play no further role in the company ``in the direct management sense.'' Bond still retains a controlling interest in Bond Corp. through his private company, Dallhold Investments. The resignation came earlier than expected. Bond said on July 20 he would resign once European and British bond holders had accepted a Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd. buyback offer. The offer is yet to be accepted. Bond Corp., which reported an annual loss of 979 million Australian dollars, worth $815 million (U.S.) at current exchange rates, for the 1988-89 financial year, has had to sell assets to reduce its crippling debt levels. The brash, flamboyant Bond rose rapidly from humble roots - his first job was as a sign painter at 14 - by investing in land around Perth and taking advantage of rapidly rising property values. With a flair for picking the best development sites and promoting them well, he was made his first million dollars by 1969 at age 29. He rode out the 1987 stock market crash on strong cash flow from his beer assets. But the man who built a fortune by making the most of borrowed funds has been plagued by heavy debts, rising interest rates and bad business decisions. The combination alienated his bankers and creditors, put his Australian brewing interests into receivership and forced him to sell assets ranging from a Hong Kong development office to a coal mine. Unlike business rival Robert Holmes a Court, who died recently from a heart attack, Bond maintained a high public profile. He probably is best known for financing the Australian sailing team's stunning triumph over the United States in the 1983 America's Cup race.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Trustee Wants Bush Intervention
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines may become a casualty of the Persian Gulf crisis, says the carrier's trustee, who called for presidential action to help alleviate the impact of fuel price increases. ``The airlines cannot support the increased cost. Eastern cannot support the increased cost,'' Martin Shugrue said Tuesday in a speech at Florida International University. ``And the public cannot tolerate the increased burden in air fares.'' Shugrue was appointed to run Eastern last April, 13 months after the Miami-based carrier filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection amid a crippling strike. He soon launched a much-publicized marketing campaign to revitalize Eastern and it was making progress, he said. ``We looked like we were about ready to take off. At the very least, we were moving ahead. We were cooking. The trouble is, to put it cutely, we're cooking with gas,'' Shugrue said. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the international sanctions against Iraq, Shugrue said, Eastern's fuel prices have jumped from 56 cents to 96 cents a gallon. At that rate, he said, Eastern, which reached a 72 percent passenger load capacity for August, would have to fly at 102 percent of capacity to break even. Shugrue said oil companies rushed to jack up prices, at the airlines' expense. ``We are calling for the administration, President Bush, to do two things that we need done immediately,'' Shugrue said. The first, he said, is to form a task force of officials of the airlines, oil companies, administration and Congress to study and recommend actions on oil prices. The second is a pledge by the president or secretary of transportation to draw from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve should a domestic shortage develop. Shugrue said those actions could reduce oil prices by $5 to $10 per barrel right away. Crude oil futures prices have approached $40 a barerel in recent days, up from about $17 a barrel in July. He said afterward that he plans to write letters to the White House and Transportation Department.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Confirms Pan Am Shuttle Talks
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines has confiemd it is in talks about the possible purchase of the Pan Am Shuttle, and for the backing of major aircraft manufacturers and leasing companies to finance the deal. The New York Times reported Tuesday that Guiness Peat Aviation, the world's largest aircraft-leasing company, and International Aero Engines, a consortium of engine manufacturers, would finance America West's purchase of the shuttle in exchange for the airline's agreement to buy or lease more than 100 Airbus Industrie A320 jets. America West issued a statement Tuesday confirming that it is holding talks with ``manufacturers and certain potential lessors'' for the acquisition of Airbus A320 aircraft ``together with related financial support and aircraft purchase options.'' However, officials of the Phoenix-based airline declined to discuss specifics. ``The possible transaction has not been finalized and an appropriate announcement will be made if the transaction is consummated,'' said Michael J. Conway, America West president. He also confirmed that the airline has held talks with Pan Am, but said the discussions ``are ongoing and have not resulted in any agreements.'' The Times put the purchase price at $200 million, but Conway said such speculation is ``premature and not well founded.'' The Pan Am Shuttle flies between New York and Washington, D.C., and New York and Boston. Thomas Plaskett, chairman of Pan Am, said last week that he expected to sell the shuttle by the end of the year, although he declined to identify potential buyers. America West tried last year to buy the Trump Shuttle, which also serves the New York-Boston-Washington corridor, but was unable to come up with the necessary financing. Airbus Industrie, a European aerospace consortium, said last week that it and General Electric Co., which makes engines for its jets, had arranged for a $500 million loan for Northwest Airlines as part of a deal in which Northwest would by 75 Airbus jets. Alan Boyd, chairman of Airbus North America, said Airbus would not loan any money to America West. But The Times quoted sources familiar with the talks as saying Airbus ``was instrumental in arranging the financing'' for the shuttle purchase, and said the deal could be closed as early as Friday. Officials of Guiness Peat Aviation and International Aero Engines delined comment. America West Chairman Ed Beauvais said last month that the airline was discussing the possible acquisition of an undisclosed number of A320 jets, but refused to discuss details, saying it would ``create needless speculation.'' He also said the airline was trying to acquire more Boeing 737-300s, which make up the bulk of the carrier's fleet of 92 aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: USX Names New Steel Division Chief
DOC.TEXT: Thomas J. Usher was promoted from executive vice president of USX Corp.'s heavy products division to president of its steel divison, USS. He succeeds Thomas C. Graham. The company's board voted Tuesday to name Graham to the new post of vice chairman of the company's Steel & Diversified Group. USX spokesman William Keslar said the change was ``simply a matter of transition'' because Graham, who joined USX in 1983, will retire in about a year. ``You want to season a new guy into the new job,'' Keslar said. Usher, a native of Reading, was named to the heavy products post in 1986. Also Tuesday, Charles C. Gedeon was appointed president of the USX's U.S. Diversified Group and senior vice president of raw materials for USS.

DOC.HEAD: American National Can Announces New Recycling Efforts
DOC.TEXT: American National Can Co. has forged an agreement with Du Pont Co. to recycle rigid plastic bottles that recyclers often reject. The pact should go a long way toward resolving one of the recycling industry's major problems: finding someone to use the reconstituted product by guaranteeing a continuing supply. One of the big remaining obsticles to increasing the re-use of plastics above the current rate of 1 percent to 2 percent is to improve the sorting process to segregate the various kinds of plastics, said Clifford Klotz, American National Can's vice president and general manager for recycling. Now, plastic is hand-sorted at a Chicago area plant operated by the Plastic Recycling Alliance, a joint venture between Du Pont and Waste Management Inc. Researchers are trying to find a way to speed up this process, Klotz said Tuesday. ``The economics (of plastic recycling) is not as good today as it will be a year from now,'' he said. In addition to the plastics agreement, American National Can also announced a pact with Waste Management of North America Inc., which will supply all types of presorted metal and glass containers. American National Can will melt them down to form new containers or sell the material to other manufacturers. Under both agreements, trash will go through a preliminary presorting at the curbside when Waste Management picks it up. The metal and glass recycling alliance will begin next year when when a final sorting and processing facility is completed in the Chicago area. At first, Waste Management will provide trash from 140,000 homes. The company serves 2 million households in more than 250 communities nationwide, although recycling in many of these towns is voluntary. Nonetheless, American National Can and Waste Management foresee eventually extending the program beyond the Chicago area. ``These recycling efforts will be extended throughout the United States and eventually throughout the world,'' said Jean-Pierre Ergas, chief executive officer of American National Can. Klotz said that, except for plastic, much of the recycling pays for itself through the value of the trash. Aluminum cans have been money-makers for years, he said. Steel-can recycling should pay for itself, Klotz said, and so should glass if it's handled efficiently. He said it's too early to project the quantity of recyclable materials the new pacts can be expected to generate. David Goeller, a spokesman for Environmental Action, said his group ``is always in favor of re-use.'' ``We applaud more recycling, but we also wold like to see less use of some of these items to start with, particularly on the plastic end,'' he said. Goeller said it's difficult to make a specific assessment of the American National Can projects without knowing more about them. Environmental Action, headquartered in Washington, is a national research and lobbying group.

DOC.HEAD: City Proposes Steps to Regain Market Access
DOC.TEXT: Without a short-term loan, the city of Philadelphia will be forced to live day to day on cash receipts until major property tax payments arrive in late February, according to a city report. In an analysis of the city's cash condition, the Finance Director's Office urged state and local political leaders Tuesday to back its search for such a loan. ``The city would in this event be insolvent,'' the analysis said. ``Such a condition of insolvency has never happened to a major American city.'' Two of the city's three major taxes - property and business privilege - are due annually in the spring, and the city has borrowed annually since 1972 to meet payroll and other obligations until those funds arrived. A $375 million note offering was postponed Sept. 12 because it failed to attract investors. The analysis said the offering was undercut by ``adverse publicity, the lack of definitive public commitments at the state and local levels to find a permanent correction, and the corresponding high degree of uncertainty about Philadelphia's fiscal future.'' According to the analysis, five steps are needed to regain access to the markets. -Pledges from key state and local leaders to ensure that noteholders would be repaid. -Clarification from city Controller Jonathan A. Saidel of his position on the need for seasonal cash-flow borrowing. -Demonstrated willingness by state and local leaders to find a long-term solution to the city's underlying fiscal problems. -At least a minimal commitment from state and local banks to back the notes. -Action by the state on one of six proposals that would enhance the city's financial standing. The proposals that would need state approval include longstanding requests for full state funding of state-mandated human services programs, a significant advance on state funds the city already is expected to get this fiscal year or state guarantees on the notes. The other possibilities are passage of mandatory withholding of the city's wage tax from the paychecks of an estimated 25,000 city residents who work in the suburbs, passage of a local sales tax and approval of deficit financing. The analysis also outlines various cash-saving steps it can take itself without a short-term note, including freezes in hiring, payments to the city pension fund and repayment of an illegal real-estate transfer tax. Mayor W. Wilson Goode said last week the city could save $122 million through such steps, delaying until Dec. 1 the date when it would run out of cash. For a long-term solution to the city's financial ills, the analysis restated proposals Goode's administration has pushed for two years. The main elements still lacking, the analysis said, are a permanent funding source for the regional mass-transit system; tax reform and increased local taxes; and additional state aid, mostly for mandated human services programs.

The stock market opened slightly lower today, unable to build upon the gains of the previous session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 3.71 points at 2,481.93 in the first half hour of trading. Losing issues narrowly outnumbered gainers, with 478 declining, 420 advancing and 535 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.33 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Though oil prices continued to retreat today, the move had little affect on the stock market. Analysts stressed that there are few compelling reasons to buy equities and stressed that no clear trend has emerged in stock trading. ``The market is basically lobbing around at the bottom,'' said Larry Wachtel, first vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Wall Street was largely unaffected by a sharp drop overnight in Tokyo, where the key Nikkei stock index plunged nearly 5 percent to its lowest level in three years. MCA continued to trade actively, a day after it was disclosed that the company is discussing a buyout with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. MCA was up } at 54} on the Big Board and helped generate some enthusiasm for other potential ``deal'' stocks. Among other actively traded issues, Pepsi was unchanged at 22; Philip Morris was down \ at 44|, and Boeing was unchnaged at 40}. Citicorp, which confirmed it was laying off 100 employees in its leveraged buyout department, was down ] at 15[. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was at 168.71, off 0.49. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.50 to 312.67. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 32.76 to 2,485.64 Advancing issues only slightly outpaced decliners in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 770 up, 745 down and 471 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 155.94 million shares, down from 162.21 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat, Corn, Soybeans Open Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened slightly lower today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders foresaw continued sluggish export demand for both corn and soybeans. An expected bumper harvest also helped push soybean prices lower. Wheat followed the lead of corn and soybean prices as traders cautiously waited for the release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly grain stocks report after Thursday's close. Analysts expect the USDA to report higher soybean and wheat stocks and lower corn stocks than a year ago. The lower prices also reflected follow-through selling after Tuesday's weak close in the corn and wheat markets. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to } cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.74\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $2.26} a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2\ cents lower with December at $1.12} a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents to 4{ cents lower with November at $6.14 a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .10 cent higher with October at 78.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .10 cent higher with September at 88.95 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent to .53 cent lower with October at 54.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .27 cent to .50 cent lower with February at 56.20 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled lower Tuesday and pork bellies were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: With Graphic
Foreign Bankers Find Bonanza on U.S. Shores
DOC.TEXT: Foreign banks have been setting up shop on U.S. soil in increasing numbers over the years, lending money to corporations, investing in government securities, even accepting deposits. In many cases, they've been competing head-on with American-owned banks. Now, as many U.S. banks retrench abroad and struggle with a slumping real estate market at home, some critics charge foreign institutions are bullying their U.S. counterparts in a financial free-for-all. They suggest foreign banks be bound by new controls. But others say the current open-door policy best serves the American consumers. Buoyed by the equal-treatment policies of the International Banking Act of 1978, overseas bankers have expanded their American operations by a startling 2,800 percent since the early 1970s. They rushed in to help finance the federal deficit and make commercial loans in a vast, diversified market that offered new horizons for expansion. Meanwhile, American banks reined in their international lending as some of their loans soured and capital considerations grew more urgent. The 670 foreign-owned bank branches, agencies and subsidiaries account for nearly 30 percent of all outstanding commercial or business lending. At the end of last year, U.S. assets of foreign banks totaled $735.7 billion, compared with $26.1 billion in 1972, according to figures provided by the Federal Reserve. About 55 percent of those assets are from Japanese institutions, the Fed said. Real estate developer Donald Trump knows first hand the global power and importance of Japanese banks. He has been forced to knock on the doors of several Japanese banks during his cash crunches this year. In a recent report, the Nippon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's premier financial newspaper, claimed Trump owes a third of his debts to Japanese banks. Faramarz Damanpour, author of the recently published book ``The Evolution of Foreign Banking Institutions in the United States,'' called the growing dependence on foreign banks alarming. He suggests requiring a certain level of U.S. participation in foreign banking operations. ``If we do not please the Japanese, then we are at their mercy,'' said Damanpour, a James Madison University professor. ``The similarity can be to the OPEC oil.'' Robert Dugger, chief economist of the Washington-based American Bankers Association, says foreign banks often act in concert with the fiscal policies of their home countries, not those of the United States. As a result, they sometimes can draw on extra funds because of lower reserve requirements, regulatory costs, and deposit insurance premiums in many foreign lands, he said. ``The playing field is tipped significantly in their favor.'' But Lawrence R. Uhlick, executive director of the New York-based Institute of International Bankers, says foreign banks also have guidelines to follow. He noted that the Bank for International Settlements, which acts as a bank for central banks of major industrialized countries, adopted risk-based capital standards two years ago. The Swiss-based bank also set a March 1993 deadline for banks to hold capital equal to at least 8 percent of their loans and other assets, he said. Uhlick said foreign bnnks provide healthy competition in lending and other banking services and additional financing to the U.S. market. They also boost international trade, in part by financing U.S. operations of businesses from their home countries, he said. ``A lot of people look at the size of the U.S. business that has been done by banks around the world, and they draw from that the conclusion that foreign banks are stealing U.S. business somehow,'' said James M. Stewart, general manager of Den Danske Bank, a Danish company with offices in New York and Los Angeles. ``Really, that's not the case. What's happening is that banks are bringing capital and a capacity to participate in transactions that would not otherwise be completed.'' Any effort to pass protectionist legislation will only backfire, some say. ``Other markets may not remain open to American banks if the U.S. restricts access of other countries' banks to its market,'' said Uhlick. ``I'd let the consumer decide how best their financial services are going to be met.'' Some bankers and lawmakers have called for deregulating the entire U.S. banking system to unshackle both foreign and American institutions. To develop a foundation to compete worldwide, they say, U.S. banks must be given freedom to expand easily from state to state and to do insurance and securities business that is now off-limits to them. ``If you can't go where other individuals can go, if you can't do what other individuals can do, that impedes your ability to compete,'' said Rep. John LaFalce, D-Buffalo, N.Y., a member of the House Task Force on International Competitiveness. One effort to rework the banking system is embodied in House Bill 1992. It would allow creation of ``depository institution holding companies'' that could provide banking, securities, or insurance services though subsidiaries. While that may help, some banking experts say the problems facing U.S. banks run much deeper. ``We are losing our respect in financial and capital markets,'' said Damanpour. He says that in the long term, Americans must improve their educational system, rebuild the infrastructure, and abandon what he views as an outmoded ethos of greed and easy living.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday Sept. 30

DOC.HEAD: U995
DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for light sweet crude was $38.80 per barrel at 12 p.m. Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Stock prices sank today, erasing the gains of the previous session as the pace of trading quickened. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 35.14 points at 2,450.50 at midday. Losing issues outpaced gainers by about 13 to 4, with 1,009 declining, 311 advancing and 485 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 85.35 million shares as of noon on Wall Street, against 73.45 million shares at the same time Tuesday. Stock prices opened mixed before the drift lower gathered momentum. A turnaround in the energy market, where oil price resumed their move upward and the near-term crude contract again traded above $38 a barrel, put pressure on stocks. Further, traders continued to be concerned about the economy and the budget deficit. The lack of agreement on a budget-reduction plan coupled with a 0.8 percent decline in durable goods orders in August ``brings everything back into light that things are not that good,'' said James Schroederade the effort to open channels of communication between the military and civilians. Any armchair general is entitled to speculate about what military actions the United States might take if the attempt to starve Iraq out of Kuwait fails. Dugan, however, was no armchair general. He was the real thing. Anything he said as Air Force chief of staff carried the weight of an inside opinion, the musings of someone with access to high-level planning. Even if Dugan's assessment that U.S. planes would bomb Baghdad and specifically target Iraqi President Saddam Hussein wasn't official, the damage had been done. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who fired Dugan, said that discussion of likely military targets inside Iraq violates Pentagon policy. Furthermore, Dugan may have disclosed classified information about the size of U.S. forces in the gulf area. Despite the charges, however, it seems unlikely that Dugan disclosed anything that Iraq had not considered already. Even a layman would guess that the United States would rely heavily on air strikes in a region where its ground troops are outnumbered. If the United States does resort to force, it also seems likely that one of its primary objectives will be to cripple Iraq's war machine and cut supply lines to Kuwait - all from the air if possible. And finally, it should be no surprise that sending planes to gun for Hussein is a possibility. After all, one of the objectives of the bombing raid on Libya allegedly was to kill Moammar Gadhafi. Pentagon officials, chiefs of staff and high-ranking military officers can't say that, however. For one thing, the president is forbidden from sanctioning official assassinations. For another, it is foolish for members of the U.S. military to discuss their options in public. ... It's a bad ending for a fine career, but with that much experience in how the military works, Dugan should have known better. --- Sept. 21 Bakersfield (Calif.) Californian on the firing of Gen. Michael Dugan: In one respect, it is sad to see the distinguished military career of former Air Force Chief of Staff Michael J. Dugan go down in inglorious flames as a result of a single lapse of judgment. But of all people, a four-star general should know better than to discuss with the press specific targets in the event of war in the Persian Gulf. All considered, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was justified in firing General Dugan for thoughtless remarks that subsequently were printed in the Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. Dugan told three reporters during a trip to Saudi Arabia that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had concluded that the only effective military option for driving Iraqi forces out of Kuwait was heavy bombing of Baghdad to ``decapitate'' the senior Iraqi leadership, making Saddam Hussein, his family and palace guards primary targets. Any buck private has the common sense not to publicize battle plans. By discussing possible targets, the general has warned Saddam Hussein to fortify the sites. He'll likely place American hostages in targeted areas. ... It's hard to believe that a ranking officer, molded by 32 years of military discipline, would succumb to loose talk as the nation prepares for possible war. ... The general had to be silenced. --- Sept. 19 The Mesa (Ariz.) Tribune on David Souter: A reporter asked former Supreme Court Justice Warren E. Burger if it is proper for the Senate Judiciary Committee to ask Supreme Court nominee David Souter about abortion. Burger was emphatic: not only would it be improper to ask, it would be improper for Souter to answer. Such a remark is not surprising coming from a Nixon-appointed conservative. But Burger is correct. The committee's duty is to oversee the selection of a judge, not a politician. If the senators insist on unveiling Souter's feelings on abortion, they not only will flout the intent of the court, they will lay a distressing groundwork for selecting future jurists. The contrast between Souter and those measuring his character are stark indicators that we don't want a politician on the bench. Compare the quiet dignity of Souter to his inquisitors. (He) has lived a life of scholarly seclusion, driven by a passion for history and the law. The pro-choice members of the judiciary committee have an opportunity to teach the American people the distinction between the court and the Congress. The two have different jobs. Politicians create laws. Judges interpret them. The callings are different, and so too must be their approach to the law. (Committee chairman Joseph) Biden wasted little time getting to abortion. He danced on the periphery with questions on civil rights and the implied rights of privacy - the foundation on which Roe vs. Wade is built. But Souter wouldn't budge. He told the senator repeatedly it would be improper for him to reveal his inner feelings about a case that might soon be before him. If we choose judges based on how they'll vote on the hot issues of the day, we compromise the independence of the judiciary. --- Sept. 21 Valley News, Lebanon, N.H., on politicians: Polling around the country earlier this summer showed rising disaffection with the parties themselves and incumbents generally. ... And there are other indications of disenchantment with the status quo. In Oklahoma, voters agreed to limit the terms of state legislators. Polling by The Washington Post and ABC News suggests that the electorate may be remarkably willing to shop around this fall for congressional candidates, undermining the theory tha the enhanced powers of modern incumbency are creating the so-called ``Permanent Congress.''... First and most obviously it's axiomatic that people vote their pocketbook. As the economy slumps and state budget woes rise, members of the political establishment may begin to pay for the prosperity of the '80s that rendered their incumbency almost unassailable. ---
