DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rally on Iraq Rumors
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOPS with 10 new grafs to UPDATE with markets rallying. Picks up 8th graf pvs, When crude . . .
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rallied late this morning on fears of war in the Persian Gulf, wiping out an early decline that was attributed to a report of higher supplies of gasoline and heating oil. ``We're hearing rumors that Saddam wants the U.S. out of Saudi Arabia within 48 hours,'' said trader Brian Tagler of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``That's what's causing the rally.'' Light sweet crude was trading up 27 cents at $37.80 per barrel for November delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange shortly before noon. Other crude contract months were mixed. Earlier today, oil had fallen more than $1 per barrel as traders responded to the release on Tuesday evening of American Petroleum Institute statistics that showed supplies of the refined petroleum products had risen. At the opening, the market was paying less attention to a U.N. action on Tuesday night authorizing an extension of the embargo of Iraq and Kuwait to cover airways as well as the sea. Some traders had thought that move would push prices up this morning, but oil opened lower in apparent response to the weekly API report. Gasoline and heating oil also fell in early trading today, but heating oil rallied along with crude oil around midday. Heating oil moved up .30 cent to $1.015 per gallon on October contracts shortly before noon. But the October contract for unleaded gasoline was down 2.45 cents at 99.60 cents per gallon. Later months were mixed for both refined products. Natural gas prices were also mixed late this morning, with November contracts trading just before noon at $1.93 per 1,000 cubic feet, the same as Tuesday's close. Traders viewed the markets' decline early in the morning as a continuation of Tuesday's dip, which followed a dramatic surge in prices on Monday. When crude oil soared briefly above $39 per barrel Monday, people on the floor of the exchange were saying $40 was their next target. ``We haven't heard talk of that lately, but all you need is some war rhetoric and that talk will come right back,'' said Sal Gilbertie, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. The API report that was moving the market on its open showed that crude imports and stocks fell last week, as did imports and production of gasoline and distillates, which include home heating oil. Refinery capacity was also down last week, although the nation's stockpiles of gasoline and distillates were higher, API said in its weekly statistics. Crude imports were at 5.7 million barrels per day, down from 6.0 million barrels daily a week earlier but up from 5.6 million barrels a day a year ago. Crude oil stocks stood at 364.0 million barrels, down from 369.8 million barrels a week earlier but up from 330.9 million barrels a year earlier. Gasoline imports were down to 215,000 barrels per day, from 282,000 barrels per day a week earlier and 313,000 barrels per day a year earlier. Gasoline stocks were higher, at 222.3 million barrels, compared with 217.0 million barrels a week earlier and 219.2 million barrels a year earlier. Distillate imports were down to 220,000 barrels per day, from 394,000 barrels per day a week earlier and 278,000 barrels per day a year earlier. Distillate stockpiles were up to 136.5 million barrels, compared with 133.3 million barrels a week earlier and 122.8 million barrels a year earlier. Gasoline production was down to 7.2 million barrels per day, from 7.4 million barrels a week earlier and 7.3 million barrels per day a year earlier. Distillate production was down to 2.9 million barrels per day, from 3.0 million barrels, the figure both a week earlier and a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: CAW Going to GM Next; Oct. 10 Deadline
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Auto Workers union today set an Oct. 10 strike deadline for reaching a new labor agreement with General Motors Corp.'s Canadian subsidiary. CAW members last weekend ratified a new contract with Ford of Canada after a six-day strike by about 12,800 workers. It's expected the union will use that contract as a pattern for negotiations with General Motors of Canada Ltd., which has about 36,000 workers covered by the CAW national contract. CAW President Bob White said today a strike next month at GM's 12 facilities in Canada is possibile. ``We should not fall into a false sense of security,'' White said. GM has said it wants to shut its Scarborough, Ontario, van assembly plant in 1992 and cut 700 jobs from its Windsor, Ontario, trim plant. White said negotiations with GM would focus on saving jobs from those two factories. ``The agreement reached at Ford is an expensive proposition,'' said Rick Curd, vice president of personnel for GM of Canada. The company, he added today, wants improvements in cost-competitiveness, workplace flexibility and worker attendance. In the United States, meantime, United Auto Workers union members at GM plants today continued voting on a proposed three-year agreement reached Sept. 17. That pact appeared headed to an overwhelming ratification margin. Voting should be completed by Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Allies Question Details in U.S. Fund Raising Effort
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 4-5 with Brady comments; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, bgng, `Officials said . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: American allies raised new questions today concerning a fund-raising campaign launched by President Bush to collect the billions of dollars needed in the Persian Gulf crisis. As officials representing more than 20 nations prepared to hold an organizational meeting of the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group, it was clear that the allies who were expected to put up the cash had a number of objections to the outline of the effort unveiled by Bush on Tuesday. The disputes ranged from such basic issues as how much money should be contributed to which countries should receive the assistance. There were also debates over what mechanisms to use to disburse the funds. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady expressed the hope today that the various questions could be resolved, telling global finance ministers in a speech that they needed to forge ``a united economic front'' against Saddam Hussein. ``The economic strength represented by all of you in this room must be mobilized to demonstrate collective resolve and make clear our intention not to yield to aggression,'' Brady said. Officials said that while the United States was pushing for more than $14 billion in assistance for the frontline states of Turkey, Egypt and Jordan and other hard-hit countries, some European countries were insisting that a much smaller amount of around $9 billion was all that was needed. Saudi Arabia reportedly was objecting to including Jordan as a beneficiary country until Jordan moved more forcefully to close its borders to trade with Iraq. President Bush put forward his proposal for the crisis coordination group during an address Tuesday to the opening sessions of the 154-nation International Monetary Fund and its sister organization, the World Bank. While officials of the large donor countries indicated general support for a coordinating group, they let it be known that many of the details remained to be worked out. British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major told reporters that it was possible that a working group session today would be unable to resolve all the outstanding issues and would end up bucking the dispute to a later meeting of finance ministers. ``It is clearly sensible for the world to get together and determine what should be the elements of assistance, how much it should be and how that should be divided among the donor nations,'' Major said. Officials of Japan, which already has pledged $4 billion, more than any other country outside of oil-rich Persian Gulf nations, indicated they had questions as well on how the informal coordinating council would work. ``President Bush gave one idea. Whether it will go ahead will depend on the response of the countries involved,'' Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told reporters late Tuesday. In his speech, Bush noted the refugee crisis as well as unemployment problems and serious economic disruptions resulting from rising oil prices. ``This staggering burden, which is pressing upon those most seriously affected countries, calls for a generous response from the world community,'' the president told the finance officials. ``The political leadership of the U.N. must be matched by the economic leadership of the IMF and World Bank,'' he said. The United States has been trying for a month to mobilize financial support to pay the cost of the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf and to compensate countries harmed by the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. The administration fears that the sanctions against Iraq could begin to unravel without substantial economic assistance. The United States has obtained pledges of $20 billion from the allies, divided equally between support for the military effort and assistance for the three countries hardest hit by the turmoil - Turkey, Egypt and Jordan, the so-called frontline states. However, a West German official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said the United States now was seeking $14.5 billion in aid for the frontline states, up from an initial estimate of $10.5 billion earlier this month. The German official said some European countries questioned whether this amount overstated the need. He said his country also would like to see the donor pool widened to include such nations as Switzerland and Sweden. In a fact sheet released by the White House, the countries expected to participate with the United States in the crisis coordination group included Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and South Korea. In addition, representatives of the 12-nation European Community were being included in the discussions along with the Gulf Cooperation Council of Persian Gulf countries. The administration received assurances Monday from policy-setting panels of the IMF and the World Bank that both agencies stood ready to accelerate their lending activities in order to cushion the economic fallout from the doubling of world oil prices. While the administration has focused its fundraising efforts primarily on Egypt, Turkey and Jordan, officials of the IMF and the World Bank say they expect to provide aid to many other Third World nations that have been hurt by rising oil prices, the loss of export markets and a flood of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prosecutors Want Milken Put Away in `Substantial Sentence'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New information on government's documents, editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors seeking a stiff prison term for Michael Milken released their long-awaited arguments to the sentencing judge today, urging her to concentrate on the convicted financier's ``sweeping and serious crimes.'' The 200-page memorandum to U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood exhorted her to pay scant attention to Milken's good deeds and instead consider evidence that he was a systematic crook. ``The court's sentence must demonstrate that persons who possess great wealth and prominence cannot expect that their privilege or their money will insulate them from certain and serious punishment,'' said the document signed by Acting U.S. Attorney Roger Hayes. It was released a day after Milken's high-powered legal team released their own recommendations to the judge, who is scheduled to pronounce sentence Monday on the most celebrated defendant in the securities fraud scandals that rocked Wall Street in the 1980s. The defense lawyers have urged the judge to weigh Milken's generosity and philanthropy and spare him from prison. They suggest alternatively that Milken be ordered to work full-time with youths in the drug-plagued ghettos of Los Angeles. He faces a maximum 28 years in prison on six felony counts, to which he earlier pleaded guilty, including conspiracy, securities fraud and tax violations. ``His good works, however commendable, should not shield him from incarceration,'' the prosecution memorandum said. ``Milken is guilty of sweeping and serious crimes. He should be sentenced to a substantial term of imprisonment.'' The prosecution cannot recommend a specific prison term, and Wood has wide discretion in passing sentence. But many legal experts expect the 44-year-old ex-trader of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bonds to do time. Wood ordered the release of sentencing memorandums earlier this week because of the enormous public interest in the Milken case. But she instructed the two sides to edit the documents to delete incriminating references to Milken associates. Milken abandoned claims of innocence in April and agreed to a plea bargain that spared him from a much wider indictment and assumes his cooperation with prosecutors in other probes. But in sentencing, the defense has opposed the prosecution's effort to portray Milken as a conniving criminal mastermind who committed more crimes than he had admitted. In their recommendation to Wood, they asked her to view Milken's transgressions as an aberration in an otherwise exemplary life. ``Michael should be sentenced based on the offenses to which he pleaded guilty,'' the defense papers said. ``He should not be sentenced for crimes that he did not commit. He should not be sentenced on charges for which the government expressly has foregone prosecution in return for his guilty plea.'' Lead defense attorney Arthur Liman wrote that hundreds of letters from Milken relatives, friends and clients portrayed him as a benevolent capitalist, hardworking family man, and a ``person of great conscience, compassion and charity who has always been generous with his time, money and spirit.'' The lawyer also asserted Milken already has been punished severely by relentless public scrutiny, payment of a record $600 million in fines and penalties and a bleak future fighting civil lawsuits. ``Michael Milken is a changed person. He will be tormented for the remainder of his life by the realization that his family was devastated, his reputation destroyed and his life's work tainted by virtue of his having committed these acts,'' Liman wrote. The defense also denied suggestions that Milken played any role in the decline of the nation's savings and loans, which were among some of his most prominent clients. On the contrary, S&L holdings of junk bonds below investment grade were among their most profitable investments, the defense contended. It also rejected allegations of insider trading against Milken, including trades of securities in Caesar's World, Viacom, Republic Airlines and Lorimar, noting that those charges had been refuted earlier. Milken's guilty plea did not include any counts related to trading on the basis of nonpublic information. The defense also minimized the extent of his association with Ivan Boesky, the convicted inside trader who was Milken's chief accuser. ``Indeed, the government even secured an indictment of Mr. Milken on some of the transactions for which it now acknowledges that it does not have - and never did have - any evidence of Mr. Milken's involvement,'' the defense documents said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Silverado CEO Invokes Fifth at Neil Bush Hearing
LaserPhoto DX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to UPDATE with witness who refused to testify now agreeing to offer testimony. Edits to conform. DELETES outdated penultimate graf. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A former board member of the failed Silverado savings and loan association who refused to testify at Neil Bush's conflict-of-interest hearing has changed his mind and will testify Thursday, officials said today. Florian Barth was to have been the third witness at the Office of Thrift Supervision hearing that opened Tuesday, but he refused to appear. Today, government counsel Stephen Hershkowitz told Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson that Barth had decided to testify and would appear before the hearing Thursday morning. Davidson on Tuesday had said he would sign a subpoena to force Barth's appearance if he did not appear voluntarily. Tuesday's hearing was highlighted by former Silverado Chairman Michael Wise invoking the Fifth Amendment 14 times. Another Silverado executive, meanwhile, testified the thrift's board of directors knew of Bush's business relationship with Kenneth Good when it granted Good a no-collateral, $900,000 line of credit. The testimony came Tuesday during the hearing on whether to bar Bush from the financial industry for his actions as a Silverado director. The federal Office of Thrift Supervision has alleged that Bush, as a Silverado director, improperly voted on loans and credit for Good and Bill Walters, both of whom contributed to Bush's oil and gas exploration company. The two businessmen defaulted on more than $132 million in loans from the thrift. Silverado collapsed in late 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. Today, attorneys were to re-examine defense witness Geoffrey C. Hazard Jr., a Yale law professor who says Bush acted legally when dealing with Good and Walters. President Bush's 35-year-old son did not attend the opening session. He is scheduled as the final witness at the hearing, expected to end Thursday. Bush could have avoided a hearing by agreeing not to dispute the charges, as other S&L officials have done. By fighting the government, he has taken the case into a rare public forum. As the hearing opened, Silverado's former chief executive officer, Wise, invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. Davidson let Wise testify in the judge's chambers to be ``spared the ordeal of going through a futile gesture of taking the Fifth.'' But in the chambers, Wise still took the Fifth 14 times. He gave only his name and Wichita, Kan., address, according to a transcript later released. He wouldn't comment as he left the courthouse. Another witness, Russell Murray, a former Silverado executive vice president who reviewed the 1986 proposal for a $900,000 line of credit for Good International Inc., testified he did not recall anyone questioning it even though Good and Bush had a business relationship. He said he discussed the request with Bush, Good and Wise, and then wrote a memo to the thrift's directors about the relationship before they approved the line of credit. But he said he did not have all the details of the relationship and that he would have asked for a legal opinion if he had had all the facts. Last week, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. sued Bush and other former Silverado directors for $200 million. The lawsuit, which also named Wise and Barth, alleged gross negligence on the part of Silverado directors contributed to the S&L's collapse.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Leaders Say Bush Willing to Compromise on Capital Gains
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 5-6, Bush, at ... to UPDATE with Bush quotes from Ohio speech; picks up 5th graf pvs, Without an...; trims at bottom to tighten. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may be willing to compromise on his call for a capital gains tax cut, the main sticking point in talks to slash the federal deficit, Republican members of Congress who met with the president said today. Instead of reducing the rate on capital gains taxes, Bush might accept other incentives to economic growth, the lawmakers said. ``He might be willing to look at alternatives in the growth area,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., as he and other GOP lawmakers left the White House. But Bush and GOP lawmakers warned that without Democratic concessions at ongoing budget talks, no deal would be reached in time to avoid $85 billion in federal spending cuts that the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will impose on Monday. Bush, at a political fund-raiser today in Akron, Ohio, criticized congressional Democrats, saying ``it's their fault for holding up getting a budget agreement.'' ``We will continue to press hard for incentives for capital investment,'' Bush said. However, he did not further discuss his longstanding insistence on a capital gains tax reduction as part of any budget agreement. Without an agreement by Monday, the start of the new budget year, the government faces the possibility of mass disruptions of services and furloughs of many of the two million federal civilian employees. ``It can be avoided if they do what they should,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One en route to Ohio. ``It's the Congress. I would now say the Democrats in Congress have not come forward with a package.'' ``There are a couple of points now where the Democrats need to move,'' said Dole. He said he was referring to economic incentives. Dole and House Republican Leader Robert Michel already have said they would be willing to put aside Bush's proposal to cut the capital gains tax rate in order to get a budget agreement. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the No. 2 House Republican, said the incentives Bush might be willing to accept include tax breaks for businesses to encourage research and investment, and a proposal to establish so-called enterprise zones. The zones would provide tax breaks for businesses in poor urban and rural areas. ``While he's going to be very flexible and he's willing to look at a Democratic offer, he wants part of this final agreement to be a growth package,'' Gingrich said. ``He's willing to negotiate every item that's been advanced,'' said Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., when asked if Bush was now ready to bargain on the question of capital gains. Both Michel and Dole said they would be willing to put the capital gains cut in order to get an agreement to slash the budget deficit over five years by $500 billion. Asked by reporters about the GOP defections, Bush refused to answer. Earlier, negotiators for Congress and the White House claimed some progress early today in their talks. ``I think we made some headway,'' Dole told reporters after the eight-hour, closed-door session. Asked for details, he refused, saying, ``I don't want to blow the whole thing up.'' ``It's still going to be tough'' to get an agreement enacted into law before the Oct. 1 start of the new budget year, said Richard G. Darman, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget. Asked whether the Bush administration was ready to drop its demand for a cut in taxes on capital gains, Darman scoffed, ``Don't be ridiculous.'' Just before the bargaining resumed Tuesday evening, Michel signaled a willingness to drop the capital-gains cut, which has been a top priority of President Bush since his 1988 campaign. For his money, Michel said, ``the doggone price (of a capital-gains cut) is too steep.'' Democratic leaders, who have been resisting a capital-gains cut because 80 percent of the direct benefit would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year, have insisted they will go along only if taxes on the wealthy are raised in some other fashion to pay for the cut. Capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments, now are taxed at the same rates as ordinary income. Bush says they should be given a lower rate to encourage investment. Michel's Senate counterpart, Dole, earlier had expressed his own misgivings about sticking to the capital-gains demand so long that it threatened a deficit agreement. The reduction is still a sound idea, he said, ``but you just can't keep everything on hold'' in an attempt to win it. The government's financial woes are complicated by the fact only five days before the new year, none of the 13 annual appropriations bills has been enacted. The Democratic-controlled House Appropriations approved a bill Tuesday aimed at giving negotiators 20 days past the Oct. 1 deadline to write a deficit-cutting plan. The ``continuing resolution'' approved by the panel, with all but one Republican dissenting, would continue spending, generally at current levels, until Oct. 20 and block any of the scheduled across-the-board spending cuts until after that date. Bush repeated his vow to veto any legislation that delayed the spending cuts without a long-term deficit-cutting agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Flamboyant Australian Financier Resigns from Company He Founded
LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Financier Alan Bond resigned Wednesday as chairman and director of Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., the brewing company he founded that's fallen victim to financial problems. The resignation was expected. Bond had said in July he would step down to appease the company's creditors, who are owed an estimated $6 billion. Bond Corp. said in a statement that two other directors, Tony Oates and Peter Mitchell, had also resigned, while director Peter Lucas will become the new chairman. Bond, Oates and Mitchell will act as consultants until the company's proposed brewery sale and capital restructuring is completed. A spokesman said the three would play no further role in the company ``in the direct management sense'' after the restructuring and sale are finished. Bond still retains a controlling interest in Bond Corp. through his private company, Dallhold Investments. Bond Corp., which reported a loss of 979 million Australian dollars, or $815 million, for the 1988-89 financial year, has had to sell assets to reduce its crippling debt levels. The resignation ends a long fall for the brash, flamboyant Bond, who rose rapidly from humble roots by investing in land around Perth and taking advantage of rapidly rising property values. He emigrated to Perth from Britain with his father, quit school at age 14 and took a job with a sign-painting company. When things didn't work out, he and his father started a competitor, Nu-Signs, that provided the cash for some of his later deals. With a flair for picking the best real estate development sites and promoting them, he was successful enough to make his first million by 1969 at age 29. He took advantage of eager bankers peddling expensive credit, particularly after Australia's financial deregulation in 1983, and a stock market full of hungry investors. At its peak, Bond Corp. Holdings had interests in brewing, media, natural resources and property. Its best known U.S. business is G. Heileman Brewing Co., a La Crosse, Wis.-based company he bought in 1987 for $1.3 billion. Bond rode out the 1987 stock market crash on the cash-generating strength of his beer businesses. But the man who built a fortune by making the most of borrowed funds has been plagued by heavy debts, rising interest rates and bad business decisions. The combination alienated his bankers and creditors, put his Australian brewing interests into receivership and forced him to sell assets ranging from a Hong Kong development office to a coal mine. Unlike business rival Robert Holmes a Court, who died recently from a heart attack, Bond maintained a high public profile. He probably is best known for financing the Australian sailing team's stunning triumph over the United States in the 1983 America's Cup race. Only three years ago, he bought Vincent Van Gogh's ``Irises'' from Sotheby's for a record $53.9 million, a sale that the auction house helped him finance. In March, he sold the painting for an undisclosed amount amid reports he had taken a loss. Bond's resignation does come a bit earlier than expected. He had said he would resign once European and Britis bond holders had accepted a Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd. buyback offer. The offer has yet to be accepted.

DOC.HEAD: Symbolic Strikes Warn Government As Privatization Starts
DOC.TEXT: Vendors across the country went on brief symbolic strikes Wednesday to protest government plans to sell their shops in auctions. The expected sale will be the beginning of a comprehensive privatization process, the cornerstone of the ongoing economic reform aimed at transforming the state-owned system of command economy into a Western-style market mechanism. The heads of the federal government and the Czech and Slovak republics plan to meet Thursday with President Vaclav Havel in the Moravian city of Kromeriz, 180 miles east of Prague, to complete work on the wording of the privatization law. The law must then go to parliament for approval. In the first round of what the government dubbed ``small privatization,'' original owners may reclaim shops confiscated after the Communists seized power in 1948 and nationalized private property. Shops and small enterprises not claimed by former owners will then be offered either to their employees or auctioned off to the highest bidder. While an outsider will have to pay for the shop within seven days of the purchase, a current employee will be given five years to pay up to 50 percent of the price. This measure is designed to give vendors incentive to take over their shops and to compensate for the lack of cash available to buy enterprises outright. Vendors have protested the provision, demanding a clear first priority on shops to be sold off. ``If a guy comes to the auction and puts half a million crowns on the table, there is no way I can compete with him even if I have state credit. I can never handle a transaction worth that much money,'' said Vitezslav Klement, a vegetable vendor in Prague's working class district of Smichov. ``Shops to the vendors, not money-changers and Communist Mafia,'' read a sign across an antiques shop window Wednesday. Shops shut down for anything between five minutes to an hour in Wednesday's protest strike against the privatization laws. Large savings were exceptional in Czechoslovakia's centrally planned economy, where monthly wages averaged 3,200 crowns, or about $200. Those who thrived on the black market and other components of the ``shadow economy'' tolerated by Communists have saved millions, often in convertible currencies stashed in Western banks. Shop vendors claim the auctions would put an abrupt end to the already poor network of food and services, with the new owners likely to switch to the sale of electronics and other consumer goods that turn a fast profit. The government says the most important thing is to privatize the economy as quickly as possible. The government of the Czech republic wants ``small privatization'' completed by Dec. 31. ``It's not so important who gets the actual shop. What matters is the earliest possible occurrence of private ownership, without which a free society cannot exist,'' the Mlada Fronta daily, which is known for its support of the reforms of Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, said Wednesday. Privatization of large industrial plants and the agricultural sector is expected to start in early 1991 when the legislative framework giving access to foreign capital is ready and prices are decontrolled.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita Seeks Bigger Market with Bid for MCA, Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: A rich vault of movies and television tapes, and studios with which to make more, apparently lured Japanese electronics giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Cois talking with, but would not comment further. If it purchases MCA, Matsushita also would acquire studios where it could introduce its professional products, Petersik said. If the company makes the match, it will add to already enormous holdings. Since 1918, when 23-year-old Konosuke Matsushita left his employer to push the electrical switch he had invented, the Matsushita empire has mushroomed to include nearly 500 related firms operating in 36 countries. With its 163 consolidated subsidiaries, Matsushita Electric is Japan's third largest corporation and commands the largest share of Japan's home electronics market. Fortune Magazine ranked it last year as the world's 16th largest corporation. Huge cash holdings - more than $10 billion last year - are a big reason why the company can afford to consider the MCA purchase, Tsuzura and others said. The company's annual report forecasts total sales of more than $44 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Mirror Rivals End Fued, Join Hands
DOC.TEXT: Two Michigan automotive mirror rivals in a legal battle over alleged patent infringement have announced pla to manufacture its own version of the mirror. Donnelly countersued, alleging Gentex's patent was invalid. Under the new plan, Gentex will become a 50 percent shareholder of Donnelly's Irish subsidiary, DML Ltd., and Donnelly will receive new Gentex common stock equal to 12 percent of the outstanding shares. Donelly also received the right to buy up to 35 percent of Gentex's outstanding shares. A final agreement is still one or two months away, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Government Outlines Economic Program
DOC.TEXT: The center-right government coalition on Wednesday made public its plans to dismantle Hungary's command economy and replace it with one governed by market forces. A 222-page book, ``The Program of National Rebirth,'' outlined the government's economic priorities over the next three years. Approval of the program is virtually assured in the 386-seat Parliament, where the government holds a majority. Prime Minister Jozsef Antall's Hungarian Democratic Forum and its two junior coalition partners envisage a ``social market economy'' of a dominant private sector and a smaller state sector also run on the profit motive. Social welfare programrivileged also figure prominently in government plans. Privatization, deregulation and gradual moves to make the forint into a convertibls for the underpe currency are among the priorities of the economic program. State ownership, now at 80 percent, is to be reduced to under 50 percent in three years. A special fund is to make loans at preferential rates to entrepreneurs buying state businesses. Over the same period, the government plans to simplify procedures governing foreign investments and the export licensing system. The government also wants to halve import tariffs, now at 16 percent, bringing them ir. Comments or questions should be directed to Vivian Marino at 212-621-1687. Repeats can be obtained through the AP Service Desk at 212-621-1595.
DOC.BYLINE: MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET: Legndary Retailer Ready To Withstand Slump
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - The way skeptics tell it, the modern day R. H. Macy & Co. story wouldn't be fit for a feel-good Hollywood film. The retailer, they say, may need something like divine intervention, if not another miracle on 34th Street, to shoulder a heavy debt burden while losing support from retail revenue. Not so, say executives of the department store chain. They acknowledge that Christmas 1990 won't go down as one of the merrier holidays in history for the industry. But Macy's can survive a consumer spending slump and will prosper again, they say. Slug BC-Macy. By Business Writer Marybeth Nibley. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With LaserPhoto.
With BC-Macy-Thumbnail
DOC.BYLINE: THE PIT AND THE PENDULUM: Commodities Trader Fights Federal Charges
DOC.TEXT: CHICAGO - From the boxing ring to the football field to the fray of a commodities trading pit, Ray Pace never has been one to back down. But in the federal courtroom, where he and 13 other traders face charges of fraud and racketeering, Pace fights the feeling that he is already whipped. It's not because he has no hope of winning his case but because he says the cost of his defense has nearly wiped him out. Slug BC-Personal File-Pace. By Business Writer David Dishneau. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: BANKING BULLIES OR BUDDIES?: Foreign Bankers Find Bonanza On U.S. Shores
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - Foreign banks have been setting up shop on U.S. soil in droves, lending money to corporations, investing in government securities, buying loans from other financial institutions, even accepting deposits. In many cases, they've been competing head-on with American-owned banks. Now, as U.S. banks retrench abroad and struggle with a slumping real estate market at home, some critics charge foreign institutions are bullying their U.S. counterparts in a financial free-for-all and should be bound by new controls. Slug BC-Banking Invasion. By Jeff Donn. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With Graphic.
DOC.BYLINE: HAVE YOU ANY WOOL?: Farmer Sees Pot of Gold In Cashmere Goats
DOC.TEXT: LEBANON, Conn. - When Peter Sellew told his friends he planned to breed Australian cashmere goats, they thought he was crazy. No one in the state and only a handful of farmers on the East Coast had ever tried to raise cashmere goats. ``Now they call up and say, `How can we get some of those goats?' '' says the former publishing executive-turned farmer. In 18 months, Sellew has built his stock from five imported goats to a herd of nearly 100. This spring, he expects to sell their precious cashmere fleece for up to $45 a pound, compared to about 85 cents a pound for sheep's wool. Slug BC-Cashmere Goats. By Denise Lavoie. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 1. With LaserPhoto HF1 of Sept. 25.
DOC.BYLINE: BUMPER-TO-BUMPER BUSINESS: Upstart Company Offers Products For Commuters
DOC.TEXT: EMERYVILLE, Calif. - Mabel Yee was just another frustrated commuter, stuck in the middle of her stop-and-go crawl to work, when an idea hit her like an antsy driver following too close. ``I thought, `Gosh, there must be some option to just sitting here . . . There must be something to do,' '' she said. More than a year later, Yee has found lots for commuters to do through her company, Commuter Products Corp., which sells everything from massaging car seats to travel desks. Slug BC-Commuter Products. By Catalina Ortiz. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 1. With LaserPhoto FX2 of Sept. 25.
DOC.BYLINE: TANKED UP: Gulf Crisis Revives Brazil's Alcohol Fuel Progam
DOC.TEXT: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil - The Persian Gulf crisis has given new life to Brazil's program to run its vehicles on pure sugar-cane alcohol instead of gasoline. Shortages of the sugar-cane fuel, which has high production costs, and an abundance of inexpensive foreign oil had turned Brazilians off to alcohol. But as oil prices have risen beyond $34 a barrel as a result of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, critics are taking another look one of the world's leading alternative fuel programs, called Pro-Alcohol here. Slug PM-Brazil-Alternative Fuel. By Peter Muello. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct 1. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: MIDEAST TOURISM:
Saddam Hussein's Shadow Of Fear Hits Egypt Tourism Hard
DOC.TEXT: CAIRO, Egypt - As July ended, Egypt was celebrating a tourism boom with no end in sight. Almost 3 million visitors last year, and officials foresaw visions of at least 5 million by 1995. Egypt finally was returning as an international tourist mecca after years of Middle East uncertainty that had devastated an industry as old as the pyramids. Then, on Aug. 2, Iraq invaded Kuwait. Slug PM-Egypt-Tourism Blues. By Mimi Mann. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Thursday PMs, Sept. 27. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: . . .And Cripples Tourism To Holy Land
DOC.TEXT: JERUSALEM - Most days, Abdel Raouf Abu Assab sits at the door of his souvenir shop in Jerusalem's Old City, smoking his water pipe and waiting for tourists. These days he waits in vain. Although Israel is hundreds of miles from the Persian Gulf, the headlines created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait have scared away travelers from the Holy Land, government and industry officials say. Slug PM-Israel-Tourism. By Eileen Alt Powell. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Thursday PMs, Sept. 27. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended slightly higher Wednesday, as share prices lost earlier gains following a sharp drop on Wall Street. Although London remained firm for most of the day, traders had warned that a marked decline on Wall Street would trigger a similar reaction in London. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index ended up 0.8 point, or 0.04 percent, at 2,000.0. The Financial Times 30-share index closed up 6 points at 1,532.6, while the Financial Times 500-share index rose 1.99 point to 1,074.11. Volume was 410.3 million shares, compared to 412.4 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Meridian Bancorp Downsizing to Focus on Banking
DOC.TEXT: Meridian Bancorp Inc. plans to boost its loan-loss reserves by $75 million and shed its credit card and title insurance businesses amid signs of a weakening economy. The bank holding company said the moves would allow it to focus on and expand its core banking businesses. Meridian said it expects to announce next month a net loss of $35 million to $39 million for the quarter ending Sunday, or about 86 cents to 96 cents per share. During last year's third quarter, Meridian made $22.5 million, or 56 cents a share. Most of the loss would stem from the addition to loan-loss reserves and a charge of $15 million to $17.5 million related to the sale of the title operations, Meridian said. ``We expect to return to normal levels of profitability in the fourth quarter, to be profitable for all of 1990 and to continue the payment of dividends at current levels,'' said Samuel A. McCullough, chairman and chief executive officer. Meridian said it had re-evaluated its loan portfolios in response to the weakening economy in general and the real estate sector in particular. The reserve for possible loan losses will be increased to about $165 million, or about 2 percent of loans outstanding. Goldman, Sachs & Co. will arrange the sale of the title operations, which had losses of $7.3 million for the six months ending June 30. The company decided to sell its $300 million portfolio of credit card receivables because of high overhead, potential legislative restraints and the need for costly technology, McCullough said. Meridian also said it would convert $300 million of indirect automobile loan receivables to marketable securities to improve its capital ratios and reduce reliance on external funding.

DOC.HEAD: Report: BankAmerica to Acquire MeraBank
DOC.TEXT: BankAmerica Corp. outbid another California institution to buy MeraBank, a Phoenix-based thrift seized by the federal government, The Phoenix Gazette reported Wednesday. Spokesmen for BankAmerica and the Resolution Trust Corp. declined Wednesday to comment on the report that San Francisco-based BankAmerica outbid Security Pacific Bank of Los Angeles. But Kevin Shields, an RTC spokesman in Denver, said an announcement regarding MeraBank was expected Friday. The RTC is a federal agency created to dispose of thrifts taken over by the government. MeraBank was a subsidiary of Phoenix-based Pinnacle West Capital Corp. until it was declared insolvent and seized by the RTC on Jan. 31. It has an estimated $4.7 billion in deposits and 1,200 employees. BankAmerica, which on June 1 acquired Western Savings, would add 66 branches in Arizona with the acquisition. BankAmerica outbid Security Pacific for Western Savings and for Benjamin Franklin Savings in Portland, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Farmers Battle Police As Government Announces Aid Program
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet on Wednesday announced an emergency aid program intended to curtail the wave of demonstrations and truck hijackings by farmers protesting low-priced meat imports. The centerpiece of the program will be a $270 million (1.4 billion franc) fund to assist farmers in debt because of foreign competition or a prolonged drought in France. Special protection would be given farmers over the age of 55. Nallet said the government would seek to ensure they are not put out of business for non-payment of debts. Earlier in the day, riot police protecting Premier Michel Rocard hurled tear gas grenades at protesting farmers who pelted the officers with eggs, tomatoes and bottles. In the town of Valence, 500 sheep farmers protested outside a fairgrounds where Rocard was to address a communications forum. About 1,000 police officers blocked the protesters from entering. Officers used tear gas grenades after being pelted. Some farmers tried to drive tractors through the barriers, while others set fire to tires to block the entrance to a local government building. Rocard, who flew to the fairgrounds by helicopter, said in his speech that the protesters hurt their own cause by giving themselves a bad image and complicating efforts to aid their industry. In recent weeks, angry French farmers have staged dozens of demonstrations nationwide and hijacked numerous livestock trucks carrying imported animals. Hundreds of cows and sheep have been killed, in some cases burned alive, during the hijackings.

The stock market staged a broad decline today, erasing the gains of the previous session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 32.17 points at 2,453.47 an hour before the closing bell. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 4 to 1 with 1,110 issues declining, 357 advancing and 484 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 134.36 million shares as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Stock prices opened mixed before the drift lower gathered momentum. The market was pressured by higher prices in the energy pits, where the near-term crude contract climbed back above $38 per barrel. But Alan Ackerman, senior vice president at Gruntal Financial Inc., cautioned that what's burdening the stock market is more complex than just rising oil prices. ``We've had some relief in the upward pressure on energy prices, but we've had no relief in the . . . war talk.'' Further, traders continued to be concerned about the economy and the budget deficit. The lack of agreement on a budget-reduction plan coupled with a 0.8 percent decline in durable goods orders in August ``brings everything back into light that things are not that good,'' said James Schroeder, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. Money-center bank stocks were hard hit, and one trader noted that the market would be hard pressed to extend Tuesday's rally without an upturn in the banking sector. DOC.HEAD: With BC-Macy-Thumbnail, LaserPhoto
Can Legendary Retailer Withstand Slump?
DOC.TEXT: To those who think debt is a dirty word, the modern day R. H. Macy & Co. story wouldn't be fit for a feel-good Hollywood film. A number of outsiders believe the 132-year-old retailer's future is more precarious now - on the eve of an expectedly bleak Christmas shopping season - than at any time since it went private in 1986. Macy's, some skeptics say, might need something like divine intervention to shoulder its heavy debt burden while losing support from retail revenue. Not so, say Macy's executives. They acknowledge Christmas 1990 won't go down as one of the merrier holidays in history. But a consumer spending slump won't put Macy's on the ropes because the retailer is ready for it, they say. ``We would feel very positive other than the fact that it is a very soft economy out there,'' Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive officer, said in an interview at the retailer's headquarters atop the Manhattan flagship immortalized in the movie ``Miracle on 34th Street.'' ``It's hard to be euphoric when the economy is this lousy so I wouldn't describe my attitude as euphoric. But I have never felt better about our organization . . .,'' Finkelstein said. He was joined in the interview by the two other members of his management troika: Mark S. Handler, president and chief operating officer, and Myron E. Ullman, executive vice president and chief financial officer. Inventories are $400 million below last year's bloated level and the year-to-year expense increase has been shaved to 1 percent, Finkelstein said, noting the retailer has planned for sales to be flat or even a bit lower than last year's. Expenses rose 7{ percent in 1989 from 1988. Outsiders aren't as confident. Macy's has been begging for business by hyping merchandise at reduced prices. This suggests the company is desperate for sales to generate cash needed to cover payments on debts incurred in its $3.74 billion leveraged buyout and afterward, say analysts - who aren't privy to Macy's inside information. Just as the back-to-school season was starting, Macy's advertisements for special price breaks on children's clothing blared over the airwaves and leaped from newspapers. In September - typically a transitional time in retailing when stores gear up for the climax of their selling years - Macy's advertised a series of sales on bedding, women's clothing, accessories, fine jewelry, oriental rugs, etc. Merchandise also is marked down without fanfare. Macy's makes a habit of hosting unannounced sale events, possibly to encourage shoppers to stop by regularly to see what's on sale, according to Kurt Barnard, publisher of a New York-based retailing newsletter. Consultants contend Macy's obsession with sales has caused the retailer to crowd its promotional calendar. This compounds the problem of ``sale syndrome,'' an irksome phenomenon for retailers caused by customers who have grown so accustomed to markdowns that they almost never expect to pay full price anymore. Finkelstein disagreed and said the retailer has curbed its promotional activity - especially compared to last year when stores fell over each other marking down merchandise. The price war was started last year by Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied U.S. department store chains, which succumbed to bankruptcy court in January. Macy's has 10 percent fewer promotions this year than last and conducts fewer one-day sales, Finkelstein said. He blasted predictions that this Christmas Macy's must slash prices and push merchandise as aggressively as it did a year ago. ``There is absolutely no reason we have to trash ourselves in spite of what know-nothing, uninformed observers say,'' he fumed. Fiesty Finkelstein clearly has no patience with speculation that he thinks lacks facts. He said reports criticizing Macy's for everything from sloppy shopkeeping to tardy bill-paying practices are unfair. ``I'm convinced that most of the people who trash our stores either haven't been in them, don't shop them or don't know what the hell is going on,''he said. He is annoyed that more mention isn't made of positive developments. Business is going better in Texas and Florida than elsewhere in the country, for instance, while Macy's Bullock's Inc. chain has had strong business without the need for power-packed promoting, he said. Macy's gets high marks for keeping interested parties up to date. A few months ago, senior Macy's executives huddled with vendors and other creditors to provide evidence of its bill-paying ability. An executive with a women's apparel manufacturer, which supplies large volumes to Macy-owned department stores, confirmed the retailer pays promptly. The executive, speaking on condition of anomymity, said the trade lately has more faith in Macy's. ``All of us are feeling more comfortable than we were three or four months ago,'' he said. ``Everyone has always felt that the people who run Macy's were among the most outstanding retail executives in the country. The question was had they bitten off more than they could chew?'' Some of the concern in the trade and financial community subsided after Macy's made it clear it was trimming its annual interest bill of $595 million. At about 10 percent of sales, Macy's interest tab is one of the highest in the industry. Macy's long-term debt amounts to $4.8 billion. At peak times during the year, Macy's total debt load is about $5.6 billion, Ullman said. Macy's used some of the $15 million it obtained by selling a 1 percent equity stake in August to buy back a portion of the $1.6 billion of its outstanding junk bonds. Further bond buybacks are planned, taking the opportunity to cheaply retire debt that currently is selling at substantial discounts of around 50 cents on the dollar and lower. Finkelstein said Macy's will consider selling up to 20 percent of the company and use the proceeds to cut interest expenses. The odds are good that a stake of some size will be sold in the next three to six months, he said. But Macy's has no intention of parting with retail assets. It is exploring more possible sales of non-retail holdings, such as real estate, Finkelstein said. Doubting Thomases don't believe Macy's merchandising clout, strong market position and consumer identification will automatically spare it from misery if Christmas is as bad as doomsters foresee. Forecasts of operating profit, or income before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, have been scaled back for the six months ending Jan. 31. But estimates still are well above the dismal $416 million Macy's had in operating profit in the same period a year earlier and profit margins are expected to improve. Finkelstein doesn't delude himself about how tough his job will be in a prolonged economic slump. ``We may have to be running this business with tight economies, with tight expense control for as much as two years,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Macy
Retailer Has Endured World Wars, Great Depression and an LBO - So Far
DOC.TEXT: The retailer that evolved from a dry goods shop started by one-time Nantucket whaler Rowland Hussey Macy today boasts an urban department store that rakes in more annual sales than any other in the country. In addition to the Manhattan flagship, the chain famous for Thanksgiving Day parades operates a branch at the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J., which the company says outsells all competitors in suburbia. R. H. Macy & Co. employs 78,000 people at its 149 department stores in the United States. It runs 97 stores under the Macy's name, 22 Bullock's stores, 30 I. Magnin stores, plus about 90 smaller specialty Aeropostale, Charter Club and Fantasies by Morgan Taylor shops selling Macy's private label merchandise. It also operates about a dozen furniture clearance centers. Here is a summary of some major events in Macy's history: - Oct. 27, 1858, Rowland Hussey Macy, a seafaring Quaker who was unsuccessful as a merchant in three earlier ventures, opened a small dry goods store on Sixth Avenue in Manhatan. His first day's sales were recorded as $11.06. His store sold ribbons, laces, fake flowers, handkerchiefs, gloves and other miscellaneous items. - 1866, Macy's store embarked on an expansiondal begin. We also have photographers staking out all entrances to the courthouse for photos of key figures, but have no time estimates for photos.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Philip Morris Ranks as Biggest U.S. Ad Spender in 1989, Magazine Says
DOC.TEXT: Food and tobacco giant Philip Morris Cos. was the heaviest U.S. advertiser in 1989 for the third consecutive year, the trade publication Advertising Age reported Wednesday. Philip Morris, the New York-based manufacturer of Marlboro cigarettes, Miller beer, Maxwell House coffee and Kraft foods, spent $2.07 billion on advertising last year, up from $2.06 billion in 1988, the magazine reported. Procter & Gamble Co., the Cincinnati-based consumer products maker that was displaced in 1987 after a longstanding run atop the ad spending list, came in second once again at $1.79 billion, Ad Age said. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the retailer based in Chicago, moved up one spot on the list to third place at $1.43 billion while the auto giant General Motors Corp. of Detroit slipped one spot to fourth place at $1.35 billion. Fifth was Grand Metropolitan PLC, the British owner of Pillsbury Co. and Burger King Corp., at $823.3 million. Rounding out the Ad Age list of the top 10 U.S. advertisers and their spending totals were: Pepsico Inc., $786.1 million; McDonald's Corp., $774.4 million; Eastman Kodak Co., $718.8 million; RJR Nabisco, $703.5 million, and Kellogg Co., $611.6 million. Overall, the top 100 U.S. advertisers spent $33.9 billion in 1989, up 6.4 percent from $32.2 billion in 1988, Ad Age said.

DOC.HEAD: Crops Mixed on CBOT
DOC.TEXT: Wheat closed higher, corn was mixed and soybeans were lower Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rumors and rising fears of war in the Middle East. Wheat futures rose amid unconfirmed rumors that an Iraqi jet had been shot down in the Persian Gulf and rumors that the government might be interested in offering subsidized flour to the Soviet Union. Choppy trading throughout the day reflected a growing nervousness that the Middle East crisis could not be solved diplomatically, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division for Gerald Inc. ``I think everybody's very nervous,'' Frazier said. ``They're afraid something's going to happen and it'll run the markets up.'' mixed after large purchases of contracts by a grain dealer prompted speculation of impending export sales of the grain. Soybeans extended Tuesday's losses as traders expecte Corn closedd a bumper harvest and waited for the release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly grain stocks report after Thursday's trading close. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 2\ cents higher with contracts for delivery in December at $2.77 a bushel; corn was { cent lower to } cent higher with December at $2.28\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with December at $1.14\ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 1{ cents lower with November at 6.15} a busn Northern California, she said, she was primarily interested in nutrition. ``But you quickly find out that what you're really doing is supporting the small farmer, and in the long run helping maintain a regional food belt.'' In a study, Robert Sommer, director of the Center for Consumer Research at the University of California-Davis, found that people shop at farmers' markets for high-quality food, lower prices and atmosphere, in that order. ``In the old days people went to the dump; now they go to the farmers market. It's become a big social event,'' said August Schumacher, outgoing commissioner of Food and Agriculture in Massachusetts. ``Market shopping is really a form of entertainment. ... You don't go to an open-air farmers market because it's convenient,'' said Hilary Baum of Public Markets Collaborative. All year, every Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, dozens of growers do business in Manhattan at Union Square Park - once a haven for drug dealers - and provide more than ample atmosphere amid fragrant waist-high stalks of basil, chef demonstrations, tours and tastings. One recent day shoppers could choose white eggplant, cider, peaches, apples, okra, sour cherries, squash blossoms, raspberries, eggs, chickens, bursting sunflowers, and apple and blueberry pies. A woman at a fish stand hands out cards with a number to call a day ahead to find out what kinds of fish will be spread out on ice the next morning. The Blews, who farm in Pittstown, N.J., offered 13 kinds of peppers. New York City's markets range from the sprawling Union Square market - where, Benepe said, growers can make up to $10,000 a day - to one on the Lower East Side, six farmers once a week. Farmers pay less than 5 percent of gross for their stalls, he said. Growers first came to Greenmarket ``with great skepticism,'' Benepe said. ``They feared they'd come with full loads and go home with empty pockets. Rip-off city.'' They found otherwise. Merrie Kernan gets up at 2:30 a.m. three days a week to drive a truckload of produce 125 miles from Bridgton, N.J. She likes talking with New Yorkers, even those who ask when banana season starts, or will she have oranges or artichokes soon. Then there are the kids she brings lightning bugs for. And the customer who just bought a small farm and told Kernan she was going to pay someone to cut the hay. ``I told her - you don't pay somebody. They pay you.'' ``Running a farm is very grueling and very demanding. There are times you feel discouraged,'' Ryan said. ``And the thing that really makes it worth it, honestly, it's such a shot in the arm to get in that truck and go to market on Saturday and know that it's all worthwhile.'' And for consumers, studies show prices are 5 percent to 30 percent lower at farmers markets, where there are no ``middlemen'' and low transportation costs. There is more than good shopping at work, however. Without the markets, many family farms - too small to comply with demands for volume and uniformity of whole distributors - would be forced to sell out. A Greenmarket survey found that 70 percent of its farmers said the market was either essential or important to their economic well-being, Benepe said. In Connecticut, the non-profit Hartford Food System found that farmers could not afford to run full-scale markets in the poorest neighborhoods. So it linked up with neighborhood organizations, bought food from farmers and opened farmstands, said Mark Winne, the organization's executive director. Connecticut also is one of 10 states in the federal Farmers Market Coupon program. Last year an estimated 275,000 poor women and children were issued coupons worth $2.5 million. Many farmers also accept food stamps. In Massachusetts, government made a difference, Schumacher said. ``The mayors of many cities wanted to link consumers to local growers. They gave us wonderful spots, many in front of city halls - Boston, Brockton, Springfield.'' The markets, in turn, can help a city. A twice-weekly market saved downtown Pasco, Wash., said Linda Sue Williams of the Pasco Downtown Development Association. Seventy farmers drive to a lot where the city has in the last five years built 48 shelters for growers and their food. Three thousand to 5,000 people shop there a week, she said. ``It's been credited by many many people with saving the downtown,'' Williams said. ``It's the best thing that's happened to Pasco in a long, long time.'' But a Saturday market in Columbus, Ohio, across from a convention center under construction, may be threatened by related commercial development. ``There is support, but our future is still a little unknown,'' said Nancy Duncan Porter, executive director of the North Market Development Authority, which formed to save the market from becoming a parking lot just three years ago. ``Some people just like to tear down and build more than they like to preserve,'' she said. ``The market is a very `people' activity and social in nature, and we think a great drawing card for downtown.''

DOC.HEAD: Casino Panel Rejects Trump Bondholder Bid for Role in Finances Hearing
DOC.TEXT: State casino regulators on Wednesday refused to let bondholders in the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort participate in a hearing to determine the developer's financial stability. The Casino Control Commission voted 3-2 against allowing bondholders from arguing orally at the Oct. 30 hearing. However, commissioners said the bondholders could petition to participate later when the agenda for the hearing becomes more certain. The hearing will examine the financial stability of Trump's three casinos and his ability to make a $47.3 million payment due Nov. 15 to Taj Mahal bondholders. Negotiations on the payments are continuing, so the scope of the hearing could change. The bondholders control $244 million, or 36.3 percent of the $675 million in notes used to finance the casino. The commission ordered the hearing in August when it approved a $65 million bank bailout to help Trump make an overdue June 15 bond payment on the Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay. A state Division of Gaming Enforcement report cast doubt on Trump's ability to make the Taj Mahal payment in November and on his overall finances, which are weighed down with $3.2 billion in debt. Martin Greenberg, the attorney for the petitioning bondholders, told the commission the bondholders should be allowed to argue orally and in writing during the hearing. ``It is safe to say there is concern with the apparent inability to make that payment,'' Greenberg told the commission. ``We do not seek to delay. We do not seek to make more difficult your function. ... We do not seek to use this forum as a means of negotiating with the Taj Mahal.'' But acting commission Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said the request was premature because the scope of the hearing has yet to be determined. She also said she wanted to avoid setting a precedent that would allow groups to use the commission as a forum, although she stressed the bondholders are not in that category. Letting anybody participate in hearings would be tantamount to ``birds flocking to an open landfill,'' Ms. Armstrong said.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Expects $19 Per Barrel Oil Average in 1991
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela projected its oil sales at $19 per barrel for 1991, and expects to export an average of 1.9 million barrels per day, newspaper reports said Wednesday. Quoting Marcos Morales, the planning ministry's director of short-term planning, the daily Economia Hoy said average crude sales for 1990 were now projected at 1.85 million barrels per day, up from the originally forcast 1.75 barrels. Venezuela also hiked its expectations for 1990 economic growth, from 2 percent to 2.5 percent, the report said. Venezuela's GNP shrank by more than 8 percent in 1989 following the government's start of a drastic economic austerity program.

The stock market declined today, nearly erasing the gains of the previous session as anxiety over the Middle East prevailed. Prices opened mixed before the drift lower gathered momentum. Analysts said the market appeared to stabilize only because sellers moved to the sidelines, not because buyers had surfaced to put a floor under prices. Stocks managed to inch up from their worst levels only in the last hour of trading. In the energy pits, the near-term crude contract climbed back above $38 per barrel. But Alan Ackerman, senior vice president at Gruntal Financial Inc., cautioned that what's burdening the stock market is more complex than just rising oil prices. ``We've had some relief in the upward pressure on energy prices, but we've had no relief in the . . . war talk.'' Indeed, many analysts said the possibility of a military conflict with Iraq has paralyzed the market, inhibiting traders from holding stocks even overnight for fear war might break out and they would be left vulnerable. Further, concerned about the economy and the budget deficit add an element of confusion to the market. The lack of agreement on a budget-reduction plan, coupled with today's announcement that durable goods orders fell 0.8 percent in August, ``brings everything back into light that things are not that good,'' said James Schroeder, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago.
