DOC.HEAD: Italian Authorities Seize Facilities Of Cetus Supplier
DOC.TEXT: Cetus Corp. said it will seek other sources of the anti-cancer drug doxorubicin after Italian authorities seized the production facilities and inventory of a supplier. But the biotechnology company, already smarting from federal refusal to approve one of its own cancer-fighting drugs, said Tuesday's seizure of SICOR could be harmful. ``Unless SICOR is able to overturn this decision ... it could have a significant effect on our generics business,'' said Cetus spokeswoman Katharine Russell. Doxorubicin is considered the most important product that Cetus has sold through a joint venture with Ben Venue Laboratories of Bedford, Ohio. The venture generated $33 million in sales for the fiscal year that ended June 30. The seizure followed an investigation by the public prosecutor in Milan into allegations of conspiracy and theft of trade secrets by SICOR. SICOR also has been accused of stealing the strain that produces doxorubicin from Farmitalia Carlo Erba, S.R.L., an affiliate of Erbamont NV of Stamford, Conn. Erbamont sells doxorubicin in the United States under the trademark Adriamycin. The Cetus-Ben Venue joint venture began selling doxorubicin last year after the original patent for Adriamcin expired. Farmitalia had developed the drug in the early 1970s. In July, the Food and Drug Administration refused to approve Interleukin-2, Cetus' anti-cancer drug. The company also has been troubled by layoffs and a loss of $61.5 million for the past fiscal year.

DOC.SECOND: Federal Budget Impasse Has Meat Packers Fretting
DOC.TEXT: Monfort Inc., one of the nation's largest meat packers, has stopped buying cattle for slaughter because of a possible furlough of federal meat inspectors. Other southwest Kansas packers say they are concerned that failure by Congress to approve a budget by Sunday - the deadline under the severe Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction measure - might force furloughs of federal government employees, including meat inspectors. The Food Safety and Inspection Service and the U.S. Department of Agriculture would have to lay off 7,500 meat inspectors from Oct. 9 through 13. In effect, that would shut down all meat and poultry slaughter and processing plants regulated by the agencies, said Jim Greene, a spokesman for the inspection service in Washington. ``Obviously, if you don't have federal inspectors, you can't operate your plant,'' said Gene Meakins, vice president of public relations for Monfort. That could cause ripples throughout the industry, such as a backlog of cattle at feed yards and higher consumer prices, company officials say. Harry Siegelman, group vice president of cattle procurement for Monfort, said Wednesday the company won't buy cattle for the week of Oct. 8. ``We are planning on not killing that week, the way it stands right now with inspection,'' he said. Monfort, based in Greeley, Colo., has a Garden City plant that employs 1,270 people. Dave Bartel, a spokesman for Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., said earlier this week that if a budget agreement isn't reached, Kassebaum has promised a continuing resolution to keep the present arrangement with meat inspectors until there is an agreement. Officials at IBP, which owns a 2,700-employee plant near Garden City, said they were working through the American Meat Institute in Arlington, Va., to ensure a furlough doesn't happen. ``We're not aware of any slowdowns at this point,'' said Gary Mickelson, manager of communications. He said it wasn't the first time the industry has faced the possibility of a budget-related furlough of inspectors, but they were always averted before. ``We're hopeful this will be the case this time,'' Mickelson said. Rich Parker, director of information for the American Meat Institute in Arlington, Va., said members of Congress have been told that furloughs could hurt the industry. ``There's a possibility you could see a shutdown but we don't think it will happen,'' he said. Five giant packing plants in southwest Kansas, including Monfort and IBP, employ more than 8,200 people. The state ranked first in the nation in 1989 for the number of cattle slaughtered, at 6.2 million head killed.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Fraud Lawyer Seeks Merc Leader's Records
DOC.TEXT: A federal subpoena seeking the trading records of Chicago Mercantile Exchange leader Leo Melamed and other officials is ``a publicity stunt,'' the exchange said Wednesday. The records were requested by Thomas A. Durkin, a defense lawyer in a commodities fraud trial who contends that everyone at the Merc ``from the top on down'' routinely ignored trading rules. Melamed is chairman of the exchange's executive committee and its best-known official. He has not been charged in the case. Durkin sent a subpoena last week to Melamed's trading firm, Dellsher Investment Co. He sent another to the Merc seeking more general trading records of exchange officials, including the board of governors. ``The defense attorney's subpoenas served on officers of the exchange can be characterized in the nature of a publicity stunt,'' Merc spokesman Andrew Yemma said. ``The U.S. attorney's office has repeatedly stated that neither the exchange nor its officers nor its member firms are in any way targets of the investigation.'' Yemma said Melamed was unavailable for comment. Durkin is defending Sam Cali, one of 14 Japanese yen futures traders currently standing trial on federal charges including mail fraud and racketeering. The charges stem from a federal probe of corruption at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two largest commodities exchanges. Cali and the other defendants are accused of systematically cheating customers, partly to avoid responsibility for mismatched buy and sell orders known as out-trades. The subpoena served on Dellsher requests documents relating to ``all out-trades, price adjustments, errors or customer complaints'' on yen futures contracts traded directly or indirectly by Melamed. It also asks for copies of any checks, journals or ledgers ``reflecting the receipt of checks from floor brokers'' to settle trading discrencies. Durkin said in his opening statement that all traders routinely violated exchange rules to settle out-trades, but that such violations did not constitute fraud or racketeering. He said exchange officials were aware of such violations, although the exchange has denied it.

DOC.HEAD: Two Michigan Newspapers Bans Tobacco Ads
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of two Michigan newspapers has joined the ranks of those banning national tobacco advertisements, a move a tobacco industry official predicted ``may come back to haunt them.'' Greenville News Inc., which owns The Daily News and The Carson City Gazette, a weekly, as well as shopping guides, announced its decision in an editorial last week in The Daily News. ``Turning away easy dollars provided by agency-generated tobacco advertising will be tough,'' wrote John Stafford, publisher of the six-day-a-week, 8,500-circulation newspaper. ``But it's necessary and responsible.'' Thirteen other newspapers nationwide do not accept tobacco advertising, but these are the first in Michigan, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. A spokesman for The Tobacco Institute, which is funded by the tobacco industry, said the publisher had made itself vulnerable to special interest groups offended by particular ads. ``It is hard for a newspaper to talk about free speech and to rattle off bad restrictions for a common consumer product,'' said Thomas Lauria, assistant to the president of the Washington, D.C.-based group. ``They are starting down a road that can lead to serious financial consequences and their self-imposed censorship of giving information to smokers may come back to haunt them,'' he added. Larry Carbonelli, the newspaper's general manager, said the decision was made after an anti-drug coloring book was inserted in the Sept. 13 edition. ``It finally settled with us that it's kind of hypocritical on our part telling kids not to use drugs and at the same time carrying tobacco ads,'' he said. He said the ban is aimed at ads placed by industry agencies and would not affect coupons advertising discounts on cigarettes by local stores. Tobacco ads account for about half of newspapers' national advertising, or roughly 3 percent of total advertising revenues, according to advertising director John Dallos. He said the paper would find some way to make up the lost revenue without increasing its rates.

DOC.HEAD: California Firm to Market Bankrupt Casino
DOC.TEXT: A California real estate marketing company has been retained to sell the bankrupt Aladdin Hotel and Casino after months of behind-the-scenes efforts failed to find a buyer. Representatives of Santa Monica-based Kennedy-Wilson Inc. said they would advertise the property in the United States and abroad, and would accept sealed bids until Nov. 15. Officials hope the responses will produce someone who can qualify financially and be able to obtain a gaming license. The responses will be evaluated by the bankruptcy trustee in hopes of locating a buyer, although bids could be rejected, officials said. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Linda Riegle will have the final say on who buys the Strip property. The troubled resort has been under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since last October. It was placed in bankruptcy by the late Ginji Yasuda, who bought the property out of bankruptcy in 1986 for $54 million, then spent another $35 million refurbishing it. Yasuda died of cancer in December. An attorney representing the bankruptcy trustee said efforts had been made to assist parties showing an interest in the hotel, but it was finally decided to hire a professional firm to market the resort.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in U.S., Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed against major currencies in a thin and choppy U.S. session Wednesday during which traders refrained from staking out new positions ahead of the month's end. The approaching close to the first half of Japan's fiscal year, coinciding with the end of the calendar year quarter on Sept. 30, kept Japanese and U.S. banks from participating heavily in foreign exchange markets. Dealers said institutional currency investors were busy catching up on seasonal paperwork. ``It was a rather lackluster day in terms of liquidity,'' said Scott Horwitz, a trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York. The dollar closed in New York near its lowest levels of the session against the German mark, at 1.5660, down from 1.5735 late Tuesday. Renewed speculation about a possible interest rate hike in Germany after the east and west unite on Oct. 3 boosted the mark. High oil prices continued to weigh down the Japanese yen. Worries about how Japan's oil-dependent economy will cope with the price spiral caused a major selloff on the Tokyo stock exchange overnight and eroded confidence in the yen. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 137.40 Japanese yen from 136.70 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 137.20 yen. The dollar traded at 136.855 late in New York, higher than late Tuesday's 136.70 yen. Fresh U.S. economic news went virtually ignored. The two Commerce Department reports confirmed the economy lacks vigor. The report on durable goods showed orders to U.S. factories for long-lasting, generally expensive items dropped 0.8 percent in August. Separately, the department reported U.S. personal incomes rose 0.3 percent in August, the slowest pace in four months, while consumer spending rose 0.5 percent, the lowest in three months. European currency dealers, meanwhile, said the dollar gained there on news that the U.N. Security Council had adopted a resolution to tighten its economic embargo against Iraq by halting air traffic into that country. An international force has been massing in the Persian Gulf area since Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2, and the U.N. Security Council has adopted a series of resolutions imposing economic sanctions on Iraq. The dollar is usually seen as a safe investment haven in times of international tension. The British pound fell to $1.8635 in London from $1.8765 there late Tuesday. A pound fetched $1.8718 late in New York, compared to $1.8785 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Tuesday, included: 1.3025 Swiss francs, down from 1.3080; 5.2410 French francs, down from 5.2665; 1.15635 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15055; and 1,172.00 Italian lire, down from 1,177.00. Selected dollar rates late in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's levels, were: 1.5715 German marks, up from 1.5630; 1.3110 Swiss francs, up from 1.2990; 5.2615 French francs, up from 5.2340; 1.7725 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7618; 1,176.00 Italian lire, up from 1,168.25; and 1.1535 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1493. Bullion dealers said continued uncertainty in the Mideast meant gold would continue its general upward trend, despite declines on some markets Wednesday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold settled at $406.60 a troy ounce for the September contract, up $4.20 from Tuesday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $406.70, $5.45 higher than Tuesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $404.85 a troy ounce from $403.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal fell to a closing bid of $402.50 from $404.25 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.28 to close at a bid of $400.17. Silver prices moved lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery fell to $4.798 a troy ounce from Tuesday's settlement of $4.834. In London, silver dropped to a late bid of $4.81 a troy ounce from $4.87 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Norden Systems To Shut A New York Plant
DOC.TEXT: Norden Systems Inc. announced plans Wednesday to close one of its two New York plants and consolidate its radar manufacturing at its Norwalk facility. The defense contractor said the move would result in an undetermined number of layoffs. Norden's Farmingdale, N.Y., plant will close, while radar operations at its other Long Island plant in Melville will be shifted to Norwalk, the company said. The manufacturing of non-radar systems will be consolidated at Melville. ``Long Island operations will be consolidated into a single facility in Melville,'' Daniel R. Nuzzo, Norden's president, wrote Tuesday in a letter to employees. Norden, a subsidiary of Hartford-based United Technologies Corp., has already laid off 275 employees this year and cut 62 jobs through attrition and retirement. The company's two New York plants employ about 770 people. Norden was dropped last year as a subcontractor to develop the radar system for the U.S. Navy's A-12 fighter jet, resulting in 600 layoffs.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Decline
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices declined in light dealings Wednesday as investors gave up hope that the market could stage back-to-back rallies. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which gained 32 points on Tuesday, fell 25.99 to close at 2,459.65. Declining issues outpaced advancers by a margin of about 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,119 down, 421 up and 454 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 155.57 million shares, against 155.94 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 187.44 million shares. Stock prices opened mixed but quickly turned lower. ``The market is without perspective . . . there's no focal point,'' said Eugene Peroni, an analyst with Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. ``Earnings estimates are in flux, analysts are scrambling to downwardly revise their outlooks, current dividends are in question and there's not a lot of confidence they will be maintained,'' Peroni said of the factors that have eroded confidence in equities. Indeed, portfolio managers, who are ``frustrated and tired of waiting for a technical rally that hasn't arrived,'' are selling blue-chip stocks, which puts pressure on the rest of the market, said Ralph Acampora, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Higher oil prices also worked to depress the stock market. The near-term crude contract rose above $39 a barrel before backing off at the close. Continued uncertainty in the Middle East is inhibiting traders from taking even short-term positions for fear war could break out overnight. One analyst called Iraq a ``wild card'' that is preventing the market from responding to fundamental factors, like interest rates and general economic data. One of the session's few bright spots was MCA, which is rumored to be near a buyout agreement with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. at a price that could go as high as $7.5 billion. A burst of trading in MCA helped lift the Dow from its worst levels in the final hour of trading. MCA jumped 7\ to close at 61\ and was the second most active issue on the Big Board. Some analysts are hoping MCA will rekindle interest in potential takeover targets. Elsewhere, however, the banking sector was hard hit. Citicorp, which confirmed it was laying off 100 employees in its leveraged buyout department, fell 1 to 14{; Chase Manhattan was off ~ at 11[; Manufacturers Hanover was off 1[ at 21\, and Chemical Bank was down } at 15. Among other actively traded issues on the Big Board, AT&T fell ] to 31{; IBM was down 1 at 105]; General Electric slipped | to 55; Waste Management fell 1[ to 32], and Eastman Kodak lost 1 to 39[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $28.95 billion, or 0.99 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.68 to 167.52. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.74 to 359.99, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 3.20 to 305.06. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 4.75 to 350.03. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 310.06, down 3.11.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Consumer Confidence Remains at Low Level, Survey Finds
DOC.TEXT: The level of consumer confidence in the United States was unchanged in August, but that left public sentiment on the economy at its lowest point since the 1982 recession, the Conference Board said Wednesday. The business research organization said its Consumer Confidence Index remained at 84.7 in September. The index plunged 17 points to that level in August following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Fabian Linden, a Conference Board economist, said consumers remained uncertain as there was little progress in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``People are increasingly concerned that inflation and interest rates will be rising,'' Linden added. Oil prices have surged since the Middle East tensions erupted. This has heightened consumer concerns about inflation and the economy, and many have curtailed their plans to buy houses or cars in the last two months, the Conference Board said. A drop in consumer spending is itself a threat to the economy because consumer pending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product. The Conference Board is a business-funded organization. Its monthly survey on consumer confidence is conducted by National Family Opinion Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, and questions 5,000 households throughout the country.

DOC.HEAD: Newsweek, Times Mirror Magazines Team Up to Offer Joint Ad Deals
DOC.TEXT: Newsweek and Times Mirror Magazines are teaming up to offer advertisers package deals involving combinations of their magazines and affiliated newspapers, television stations and cable TV systems. The sponsors said the program was a first for separately owned consumer magazine publishers. Companies that publish several magazine titles, such as Time Warner Inc. and Hearst Corp., have frequently sold packages involving space in combinations of their own magazines, newspapers or radio and TV stations. But Newsweek, which is owned by Washington Post Co., and the Times Mirror Inc. subsidiary said their program is the first marketing package involving consumer magazines to be offered by companies independent of each other. It is being called the Newsweek-Time Mirror Ad-Vantage program. Media analysts and the program's supporters say it should help Newsweek compete more effectively against the newsweeklies Time and U.S. News & World Report in the scramble for advertising revenue. Many advertising experts felt Newsweek was placed at a disadvantage when Time Magazine Co. launched an incentive plan more than a year ago involving its magazines, which includes Time, People, Sports Illustrated, Life and Fortune. The Ad-Vantage plan gives discounts to advertisers who meet certain minimum spending criteria in Newsweek and at least four of the 10 Times Mirror titles and agree to boost their spending in those magazines by 20 percent. The companies said the 11 magazines in the program have a combined circulation of 12.5 million, led by 3.1 million for Newsweek, and can reach some key audiences. For example, they said the magazines reach 28 million men, or 33 percent of the adult men in the United States. The Times Mirror titles in the program are Field & Stream, Golf Magazine, Home Mechanix, Outdoor Life, Popular Science, Salt Water Sportsman, Ski Magazine, Skiing, The Sporting News and Yachting. In addition to the discount plan, the companies plan to publish special supplements that will appear in combinations of the magazines. A supplement called ``Travels,'' for instance, will be published next spring in Golf, Ski, Yachting and the portion of Newsweek that goes to business executives. Another supplement called ``Your Home'' will be published in the fall of 1991 with the full run of Newsweek, Home Mechanix and Popular Science. The program will also enable advertisers to buy multimedia packages that could include combinations of magazines and newspapers owned by the parents of the magazines, such as The Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford (Conn.) Courant. The multimedia packages could also include commercial time on the parent companies' eight TV stations and their cable TV systems. The companies will also offer to create programs for magazine advertisers that can include event sponsorship, outdoor advertising and store displays. Peter Eldredge, publisher of Newsweek, said Newsweek hopes to attrac more advertising from companies that deal in sporting goods, insurance and home improvement that are heavy spenders in Times Mirror magazines. At the same time, he said Times Mirror may get more revenue from advertising categories represented heavily in Newsweek such as automotive, business equipment, airline and liquor. James Kopper, executive vice president at Times Mirror Magazines, said his company teamed up with Newsweek because of the quality of the magazine and the long corporate relationship between their parent companies. The Washington Post and Los Angeles Times, for instance, have operated a news service since 1963. He said in a telephone interview that he expects ``a considerable incremental benefit'' to result for both magazine operations as a result of the program. ``The entire marketing community has been screaming for multimedia buys. This is a strategic alliance that enables us to accomplish what the marketplace has been asking for,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Downgrades Chase Manhattan Rating
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. on Wednesday downgraded its credit rating of Chase Manhattan Corp., becoming the second major credit-rating agency to take the step in as many days. Chase, the nation's second largest bank, said Friday it would cut its dividend in half this quarter, reduce its payroll and increase its reserves for potentially troubled loans. Chase said the steps would result in a third-quarter loss. S&P said its action was prompted by Chase's expectation of a loss as well as the rating agency's belief that as the economy slows, the quality of real estate and other loans will deteriorate more quickly than originally anticipated. ``Operating earnings (at Chase) should continue to be restricted by poor loan quality,'' S&P said. S&P said it lowered by one notch its ratings of long-term debt, preferred stock and certificates of deposit issued by Chase and some of its subsidiaries. It affirmed its ratings of Chase commercial paper. The ratings agency said about $5.2 billion worth of debt and preferred stock is affected. In a statement, Chase said it disagreed with S&P's action, ``particularly in light of S&P's own comments citing Chase's strong base of retail banking profits, the enhanced profits expected from our aggressive restructuring efforts, as well as our liquidity and financial flexibility.'' On Tuesday, Moody's Investors Service, the other major credit-rating agency, lowered its evaluation of Chase debt by one notch on its scale.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Continues Rise Following Mideast Rumors, Inflation Worries
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices overcame early choppy trading Wednesday and settled sharply higher amid unconfirmed rumors of fighting in the Middle East and worries that an already sluggish economy is giving way to inflation. On other commodity markets, silver and platinum fell sharply; energy futures were mostly higher; wheat was higher; meat futures were lower; and corn was mixed. Gold settled $4.20 to $5.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September at $406.60 a troy ounce. The December contract jumped as high as $10.80 before settling lower. Demand for gold was triggered by an uncomfirmed rumor around midday that an Iraqi jet had been shot down in the Persian Gulf. Higher crude oil prices and investor worries of inflation also helped the market along, analysts said. ``With oil prices approaching $40 (a barrel) and inflation, that changes the picture for gold,'' said Peter Cardillo, director of commodities research at Jesup, Josephthal and Co. Inc. in New York. ``It puts gold at a higher level. We may see it trading at $435 to $440 (an ounce) in the coming days.'' On the New York Mercantile exchange, light sweet crude oil settled 3 cents lower to $1.14 higher with November at $38.67 a barrel; heating oil was .74 cent to 2.48 cents higher with October at $1.0257 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.95 cents lower to 1.45 cents higher with October at $1.001 a gallon. Analysts said platinum and silver extended losses from Tuesday on signs of weakening economic activity in the United States and a further decline in the Tokyo stock market. Platinum futures settled $4.10 to $3.80 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with October at $448 a troy ounce. Silver fell 4.2 cents to 3.6 cents on the Commodity Exchange with September at $4.798 a troy ounce. Agricultural commodities also were affected by the Middle East rumors. Wheat rose, corn settled mixed and soybeans were lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Choppy trading throughout the day reflected a growing nervousness that the Middle East crisis could not be solved diplomatically, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division for Gerald Inc. ``I think everybody's very nervous,'' Frazier said. ``They're afraid something's going to happen and it'll run the markets up.'' Rumors that the government might be interested in offering subsidized flour to the Soviet Union also contributed to wheat's gain. Corn was mixed after large purchases of futures contracts by a major grain dealer prompted speculation of impending export sales of corn, Frazier said. Soybeans extended Tuesday's losses as traders expected a bumper harvest and waited for the release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly grain stocks report after Thursday's trading closes. Wheat settled were { cent to 1} cents higher with December at $2.76{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cent lower to { cent higher with December at $2.28\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with December at $1.14\ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 2 cents lower with November at 6.15{ a bushel. Cattle futures fell for a third straight day amid speculation that demand for beef will slow if the economy weakens further and the possibility that U.S. packing plants will close in mid-October if there is failure to reach a federal budget agreement by Monday. Hog futures also fell as profit-takers continued to cash in on last week's gains. Live cattle were .45 cent to .08 cent lower with October at 78.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .62 cent lower to .15 cent higher with September at 89.17 cents a pound; hogs were .73 cent to .03 cent lower with October at 54.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent to .25 cent lower with February at 56.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Meets Again With Bankers on Shuttle Debt, But Keeps Mum
DOC.TEXT: Debt-stricken developer Donald J. Trump and bankers who loaned him $245 million to buy the Trump Shuttle met again ednesday to discuss Trump's problems making payments. Trump has already missed a $1.1 million interest payment on the shuttle. A top aide said last week following a meeting with Citibank officials that Trump wants to delay further interest payments. A Trump spokeswoman, Norma Foerderer, confirmed that a meeting between bankers and members of the Trump Organization took place Wednesday. She would not say who attended or what occurred. ``As I understand, it was a very good meeting and everyone understands what Saddam Hussein has done to the airline industry,'' she said. Trump has said his shuttle, like other airlines, is being hit hard by rising jet fuel prices due to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday that bankers would demand that Trump cut salaries and lay off workers in exchange for his continued control of the shuttle. Officials at the shuttle's headquarters did not return a message left by The Associated Press. A spokesman for Citibank, the lead lender, did not return a phone call Wednesday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Stock Slumping As Analysts Ponder Loss
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. stock fell Wednesday to a level unseen for years, amid growing concern about losses the automaker will report for the third quarter. ``It's getting back to a price that it hasn't been at since 1982,'' said auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. Chrysler stock closed at $10 a share Wednesday, down 12{ cents from Tuesday. It dipped below $10 briefly before struggling back on the New York Stock Exchange. The last time Chrysler stock closed at $10 a share was Nov. 12, 1982. Its highest price, after 3-for-2 splits in 1986 and 1987, was $45.25 in September 1987. Chrysler's stock has been moving steadily down throughout the year, but Phillippi and other analysts said Wednesday the company isn't facing nearly the same problems that it did in the late 1970s and early 1980s when it brushed with bankruptcy. Chrysler's stock hit its low point at $3.125 per share on Dec. 23, 1981, as it battled back toward profitability. ``We would make a huge distinction between '79 and wherever this bottoms out,'' said analyst Douglas Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York. ``The balance sheet liquidity, the product position and the competitiveness of the (auto) group is better overall.'' The current decline apparently is being driven by increasing estimates of Chrysler's third-quarter losses, which could exceed $200 million, analysts said. Through the first half of the year, Chrysler earned $251 million, down 64 percent from the same period last year. ``The whole market is off and when the market gets sick, people think Chrysler's sicker,'' said company spokesman Tom Houston. ``We haven't made any bones about we're not going to make any money in the third quarter.'' The analysts said the decline has nothing to do with concern directly related to current national contract negotiations with the United Auto Workers union or rising oil and gasoline prices stemming from the Mideast crisis. Chrysler has about $4 billion in cash and marketable securities on hand, a good amount for the company, they said. Chrysler's car and truck sales have been on the skids. The company reported Tuesday that sales of its North American-made cars and trucks, which make up nearly all of Chrysler's sales, were down 15 percent from last year. ``I think what you're looking at is a temporary gap in product that's affecting their selling raee,'' Laughlin said. Chrysler executives and analysts are awaiting the 1992 introduction of a new mid-size sedan code-named the ``LH.'' It will be the first all-new high-volume car designed by Chrysler in years. ``We've got enough (money) to get us to the time that we are going to have the `LH' on the street, at least then and beyond,'' Houston said.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: . . . Hills Hotel.
ON INSIDER TRADING
DOC.TEXT: During the period form 1984 through 1986, Drexel was at the center of Wall Street's takeover boom. Clients came to Drexel, for the most part, because of Drexel's unmatched ability to raise capital through the sale of high-yield securities. . . . there is substantial evidence that Milken caused Drexel to buy and sell securities based upon material, non-public information misappropriated from certain Drexel clients. In one of these instances, Milken traded on insider information for his own account.
DOC.HEAD: ON THE DEFENSE
DOC.TEXT: Milken's submission dramatically exposes the gulf between his crimes and his conviction, on the one hand, and his continuing agitprop on the other. Milken has been convicted of serious and sweeping crimes. His good works, however commendable, should not shield him from incarceration. He should be sentenced to a substantial term of imprisonment. . . . Milken is selling an old and threadbare story. By focusing the court's attention on the five specific crimes he had admitted - and by wholly ignoring his conviction on a broad conspiracy charge - Milken is attempting to minimize his criminal conduct. Were Milken to address the true range of his crimes, however, even he would have to acknowledge a different conclusion. Milken's crimes were serious and extensive.
DOC.HEAD: LIKE HELL'S ANGEL CASE
DOC.TEXT: Milken has been convicted of enormously serious crimes: conspiracy to violate the laws of the United States, securities fraud, mail fraud, wire fraud, tax fraud, and recordkeeping and reporting violations. . . . Although he has limited his allocution to five separate acts in furtherance of that conspiracy, this court can and should sentence Milken for all of his crimes. . . . In United States v. Kittel . . . Kittel, a member of the New York Chapter of the Hell's Angels Motorcycle Club, was charged with conspiracy to manufacture and distribute large quantities of methamphetamine and with 11 substantive counts relating to the unlawful distribution of methamphetamine. He was convicted on his plea of guilty to the conspiracy charge and to one of the distribution charges. In . . . Kittel's sentencing, however, the government alleged that Kittel had participated in the murder and dismemberment of another Hells Angels club member and the unlawful manufacture of an explosive device among other acts of violence. Judge (Pierre) Leval sentenced Kittel to a 14-year term of imprisonment stating that the sentence was based not only the particular offenses to which Kittel had pleaded guilty but on the government's evidence of Kittel's unadmitted crimes - persistent drug dealing and acts of violence.
DOC.HEAD: CONTRAST TO FREEMAN
DOC.TEXT: Moreover, although the government is asking the court to sentence Milken on crimes more numerous than he has specifically admitted, these additional charges are similar to the crimes that Milken has admitted: manipulating stocks, unlawfully influencing corporate events through the concealed ownership of securities, unlawfully providing benefits to clients and client representatives in order to cultivate their business, and fraudulently misappropriating funds from clients. . . . Indeed, Milken's agreement to pay $200 million in criminal penalities and $400 million in restitution dramatically belies both his contention that he committed only the five enumerated crimes and his argument that even these crimes were aberrational and technical violations. These fines, penalties, and restitution fix the scope of Milken's criminal conduct. Milken's agreement to pay these monies stands out as the most reliable measure of his criminal conduct. For all these reasons, this case is sharply different from United States v. Freeman . . . In Freeman (where the judge refused to admit a sentencing report on additional crimes), the defendant pleaded guilty to one narrow insider trading charge, not to multiple offenses and a broad conspiracy charge. Unlike Milken, Robert Freeman did not acknowledge the government's right to put before the court his ``unadmitted'' offenses. Unlike Milken, Freeman, in his allocution, did not admit that he committed crimes additional to the crimes to which he specifically pleaded guilty. Finally, Freeman did not agree to pay criminal fines and restitution penalties of $600 million.
DOC.HEAD: PUSH FOR PRISON TIME
DOC.TEXT: Milken should be sentenced to a substantial period of incarceration commensurate with his crimes. Those crimes were pervasive and systemic. They were committed for venal reasons - to enhance Milken's personal power and increase his wealth. No good works undertaken by Milken mitigate the imperative of a substantial prison term. Milken's proposal that he be sentenced to a probationary term and community service is absurd. Such a sentence would eviscerate law enforcement's efforts to police and deter financial crime. . . . Milken's crimes have had nationwide impact and his sentence will become the touchstone for every sentence for financial crime in the country. . . . other sentences demonstrate a consensus among judges that absent significant actual cooperation, a major securities law violator such as Milken will receive a substantial term of incarceration. Boesky's three-year term of incarceration provides a useful point of departure. As an initial, symbolic matter, Milken stands convicted of six times as many felony charges as Boesky and has agreed to pay six times Boesky's criminal fine and civil penalty. While the government does not suggest that simple arithmetic should determine Milken's sentence, Milken's suggestion that - facing almost six times Boesky's penalty - he merits a fraction of his punishment is preposterous.
DOC.HEAD: MILKEN'S COOPERATION
DOC.TEXT: Like Boesky and Levine, Milken committed very serious crimes. Unike Boesky and Levine, however, Milken has not cooperated. On the urging of the government, Boesky and Levine each received reduced sentences because of their extraordinary assistance in the successful prosecutions of others. . . . Boesky's cooperation resulted, directly and indirectly, in the successful prosecution of numerous prominent securities industry professionals in addition to Milken. In sharp contrast, during the four years of Boesky's cooperation, Milken has vigorously contested the government's charges and allowed the statute of limitations to preclude prosecution of others based on any information he could provide. . . . (The) sentence of Paul Bilzerian (to four years in prison) for repeated securities fraud crimes should also inform this court's exercise of its sentencing discretion. Bilzerian's sentence was based on multiple criminal acts over an extended period of time. His violations were similar in type to Milken's admitted crimes though fewer in number . . . Milken's conduct is, of course, far more widespread and systemic than Bilzerian's.
DOC.HEAD: RECOMMENDATION
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken stands before this court having been convicted of six felonies carrying a maximum sentence of 28 years. He has committed a range of serious white-collar crimes unmatched in the 1980s. The government respectfully submits that this court should impose a sentence that reflects the full magnitude of Milken's unlawful conduct and that unmistakably deters others . . . The court's sentence must demonstrate that persons who possess great wealth and prominence cannot expect that their privilege or their money will insulate them from certain and serious punishment. For these reasons, the government respectfully urges that . . . Michael Milken be sentenced to a substantial term of imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Asks U.S. Others to Use Oil Reserves
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2nd graf to note that Bush ordered; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Iran's top financial official on Wednesday asked nations with huge oil stockpiles to help restore stability to oil markets by tapping their strategic reserves. The White House announced later that President Bush would do just that, offering 5 million barrels from the 590-million barrel reserve stored in salt domes along the Texas and Louisiana coasts. But Bush was not acting in response to the Iranian request. Industrial countries should ``use their current reserves to relieve the current pressure on the international oil market and to restore stability,'' said Mohsen Nourbakhsh, Iranian minister of economic affairs and finance. The United States, Japan and European countries have reserves of crude oil set up after the oil crisis of the 1970s to provide a cushion against shortages. Some members of Congress have called for a release of some U.S. reserves to help bring down the price of crude oil, which has been moving up toward $40 a barrel. ``As far as we're concerned, a stable international oil market will be beneficial for both the oil producers and the consumers,'' Nourbakhsh told the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. He said the crisis is bringing many oil-producing countries, including Iran, additional expenses for defense and for resettling refugees from Iraq and Kuwait. Nourbakhsh said the cost of imports from industrial countries has risen, ``resulting in erosion of any increase in the oil export earnings of oil producers and fueling global inflation.''

DOC.HEAD: J2 Modifies Offer for National Lampoon; Vote on Deal Set for Oct. 24
DOC.TEXT: J2 Communications said Wednesday it had changed its offer for National Lampoon Inc. to keep the deal's value at $4.7 million in stock and warrants. The adjustment was made to reflect changes in the companies' stock price since the deal was announced in March, said James P. Jimirro, J2's chairman and chief executive. J2, a Los Angeles-based home video producer and distributor, said it was mailing proxy material to shareholders of both companies this week. The shareholders will vote on the offer at special meetings scheduled for Oct. 24. Under a previous agreement, National Lampoon shareholders were to receive two thirds of a share of J2 common stock for every share of National Lampoon, plus a warrant to purchase an additional share at $3.75. Under the new agreement, the warrant price will be $3.25. Jimirro, a former Walt Disney Co. executive, said J2 hopes to breathe new life into the New York-based National Lampoon magazine, which has lost money for a decade. J2 also hopes to cross-market the National Lampoon name, made familiar through National Lampoon's movie and TV operations in Los Angeles. ``Look at Disney,'' Jimirro said. ``What Disney does is fully exploit franchises, and the Lampoon is a franchise in the same sense Disney is, except on a smaller scale.'' He said he hopes to create ``synergies'' through mutually promoting projects in radio, television, film, merchandise, comedy clubs and even satirical reviews on Broadway.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Use of Strategic Oil Reserve Likely To Calm Markets
With AM-Bush-Oil
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's decision to tap into the nation's strategic crude oil reserve will probably put the brakes on the rapid rise in oil prices, at least in the short run, experts said Wednesday night. ``We should be considerably lower,'' said Ed Kevelson, a Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. trader who deals in oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange. ``You've certainly got that possibility for a big move to the downside.'' The president's announcement on Wednesday night was made after the market closed to finish off a day in which wild rumors pushed crude oil futures to a record-high settlement price of $38.67 per barrel. Kevelson said that when the exchange opens on Thursday morning, speculators will probably take a cue from the way overseas oil markets respond. ``I'd be interested to see how London reacts off this,'' Kevelson said. The White House said the government would take 5 million barrels of crude out of the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which contains nearly 600 million barrels of oil stored in salt caverns in Texas and Louisiana. In announcing the decision, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there has been no justification for the recent run-up in oil and gasoline prices. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, crude oil prices have almost doubled, from around $20 per barrel to nearly $40. Oil has shot up amid war jitters on the trading floor, even though supplies have remained at adequate levels. The cash price that is paid by oil companies is closely related to the futures price that is paid by speculators who gamble on future supply and demand but rarely take possession of any oil. Bush's move drew criticism from those who point out that the strategic reserve was put in place following the oil shocks of the early 1970s as a mechanism to fight oil shortages, but not high prices. ``I think the administration may be trying to curb the speculation of people in the Mercantile Exchange who keep bidding up the price, which is having an effect on inflation,'' said Professor James M. Patterson of the Indiana University School of Business. ``This is really an economic move rather than an energy-policy move.'' Patterson said, ``I think this is strictly a political response. I think it's inappropriate, but it may also serve as a test for the workability of the reserve.'' The reserve has never been used apart from a 1-million barrel test sale in 1985 that was not aimed at influencing prices. Oil from the reserve is auctioned by the Energy Department and picked up by the bidders who are selected. A potential problem of the reserve is its quantities of ``sour'' crude, which contains high sulfur content that makes the oil unusable in many U.S. refineries.

DOC.HEAD: Law Professor: Bush Kept Silverado Board Informed of Potential Conflicts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with Conry testimony, quote from lawyer saying Bush won't plead the Fifth; pick up 17th graf, `On Tuesday . . .'; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A law professor testified Wednesday that Neil Bush adequately informed fellow Silverado savings and loan directors of his dealings with a developer who got a $900,000 line of credit from the thrift. A federal Office of Thrift Supervision official, however, implied in testimony at an administrative hearing that President Bush's son could have been more forthright with the Silverado board about his relationship with Denver developer Kenneth Good. And another law professor said Bush's actions as a Silverado board member were ``unsafe, unethical and unreasonable.'' Geoffrey C. Hazard Jr., a Yale law professor summoned as an expert witness by Bush's lawyer, said Bush, a Silverado director from 1985 to 1988, gave the board enough information. He said Bush told the board he had business dealings with Good before the board approved the line of credit for Good International Inc., a partnership formed by Bush and Good. Bush abstained from voting on the line of credit, which he and Good never used. The Office of Thrift Supervision has alleged that Bush, as a Silverado director, improperly voted on loans and credit for Good and Bill Walters, another Denver developer who invested in Bush's oil and gas exploration company. Good and Walters eventually defaulted on more than $132 million in loans from the thrift. Silverado collapsed in late 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. The hearing, which could lead to Bush being banned from the banking and savings industry, began Tuesday. Bush, 35, has not yet attended the hearing. He is scheduled to be the last witness to testify, probably Thursday. His lawyer, James Nesland, said Bush wouldn't invoke his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. ``He will testify, and he will answer all the questions he is asked,'' Nesland said. On Tuesday, former Silverado chairman Michael Wise, the hearing's leadoff witness, invoked the Fifth Amendment 14 times when questioned in the judge's chambers about his knowledge of Bush's business dealings. Appearing with Bush will be another former Silverado director, Denver car dealer Florian Barth, who refused to testify Tuesday, but changed his mind, attorneys said Wednesday. Government counsel Stephen Hershkowitz told Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson that Barth had decided to appear before the hearing Thursday morning. Davidson had threatened to subpoena Barth. Hazard testified he was unsure how much Bush actually told the board about the relationship, but ``it was sufficient that he told them he was in business with Mr. Good.'' Hazard said he believed directors need to consider state laws and legal opinions to gain insight into what their responsibilities are. But Terry Sandefur, the OTS' assistant deputy district director of supervision in Topeka, Kan., said Tuesday he was not as certain as Hazard that the disclosure was adequate. He implied that Bush may not have told the board all that he could have. Nesland pressed Sandefur on the issue. He said Silverado's investment committee and the board itself - with Bush abstaining - approved the line of credit unanimously. ``No doubt, at the board meeting, the transaction was found to be in the best interests of Silverado,'' Bush's lawyer said. ``Maybe they perceived it to be in the best interests of Silverado,'' Sandefur said, emphasizing ``perceived.'' Edward G. Conry, a law professor at the University of Colorado and a witness for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said Bush's actions were ``unsafe, unethical and unreasonable.'' ``His capacity to exercise impartial judgment was diminished because of his relationship with Mr. Walters,'' Conry said. He said Bush put his self-interest above Silverado's. Nesland, irritated, asked Conry: ``Are you a mind-reader?'' ``I can see a vivid conflict of interest as well as anyone else can,'' Conry said. On Tuesday, Russell Murray, a former Silverado executive vice president, discussed his review of the $900,000 line of credit for Good International. He testified he did not recall anyone questioning it even though Good and Bush had a business relationship. He said he discussed the request with Bush, Good and Silverado chairman Michael Wise, and then wrote a memo to the thrift's directors about the relationship before they approved the line of credit. But he said that he did not have all the details of the relationship and that he would have asked for a legal opinion if he had had all the facts. After the hearing, Davidson and OTS officials will examine the testimony and then recommend whether any action should be taken against Bush. Last week, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. sued Bush and other former Silverado directors for $200 million. The lawsuit, which also named Wise and Barth, alleged gross negligence on the part of Silverado directors contributed to the S&L's collapse.

DOC.HEAD: C-5B Safety Charges Surface in Lockheed Wrongful Dismissal Case
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. fired three auditors because they blew the whistle on dangerously flawed metal used in the C-5B cargo plane, their lawyer said Wednesday as trial of their wrongful dismissal suit began. The lawsuit, being heard in state court here, contends they were fired in 1985 for questioning the structural integrity of the bodies of the C-5B, the biggest plane in the Western world. The suit seeks unspecified damages. Lockheed says the men were let go for unprofessional conduct and violating company policies. But in his opening statement Wednesday, attorney Herbert Hafif accused the big military contractor of lying. The men were fired after they wrote letters to Lockheed's second highest-ranking official demanding grounding of C-5Bs while additional tests were conducted, Hafif told jurors. The first letter was ``the hottest potato ever handed down in this industry,'' Hafif said. ``After a letter like that you've kissed (a promotion) goodbye.'' Hafif contends that even though no provable accidents have occurred because of the deficiencies, the C-5B is very dangerous. The plane, which can carry 145 tons of cargo, is being used heavily in the Persian Gulf. Lockheed acknowledges that problems emerged in 1983, early on in the C-5B program, with forged metal mainframe parts that were heat-treated. The company maintains that it and the Air Force fixed the problems and have studied the possibility of mainframe deficiencies over the years. They have determined that parts were properly prepared and are safe, Lockheed said in a statement. The auditors say they took their concerns all the way up the chain of command to Lockheed's president at the time, Lawrence O. Kitchen. Lockheed says one employee, Clyde Jones Jr., had already retired before Kitchen learned of the matter. It maintains the others, Thomas Benecke and Terrence Schielke, were dismissed for circumventing company policies and audit procedures. ``Simply put, they totally failed to perform their jobs in a professional manner,'' Lockheed said in a written statement of its side of the case. In an August 1985 letter to Kitchen, the auditors said: ``Our patience is exhausted.'' ``We will not be delayed or stonewalled for any reason. This issue deals with life and death, and this letter represents our last resort in dealing with this problem internally.'' Lockheed says the employees waited 22 months before suddenly demanding that the C-5Bs be grounded. In a deposition, Kitchen said he told the employees he didn't like their approach. ``I asked why they had not followed the procedure of an audit report and taken it through the proper process; why they hadn't carried out their responsibilities that they had as auditors; and that I didn't appreciate them coming in at the last hour,'' he said. Lockheed also said that it has proved sample materials taken by the workers ``were not from production mainframe parts, and additional tests of the materials themselves proved that they were not defective as claimed.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Grants Extension for Greyhound's Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge granted Greyhound Lines a 48-day extension to file its financial reorganization plan, the Dallas-based bus company announced Wednesday. The ruling by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Richard S. Schmidt extends the deadline from Oct. 2 to Nov. 19. On June 4, Greyhound Lines filed for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws. Under federal law, it has the exclusive right to present a plan of financial reorganization for 120 days. That period ends Oct. 2. ``We appreciate the court's vote of confidence in giving us this brief extension,'' said J. Michael Doyle, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Greyhound. In June, July and August the company's cash flow - earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation - was $3.72 million, $10.16 million and $11.80 million, respectively, the company reported. For the week ended Sept. 23, the company had ticket sales equal to 94.2 percent of the comparable week last year. ``In many large, complicated cases such as ours, companies often stay in Chapter 11 for two or three years, or even longer,'' said George W. Hanthorn, senior vice president and general counsel of Greyhound. The company has indicated it expects to complete its reorganization plan before Thanksgiving. ``We have no plans to ask for additional time,'' Hanthorn said. ``Barring an unforeseen emergency, our plan will be submitted to the court no later than November 19.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Taps Oil Stockpile
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf: ``Bush, in,'' with one graf bgng: ``Announcing his,'' to delete reference to prepared remarks, now delivered. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, arguing there is ``no justification'' for speculation that has driven up the price of oil and gasoline, said Wednesday he would sell 5 million barrels of crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The White House said the Bush decision would send a ``signal'' to those who would take advantage of the Persian Gulf crisis to profit from skyrocketing oil prices. Tapping the reserve, a move urged by industry analysts and some members of Congress since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, was aimed at driving down the price of crude on world markets. The president is turning to the 590-million barrel reserve to stabilize the oil market for the first time since it was created in 1975. Oil was briefly pumped from the reserve in 1985 to test the physical and bureaucratic systems for moving it. The price of crude oil has edged toward $40 a barrel this week, nearly twice the level when Iraq's occupation of Kuwait touched off the current oil crisis. Ed Kevelson, a Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. trader who deals in oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange, said the sellng of reserve oil could have a quick effect. ``We should be considerably lower,'' he said. ``You've certainly got that possibility for a big move to the downside.'' Announcing his action at a Republican fundraiser, Bush said, ``It's especially important that America is economically healthy and militarily strong. ``At home and abroad, let me caution those who might take advantage of the current crisis in the Persian Gulf, those who might seek profit by subverting the sanctions or, here at home, those speculators who might try to drive up the price of oil.'' The President said that even though ``the oil market is very tight, with little spare capacity, there is sufficient oil to meet current needs.'' Bush said that oil markets had not taken into account additional production from Saudi Arabia and other sources nor the availability of existing stocks. Congress authorized the 5-million-barrel test sale two weeks ago, over the administration's opposition, in a bill extending Bush's authority to tap the reserve. That authority would have expired Sept. 15 had he not signed the bill that day. ``We've been suggesting this to him,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, who called Bush's action a good first step. But Dingell said the administration needs to follow it up by calling on West Germany and Japan - possibly at a meeting Friday of the 21-nation International Energy Agency in Paris - to also tap stockpiles. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, who more than a month ago called on Bush to tap the reserve, also welcomed Bush's decision. ``The taxpayers have been paying for the oil reserve for years, and they have every right to expect that it be put to good use in the face of an energy crunch.'' The 14-year buildup of the reserve has cost an estimated $20 billion. Industry experts have estimated that production in other countries has restored about two-thirds of the 4.8 million daily barrels of oil production removed from world markets by Iraq's takeover of Kuwait and the world embargo against Iraqi-Kuwaiti oil. ``There is no justification for the intensive and unwarranted speculation in oil futures,'' Bush said. As recently as a week ago Bush, who spent nearly 20 years exploring for and producing oil in Texas before entering politics, voiced hesitation about resorting to the reserves, saying such an action could stabilize the market but would not be justified in terms of an oil shortage. ``This is a decision that the president came to reluctantly,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. He said Bush reached the decision only hours earlier in Chicago, after consulting with Energy Secretary James Watkins. Another official said opinion in the administration had been divided over whether to tap the reserve but in recent days ``people were coming around'' to the view that it should be done. Fitzwater said there was no evidence that the oil industry was involved in price gouging, but ``it's our judgment that price rises of this nature could not be entirely based on legitimate market forces.''. Fitzwater said the decision to put 5 million barrels on the market was a test and the president would take ``additional steps to stabilize energy prices'' if he believed they were needed. The oil is stored in a system of salt-dome caverns in Louisiana and Texas and represents a 73-day supply of imports. The United States uses more than 17 million barrels a day. It should take about 15 or 16 days for the Energy Department to award contracts after asking for bids and 30 to 60 days to deliver the oil, the White House said. The reserves are accessible through the vast oil pipeline network in Texas and Louisiana. Professor James M. Patterson of the Indiana University School of Business said: ``This is really an economic move rather than an energy-policy move. ``I think this is strictly a political response. I think it's inappropriate, but it may also serve as a test for the workability of the reserve,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Seeks To Open MCA Acquisition To Other Bidders
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. stockholders filed a class-action lawsuit Wednesday in an attempt to open the bidding on a possible buyout of the entertainment conglomerate by Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. The Superior Court lawsuit seeks a court order to prevent MCA and its board of directors from limiting talks to the Japanese firm, a leader in the production of stereos, televisions and tape players. An attorney for the shareholders said his clients aren't sure if any other firms are interested in MCA. But Allan Schulman said the plaintiffs felt an open bidding process might attract a more lucrative offer. The Wall Street Journal has reported that Matsushita is offering $70 to $80 a share for MCA stock, or $6.7 billion to $7.5 billion for the firm. Roger Armstrong, MCA's vice president for publicity, said he had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment. Other MCA officials could not be reached Wednesday night. If completed, the acquisition would combine Matsushita's dominance in electronics hardware with MCA's broad strength in movie, record and television production. Matsushita's product lines include Technics, Panasonic and Quasar. MCA's holdings include Universal Studios, MCA Records, Universal Television - the producer of the ``Murder, She Wrote,'' series - as well as MCA-Universal Home Video, a theme park franchise, a cable TV unit, a publishing group, a concert and sports merchandising arm, movie theaters and a 49 percent share in movie theater chain Cineplex Odeon. Schulman said more than 73 million shares of MCA stock have been issued, and public stockholders number in the thousands, although he could not provide an exact figure. Both Matsushita and MCA have remained tightlipped about the talks. Matsushita has said only that MCA is one of several companies with which it is talking. MCA confirmed in a prepared statement that it is in discussions with a major international company regarding a possible acquisition, but would say no more. Word of the talks Tuesday sent stock soaring $19.50 to $54.00 per share. On Wednesday, stock rose another $7.25 to $61.25. MCA's 1989 revenues were $3.4 billion, with income of $191 million. Matsushita reported 1989 sales of $44.4 billion.
